site_title: Foreign companies in China brace for VPN crackdown
summary: Foreign companies in China are bracing for a March 31 deadline to use government-approved virtual private networks (VPNs) to access the global internet. The government's "Great Firewall" has restricted access to blocked websites, and using unlicensed VPNs can lead to surveillance. Critics argue the policy is a revenue grab, while some companies plan to comply, citing the need to avoid disruptions to their operations. The Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has assured that state-approved providers can maintain data security. The new regulations are seen as a way to increase control over access to information and eliminate low-cost VPN providers.

site_title: Pippa Middleton's father-in-law charged with rape of minor: French judicial source
summary: Pippa Middleton's father-in-law, David Matthews, has been charged in France with the rape of a minor from 1998-99. Matthews was taken into custody for questioning and denies the allegation. A family spokesperson described the accusation as "untrue and scandalous."

site_title: Platforms like Grab, Go-Jek to drive next wave of economic growth
summary: Grab, along with other commercial platforms like Carousell and Go-Jek, is set to drive the next wave of global economic growth, according to Stripe CFO Will Gaybrick. These platforms have enabled more commerce in South-east Asia, particularly through Grab's transport and payments services. As internet usage in the region is expected to boom, these platforms' online reach is expected to expand, playing an increasingly powerful role in the global economy.

site_title: Taking ideas to new highs
summary: A Jetstar Asia flight to Bangkok featured an in-flight conference, "High Altitude Conference", where passengers could network, pitch ideas, and discuss startups. The event, similar to a tech conference, offered a unique experience for travelers. It showcased the airline's efforts to create engaging content and amenities for passengers. The conference was part of the airline's efforts to cater to the evolving needs of travelers, providing a platform for innovation and idea-sharing.

site_title: Russian hacker suspect faces US judge after Moscow snubbed
summary: A Russian citizen, Yevgeniy Nikulin, 30, accused of hacking LinkedIn and Dropbox in 2012, appeared in a US courtroom after being extradited from the Czech Republic. Nikulin faces a medical evaluation and potential prosecution for computer-enabled fraud and identity theft, carrying a sentence of up to 10 years in prison. Russia is "deeply disappointed" by the Czech decision, citing concerns over the extradition process. The move comes amid US investigations into alleged Russian cyber attacks and interference in the 2016 presidential election campaign.

site_title: Gear up for S'pore's biggest auto show
summary: Singapore's largest auto show, Cars@Expo, is set to take place at Singapore Expo Halls 3 and 4 from April 7-8, attracting 120,000 visitors and featuring over 50 car and accessory exhibitors. Luxury brands like Audi and BMW will be present, alongside pre-owned cars and car accessory exhibitors. Visitors can win up to S$3,000 worth of shopping vouchers, marking the first run of the twice-yearly event organized by ST Classifieds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.02 points to 1,859.37. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 43, with volume reaching 23.54 million lots worth RM11.67 million.

site_title: Son's not running for cover in Softbank's Swiss Re swoop
summary: SoftBank Group Corp is in talks to buy 25% of Swiss Re AG, valuing the reinsurer at up to $50.8 billion. The deal could help SoftBank service its debt levels and provide a steady stream of dividend income. Swiss Re's net income fell 90% last year due to natural disasters and low interest rates, but its float - the premiums collected by insurers before claims are paid - could be attractive to SoftBank. The deal may also give SoftBank strategic influence and access to the US$700 billion motor insurance market.

site_title: Affordable luxury: Wayne Goss make-up brushes
summary: Japanese make-up brands Chikuhodo and Hakuhodo are renowned for their high-quality, handmade brushes. These artisan-crafted tools take a week to create, involving over 100 artisans and 60 steps, resulting in weighted and balanced brushes with super-soft bristles. The attention to detail and use of cruelty-free materials make these brushes a favorite among make-up mavens, offering beautiful and even application that lasts for years.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise following Wall Street, won steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.76% to 2,454.79 points on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street overnight. The won remained steady, while bond yields fell. Hyundai Mobis and Hyundai Glovis shares fell due to concerns over the parent group's restructuring plan, while Kumho Tire Co Inc's shares jumped 16.7% ahead of a decision on court receivership. The Kospi is down 1.3% so far this year, but has gained 2.14% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Buffett's home brokerage booms, with No 1 ranking in sight
summary: Warren Buffett's home brokerage, HomeServices of America, has seen significant growth after acquiring Long & Foster, catapulting it to the second-largest residential brokerage owner in the US. The company's volume increased by 34% in 2017, putting it within striking distance of the top residential brokerage, Realogy Holdings Corp's NRT LLC. Despite this, Buffett is fixated on becoming the number one player, stating that HomeServices will only represent 3% of the country's home-brokerage business in 2018, leaving 97% to compete for.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.11 points to 1,863.46. The index saw a 476-384 gain-to-loss ratio, with a total of 1.82 billion shares traded worth RM1.90 billion.

site_title: The business of benevolence
summary: A business model for charities is being advocated by Dan Pallotta, founder of Pallotta TeamWorks, a producer of fundraising events that raised over $300 million for charities. Pallotta argues that charities should be run like businesses, setting robust goals for fundraising and using innovative, even risky, methods to achieve them. He criticizes the current focus on low-cost, efficient fundraising, which he says stifles innovation and limits the potential for charities to make a significant impact. Advocates for good governance and transparency are also being highlighted as crucial for the sustainability and growth of the charity sector.

site_title: Who will be Mexico's next president?
summary: Mexico's next president faces a challenging task, dealing with a record murder rate, a sluggish economy, and corruption in the political system. Four candidates are vying for the July 1 election, but no clear frontrunner has emerged. The president will have to navigate a complex situation involving Donald Trump's criticism and a messy war on drugs, while also addressing economic and social issues. The winner will have to find a balance between dealing with these problems and implementing reforms to restore trust in the government.

site_title: Region's best deals under one roof
summary: A travel article highlighting the best deals for courses in Southeast Asia, featuring 250+ courses in Thailand, 41 in Vietnam, and over 200 in Malaysia. The region's diverse cultural offerings cater to seasoned travelers.

site_title: China says protectionist moves will mean shutting door on the country
summary: China's top diplomat, Wang Yi, warned that protectionism will close the door to the country, amid a trade dispute with the US. China has vowed to maintain its reform and opening-up policy, which benefits other countries, despite US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Chinese imports. China has threatened to retaliate with duties on US imports, and Wang stated that protectionism will undermine China's interests and suffer consequences. The Chinese government emphasizes the need for reasonable solutions through equal consultations, as protectionism is seen as an approach against history's trend.

site_title: Facebook employees in an uproar over executive's leaked memo
summary: Facebook employees are in an uproar after a leaked 2016 memo from a top executive, defending the social network's growth at any cost, including potentially causing deaths from terrorist attacks. The memo, written by Andrew Bosworth, a Facebook vice-president, was disavowed by CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Bosworth himself. The backlash has led to calls for increased transparency and action against media leaks, with some employees deleting old comments or messages that might be deemed controversial. The incident follows recent scrutiny over Facebook's data privacy and its responsibilities to its 2.2 billion users.

images.alt_text: Facebook employees were in an uproar Friday over a leaked 2016 memo from a top executive defending the social network's growth at any cost - even if it caused deaths from a terrorist attack that was organised on the platform.

site_title: Hon Hai Q4 profit propped up by NT$66b sale of Sharp shares
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn, reported a fourth-quarter net income of NT$71.7 billion, thanks to a one-time gain of NT$66 billion from the sale of Sharp shares. Analysts say this sale prevented the company's earnings per share from missing estimates by 65%. The sale of 352.5 billion yen worth of Sharp C shares generated a profit of 252.5 billion yen. This sale partially offset missed estimates in gross margin and operating profit margin.

site_title: White House says Russia expulsion of diplomats marks 'deteroriation' in ties
summary: The US and Russia have further deteriorated relations after Russia expelled 60 US diplomats and closed a consulate, with the White House describing the move as a "further deterioration" in ties. This comes after a similar expulsion of Russian diplomats in response to the poisoning of ex-spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter in England. The US had previously ordered over 150 Russian diplomats to leave the country in a coordinated effort to isolate Russia. The US will continue to work with Russia despite the tensions, with President Trump emphasizing the need to maintain dialogue with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

site_title: China cuts tax rates for chipmakers amid trade tensions
summary: China's finance ministry has introduced tax breaks and exemptions for semiconductor firms, aiming to reduce dependence on Western technology amid trade tensions. The corporate tax will be waived for up to 5 years, a move seen as a response to the US considering tariffs on $50 billion worth of Chinese exports. This move is part of China's efforts to limit its reliance on foreign semiconductors and counter US allegations of discriminatory trade practices.

site_title: French First Lady Brigitte Macron targeted in VIP identity fraud
summary: French First Lady Brigitte Macron's office filed a complaint for identity fraud after receiving e-mails seeking VIP treatment in her name. The scammers used her official email address, cabinet@presidence.fr, and claimed to be from her office. The emails sought favors, such as airport pickups and restaurant reservations, for people supposedly close to the first lady. The incident highlights the vulnerability of high-profile targets to identity fraud and the need for increased security measures to protect them.

site_title: Thai junta vows to lift politics ban in June
summary: Thailand's junta announced plans to lift a nearly four-year ban on political activity in June, allowing gatherings of five or more people. The ban, implemented after the 2014 coup, has restricted debate and led to promised elections, with the generals insisting on a "no later" than February 2019 date.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles toward US$7,000 in downbeat end to dismal quarter
summary: Bitcoin's value dropped as much as 10% on Thursday, pushing it toward the $7,000 mark and its lowest level since early February, with losses in 2018 reaching 50%. Other digital assets also slumped. Regulatory pressure and major social media platforms distancing themselves from the industry have contributed to the decline. The trustee of Mt Gox, which sold $400 million in Bitcoin to reimburse creditors, is expected to sell more, further weakening the market. Bitcoin's 50% slump this year is its biggest quarterly decline since 2011.

site_title: US judge dismisses Exxon lawsuit to stop climate change probes
summary: A US federal judge dismissed Exxon Mobil Corp's lawsuit seeking to stop New York and Massachusetts from investigating the company's alleged climate change cover-up and lies to investors. Judge Valerie Caproni rejected Exxon's claim that the probes were politically motivated and violated its constitutional rights. The lawsuit was dismissed with prejudice, meaning Exxon cannot bring it again. The states' Democratic attorneys general, Eric Schneiderman and Maura Healey, will continue their investigations into Exxon's knowledge of climate change.

site_title: Sarkozy ordered to stand trial for attempt to influence judge
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has been ordered to stand trial for corruption and influence peddling, involving a judge he sought information about an investigation in 2014. Prosecutors have also recommended Sarkozy's lawyer and former judge stand trial. This would be Sarkozy's second trial, stemming from allegations of illegal campaign financing for his 2012 re-election bid.

site_title: The 'dirty' side of the Porsche Cayenne
summary: The Porsche Cayenne, a half-million-dollar SUV, was put to the test in an off-road setting in Dubai, UAE, to see if it's capable of handling rough terrain. The vehicle performed surprisingly well, showcasing its capabilities in an unlikely scenario. This test highlights the Cayenne's off-road prowess, challenging the common assumption that luxury SUVs are only used on paved roads.

site_title: Grab, Uber deal may have breached Competition Act; watchdog calls for pre-sale operations to continue
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has proposed interim measures on Grab and Uber, requiring them to maintain independent pricing and product options following Grab's acquisition of Uber's Southeast Asian ride-hailing business. The CCS suspects a breach of the Competition Act, citing substantial reduction of competition in the market. Grab and Uber will be given an opportunity to make written representations, and the commission will consider these before making a decision on whether to issue directives. The measures will remain in effect until the completion of the commission's investigations.

site_title: Facebook gets thumbs down for handling of data scandal
summary: Facebook receives a negative assessment from crisis management experts regarding its handling of the Cambridge Analytica data scandal, which involved the harvesting of users' data to influence the 2016 US presidential election. Experts consider the company's explanations to be slow and unconvincing, leaving Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg exposed. The social network's response is seen as inadequate, raising concerns about its ability to manage crises effectively.

site_title: Starbucks must put cancer warning on California coffee: judge
summary: A California judge ruled that Starbucks and other coffee companies must put a cancer warning label on coffee products sold in the state. The ruling was based on a chemical compound produced when roasting coffee, which the judge found had not been adequately proven to be insignificant. Starbucks and other plaintiffs have until April 10 to file objections. The decision applies only to California, but the ruling could have implications for coffee companies nationwide.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Corp and other coffee companies must put a cancer warning label on coffee products sold in California, a Los Angeles judge ruled.

site_title: Now Showing
summary: A new biopic, "I Can Only Imagine", tells the story of MercyMe's lead singer Bart Millard, who penned the Christian single after trying to mend his relationship with his father. The film is based on Millard's life and lyrics, which took him a lifetime to craft. Meanwhile, three new movie releases celebrate Easter, the 80s, and local dishes, perfect for a long Easter weekend.

site_title: China official factory PMI rises to 51.5 in March, beats forecasts
summary: China's official factory PMI rose to 51.5 in March, beating forecasts and marking 20 consecutive months of improvement. The increase was attributed to lifted winter pollution restrictions, steel mill production, and construction activity. The reading remains above the 50-point mark, indicating growth. Economists expect China's growth to slow this year due to weaker property investment and rising borrowing costs, despite resilient exports and government infrastructure spending.

site_title: Oil prices rise with Wall Street; US crude discount widens
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, driven by a rally on Wall Street and OPEC supply curbs, despite a rise in US crude inventories and production. June Brent crude futures rose 58 cents to $69.34, while WTI crude futures gained 56 cents to $64.94. Market participants weighed the impact of these factors on oil prices, with prices influenced by ongoing OPEC supply curbs and market sentiment.

site_title: Anita Wong
summary: Anita Wong, founder of PHS Hairscience, has developed research-based solutions for hair loss and greying hair. Inspired by her own thinning hair, Wong created Phyto Hair Spa in 2006, which later rebranded as PHS Hairscience in 2014. The business now features three luxury service centers and two capsule retail outlets offering scalp and hair care services, as well as trichology expertise. Wong's journey began with working in her mother's salon and later in London and Hong Kong, before launching Revamp in 1997, a prototype salon for kids.

site_title: Japan factory output turns up in February
summary: Japan's factory output increased 4.1% in February, beating expectations of a 5% rise, according to industry ministry data. This marks a rebound from the 6.8% plunge in January. The solid expansion is attributed to the gradual recovery of the global economy. Japan's jobless rate remained low, with Takeshi Minami, chief economist at Norinchukin Research Institute, stating that the Japanese economy continues to recover. This solid expansion is a positive sign for the country's economic growth.

site_title: Singapore juniors in the groove in KL event
summary: Singaporean junior table tennis players showcased their skills in a recent event in Kuala Lumpur, marking a significant improvement in their performance over the past 18 months. The SGA junior development committee, led by Lyn Sen, implemented various initiatives such as junior clinics, age-group tournaments, and novelty games to boost their development. The success of these efforts has led to increased exposure for young players, with some even competing in major tournaments like the SMBC Singapore Open and the HSBC Women's World Championships.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Wall St rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following a Wall Street rally. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.00% to 21,370.36, while the Topix index increased 0.72% to 1,716.27. The rally was attributed to upturns in the tech sector ahead of a holiday weekend.

site_title: Trump says may hold up South Korea trade deal until after deal with North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump said he may hold up a trade agreement with South Korea until after a deal is reached with North Korea on denuclearization. Trump made the statement during a speech in Ohio, citing North Korea as a "very strong card" in negotiations. The agreement with South Korea, reached earlier this week, aims to revise the six-year-old free trade agreement and lift US tariffs on steel imports. Trump's comments have raised concerns among senior US officials, who see South Korea as the weak link in the US-Japan-South Korea alliance.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said on Thursday he may hold up a trade agreement reached this week with South Korea until after a deal is reached with North Korea on denuclearization.

site_title: US: Stocks end weak quarter on upbeat note
summary: US stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.6% to close at 7,063.45, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 advanced 1.1% and 1.4%, respectively. Despite the gains, the S&P 500 finished with a loss for the quarter, its first in nearly three years. The tech-rich Nasdaq and Dow Jones finished ahead of a holiday weekend, but volatility reemerged in the first quarter of 2018, driven by inflation concerns and trade war fears.

site_title: SS Teo to succeed father at helm of PIL
summary: Singapore's Pacific International Lines (PIL) is handing over its leadership to son Teo Siong Seng, succeeding his father Chang Yun Chung after 51 years. This comes at a challenging time for the box ship industry, which is facing renewed pressure on freight rates. Chang Yun Chung, who turns 100 in August, will step down as founding chairman, marking a significant change in the company's leadership.

images.alt_text: Mr Teo Siong Seng, 63, has worked in the family-owned line for close to five decades.

site_title: Nobel-winner Malala visits hometown in Pakistan for first time since shooting
summary: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala Yousafzai visited her hometown in Pakistan's Swat Valley for the first time since being shot by a Taliban gunman as a teenager. The visit, which included a trip by helicopter, was facilitated by the government and military due to security concerns. Malala expressed her love for Pakistan, describing her longing for the country's natural beauty, friends, and memories. The visit was a rare opportunity for Malala to reconnect with her roots and see the area that was once under Taliban rule.

site_title: Minimising the risks of a heart attack
summary: Cardiovascular disease is a major global health issue, accounting for 29.5% of all deaths in Singapore, with 16 daily deaths in 2016. Coronary heart disease is a leading cause of sudden cardiac arrests, with 70% attributed to it. To minimize the risk of heart attack, key signs include chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Identifying these symptoms early can help prevent a heart attack. Abnormal coronary artery origins can also increase the risk of myocardial ischemia and sudden death. Awareness and early detection are crucial in reducing the risk of heart attack.

site_title: China creates cross-region tie-ups to boost rustbelt north-east
summary: China has created cross-region tie-ups to boost the rustbelt northeast provinces of Liaoning, Jilin, and Heilongjiang. The National Development and Reform Commission has published implementation plans to rejuvenate the region's struggling heavy industrial economy. Eastern China's Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces will share resources with Liaoning and Jilin, respectively, while Guangdong will provide support to Heilongjiang. Separate plans have also been established between Beijing and Shenyang, and Shanghai and Dalian. This initiative aims to stimulate economic growth in the region.

site_title: Developers send Q1 property investment sales to new high
summary: Singapore's property investment sales market saw a record high in Q1, reaching S$10.84 billion as of March 28, driven by land-banking activities and en bloc sales totaling S$5.83 billion. This marks the strongest first-quarter sales on record since 1994, according to property consultancy JLL.

images.alt_text: A flurry of land-banking activities by developers propelled Singapore's property investment sales market to its strongest quarter in the first three months this year.

site_title: China to spend 1.88b yuan on improved irrigation in southern Xinjiang
summary: China plans to invest 1.88 billion yuan (S$392 million) in improving irrigation systems in southern Xinjiang, a region plagued by violence and poverty. The funds will upgrade irrigation facilities and promote water-saving technology to boost farm output, primarily in cotton and fruit production. The move aims to address the economic causes of unrest in the region, where over 1.6 million people live below the poverty line. This investment is part of Beijing's efforts to promote development in southern Xinjiang and alleviate poverty.

site_title: Music Untangled
summary: JBL has introduced three Bluetooth-enabled headphones catering to different lifestyles. The T110BT is an entry-level model priced at S$59.90, featuring a cord that can be worn behind the neck for a no-frills, all-purpose design.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Google women march ahead with gender bias suits
summary: A US judge ruled in favor of approximately 2,300 Goldman Sachs female employees who claim they faced pay and promotion disparities compared to their male counterparts. The lawsuit, filed in 2010, alleges a "culture of discrimination" and unfair treatment by company policies. This decision comes as part of a larger trend of women's lawsuits in the tech industry, including a class-action case against Google and a settlement with Uber. These rulings aim to address gender bias and promote diversity in the workplace.

site_title: SBI Offshore says CAD finds insufficient evidence of criminal offence relating to 2016 police report
summary: SBI Offshore received a letter from Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) stating that insufficient evidence exists to prove a criminal offence in relation to a 2016 police report regarding potential breaches of securities laws and a lifeboat company stake. The CAD completed its investigation, considering facts and circumstances, and found no evidence to support further action.

site_title: Older investors need some illiquid assets, says fund manager
summary: Veteran fund manager Gerard Lee of Lion Global Investors believes that illiquid assets, such as private equity and real estate, can help retail investors generate consistent, above-market returns. As longevity extends the retiree's years in retirement, Lee argues that retirees should adopt a more conservative approach and invest for 20-30 years, rather than just 10-15 years. He also sees an opportunity to democratize these investments for individual retirees, citing the emergence of socially-minded millennials who prioritize ESG investing. Lee aims to develop low-cost, diversified funds that can serve as long-term savings vehicles for retail investors.

site_title: Listed Chinese developers flag higher sales to gain rank
summary: Chinese property developers have published eye-catching sales targets, causing a surge in their share prices. However, analysts warn that these figures often include joint venture sales, which can be more than double the actual attributable sales. This can lead to investors being misled and taking on excessive risk. As a result, regulators and investors are urging caution, highlighting the need for transparency and accurate reporting in the industry.

site_title: 'Benjamin Button' Ibrahimovic ready for Galaxy debut after Manchester United
summary: Zlatan Ibrahimovic, 36, is set to make his debut for the Los Angeles Galaxy after training with his new team-mates for the first time. The Swedish striker, who joined the team after Manchester United, expressed his excitement to play after a 12-month break due to a serious knee injury. Ibrahimovic compared himself to the movie character Benjamin Button, who ages in reverse, saying he feels young and ready to conquer Major League Soccer. He has signed a two-season deal with the Galaxy and is available to play in their upcoming derby match on Saturday.

site_title: More family members of woman killed in Uber self-driving car crash hire lawyer
summary: More family members of Elaine Herzberg, who died after being struck by an Uber self-driving SUV in Tempe, have hired a lawyer. Herzberg's mother, father, and son have retained Phoenix attorney Patrick McGroder, who will represent the family in the case. Meanwhile, Herzberg's daughter and husband reached a settlement with Uber, but the terms were not disclosed. The incident has stalled the development and testing of self-driving vehicles, with Uber suspending its testing and other companies, including Toyota and Nvidia, also halting their public road testing.

site_title: Jeff Koons on money, risk and acceptance
summary: Jeff Koons, a renowned Pop Art artist, emphasizes the importance of accepting oneself and others in the creative process. He views money as an "abstraction" and focuses on creating art that resonates with individuals, rather than its monetary value. Koons' works, including his mirror-polished steel sculptures and Gazing Ball series, aim to evoke emotions and spark self-discovery. Despite controversy surrounding his art, Koons remains committed to his vision and encourages young artists to believe in themselves and take risks, using technology as a means to express something "metaphysical".

site_title: US dollar share of global currency reserves hits 4-year low: IMF
summary: The US dollar's share of global currency reserves declined to a four-year low in the final quarter of 2017, falling to 62.7% from 63.5% in the third quarter. The euro's share increased to 20.15%, its largest in three years, while the yen's share rebounded to 4.89%. Global reserves rose to $11.425 trillion, the highest since 2015. The decline in the US dollar's share was attributed to the weakening of the greenback due to faster growth outside the US and bets on other central banks reducing stimulus.

site_title: Singapore can be Asia hub for MNCs as HK turns to China
summary: Singapore is poised to become a hub for multinational companies' Asia-Pacific operations as Hong Kong's focus on China-centric services gives Singapore a competitive edge. About 37,400 international companies base their operations in Singapore, with over half running their Asia-Pacific businesses from the city state. Singapore's government is attracting industry leaders with its innovation-led economy, research and development spending, and tax incentives, making it a magnet for multinationals.

site_title: CPFIS changes that matter for the better
summary: Singapore's CPFIS (Central Provident Fund Investment Scheme) will see sales charges capped at 1.5% from October 2018 and removed in 2019. Wrap fees will be reduced to 0.7% in 2018 and then to 0.4% in 2019. Despite the cost reduction, long-term investors have shown consistency in generating returns, with 28% of funds posting losses and 11% failing to beat the 2.5% interest rate between 2014-2016. However, a three-year time horizon reveals a more favorable picture, with only 4% of funds delivering losses.

site_title: Japan Exchange Group to sell its 4.95% stake in SGX
summary: Japan Exchange Group (JPX) will sell its 4.95% stake in Singapore Exchange (SGX) over a 3-year period, following Japan's Corporate Governance Code introduction in 2015. The decision is based on the requirement to examine and explain economic rationale for holding shares of other listed companies. The cooperative relationship between JPX and SGX will continue despite the sale, as evidenced by a 2014 letter of intent for mutual cooperation.

site_title: Wie shifts focus to 'stay healthy, be free, and have fun'
summary: Golf star Michelle Wie, 28, has shifted her focus to prioritizing her health and well-being, adopting a more carefree approach to the game after years of struggling with injuries and high expectations. Following a recent LPGA victory in Singapore, Wie aims to maintain her momentum at the ANA Inspiration, her first major of the year, and is now more focused on staying healthy and enjoying the game.

site_title: Japan Exchange Group to sell its 4.95% stake in SGX progressively over three years
summary: Japan Exchange Group (JPX) plans to sell its 4.95% stake in Singapore Exchange (SGX) over three years, following Japan's Corporate Governance Code requirements. The decision comes after a review of the need for holding shares for reasons other than investment. JPX acquired the stake in 2007 to build a cooperative relationship with SGX, which has been enhanced through a 2014 letter of intent for mutual cooperation. The sale will continue even without JPX holding shares in SGX.

site_title: Asia: Markets including Singapore, Australia and Hong Kong closed for holidays
summary: Financial markets in Singapore, Australia, Hong Kong, and several other Asian countries are closed on Friday for public holidays. The article also mentions recent market trends, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and the extension of the stocks rally despite new Trump threats. Additionally, a mandatory offer has been made by Popiah king Sam Goi for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share.

site_title: Despite an improving economy, Americans are glum
summary: The US economy is showing signs of improvement, with low unemployment and rising growth, but Americans are experiencing declining well-being, with 21 states experiencing statistically significant declines in well-being in 2017, the worst year on record. Factors such as emotional and psychological issues, loneliness, and concerns about politics and the world are driving the decline, with women, African Americans, and lower-income households being disproportionately affected. Despite a strong economy, Americans are anxious about job security, financial stability, and the future, with fears about government corruption, healthcare, and global uncertainty on the rise.

site_title: The evolving business of asset management
summary: The asset management business is undergoing significant transformation due to disruptive pressures. Active managers face pressure to justify fees, while passive and smart beta products have driven down fees, creating cost pressures. The traditional business model is being challenged, with banks and insurance companies uncoupling from their asset management businesses. Regulatory changes, such as MiFID-II, require asset managers to rethink product sets. The industry is shifting towards allocation decisions, away from security selection, and there is a need for absolute return-based benchmarks. To survive, asset managers must evolve their business models, organisation structures, and product strategies, potentially incorporating blockchain technology to reduce intermediaries and costs.

site_title: Amber Park, Royalville en bloc sales pushing up prices in vicinity
summary: Resale prices in Districts 10 and 15, Singapore, have risen significantly following the collective sales of Amber Park and Royalville condos. Prices increased by 7% and 5% respectively on average since the sales announcements in December 2017 and October 2017. Larger units in the resale market saw a bigger price hike, with prices of units 1,000 to 1,500 sq ft and 1,500 to 2,000 sq ft increasing by 10% and 6% in District 10, and 7% and 6% in District 15. The upward trend is attributed to strong demand from cash-flush individuals seeking replacement homes and rising asking prices.

site_title: Tesla recalls 123,000 cars for power steering fix
summary: Tesla has issued a voluntary recall of 123,000 Model S cars to replace a power steering bolt that could corrode due to salt used on winter roads. The bolt's failure may cause the driver to need increased force to steer, making the car harder to drive at low speeds. No accidents or injuries have been reported. The affected cars were built before April 2016 and will be retrofitted with a protective measure. Tesla shares fell 2.5% after the announcement.

site_title: Spread innovation across the industry: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam praised Schneider Electric for contributing to Singapore's innovation ecosystem, highlighting the importance of sharing knowledge from leading-edge companies with the rest of the industry. He spoke at the grand opening of Schneider Electric's East Asia and Japan headquarters in Kallang.

site_title: Sembcorp CEOs and senior executives take voluntary pay cut
summary: Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries CEOs and senior executives took voluntary pay cuts of 10-15% in 2017 to manage costs. This move was noted in their annual reports. Wage cuts and freezes remain in place.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Family, friends bid farewell to Stephen Hawking
summary: British scientist Stephen Hawking, who defied predictions of a short life due to a motor neurone disease, died on March 14 at 76. A private funeral was held in Cambridge, attended by family and close friends, while a wider service at Westminster Abbey on June 15 will include a burial near Isaac Newton's grave. Hawking's remarkable life and work, including his bestselling book "A Brief History of Time," inspired millions, despite being confined to a wheelchair and almost completely paralyzed. Tributes poured in from around the world, reflecting his huge impact as a physicist and inspiration.

images.alt_text: Friends, family and colleagues of British scientist Stephen Hawking will gather Saturday to pay their respects at his private funeral in Cambridge, where he spent most of his extraordinary life.

site_title: Beijing 'planning merger to create shipbuilding giant'
summary: China's government is planning to merge its two biggest shipbuilders, China State Shipbuilding Corp and China Shipbuilding Industry Corp, to create an industrial giant with combined annual revenue exceeding $106 billion, surpassing South Korea's top three shipbuilders. The merger, subject to change, aims to increase competition and efficiency among China's defense companies. The resulting giant will have more than twice the combined annual revenue of Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, the world's top three shipbuilders by market value.

site_title: Trump tells advisers he wants US out of Syria: senior officials
summary: US President Donald Trump has told advisers he wants the US to exit Syria early, contradicting the view of US military officials who believe the fight against Islamic State is not yet complete. Trump has ordered the State Department to freeze over $200 million in funds for recovery efforts, citing the need for the US to focus on its own country. A National Security Council meeting is set to discuss the US-led campaign in Syria, with some officials warning that a rapid exit could allow Islamic State to regain territory.

site_title: Apple unveils new privacy tools ahead of EU law
summary: Apple is introducing new privacy tools ahead of the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) entering into force on May 25. Users worldwide will see a new data privacy information page on their iPhones, explaining an icon used to collect personal information. Apple will also introduce new privacy management tools on its Apple ID website, allowing users to request data corrections, deletions, or transfers to another service. The changes aim to give users more control over their data and align with the EU's strict data protection law, which imposes fines of up to 4% of global turnover for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: Apple is introducing new tools that will allow consumers to control how their data are used and deactivate their Apple ID accounts, as tech companies strive to bring their services into line with a tough new EU data protection law.

site_title: Bitcoin breaches US$7,000 in downbeat end to dismal quarter
summary: Bitcoin fell below US$7,000 for the first time since early February, marking a 50% loss for the year, amid mounting regulatory pressure and industry distancing from the cryptocurrency space. Major social media platforms, including Reddit and Twitter, are distancing themselves from Bitcoin. The trustee of Mt Gox, a now-defunct Japanese exchange, has sold over US$400 million in Bitcoin and Bitcoin Cash, further exacerbating the slump. Experts predict slim chances of Bitcoin's recovery, citing the tech giants' ban on initial coin offerings as a significant contributor to the decline.

site_title: Kim says N Korea to take part in 2020, 2022 Olympics: IOC chief
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has committed to sending teams to the 2020 and 2022 Olympics, according to IOC chief Thomas Bach. This comes after a rare meeting between Bach and Kim in Pyongyang, where they discussed potential joint activities and a shared march at the Tokyo games. The announcement follows a rapprochement triggered by last month's Winter Olympics in South Korea, where competitors from the two countries marched together and fielded a joint women's ice hockey team.

site_title: Schwarzenegger wakes from heart surgery declaring: 'I'm back!'
summary: Arnold Schwarzenegger, 70, is in stable condition after undergoing emergency open-heart surgery at a Los Angeles hospital, where he had a valve replaced. His first words upon waking were "I'm back," a play on his iconic catchphrase from his film "The Terminator." The surgery was performed due to a condition that outlived the original valve replacement in 1997, and Schwarzenegger is recovering well. His representatives confirmed the news, and he is expected to make a full recovery.

site_title: Rising above protectionist impulses elsewhere
summary: Singapore's economy remains open and attracts capital despite protectionist impulses from other countries, such as the US and China. The city-state prioritizes an outward-looking economic nationalism, focusing on improving its citizens' wealth-creating capacities while working with other nations. Singapore Exchange (SGX) exemplifies this approach by serving customers' needs and fostering partnerships, as seen in its MOU with Bursa Malaysia. By leveraging its AAA-rating and global financial centre status, Singapore can deliver relevant services to Asia and attract global investors, driving economic growth despite external uncertainties.

site_title: United Global enters Australia joint venture
summary: United Global, a Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer and trader, has entered into a joint-venture agreement with Australian companies to import and distribute lubricant products in Australia. The JV company will have an initial paid-up capital of A$100,000 and United Oil will hold a 35% stake, while PFR and DP United will hold 55% and 10% respectively. The joint venture aims to increase United Global's presence in Australia and gain greater market access.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: A Mark Of Good Design
summary: The Design Business Chamber of Singapore annually awards the Singapore Good Design Mark, recognizing products and spaces that enhance quality of life and promote inspiration, value, sustainability, and empathy. This year's winners embody these qualities, showcasing innovative design that improves lives and the environment.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Are Reits worth considering when rates rise?
summary: With interest rates on the rise, Reits may become less attractive due to uncertain distributions. However, Reits' performance is influenced by credit conditions and the economy, not just interest rates. Evaluating Reits requires considering factors such as P/E ratio, Funds from Operation (FFO), capitalisation rate, and book value. Choosing the right Reit with a sustainable distribution is crucial for long-term investors, and focusing on yields may not be the best approach.

site_title: From flying fighter jets to taking S'pore MMA to new heights
summary: One Championship's new CFO, Teh Hua Fung, has joined the Singapore-based MMA organization with a background in private equity and government roles. He plans to focus on digital and mobile growth, geographical expansion, and attracting new sponsors and partners. The company is also pushing into China and exploring opportunities in South Korea, Japan, and Australia. Plans for an initial public offering (IPO) are "on track," with a potential listing in the next three years. Teh believes the company has tremendous scale opportunity, with a goal to become Asia's first multi-billion-dollar sports property.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

"When I joined One Championship, a lot of people thought that because I was a private equity guy, it must mean the company is going for a listing soon. The truth is we don't need money right now. We have enough money to run the business and execute our plans. Having said that, it's really a matter of when, not if we go for the IPO." - Teh Hua Fung, One Championship CFO.

site_title: Lazada, partners launch in-depth e-commerce learning courses
summary: Lazada has partnered with several institutions to launch in-depth e-commerce learning courses, aimed at entrepreneurs and small and medium enterprises in Singapore and South-east Asia. The courses, set to begin in April, will cover topics such as e-commerce operations, supply chain management, and data analytics, and are designed to improve online selling performance. More than 1,000 participants are expected to complete the courses between April and December 2018, with plans to expand the program to other markets in the region.

site_title: Warehouses now worth more than offices, thanks to e-commerce
summary: Warehouses have surpassed office buildings in value, with giant "big box" warehouses selling at an average capitalisation rate of 5.8% in 14 North American markets. This surge in warehouse value is attributed to the growing demand for e-commerce, driven by companies like Amazon, which is the top occupier of industrial space in the US. Vacancy rates are at historic lows, and investors such as Blackstone Group LP and Goldman Sachs Group Inc are taking note, further fueling the trend.

site_title: Bank Negara foils attempted cyber attack
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia foiled a cyber attack involving fraudulent messages sent on the SWIFT platform, which was aimed at transferring funds globally. The attack, which occurred on Tuesday, was the second known hack of a central bank after the 2016 Bangladesh Bank heist. No funds were lost, but the incident is likely to prompt further security measures. SWIFT said its network and core messaging services were not compromised, but experts warn that the platform remains vulnerable to cyber threats.

images.alt_text: While Bank Negara Malaysia says no funds were lost in the incident which took place on Tuesday, it is the second known hack of a central bank after the 2016 theft of US$81 million from Bangladesh Bank.

site_title: Corporatising charity, in BT Weekend
summary: Corporatizing charities is preventing fundraisers from being more effective, say advocates. Non-profits should be run like businesses, with transparent governance and cost structures, to match salaries and risk-taking. This is partly due to excessive expenses, which charities often struggle to address. The issue highlights the need for good governance and transparency in charity management.

site_title: Party On
summary: The Singapore International Jazz Festival (Sing Jazz) has announced four new acts, including French singer-songwriter Sebastian Tellier and veteran Brazilian guitarist Paulinho Garcia, to perform on its main stage on Friday night. DJs Sasha and Ferry Corsten will also be part of the official after-party, The Late Show. The festival takes place at Marina Bay Sands from April 6 to 8, featuring a lineup that includes Jamie Cullum, Lauryn Hill, and more.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Vinyl Pop-Up
summary: The Analog Assembly, a vinyl fair, is returning for its third edition on Saturday after a year-long hiatus. The event will feature a mix of local dealers, collectors, and record labels, offering a wider range of genres and rare titles. 'Live' DJ sets will also be available, along with books for those not into vinyl collecting. The fair promises to be a treasure trove for crate diggers searching for obscure records, including a sought-after Bauhaus bootleg.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Brokers' Take:

- OCBC Investment Research upgraded Soilbuild Reit from "hold" to "buy" with a fair value of S$0.70 due to reduced expected lost income from the NK Ingredients asset.
- CGS-CIMB upgraded Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust from "hold" to "add" after acquiring a 98.47% stake in a Japan commercial properties portfolio, which is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive and drive FY2019-2020F DPU estimates up by 0.4-2%.

site_title: What is a movie and who gets to decide?
summary: A Cannes director and Steven Spielberg have sparked debate over the definition of a movie, with Spielberg suggesting that films produced by streaming services like Netflix should not qualify for Oscars. This comes as Netflix has announced that films produced by the company will no longer be invited to Cannes unless they commit to a French theatrical release. The distinction highlights a bifurcation in the movie business between traditional filmmaking and streaming, with Spielberg's Ready Player One exemplifying the latter. The debate raises questions about the future of cinema and the role of streaming in the film industry.

images.alt_text: The Post is the very kind of old-school, serious-minded movie that special-effects spectacles constantly threaten to crowd out of the marketplace. It also exemplifies the kind of storytelling that is increasingly migrating to traditional television and sites like Netflix and Amazon.

site_title: Game Changers
summary: Designers Patricia Urquiola and Tom Dixon are renowned for their innovative approaches to furniture design. Urquiola, who started breaking barriers early in her career as a female in a male-dominated industry, has become a role model for women seeking to make headway in the profession. Her studio, Studio Urquiola, is the fastest-growing architecture and design studio in Italy. Urquiola's focus is on curating an exhibition in conjunction with the Milan Triennial to commemorate the centenary of Achille Castiglioni. Meanwhile, Tom Dixon is on an extended road trip to introduce new products and serve as head cheerleader for his brand, highlighting the importance of networking over traditional trade shows.

site_title: Record stock streak enriches Galaxy Entertainment founder by US$12b
summary: Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd, a top casino operator in Macau, has achieved a record winning streak, jumping about 200% over the past seven quarters. The company's founder, Lui Che-Woo, has seen his wealth increase to US$12 billion, surpassing his pre-anti-graft campaign losses. Analysts predict a further 12% gain, citing Galaxy's focus on mass-market gambling and its recovery from the 2015 low. The company's annual profit beat analyst estimates, and it secured a significant share of Macau's casino revenues, setting it up for potential growth in the US$33 billion market.

site_title: Euro edges higher after German jobs strength
summary: The euro edged higher against the dollar after German unemployment data showed a decline, indicating continued strength in the eurozone's largest economy. The euro traded 0.1% up at $1.2318, while the dollar fell slightly to 89.954 against a basket of major currencies. The data overshadowed inflation figures, which eased a slight slowdown in price rises. Investors took profits after a hefty rise in the previous session, with some analysts suggesting the dollar's bounce was overdone due to structural reasons such as trade and budget deficits.

site_title: Trump says infrastructure plan may wait until after elections
summary: US President Donald Trump said his major infrastructure plan may not be passed by Congress until after the midterm elections in November due to likely Democratic opposition. The plan aims to attract private investment of $1.5 trillion with $200 billion in federal funding. Trump cited the Democrats' opposition to his policies as a reason for the potential delay, despite having his party control both houses of Congress. The elections, which will determine control of Congress, may swing control to the opposition, putting pressure on Trump's administration.

site_title: Data for sale - with or without your consent
summary: A growing number of companies are collecting and selling personal data without users' consent, highlighting the need for vigilance in data protection. Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal exposed the value of personal data, while other companies like the Shanghai Data Exchange in China and numerous app developers are monetizing datasets. Global data analytics revenues are expected to exceed $200 billion in 2020, with data collection dating back decades. Despite laws protecting individual data, companies often aggregate data and sell it, raising concerns about conflicts of interest and the consequences for those who refuse to surrender data.

site_title: Tesla says driver's hands weren't on wheel at time of accident
summary: Tesla says a driver's hands weren't on the wheel for 6 seconds before a fatal crash in California, where 38-year-old Wei Huang died. The company's computer logs showed the driver received several visual and audible warnings before the accident. Tesla defended its Autopilot program, citing statistics that show it reduces the likelihood of fatal accidents by 3.7 times. The incident raises questions about self-driving features and the company's production and recalls amid a $5 billion loss in market value.

site_title: Midas audit committee files police report
summary: The audit committee of Midas Holdings has filed a police report in Singapore over suspected breaches of securities laws and other offenses linked to irregularities in the company's China operations. The audit committee, comprising three independent non-executive directors, is investigating a possible breach of securities laws and will take necessary actions to protect shareholders' interests. The company has also failed to receive funds from its subsidiaries in China for the redemption of its US$30 million notes due 2017, prompting the audit committee to urge cooperation from local staff.

site_title: From airwaves to fairways
summary: A 25-year-old man who started his career as a radio DJ is now a self-proclaimed struggling 15 handicap-index golfer, hosting a golf travel fair at Marina Square Shopping Mall from April 6 to 8.

site_title: Countries affected by Russia's latest diplomat expulsions
summary: Russia has expelled diplomats from 23 European Union countries in retaliation for the UK's expulsion of Russian diplomats following the poisoning of a former double agent. Russia also told Britain to make "reductions" to its diplomatic staff. This move is seen as a tit-for-tat response to the UK's actions, with most of the affected countries being EU members. The expulsions are part of a broader diplomatic row between Russia and the UK over the poisoning incident.

site_title: China's yuan to post biggest quarterly rise against US dollar in a decade
summary: China's yuan is set to post its biggest quarterly gain in a decade, with a 3.7% appreciation in the March quarter, as capital inflows and US trade frictions boost expectations of a firmer Chinese currency. The yuan's value has risen to 6.2695 per dollar, surpassing its highest closing level since August 2015. Analysts attribute the recent strength to China's stabilizing economy, structural reforms, and the looming US-China trade war, which may fuel expectations of a stronger yuan to defuse tensions with Washington.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the dollar on Friday and is set to post its biggest quarterly gain in a decade, as the country attracts capital inflows and US trade frictions bolstered expectations of a firmer Chinese currency.

site_title: Beauty, According To The Italians
summary: The Parkview Museum in Singapore has opened its new exhibition "Challenging Beauty: Insights Into Italian Contemporary Art," showcasing works from the past 50 years of Italian art. The exhibition, curated by Lorand Hegyi, features over 40 artists, including notable figures such as Jannis Kounellis and Sandro Chia, and explores the evolution of Italian art from the Arte Povera movement to contemporary artists. The exhibition runs until August 19, 2018, and is free to the public, ensuring the museum will continue to operate for at least two more years.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

US mortgage rates rose for the first time in five weeks, with a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore potentially testing demand for prime projects above $3,000 psf. New World Group is selling China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at its Singapore location after emerging from bankruptcy. These developments signal ongoing market volatility and uncertainty.

site_title: China's manufacturing growth seen picking up slightly in March
summary: China's manufacturing growth is expected to slightly pick up in March, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) forecast to rise to 50.5, marking the 20th straight month of expansion. Steel companies ramped up output in response to strong sales, boosting borrowing and hiring. However, steel prices have fallen due to inventory surges. The economy is expected to maintain solid growth momentum, with a forecasted 6.9% growth in the first half, but economists predict a slowdown later in the year due to cooling property markets and rising borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: Defying expectations for a winter lull, Chinese steel companies have continued to ramp up output in Q1 in response to strong sales, and also boosted borrowing, capital expenditures and hiring, a survey from the China Beige Book showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Air China, China Eastern profit up despite fuel-cost surge
summary: Air China and China Eastern Airlines reported solid profit growth in 2017, driven by increasing travel demand from China's growing middle class. Air China earned 7.24 billion yuan, a 6.3% increase, while China Eastern took in 6.34 billion yuan, a 4.1% gain. Higher fuel costs, which rose 30% in 2017, were the main factor limiting profit growth. Despite this, both airlines saw significant revenue increases, with Air China's passenger revenue up 6.2% and China Eastern's up 9.6%. The strong yuan also helped reduce debt costs.

site_title: Samurai 2K gets growth through marketing and educational drives
summary: Singapore-based manufacturer Samurai 2K Aerosol has seen its profit triple to RM7.8 million in the first half of 2018, driven by growth in its 2K aerosol paint system. The company aims to expand its reach through marketing and educational drives, focusing on South-east Asian markets where motorcycles are popular. Samurai 2K plans to build deeper relationships with customers and introduce new products, including mirror chrome aerosol paint and an aerobrush system. The company will also expand to other international markets through digital channels.

site_title: UN blacklists dozens of ships, businesses over North Korea smuggling
summary: The UN Security Council blacklisted 27 ships, 21 companies, and a businessman for helping North Korea circumvent sanctions. The move, approved by the US, targets ships and firms involved in smuggling North Korean commodities, including oil and coal. The sanctions aim to cut off revenue to the nuclear-armed state's military programs, despite recent diplomatic overtures towards talks between the US and North Korea. The move is part of a global crackdown on North Korean smuggling, with 13 vessels banned from ports worldwide and 21 firms hit with an assets freeze.

images.alt_text: The UN Security Council on Friday blacklisted 27 ships, 21 companies and a businessman for helping North Korea circumvent sanctions, as the United States keeps up pressure on Pyongyang despite its recent overtures toward talks, diplomats said.

site_title: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group posts 12% rise in full-year net profit
summary: Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group reported a 12% increase in full-year net profit to 476.1 million yuan, despite a 9% revenue drop to 5.7 billion yuan. The company's gross profit improved by 9% to 2.1 billion yuan. Earnings per share rose to 0.62 yuan, and the directors proposed a final dividend of 153.8 million yuan. The company's net asset backing per share increased to 5.82 yuan.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Overlooked human 'organ' could play role in cancer spread
summary: Scientists have discovered a previously undetected feature of the human anatomy, the interstitium, a quasi-organ that could help explain why some cancers spread quickly. Using a laser-equipped mini-microscope, researchers found the interstitium, a network of fluid-filled pockets, throughout the body, including beneath the skin and surrounding arteries and veins. The discovery suggests the interstitium may act as a shock absorber and could be involved in cancer metastasis, potentially leading to dramatic advances in medicine.

site_title: Vietnam's economy expands 7.38%, best rate in a decade
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 7.38% in the first quarter of 2018, its fastest pace in a decade, driven by electronics manufacturing and exports. This growth rate surpassed the government's target of 6.7% and the World Bank's forecast of 6.5%. The 13% growth in manufacturing, led by exports topping $54 billion, was the main contributor to the expansion. Analysts have adjusted their forecasts, with Viet Capital Securities raising its target to 6.8%, citing strong growth at the end of 2017.

site_title: The grey side of creativity
summary: A study found that creative individuals are more likely to engage in unethical behavior when their creative personalities are activated. In experiments, individuals who were given tasks that allowed them to express their creativity were more likely to cheat or lie. This is because creative personalities often use self-serving justifications to rationalize questionable decisions. As a result, employers should exercise caution when hiring creative individuals, as their unique perspective may also lead to a lack of integrity.

site_title: M&A values in financial industry to surpass 2017 levels: Baker McKenzie
summary: Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in the financial sector of the Asia-Pacific region are expected to rise above 2017 levels in 2018, driven by Chinese outward investment, with values forecast to reach US$122.7 billion. The growth is attributed to the increasing influence of Asian financial institutions, including Chinese and Japanese banks, as well as fintech companies. The region's fintech space is also expected to be active, with both inflow and outflow deals anticipated. M&A values are expected to rise globally to US$616 billion in 2018, driven by ultra-low interest rates, tech-enabled disruption, and regulatory pressure.

site_title: Girl Power
summary: Samsui women, also known as hong tou jin, migrated to Singapore from Canton province in the 1930s to work in the construction industry. They wore distinctive bright red headgear, which also served as a sun protector and storage space. Many worked until their 70s, with some settling in Singapore permanently. Although few Samsui women remain in Singapore, they have been recognized for their labor through art exhibitions, TV shows, and books, honoring their contributions to the country's history.

site_title: Women face uphill wage battle in UK finance sector
summary: UK-based banks have been forced to publish their gender pay gaps, revealing significant disparities between men and women. The results show men earn 18.4% more per hour than women nationwide, with some institutions having pay gaps of 37.2%, 33%, and 59% respectively. Barclays' London-based investment bank unit has a 48% gap, while Goldman Sachs has a 55.5% gap. Banks are working to close the gap, but women still face an uphill struggle in the finance sector.

site_title: Bank of China back in black, CCB profit also picks up
summary: Bank of China and China Construction Bank, two of China's state-owned lenders, reported improved profits in 2017. Bank of China swung back into the black with a net profit of 172.4 billion yuan, up 4.8% from the previous year. China Construction Bank's 2017 net profit grew 4.7%, with both banks citing a "stronger-than-expected" economic expansion. The results follow a forecast-beating 6.9% economic growth in 2017, and analysts attribute the improved earnings to the Chinese government's campaign to clean up bad loans and risky lending.

site_title: Mild recovery caps short but rocky week
summary: Singapore stocks recovered slightly on Thursday, closing 0.19% higher for the week and 0.74% for the year, after a rocky week of global trade fears. The Straits Times Index rose 45.19 points to 3,427.97. Bourse operator Singapore Exchange and Keppel Corporation saw gains, while Sembcorp Industries and Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust were flat. Loss-making companies IEV Holdings and Artivision Technologies declined. Economists expressed concerns about market volatility ahead of the Easter weekend.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Legendary Suite
summary: The Anantara Mai Khao Phuket Villas has transformed its standalone Jim Thompson suite into a design tribute to the legendary American silk businessman, who disappeared in the 1960s. The two-bedroom villa features classic Thai interiors, complete with Jim Thompson silks and fabric, and has its own private pool. The suite is designed to resemble a traditional Thai home, with blue and white upholstered furniture and matching wall coverings. A huge store featuring Jim Thompson silks is also nearby, offering inspiration for guests.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Veteran businessman Koh Boon Hwee is stepping down as non-executive chairman of Far East Hospitality Trust on June 30, succeeded by Wee Kheng Jin. Meanwhile, Alliance Mineral Assets secured up to A$13 million in debt funding for its Bald Hill lithium and tantalum mine. CapitaLand's chief digital officer Ng Kok Siong has resigned, and Oxley Holdings completed its S$660 million acquisition of Chevron House. United Engineers has resettled 44 farmer households on its Shanghai Olympic Garden development land, paving the way for the next phase.

site_title: Growth in bank lending eases to 3.7% y-o-y in February
summary: Bank lending in Singapore expanded by 3.7% in February, the slowest pace since January last year, with loans totaling S$650.93 billion. This growth is weaker than the 5.4% year-on-year growth in the previous month.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Inclusion is the way forward to true innovation
summary: Singapore, a renowned hub for innovation, is facing a challenge in maintaining its momentum as a "smart nation". Experts argue that inclusion is key to innovation, emphasizing the importance of collaboration between government, businesses, and startups. Singapore's success has been built on international trade and embracing new ideas, with the country's startup ecosystem ranking 12th globally. Companies like Experian and Unilever are adopting collaborative approaches, partnering with startups to tap into fresh perspectives and resources. By fostering a culture of problem-solving and partnerships, Singapore can continue to drive innovation and stay ahead in the global landscape.

site_title: Can North Korea handle a K-pop invasion?
summary: North Korea is hosting a series of concerts featuring South Korean artists, including K-pop group Red Velvet, as part of a cultural diplomacy campaign. The move is seen as a strategic opening of the reclusive regime to the outside world, potentially hinting at a willingness to roll back its nuclear program. The symbolism is striking, given South Korea's use of K-pop for psychological warfare and the North's alleged inspiration from the genre to escape. The concerts will feature vetted performances and may include propaganda efforts to promote the North's nuclear development.

site_title: Rethinking Retail
summary: Brick-and-mortar retailers are adapting to online competition by embracing e-commerce and redefining the physical shopping experience. FJ Benjamin and OUE's retail arm are setting up advisory boards to synergize their physical and online sales channels. Luxury brands like Henry Jacques and Surrender are creating bespoke experiences in their standalone boutiques, while Japanese department store Lumine is focusing on customer service and unique shopping experiences. A hybrid retail model, where online and brick-and-mortar work together, is gaining traction, with Amazon's cashier-less store and local start-ups testing pop-up stores.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Shoe Off
summary: Repetto teams up with Japanese artist Watanabe Mayumi for two limited edition Cendrillon ballerina pumps. Jimmy Choo collaborates with Off-White's Virgil Abloh, creating a glam streetwear collection. JW Anderson partners with Converse for a classic, high-end sneaker collection. Liam Hodges collaborates with Fila, offering oversized, colorful designs. These exclusive collaborations are now available in selected boutiques worldwide.

site_title: Stop demonising the high-tech titans of Silicon Valley!
summary: In 2018, social media chiefs were hailed as visionaries, not villains, during Obama's campaigns. However, a different narrative has emerged, blaming Facebook and Google for the 2016 US presidential election's outcome, including the election of Donald Trump. This shift in perspective is attributed to the anti-tech campaign, "tech-lash," which claims that these companies are harming the public interest and exhibiting monopolistic tendencies. The narrative ignores the role of social media in Obama's election campaigns, where Facebook and Google were used to target young voters and raise millions of dollars online.

site_title: The anyday pleasure that everyday wines can provide
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of everyday wines in one's life, rather than rare and expensive bottles. It argues that paying attention to moderately priced and easy-to-drink wines can significantly improve one's drinking life. The author suggests considering wine as food, not just a beverage, and thinking of the occasion rather than the wine's universal scale of greatness. To find good bottles, it's recommended to rely on merchants and sommeliers, spend a little more, and commit to diversity, exploring lesser-known grapes and areas. By broadening the definition of greatness, one can appreciate everyday wines that are accessible, interesting, and refreshing.

site_title: Finance should be used to promote shared values and for the common good
summary: The global economy has experienced a tumultuous decade since the 2008 financial crisis, with renewed market tensions indicating that risks remain. The post-WWII global order, established through institutions like the Bretton Woods institutions, has been a key factor in promoting economic stability. However, the current state of globalism, particularly under the Trump administration, poses challenges to this order. The ongoing US foreign policy shift, coupled with the rise of China, has set a new tone for international relations, highlighting the need for a revised approach to promote shared values and the common good.

site_title: Port-related counters are hit by US-China trade tensions
summary: US-China trade tensions have hit port-related counters, with Singapore's Hutchison Port Holdings Trust and Hong Kong's China Merchants Port Holdings and Cosco Shipping Ports reaching record lows. Rising US protectionism may spread to other sectors, including banking and shipbuilding. Container port business fell to a record low in Singapore, while logistics conglomerate China Merchants Port Holdings in Hong Kong reached an eight-year low. The decline is attributed to continued trade tensions between the US and China, posing a risk to the port industry.

site_title: Sustaining growth, boosting resilience and innovation on agenda at upcoming meet
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Asean countries to sustain growth, boost resilience, and foster innovation at the upcoming 4th Asean Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' meeting. The region aims to continue its remarkable progress since its founding in 1967, with a focus on infrastructure development to support rapid urbanization. A substantial financing gap of $2.8 trillion is estimated for infrastructure needs between 2016 and 2030, with a focus on mobilizing private capital and promoting sustainable financing. The meeting also aims to enhance disaster resilience, cybersecurity, and digital innovation, particularly in fintech and payment systems.

images.alt_text: At a media briefing ahead of next week's 4th Asean Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' meeting, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat laid out what needs to be done by Asean countries over the next 50 years to continue the remarkable progress the region has made since its founding in 1967.

site_title: Excelpoint builds on nexus role in electronics distribution
summary: Excelpoint Technology, a Singapore-based electronics distributor, is thriving despite the "sunset industry" narrative. Founded in 1987 by Albert Phuay, the company has grown to over 700 employees across 10 countries in the Asia-Pacific region. Excelpoint has increased revenues by 18% CAGR and net profits by 36% CAGR between 2015 and 2017, reaching a record US$1.1 billion in revenue in 2017. The company is poised for steady growth, driven by the "One Belt, One Road" initiative, the rise of the digital economy, and emerging markets such as China, India, and South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: One of the key growth drivers for the distribution industry include China's "One Belt, One Road" (OBOR) initiative, Mr Phuay says.

site_title: Eating Green
summary: Green caviar, a type of seaweed from Okinawa, is a key component of the Japanese island's local diet, credited for its residents' long and healthy lives. Rich in omega-3, calcium, and antioxidants, it has anti-cancer properties and can help prevent thyroid goiters. Green caviar is now available in Singapore and other countries, with benefits including regulating blood pressure and reducing insulin resistance. Meanwhile, a vegan restaurant HRVST and a healthy eatery Verde Kitchen have opened, offering plant-based options with superfoods like spirulina and turmeric.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: World's newest oil future still finding its feet
summary: China's newly launched oil futures contract has struggled to find its footing, with fluctuations relative to other benchmarks indicating market participants are still assessing its value. Despite initial support from major oil companies, the contract has been dragged down by lower-quality oil deliveries, resulting in prices comparable to European Brent and American West Texas Intermediate. Liquidity issues and high speculative trading volumes have raised concerns about the contract's reliability as a benchmark, hindering its ability to protect against future price fluctuations.

site_title: Down Mexico Way
summary: Aman Resorts has chosen Mexico's Baja Peninsula for its latest luxury resort, Amanvari, set within the private beachfront community of Costa Palmas. The project, designed by Heah & Co., will feature individual villas blending into the unique landscape of mountains and sea. Guests can experience wildlife, freshwater swimming holes, and activities like diving with migrant whales, sailing, and fishing expeditions. The resort aims to offer a secluded and unspoiled luxury getaway, allowing visitors to connect with nature and local wildlife.

site_title: Blumont plans to buy SEA tourism, F&B firm Samadhi Retreats for up to S$43.8m
summary: Blumont Group plans to acquire Samadhi Retreats, a South-east Asian tourism and F&B firm, for up to S$43.8 million. The acquisition will be funded through a mix of cash and shares, with S$7 million in cash and 9.2 billion shares issued at S$0.004 per share. The deal aims to diversify Blumont's portfolio, reduce reliance on existing business, and generate additional revenue streams. The purchase includes ownership and development rights to real estate in Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Global IPO proceeds up 28% in Q1 2018: EY report
summary: Global IPO proceeds rose 28% in Q1 2018 to $42.8 billion, driven by larger transactions, despite a 39% decline in deal numbers. The Asia-Pacific region saw 157 deals, a 39% fall, but remained the world's busiest for new listings. South-east Asian stock exchanges hosted 18 IPOs, a 20% increase, driven by junior boards. The Americas saw a 22% increase in proceeds raised and 29% in deals, while emerging markets contributed strongly to EMEIA's overall IPO performance.

site_title: Safeguarding organisations in a digital world
summary: Cyberattacks are becoming increasingly sophisticated, with high-profile data breaches and cybercrimes making headlines almost every month. To stay ahead, organisations are investing in automated security processes, leveraging cloud providers, and implementing advanced solutions such as identity and access management, multi-factor authentication, and artificial intelligence. Despite these efforts, many enterprises are understaffed in the security department, with a projected shortage of 1.8 million security personnel by 2022. A holistic security strategy is crucial to address the realities of today's cybersecurity, coupled with constant vigilance and software advancements.

site_title: Singapore property auction sales in Q1 up 31%
summary: Singapore property auction sales in Q1 2018 rose 31% to 11 units sold, with a total value of S$19.97 million. This increase reflects positive sentiments and strong demand in the market, despite unchanged new properties put up for sale. The government's announcement of increased buyer's stamp duty may have deterred some buyers, but local and foreign buyers are returning to the auction market. Lender sales accounted for the majority of transactions, with 8 units sold totaling S$13.42 million.

site_title: Hong Kong private home prices continue record-breaking run
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices reached a new all-time high in February, with a 1.62% increase from the previous month, marking 16 consecutive months of record-breaking growth. The year-on-year increase was 16%. A rental index also rose 0.11% in February, following a 10-month record-breaking streak. The city's financial chief expects property prices to come under pressure as more flats hit the market and interest rates rise. This is the latest development in the already highly unaffordable property market in Hong Kong.

site_title: Spending real dollars on virtual objects isn't crazy
summary: The video game industry's focus on virtual goods has led to a surge in spending on digital objects, with companies like Blizzard and Tencent Holdings generating millions from cosmetic modifications to in-game worlds. The trend has sparked debates on the ethics of selling virtual goods, but executives argue that charging for cosmetic changes keeps players engaged and happy.
