The industry's emphasis on "lifetime value" and the potential for decentralized virtual ownership, as seen in Cryptokitties, may redefine the concept of commerce in virtual worlds, with implications for the future of entertainment and services.

site_title: Seized Anbang continues to sell its products - and investors to buy them
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group, seized by the government last month, continues to sell its high-risk investment products to small investors, despite the takeover. The products, such as Anbang Abundant Stability No 10, promise triple the returns of savings accounts but are backed by the government, not the company. Investors remain confident in the government's ability to bail out struggling companies, with some even viewing the products as a safe investment. Authorities are taking steps to tighten regulations on wealth management products, but the risk of debt crisis remains, with many investors still unaware of the true nature of the products.

site_title: Chinese food-to-flights app Meituan-Dianping offers half-baked IPO
summary: Meituan-Dianping, a Chinese food-to-flights app, is preparing for a potential Hong Kong IPO despite two major issues: its lack of consistent profitability and diverse business sectors. The company, valued at $30 billion, has seen revenue more than double to $5.4 billion last year, but operates in multiple markets with high competition. Meituan-Dianping's stock could be volatile, and investors may clash with management over underperforming areas. The company has tapped banks to work on an IPO, which could happen as early as this year.

site_title: Broccolini Construction to build tallest residential tower in Montreal
summary: Broccolini Construction Inc plans to invest C$300 million to build the tallest residential tower in Montreal, a 56-storey mixed-use building. The tower will contain 400 condominium units, office, and retail space. The project, set to start marketing in fall 2018 and complete in 2023, will be located next to National Bank's new headquarters. This development is part of the city's growing commercial market, with C$3.5 billion in transactions in the first three quarters of last year.

site_title: United Global unit enters JV in Australia
summary: United Global, a Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer and trader, has entered into a joint venture with Australian companies PFR Management and DP United to import and distribute lubricant products in Australia. United Oil Company will hold 35% of the joint venture, while PFR and DP United will hold 55% and 10%, respectively. The joint venture aims to increase United Global's presence in Australia and gain market access. The investment is valued at A$35,000 and will be funded through internal resources.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: When Life Gives Lemons
summary: A romantic comedy play called "Lemons, Lemons, Lemons, Lemons" explores the complexities of romance and free speech in a society where the government limits daily word count to 140 words. The play, produced by Adeeb&Shai, follows a newlywed couple navigating their relationship under this restriction. It will be performed at the Aliwal Arts Centre Multi-Purpose Hall from April 4-7.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Breaking botnets and wrestling ransomware
summary: Microsoft publishes the bi-annual Microsoft Security Intelligence Report to educate organizations about current threats, best practices, and solutions. The report leverages massive data from various sources, including Windows, Bing, Office 365, and Azure, to scan 400 billion email messages, 450 billion authentications, 18 billion web page scans, and 1.2 billion device scans for threats each month. This intelligence helps businesses strengthen their security posture and stay informed about security trends and events.

site_title: As a giant, Grab must act responsibly
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ridehailing app, plans to acquire Uber's South-east Asian business, taking over its transport and food delivery operations. In return, Uber will receive a 27.5% stake in Grab. The merger would make Grab a regional titan, offering services like transport, food delivery, and financial services. The deal has raised concerns about Grab's potential monopolistic behavior and its impact on consumers and innovation, despite the startup's market share and current unprofitability.

site_title: Singapore market cap slips to under a trillion amid trade tensions
summary: The Singapore market capitalization dropped 2.9% to S$984.5 billion by the end of March due to trade war tensions. The Straits Times Index, which consists of 30 component stocks, saw its market capitalization decline 3.1% to S$576.3 billion. This weaker finish reflects the losses in the broader market, caused by the escalating trade tensions.

site_title: Consumer spending gain lags behind income for second month in Feb
summary: Consumer spending in the US rose 0.2% in February, lagging behind income growth for a second month. Inflation increased 1.8% from February 2017, the most in nearly a year. Despite a rise in saving rates, economists forecast slower household demand due to moderating purchases. A robust labor market and lower taxes are expected to boost spending in coming months, but some consumers may be taking a breather after credit-card balances mounted in late 2017.

site_title: Girls Wanna Have Fun
summary: Two young playwrights, Pooja Nansi and Jessica Bellamy, create a hip-hop inspired play titled Thick Beats For Good Girls, exploring female identity and experiences as ethnic or religious minorities. The play, directed by Huzir Sulaiman, will run at the Drama Centre Black Box from April 5 to 22. It promises to be a "hippest, most heartfelt experience" at the theatre this year, showcasing the funky sounds of hip-hop and the challenges of growing up as a "good girl" under familial expectations.

images.alt_text: Thick Beats For Good Girls plays.
Helmi Yusof

site_title: Design Purist
summary: Gabriel Tan, a 36-year-old Singaporean designer, has established himself as a progressive designer with works exhibited globally. He is creative director of Japanese furniture brand Ariake and founder of Gabriel Tan Studio. Tan prioritizes human interaction in the design process, believing it enhances the product. He has worked with international brands, citing Alvar Aalto as a design inspiration. Tan advocates for owning fewer, but better, things, emphasizing quality, comfort, and uniqueness.

site_title: Stella McCartney to take full control of her fashion brand
summary: STELLA McCartney is buying back the 50% stake in her eponymous fashion brand from French luxury group Kering, ending a 17-year partnership. This move establishes McCartney as a rare independent label in a consolidating market. The deal follows months of speculation and paves the way for McCartney to take full control of her fashion brand.

images.alt_text: By going it alone, Ms McCartney will be bucking the trend in the luxury space, where independently owned and operated labels are few and far between.

site_title: Shale patch making money, hiring and ready to drill for more
summary: The US shale patch is hiring and ready to drill for more oil as producers are comfortably making a profit. Over 50% of surveyed oil and gas executives said they can profitably drill a new well at current prices. The Permian Basin, a hot oil exploration area, is seeing increased investment and competition, with Concho Resources paying $8 billion for RSP Permian. The area is the cheapest place to drill, with operating expenses averaging $25-$30 per barrel. US production has added over 1 million barrels per day, causing "profound implications on energy geopolitics".

images.alt_text: The Permian Basin, covering a huge area of West Texas and New Mexico, is one of the hottest oil exploration areas.

site_title: SembMarine sees uptick in customer enquiries, but competition still intense
summary: SembCorp Marine sees an uptick in customer enquiries, particularly in the offshore production sector, but faces intense competition and depressed margins. The company expects a recovery to take time, citing a cyclical nature of its business. Oil prices have improved due to a stronger global economy and higher energy consumption, but rig orders recovery may be slow due to oversupply. The company remains optimistic on demand for vessel repairs and upgrades, especially for LNG carriers and cruise ships.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: US stocks opened lower on July 11, 2025, amid President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for H2. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. In other news, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case, and Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Additionally, MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance, and CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' citing slowing earnings growth in H2.

site_title: Landmines to be cleared from Jesus' baptism site
summary: Thousands of landmines are set to be cleared from the site where Jesus was baptized, allowing eight churches to reclaim land sealed off since the 1970s. The Halo Trust, a de-mining charity, will remove the mines at a cost of around $3 million. The majority of the mines were laid by Israeli forces after the 1967 takeover of the West Bank. The project has been approved by Israelis, Palestinians, and Jordan, and work has begun on the Ethiopian church, with a further $150,000 needed to complete the work.

site_title: Peranakan Affairs
summary: Two Singapore hotels, The Fullerton Bay Hotel and Sheraton Towers Singapore, are partnering with Peranakan chefs Philip Chia and Shermay Lee to offer heritage cuisine buffets. The Fullerton Bay Hotel's Heritage Dinner Buffet features lesser-known dishes like Babi Tohay, while Sheraton Towers Singapore's Peranakan Dinner Buffet showcases over 20 traditional dishes, including Udang Nanas Pedas, prepared according to Ms Lee's late grandmother's recipes. Both buffets are available every weekend evening until April 14, priced at S$68++. Reservations can be made by calling 6877 8911 or 6839 5621.

images.alt_text: Heritage Dinner Buffet.
Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Barclays pays US$2b to settle mortgage securities suit
summary: Barclays has agreed to pay $2 billion in civil penalties to settle a US investigation into its marketing of residential mortgage-backed securities between 2005 and 2007. The settlement resolves a Justice Department lawsuit targeting two former executives, Paul Menefee and John Carroll, who also settled for $2 million. The probe found Barclays misrepresented borrowers' creditworthiness, resulting in significant losses for investors. The bank's CEO, Jes Staley, welcomed the deal, calling it "fair and proportionate." The settlement is seen as a positive for Barclays, which had initially sought a lower amount.

site_title: UK house prices fall, with weakest showing again by London
summary: UK house prices fell 0.2% in March, marking the second consecutive month of decline, according to Nationwide Building Society. The annual pace of gains slowed to 2.1% due to a gloomy consumer mood and squeezed incomes. London remains the weakest market, with prices down 1% from a year earlier. The Brexit uncertainty and inflation have undermined consumer confidence, leading to a decline in new buyers and cautious sellers.

site_title: Emas Offshore unit served termination notice over charter
summary: Emas Offshore's indirect wholly owned subsidiary, Emas Offshore Pte Ltd (EOPL), received a notice of termination over a bareboat charter for the Lewek Avior vessel. The charter, dated April 26, 2011, was with Marina Aquata Shipping Pte Ltd. Marina Aquata claims breaches of material obligations and representation or warranty by EOPL and its guarantor, Ezra Holdings, led to the termination notice. EOPL is seeking legal advice and assessing the impact of the notice, with the company also allegedly liable to pay Marina Aquata on demand for losses.

site_title: Noble Group's US$24m sale of Kamsarmax dry bulk carrier to help pare debts
summary: NOBLE Group has entered into a memorandum of agreement to sell its Kamsarmax dry bulk carrier, Ocean Vision, to Ocean Liberty Marine Ltd and Transmed Shipping Ltd for $24 million in cash. The sale is aimed at helping the company pare its debt. The vessel is currently mortgaged and part of the proceeds will go towards paying down the mortgage. Net proceeds from the sale will be approximately $8.2 million after deducting transaction costs.

site_title: More than 25 million people apply for Indian railway vacancies
summary: More than 25 million people applied for 90,000 positions on India's state-run railways, exceeding the current population of Australia. The move is a challenge for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who promised jobs in his 2014 election campaign. The recruitment drive aims to fill vacant positions and improve safety in the world's fourth-largest network, but experts warn that training the new workers will be a logistical challenge, and the issue of unemployment remains a pressing concern in India.

site_title: Noble's creditors not its economic owners, and liquidation not the only other option: Goldilocks
summary: Noble Group's creditors, including Goldilocks Investment Company, have disputed the company's claim that senior creditors are its economic owners in a liquidation scenario. Goldilocks argued that Noble's board has rejected refinancing and White knight proposals, and that an administration process in the UK is not a better alternative to judicial management in Singapore. The investment firm also criticized Noble's existing management for receiving a stake in the new company and called for transparency on the identity and holdings of the senior creditors who have committed to a restructuring support agreement.

site_title: AusGroup plans S$37m equity fundraising, rights issue
summary: AusGroup plans to raise S$37 million through a rights issue, offering 1.05 billion subscription shares at S$0.035 each. The company also announced a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 752 million shares, priced at a 25.37% discount to its VWAP. The funds will be used to support the company's growth and expansion plans.

site_title: UMS plans to buy 70% in metal alloys specialist
summary: UMS Holdings, a provider of engineering services to semiconductor manufacturers, plans to acquire 70% of Starke Singapore Pte Ltd, a non-ferrous metal alloys specialist. The agreement was made through a memorandum of understanding, with no purchase price disclosed.

site_title: United Food's FY2017 loss narrows to 68.64m yuan
summary: United Food Holdings reported a narrowed FY2017 loss of 68.64 million yuan, down from 229.26 million yuan in the previous year. Revenue rose to 34.93 million yuan, primarily driven by the acquisition of Really Time Trading Limited in August 2017. The company clocked zero revenue in Q4 and FY2017.

site_title: CapitaLand's chief digital officer resigns
summary: CapitaLand Ltd announced the resignation of its chief digital officer, Ng Kok Siong, effective until the end of April. Ng, who has been with the company since 2005, will be succeeded by Jason Leow, the group's chief operating officer. The reason for Ng's departure is unclear, with the company stating he will pursue "other personal and professional interests".

site_title: Midas' audit committee files police report
summary: The audit committee of Midas Holdings has filed a police report with Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department over possible breaches of securities laws and other offenses related to the company's operations in China. The audit committee, comprising three independent non-executive directors, will continue to investigate and take necessary actions to protect shareholders and the group. The full extent of the possible breaches has yet to be determined.

site_title: Oxley finalises deal for Chevron House; net lettable area to get 20% boost
summary: Oxley Holdings has completed its S$660 million acquisition of Chevron House in Singapore, increasing its net lettable area by at least 20%. The 32-storey commercial building now boasts a 24,293 square metre floor area, with 97% office space and 99% retail space occupancy rates. Oxley's CEO, Ching Chiat Kwong, sees a strong office property market, driven by resilient demand and limited supply, benefiting asset owners. The acquisition caps a busy week for the property developer, which also announced several other deals.

site_title: US consumer spending up modestly; savings rise to 6-month high
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.2% in February for a second consecutive month, with savings reaching a 6-month high of $497.4 billion. Economists forecast a modest economic growth rate in the first quarter, with the Atlanta Fed predicting a 1.8% GDP growth rate. Despite a moderation in inflation, consumer spending was unchanged when adjusted for inflation, suggesting a slowdown in spending. The personal income and wages also rose, with wages increasing 0.5% in February.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher amid perceived progress on N.Korea issues
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.2% to 30,093.38, driven by perceived progress on North Korea issues. China Mengniu Dairy Co Ltd led gains, while PetroChina Co Ltd fell 1.82%. Despite caution over the China-US trade spat, investors remained optimistic.

site_title: Europe: Cyclicals drive shares higher
summary: European shares rose on Thursday, driven by a recovery in cyclical sectors and M&A news. Autos stocks, led by Renault's 6.4% gain after reports of a potential Nissan-Renault merger, contributed to the STOXX 600's 0.1% increase. Cyclical basic resources, autos, and banking stocks also rose. Despite a 5% decline in the index for the worst quarter in two years, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Blumont plans S$43.8m acquisition of South-east Asian tourism firm
summary: Blumont Group plans to acquire Samadhi Retreats Pte Ltd, a Singapore-incorporated company, for up to S$43.8 million. The acquisition will be funded with S$7 million in cash and 9.2 billion shares at S$0.004 per share. The deal aims to diversify Blumont's portfolio, reduce reliance on existing business, and provide additional revenue streams. The investment holding company will hold a portfolio of businesses in South-east Asia, including hotels, resorts, and tourism operations, with ownership and development rights in Malaysia and Thailand.

site_title: Asean finance ministers to look at sustainable growth, resiliency at next week's meeting
summary: ASEAN finance ministers will meet in Singapore next week to discuss sustainable growth, resiliency, and innovation. The region aims to sustain its remarkable progress over the past 50 years, with a focus on infrastructure development, private capital mobilization, and sustainable financing. The meeting will also address climate-adjusted infrastructure needs of $3.1 trillion, disaster resilience, and cybersecurity. Ministers will promote digital innovations like FinTech and support regional payment linkages to boost economic integration and e-commerce.

site_title: Australia shares closes at over 5-month low; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed at their lowest in over five months, falling 0.5% to 5,759.4, driven by a decline in iron ore prices and weakness in material stocks, including BHP and Rio Tinto. Consumer staples also suffered, with a2 Milk Company Ltd leading the losses. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.8% to 8,319.07, marking its second straight monthly loss. The decline marks the biggest monthly loss since January 2016.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

Noble Group's restructuring support agreement has been criticized by Goldilocks Investment Company, a major shareholder. Sembcorp Industries' CEO Neil McGregor and top management have taken a voluntary 10-15% pay cut. Singapore property auction sales rose 31% in Q1 to S$19.97m. Midas Holdings has not remitted funds for note holders' redemption, despite instructions. Schneider Electric opened its East Asia and Japan headquarters in Singapore. SembMarine saw an uptick in customer enquiries, but competition remains strong. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat warned that trade war benefits nobody, and Singapore shares closed up 1.34% on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.52 points to 1,856.35, with a volume of 1.88 billion shares worth RM2.09 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 546 to 330.

site_title: Trade war benefits nobody, says Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that a trade war benefits nobody and could damage all economies. The country is monitoring US trade measures and rising tensions with China, but has not seen a major impact yet. Heng emphasized the importance of free trade and integration within Asean, with discussions underway to integrate economies beyond trade, including services and capital markets. Singapore is seeking product exclusions from US tariffs on steel and aluminium and is working closely with US departments on trade actions.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 1.34% on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.34% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 45.19 points to 3,427.97. Gainers outpaced losers 254 to 167, driven by gains from Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Industries. The market saw a mild recovery despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. Roughly 1.48 billion shares were traded for S$1.79 billion.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Top Glove unit buys 85% stake in medical supplies maker
summary: Top Glove Corporation Bhd announced it will buy an 85% stake in Duramedical Sdn Bhd, a Malaysian medical supplies manufacturer, for RM2.85 million. The deal aims to diversify into medical products catering to Top Glove's existing customer base. Duramedical manufactures rubber dental dams, exercise bands, and other latex or rubber related products. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2018, barring unforeseen circumstances.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: North, South Korea to hold summit on April 27
summary: North and South Korea will hold their first summit in over a decade on April 27, according to South Korean government officials. The agreement was made after South Korean President Moon Jae-in met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang earlier this month. The summit will take place at the border truce village of Panmunjom, marking a significant step towards improved relations between the two nations.

site_title: Goldilocks says liquidation not the only option to Noble's restructuring
summary: Goldilocks Investment Company, a major shareholder of Noble Group, has expressed "serious inaccuracies and deficiencies" in Noble's restructuring response, disputing the claim that liquidation is the only alternative to the Singapore bourse's restructuring support agreement (RSA) plan. Goldilocks asserts that Noble's board has failed to justify its existing management's entitlement to "free equity and a full release from liability," and that the board has rejected alternative proposals, including refinancing and a "white knight" rescue plan.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend gains, won strengthens
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 17.08 points or 0.71% to 2,436.37, extending gains following a positive day for Chinese markets and news of a planned April summit between South and North Korea. The Korean won strengthened to 1,065.9 per dollar, while the US dollar fell 0.18% against the won this year.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tech stocks recover
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 121.89 points, or 0.51%, to 23,970.31. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 11.72 points, or 0.449904%, to 2,616.72, and the Nasdaq Composite up 34.95 points, or 0.5%, to 6,984.17. This recovery comes after a rollercoaster week for Wall Street, with technology shares making some lost ground.

site_title: Development to begin on next phase of Shanghai Olympic Garden: United Engineers
summary: United Engineers Limited announced the resettlement of 44 farmer households on a remaining 33,471 sq m of land for its Shanghai Olympic Garden development, allowing the project to proceed. Phase 3.2, valued at 3 billion yuan, will feature 517 low-rise apartments and construction will start in the second half of 2018, with completion by the end of 2021. The project's completion is expected to positively contribute to United Engineers' future earnings.

site_title: Shadow economy goes cashless in Russia under state bank's watch
summary: Russia's shadow economy, estimated to be over a third of the country's GDP, is increasingly shifting towards a cashless digital platform. State-controlled Sberbank, the country's largest lender, has seen a surge in person-to-person online transfers, with about 1 trillion rubles handled last year. The digital dimension of the shadow economy is giving a glimpse into previously undocumented activities, but also raises concerns about a potential crackdown on operations deemed harmless. This shift has made Sberbank a key beneficiary, with the bank's CEO envisioning a technological company with a foothold in non-financial industries.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session higher on Thursday; STI at 3,413.53, up 0.9% on the day
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.9% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,413.53, driven by gains from Magnus Energy and other actively traded stocks. The market saw 793 million shares change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 211 to 112. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite uncertainty from US trade policies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as North Korea worries ease
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, driven by the yen's fall amid easing North Korea worries. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.61% to 21,159.08, while the Topix index gained 0.26% to 1,704.00. This follows a broader Asian market trend, where traders are brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank foiled attempts at unauthorised fund transfers
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, foiled a cybersecurity incident involving attempted unauthorised fund transfers using falsified SWIFT messages. The incident occurred on Tuesday without causing any financial loss or disruption to other payment systems. The bank collaborated with SWIFT, other central banks, and financial institutions to stop all unauthorised transactions, ensuring no disruption to the country's payment systems.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank said on Thursday it had detected and foiled a cybersecurity incident involving attempted unauthorised fund transfers using falsified SWIFT messages.

site_title: China's cutting taxes for the industries Trump wants to punish
summary: China has announced tax cuts for high-tech industries, including manufacturing, transportation, and telecommunications, to support the country's "Made in China 2025" plan. Starting May 1, the value-added tax will be reduced to 16% from 17%, and the rate on services will be lowered to 10% from 11%. The tax cuts are expected to boost economic growth and profits in sectors such as construction, information technology, and machinery, and will directly benefit companies supported by the state's industrial policy.

site_title: Singapore property auction sales in Q1 up 31% at S$19.97m
summary: Singapore property auction sales in Q1 2018 rose 31% to S$19.97m, with 11 properties sold. The number of new properties put up for sale stayed unchanged at 63 units. This marks a 31.2% increase from the same period last year and a 102.3% increase from two years ago. The strong demand in the market is attributed to positive sentiments.

site_title: UK house prices fall with London again the weakest region
summary: UK house prices fell 0.2% in March, marking the second consecutive month of decline, according to Nationwide Building Society. The annual pace of gains slowed to 2.1%, attributed to a gloomy consumer mood and income squeeze. London remained the weakest market, with prices down 1% from a year earlier, the fastest pace since the recession. The average house price stands at £211,625.

site_title: China says Anbang's founder defrauded investors of US$10b
summary: China has accused Anbang's founder, Wu Xiaohui, of defrauding investors of over $10 billion through false financial statements and promotional materials. Wu pleaded guilty to the charges and is expected to be found guilty, with prosecutors alleging he used these tactics to conceal his control of companies and raise funds from the public. The case is one of China's biggest financial crimes trials, and Wu could face life imprisonment if convicted. The investigation is part of China's efforts to crack down on excessive debt and regulate its wealth management products industry.

site_title: China's Ping An starting work on up to US$3b OneConnect IPO: sources
summary: Ping An Insurance, China's largest insurer by market value, is preparing for an initial public offering (IPO) of its OneConnect financial management portal, which could raise up to $3 billion. The company has selected banks including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan to work on the Hong Kong share sale, targeting a listing as soon as September. OneConnect, which offers AI-powered services to financial firms, has valued itself at $7.4 billion following a recent funding round. The IPO is part of Ping An's efforts to expand its technology services business, which includes online healthcare and healthcare technology platforms.

site_title: Global IPO proceeds up 28% in Q1 2018: EY report
summary: Global initial public offerings (IPOs) raised US$42.8 billion in the first quarter of 2018, a 28% increase from Q1 2017, despite a 27% decline in the number of deals. According to Ernst & Young's report, larger transactions drove the growth in proceeds. This marks a strong start to the year, defying expectations for a slow quarter.

site_title: Nissan, Renault in talks to merge, create new company: sources
summary: Renault and Nissan Motor Co are in talks to merge and create a new carmaker trading as a single stock. The deal would end the current alliance and marry the companies as one corporation, with Carlos Ghosn driving the negotiations. Renault would own 43% of the new company, and Nissan would give Renault shareholders stock in exchange for their holdings. The French government's 15% stake in Renault may pose a challenge to the deal, and no final decisions have been made.

images.alt_text: Renault and Nissan Motor Co are in talks to merge and create a new carmaker that trades as a single stock, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: India beckons big tech firms, allows imports of used goods for repair
summary: India has allowed the import of used goods for repair and refurbishing, with the condition that the imported items are exported. This move is seen as a potential win for US companies like Apple, which assemble products in China and could help reduce manufacturing and labor costs. The policy change comes amid a US-China trade war, with President Trump announcing plans to impose tariffs on up to $60 billion worth of Chinese goods. India aims to treat waste generated from repair and refurbishment in line with local laws and could potentially turn into a global export hub for refurbished devices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on Thursday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.44% to 30,154.18, following a sharp sell-off the previous day. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, rising 0.16% and 0.34% respectively. The gains came ahead of the Easter break, with traders seeking bargains.

site_title: Ex-boss of China's Anbang Insurance pleads for leniency in trial for economic crimes
summary: Former Anbang Insurance Group chairman Wu Xiaohui pleaded for leniency during his trial for alleged economic crimes, including fraud and embezzlement involving over $10 billion. Wu, who was accused of concealing his control over the company and faking financial statements, expressed deep remorse for his actions and requested a light sentence. The Shanghai court will issue a verdict at a later date, with Wu facing charges punishable by up to life imprisonment. The trial comes after the government seized control of Anbang, which was facing financial difficulties amid Beijing's crackdown on financial risk.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks little changed, won stronger against dollar
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index remained unchanged on Thursday, while the Korean won strengthened against the dollar. Hyundai group shares were mixed, with Hyundai Glovis surging 24% and Hyundai Mobis falling nearly 8%. The KOSPI index closed at 2,417.47, down 1.82 points or 0.08% from the previous day.

site_title: Schneider Electric opens East Asia and Japan headquarters in Singapore
summary: Schneider Electric has opened its East Asia and Japan headquarters in Singapore, consolidating its operations and marking the company's first Innovation Hub in Asia. The nine-storey building, costing S$23 million, features a hybrid electricity power source and can house over 1,200 employees. The hub will focus on IoT enabled system architecture and platform development, as well as a machine solutions R&D team. The move reaffirms Schneider Electric's commitment to East Asia and Japan as key markets, with chairman and CEO Jean-Pascal Tricoire stating it signifies "growth opportunities" in the region.

site_title: Asia: Markets see more losses as Easter break approaches
summary: Asian markets continue their downward trend as the Easter break approaches, with Hong Kong and Shanghai experiencing losses of 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively. The tech sector is also under pressure, with big-name stocks like Facebook, Tesla, and Google parent Alphabet declining due to fears of regulatory clampdowns. Despite some gains in Singapore, the overall sentiment remains uncertain, with analysts predicting further volatility and a possible global trade war.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 1.93 points to 1,859.80. Volume reached 107.96 million lots worth RM32.69 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 129 to 70.

site_title: Cryptocurrency boom breathes life into Alpine village
summary: A Swiss village, Gondo, on the Italian border, is experiencing a resurgence in population and economy thanks to the arrival of cryptocurrency mining companies. The village, which had seen a decline in population and businesses after a devastating landslide in 2000, is now home to companies like Alpine Mining, which has brought in young workers and invested in high-tech mining facilities. The mining operations have brought in revenue and helped to revitalize the village, with plans for further expansion and investment in the area.

images.alt_text: Tucked away in a windowless bunker in Gondo, 900 graphic cards bombinate incessantly as they "mine" virtual currencies.

site_title: Chinese food-to-flights app Meituan-Dianping offers half-baked IPO
summary: Meituan-Dianping, a Chinese food-to-flights app, is preparing for a potential Hong Kong IPO but faces challenges, including not being consistently profitable and operating in multiple sectors. The company has grown rapidly, with revenue more than doubling to $5.4 billion last year, but its food-delivery business was loss-making as of February. Meituan-Dianping is moving into ride-hailing, and the market is expected to be volatile, with potential clashes between management and investors. The company has tapped banks to work on an IPO, which could happen as early as this year, but staying private until it has a clearer edge over competitors may be a more straightforward market debut.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' CEO, senior management take voluntary 10-15% pay cut
summary: Sembcorp Industries' CEO Neil McGregor and senior management have voluntarily taken a 10-15% pay cut, while non-executive directors have also reduced their fees by 15%. The move aims to "underscore their support of the company through challenging times." The company has also outlined plans to lift performance, sharpen capital allocation, and explore divestments to deliver estimated cash proceeds of up to S$0.5 billion.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement's Robert Maxwell dies from cancer, aged 56
summary: Robert Maxwell, 56, managing director of Bernhard Schulte Shipmanagement Singapore, has died after a three-year battle with cancer. Maxwell began his career at sea in 1988 and rose to managing director in 2014, growing the business significantly. He was known for his passion for shipping and professional development, and was awarded an Honorary Fellowship from the Institute of Marine Engineering, Science and Technology in January this year. Maxwell's death marks a significant loss for the maritime industry, with the company praising his leadership and dedication to his work.

site_title: British PM marks one-year Brexit countdown with UK tour
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May embarked on a one-day national tour to mark the one-year countdown to Brexit, visiting Scotland, England, Northern Ireland, and Wales. The tour aims to rally support ahead of the UK's EU departure on March 29, 2019. May met with various groups, including farmers and business owners, to hear their perspectives on Brexit. Despite tensions between the devolved governments and London over Brexit negotiations, May vowed to increase decision-making powers for Scotland and Wales. The UK's future Irish border remains a contentious issue, with May agreeing to keep Northern Ireland in the customs union.

site_title: Women face uphill wage battle in British finance sector
summary: The British finance sector has confirmed a significant wage gap between men and women, with men earning 18.4% more per hour than women nationwide. Banks such as Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking Group, and Barclays have pay gaps ranging from 33% to 59%, with Goldman Sachs having the widest gap at 55.5%. The industry's lack of diversity in top positions is a major contributor to the pay disparity, with women needing to perform harder and better than men to achieve similar roles.

site_title: Boeing possibly hit by 'WannaCry' malware attack
summary: Boeing reportedly suffered a cyberattack that some executives believe may be linked to the WannaCry malware, which affected thousands of computer systems worldwide last year. The attack, described as "metastasizing" and potentially spreading to production systems and airline software, prompted an internal memo calling for a company-wide response. Boeing played down the incident, stating it was limited in scope and did not affect production lines. The company declined to confirm whether the attack was indeed WannaCry, which was attributed to North Korea last year.

site_title: Record stock streak enriches casino tycoon by US$12b
summary: Macau's top casino operator, Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd, has recorded a record 7-quarter winning streak, jumping 200% and enriching its owner, Lui Che-Woo, to US$12 billion. Analysts are bullish, with 24 "buy" ratings and a 12% target price gain. This marks a significant recovery from the wealth loss suffered by Lui during China's corruption probes under President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Facebook cuts ties to data brokers in blow to targeted ads
summary: Facebook has ended partnerships with several large data brokers, including Acxiom and Experian, in an effort to improve user privacy following a scandal over the handling of 50 million users' personal information. The move comes as the company adjusts its privacy settings, giving users more control over their data, and faces pressure from lawmakers to regulate its practices. The change will impact advertisers who rely on third-party data services to target users, but Facebook will still allow them to use alternative methods to measure ad performance.

site_title: Singapore bank lending inches up in February
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.05% in February, reversing January's dip, with loans totaling S$650.93 billion. Business loans grew 0.03% to S$387.4 billion, while building and construction loans rose 0.7% to S$121.05 billion. Consumer lending increased 0.07% to S$263.53 billion, and housing and bridging loans grew 0.1% to S$201.33 billion. This marks a 3.7% year-over-year increase in bank lending, following a steady growth trend since August last year.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Anbang was seized by China. Now, it has a deal for you
summary: Anbang Insurance Group, seized by China in March 2018, is again offering small investors "guaranteed" returns on investment products, despite its history of using funds for risky deals. The products, sold in bank branches, carry conservative-sounding names but are likely high-risk investments. This move comes as authorities try to address financial troubles, and Anbang faces big debts from past investments, including the purchase of the Waldorf Astoria hotel. The products are sold as a way to "make your money back, guaranteed," but critics warn of a "you snooze, you lose" investment opportunity.

site_title: SembMarine sees uptick in customer enquiries but competition still intense
summary: SembCorp Marine sees an uptick in customer enquiries, particularly in the offshore production sector, but competition remains strong and margins are depressed. The company attributes the improvement to higher oil and energy consumption in Asia and a recent oil price increase. However, a cyclical nature of the business and oversupply in most drilling segments may slow down the recovery of rig orders. The company remains engaged with Sete Brasil to better understand its restructuring plan, and has initiated arbitration proceedings against the company. Recovery is expected to take time.

site_title: Kajima hopes to double S'pore revenue contribution
summary: Japan-listed Kajima Corporation aims to double its revenue contribution from Singapore within three years, driven by construction and engineering contracts. The company, which currently generates about 10% of its overseas revenue from Singapore, plans to partner with Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) on more joint development projects, including mixed-use developments. Kajima has a strong presence in Singapore, with about 20 ongoing development projects and a long history of business in the city-state.

site_title: US judge rules 9/11 suits against Saudi Arabia can proceed
summary: A US federal judge ruled that lawsuits against Saudi Arabia alleging it helped orchestrate the 9/11 attacks can proceed. Judge George Daniels rejected Saudi Arabia's bid to drop the suits, citing that the plaintiffs "narrowly articulate a reasonable basis" to proceed. The lawsuits claim Saudi Arabia provided support to Al-Qaeda and Osama bin Laden, with 15 of the 19 9/11 perpetrators being Saudis. The US ally has consistently denied involvement.

site_title: Australia job vacancies climb to fresh record in Feb quarter
summary: Australia's job vacancies reached a record high of 220,900 in the December-February quarter, a 4.3% increase from the previous quarter. This marks a seventh consecutive quarter of solid gains, indicating continued growth in hiring. Vacancies in the private sector rose 4.2% to 201,500, a record high, and are 20.7% higher than a year earlier. Analysts view the vacancies series as a reliable leading indicator of labor demand, supporting further strength in employment growth.

site_title: China does not want a trade war with the US: China commerce ministry
summary: China's commerce ministry stated that the country does not want a trade war with the US, but will not accept unilateral negotiations. China will conduct trade-related investigations fairly and according to local and WTO rules. The ministry's spokesman, Gao Feng, emphasized that China is open to negotiations, but not if they are hijacked. China will not rule out options related to US trade issues, instead focusing on opening the door to further trade solutions.

images.alt_text: China does not want a trade war with the United States, but it won't accept any negotiations if they are hijacked unilaterally, China's commerce ministry said on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.4% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,396.57. The market saw 112 million shares traded worth S$401 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 95 to 34. Despite global equity volatility and a tech selloff on Wall Street, investors remained positive, driving the STI up. Other regional markets, such as Japan's Topix index, also saw gains. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day for Singapore stocks ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Keppel ringfenced graft penalty from dividends for FY17, says chairman
summary: Keppel Corp has ring-fenced financial penalties from a global resolution with US, Brazilian, and Singapore authorities, excluding them from dividend payouts for FY17. The company proposed a final dividend of 14 Singapore cents per share, totaling 22 cents for the year, excluding the penalties. Chairman Lee Boon Yang expressed regret over corruption investigations in Brazil and stated Keppel will rebuild trust by upholding high ethical standards and ensuring compliance.

site_title: Japan retail sales rise in Feb, suggest growing consumer confidence
summary: Japan's retail sales rose 1.6% annually in February, exceeding expectations, driven by increased spending on food, drinks, and clothes. Rising wages and a tight labor market support consumer confidence. Consumer prices may rise, potentially aiding the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. However, the ultra-easy monetary policy remains in place.

images.alt_text: Japan's retail sales rose in February as shoppers spent more on food, drinks and clothes, suggesting rising wages and a tight labour market are supporting consumer confidence.

site_title: Alliance Mineral secures A$13m loan facility to fund development of Bald Hill mine
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited secured up to A$13 million in debt funding from a consortium led by Tribeca to develop the Bald Hill lithium and tantalum mine. The loan has a two-year tenure, with the option to draw down up to A$8 million initially and up to A$13 million thereafter. The lenders will have mortgage security over Alliance's interest in the Bald Hill joint venture agreement and related tenements. The loan will be used to fund mine development and is expected to support the company's growth plans.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Far East H-Trust: Koh Boon Hwee stepping down as non-executive chairman on June 30
summary: Veteran businessman Koh Boon Hwee is stepping down as non-executive chairman of Far East Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) on June 30. He is succeeded by deputy chairman Wee Kheng Jin, who has been serving alongside Koh for the past six years. Koh, a distinguished corporate leader, has been instrumental in leading the trust since its listing in 2012. Non-executive director Chng Kiong Huat will also retire, while Vivienne Lim will be appointed as an independent director, bringing new perspective and diversity to the boards.

site_title: Singapore says it's beating Hong Kong in Asian business hub race
summary: Singapore has taken the lead as a hub for Asian business operations, surpassing Hong Kong, due to Hong Kong's increasing focus on servicing the Chinese economy. With over 37,400 international companies operating in Singapore, the city state is attracting multinational corporations and innovation-led investments. Singapore's government is focusing on raising research and development expenditure to 3% of GDP, offering incentives such as tax deductions for R&D projects, to maintain its competitiveness.

site_title: Jason Holdings gets nod to report FY2017 results by July 31, hold AGM by August
summary: Jason Holdings, a timber flooring services provider, has received a waiver from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) to extend its fiscal 2017 results announcement to July 31 and its annual general meeting (AGM) to August. The company was granted a five-month extension due to being "practically insolvent" and facing restructuring efforts. The firm's auditors expect to complete the audit for fiscal 2017 by end-March, with the AGM likely to take place by August 31.

site_title: GM Korea to ask GM to roll over debt, cut interest rate: source
summary: General Motors' South Korean unit plans to ask its US headquarters to roll over a debt of 988 billion won (S$1.2 billion) due in April, and cut interest rates on loans to the operation. The move comes after GM warned it would run out of cash in the first quarter, and after announcing plans to shut down one of its factories in South Korea. The company's South Korean unit owes GM approximately $2.7 billion, with an interest rate of about 5% a year. A bankruptcy filing is possible if a rescue plan is not agreed upon by April 20.

site_title: US court rules Trump illegal payments suit can proceed
summary: A US federal court in Maryland ruled that a lawsuit accusing President Donald Trump of receiving illegal foreign payments via his business empire can proceed. The lawsuit alleges that Trump's business operations, including the Trump International Hotel in Washington, DC, violate the US Constitution's ban on presidents enriching themselves while in office. However, the court limited the lawsuit's scope to the nation's capital. The attorneys general for Maryland and Washington hailed the judge's ruling, calling it a "first round victory" and stating that the case moves forward.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen plunges
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.91% due to exporters' rise following the yen's plunge amid receding North Korean nuclear crisis worries.

site_title: Chill out on China, says Australia watchdog to foreign buyers
summary: Australia's foreign investment watchdog, the Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB), has advised the government to relax its stance on Chinese foreign buyers, citing China's growing economic influence and Australia's need for capital for economic development. FIRB chief David Irvine stated that having a major economic partner like China is a "fact of life" and that Australia will adapt to its growing presence. The move comes as tensions between Australia and China rise over trade, investment, and influence in the Asia-Pacific region, but Irvine believes a strong economic partnership with China is possible.

site_title: Oil falls about 1% after surprise US crude build
summary: Oil prices fell about 1% on Wednesday after US crude inventories unexpectedly rose 1.6 million barrels, weighing on market sentiment. US crude stockpiles rose as net imports soared by 1.1 million barrels per day, and production reached a fresh record high at 10.433 million bpd. Despite Saudi Arabia's plans to extend oil curbs with Russia, prices fell due to rising US production and lower drilling costs.

site_title: Keppel Corp now strives for sustainable urbanisation
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore conglomerate, has shifted its focus from traditional offshore drilling rigs to sustainable urbanization through its new platform, Keppel Urban Solutions. Group CEO Loh Chin Hua stated that the company is merging diverse expertise to develop smart cities of the future. Despite a slowdown in rig orders, Keppel O&M has secured contracts for non-drilling segments and is leveraging its research capabilities to develop "rigs of the future." The company has also strengthened regulatory measures following a global resolution on corruption in 2015.

site_title: Troubled CEFC China Energy to put property portfolio up for sale
summary: CEFC China Energy, a conglomerate under government scrutiny, plans to sell its global property portfolio valued at over $4.2 billion. The portfolio includes 100 properties in China and overseas, including a Shanghai headquarters, Hong Kong Convention Centre, and a condominium in Manhattan. This sale follows similar moves by other Chinese companies, such as HNA Group and Anbang Insurance Group, amid a crackdown on outbound deals and excessive debt. The sale is expected to help the company repay debts and address concerns over its financial stability.

site_title: G7 nations agree on a 'common vision' for AI
summary: G7 nations agree on a "common vision" for the development of artificial intelligence, prioritizing human-centered AI and safeguarding privacy rights. The shared vision aims to bring significant benefits to societies and economies while minimizing risks. This agreement follows concerns over data misuse, particularly highlighted by the recent Facebook data scandal. The G7 nations also plan to host an AI roundtable in the fall, bringing together states, companies, and researchers to discuss the industry's development and potential consequences.

site_title: Cluster housing is hot again
summary: Cluster housing sales surged 168% from 2014 to 2017, outpacing land-titled houses with a 141% increase. The number of caveats lodged for landed homes rose 145% to 2,369 in 2017. Prices recovered to 2015 levels, with strata landed houses at S$805 psf and land-titled houses at S$1,290 psf. The positive recovery is attributed to improved market sentiments after a four-year slump.

site_title: Exotic distant galaxy lacking dark matter puzzles scientists
summary: Scientists have detected a galaxy, NGC1052-DF2, devoid of dark matter, challenging long-held assumptions about galaxy formation. Located 65 million light years away, this ultra-diffuse galaxy has 400 million stars, significantly fewer than the Milky Way. The discovery contradicts dark matter doubters' hypotheses, potentially confirming its existence. The galaxy's sparse population and lack of gas suggest a cataclysmic event or massive nearby galaxy interference. The finding forces scientists to rethink galaxy formation and the role of dark matter, which comprises a quarter of the universe's mass and energy.

images.alt_text: Astronomers have detected for the first time a galaxy that is devoid of dark matter, the plentiful but enigmatic material that does not emit light or energy and had been considered a fundamental part of all galaxies including our own Milky Way.

site_title: Orthopaedic group plans to raise S$10m in Catalist IPO
summary: Singapore-based Orthopaedic Centre plans to raise S$10 million through an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board, under the new name Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS). The group, comprising four orthopaedic specialists with four clinics, lodged a draft prospectus for the listing. The IPO aims to raise funds for the group's future growth and expansion.

site_title: US economy grew at a faster pace in fourth quarter of 2017
summary: The US economy grew at a faster pace in the fourth quarter of 2017, with a revised GDP growth rate of 2.9%, exceeding analyst expectations. Consumer spending reached a three-year high, driven by increased spending on goods and transportation. Business investment also rose, and the tax cuts imposed in December are expected to boost growth in the near term. However, economists warn that the tax cuts will drive the budget deficit and add to the US sovereign debt, and growth remains below President Trump's target of three percent annual growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets reported that its substantial shareholder, Burwill Holdings, plans to acquire approximately HK$30 million (S$5 million) of the company's shares, related to a corporate exercise. This announcement was made on March 26.

site_title: Two Koreas to hold high-level talks
summary: Top officials from North Korea and South Korea will meet in the Demilitarized Zone on March 29 to prepare for a summit between Kim Jong Un and Moon Jae-in. The meeting comes after a year of heightened tensions over North Korea's nuclear and missile programs, and follows Kim's surprise trip to China. A landmark nuclear summit with US President Donald Trump is also expected, potentially as early as May. The meeting is seen as a rapid rapprochement between the two Koreas, with China playing a key role in securing Beijing's backing and support.

images.alt_text: Top officials from Pyongyang and Seoul will meet in the Demilitarized Zone Thursday to prepare for a summit between Kim Jong Un and Moon Jae-in, days after the North Korean leader made his international debut with a surprise trip to China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Hyflux, IEV Holdings, Libra Group, China Kangda
summary: Keppel Corporation, Hyflux, IEV Holdings, Libra Group, and China Kangda Food Company are stocks to watch due to new developments. Keppel's chairman announced a proposed final dividend of 14 cents per share, excluding financial penalties from a global resolution. Hyflux reached a settlement agreement with a Chinese entity, withdrawing arbitration proceedings. IEV Holdings' auditors flagged material uncertainty over the business, citing a net operating cash outflow. Libra Group completed an acquisition of a 51% stake in a Malaysian business. China Kangda Food Company swung into the red due to higher mortality rates and a significant decline in fair value of biological assets.

site_title: Asian markets bleed on fresh trade fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index falling 1.64% to 3,382.78 points. US trade fears reignited, with S&P Global Ratings raising the risk level of trade interruption and geopolitical tensions to "high". The Singapore Post, Singtel, and Genting Singapore were among the lead weights, while Y Ventures Group and Lian Beng Group also saw gains. The Nikkei 225, Kospi, and Shanghai also fell, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng hitting a three-week low.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Europe: Defensives in the driving seat as shares shake off tech tremors
summary: Defensive stocks in Europe drove regional benchmarks higher on Wednesday, despite losses in the technology sector amid concerns over a regulatory crackdown. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5%, with consumer staples and healthcare stocks leading the gain. Tech stocks fell 1.8%, with European tech stocks hitting a near seven-week low. The decline was attributed to concerns over a regulatory crackdown and stretched valuation metrics.

images.alt_text: A recovery among cyclical sectors and a raft of M&A news helped boost European shares further on Thursday, shaking off a tech-led sell-off which had spread across global markets earlier in the week.

site_title: US: Wall Street sinks on deepening tech woes
summary: Wall Street declined on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq sinking amid tech woes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat, while the S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 2,605.00. The Nasdaq has tumbled in three of the last four trading days, resulting in declines of 2% and 4% since Thursday. This marks the third consecutive session of losses for the tech-heavy index.

site_title: Blockchain: One string to rule them all?
summary: Blockchain technology has the potential to revolutionize various industries, including finance and healthcare, by providing a secure and transparent way of storing and verifying data. Gartner estimates that blockchains will create at least one business worth $10 billion by 2022. Singapore is at the forefront of blockchain adoption, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore partnering with R3 and financial institutions to launch Project Ubin, a digital cash-on-ledger project. Blockchains offer a solution to the problem of trust, as any change to a block can affect all connected records, making them nearly incorruptible. However, the success of blockchain platforms depends on their ability to deliver high throughput, low latency, and a frictionless user experience, requiring organizations to treat blockchain adoption like any other IT project.

site_title: Stella McCartney to take full control of her fashion brand
summary: Stella McCartney is set to buy back the 50% stake in her eponymous fashion brand from French luxury group Kering, ending a 17-year partnership. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, establishes McCartney as a rare independent luxury label in a consolidating market. McCartney, 46, founded the brand in 2001 as a joint venture with Kering, positioning it as a socially conscious luxury brand with sustainable fashion values. The move marks a significant milestone in McCartney's career, solidifying her control over her fashion brand.

site_title: For London prime housing buyers, a penny saved is a penny earned
summary: London's prime housing market may be bottoming out after three years of price falls, according to the Savills prime London index. Values in central locations decreased 0.9% in the final quarter of 2017, with annual price falls totaling 4%. The consultancy expects prime central London to bounce back by the end of 2022, with a 20.3% increase, while outer prime London markets are expected to experience small falls and 10.2% five-year growth.

site_title: Malaysia's economy to get boost from exports, consumption
summary: Malaysia's central bank forecasts an expansion of 5.5-6% in 2018, up from the government's earlier estimate of 5-5.5%. The growth is attributed to improving global demand, private consumption, and an export boom, despite potential risks from monetary tightening in advanced nations and trade protectionism. The central bank also expects Malaysia's gross exports to climb 8.4% this year, driven by favorable demand from major trading partners and sustained commodity prices.

site_title: Facebook tweaks privacy tools to ease discontent over data leak
summary: Facebook has made changes to its privacy settings to give users more control over their information, following an outcry over a whistleblower's allegations that data was used to sway the 2016 US election. The updates, announced on Wednesday, put all settings on one page and made it easier to change and stop apps from using data. However, analysts say the changes are minor and don't address the operational issues that led to the data leak. The company's shares rose 1.2% despite ongoing regulatory scrutiny and Congressional hearings.

site_title: At Art Basel HK, local galleries struggle to get in on the action
summary: Art Basel Hong Kong has shifted the art world's center of gravity toward Asia, with local galleries competing for sales and exposure. The fair's VIP preview saw the sale of Willem de Kooning's "Untitled XII" for $35 million to a private collector, marking one of the highest-priced works in the fair's history. However, mid-tier and emerging galleries in Asia face significant costs, with booth rental and staffing fees ranging from $100,000. Some dealers view the fair as a necessary marketing cost, rather than a profit-making opportunity, and are re-evaluating their approach to international art fairs.

site_title: Enhanced grants, HDB Resale Portal to boost resale transactions in 2018
summary: Singapore's HDB resale market is expected to see a 10-15% increase in transactions to around 24,000-25,000 in 2018. The government has introduced enhanced Proximity Housing Grants, increasing the grant amount to S$30,000 for families and S$15,000 for singles, making resale flats more affordable. The new HDB Resale Portal aims to streamline the resale process, cutting waiting time from 16 weeks to 8 weeks. These measures are expected to boost resale transactions, with resale flat prices remaining flat in 2018, with a possible 1% increase.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust to buy 6 Japan office properties
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has entered into conditional agreements to acquire a 98.5% stake in six freehold commercial properties in Greater Tokyo, Japan, for 60.9 billion yen (S$753 million). The portfolio, valued at 63.3 billion yen, represents a 1.05% discount from independent valuations. The acquisition is expected to contribute a 4.8% net property income yield and be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive, enhancing MGCCT's geographical and tenant diversification.

site_title: S'pore luxury homes still in demand among foreigners
summary: Singapore luxury homes continue to attract foreign buyers, with a 23.5% share of non-Singaporean buyers in 2017, despite a 15% additional buyer's stamp duty. The luxury segment, defined as units priced above S$2,500 psf, has seen a pick-up in volumes and prices since 2016 and Q4 2017, respectively. The market is expected to remain buoyant, with a 5-6% upside anticipated for the luxe apartment and condominium segment for the rest of 2018, driven by limited supply and high demand.

site_title: Facebook's problem - and ours
summary: A self-driving Uber car struck and killed a woman in Tempe, Arizona, highlighting the second inning of technological advancements, which have both enriched and harmed society. The author notes that the first inning was marked by promise and discovery, but the second inning has seen the misuse of technologies like Facebook and self-driving cars, leading to concerns over privacy, trust, and social divisions. Experts like Dov Seidman emphasize the need for values and leadership to guide the use of these technologies and prevent harm, as the boundaries between business and society are becoming increasingly blurred.

site_title: Amazon targets French grocery market with Monoprix deal
summary: Amazon has partnered with French retailer Casino's Monoprix chain to sell groceries via Amazon Prime Now, marking the first time a local retailer has partnered with the e-commerce giant in France. The deal, limited to the Paris market, is expected to shake up the competitive local food retail market and could pave the way for future partnerships. Financial terms were not disclosed, with Monoprix reportedly benefiting from a profitable model where it picks orders in-store and Amazon handles delivery.

site_title: SembMarine unit bags FPSO contract from TechnipFMC
summary: SembCorp Marine's unit has secured a contract from TechnipFMC to build an FPSO vessel for Energean's Karish and Tanin deepwater field developments in the Eastern Mediterranean. The 227-meter long vessel will have a 800,000 barrel oil storage capacity and 8 billion cubic meters gas production capacity. Scheduled for completion in 2020, the contract is expected to contribute 15% to SembCorp Marine's full-year contracts value, with an estimated value above $300 million. The deal is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year 2018.

site_title: Return of foreign buyers to S'pore property scene
summary: Foreign buyers are returning to Singapore's property market, with mainland Chinese buyers still accounting for the largest proportion of purchases by foreigners in 2017. The number of home sales rose by 44.8% and 28.6% for non-permanent residents and Singaporean permanent residents, respectively. The profile of mainland Chinese buyers has changed, with more becoming SPRs, and they are purchasing higher-priced properties. Other foreign buyers, including those from Hong Kong, the UK, the US, and Australia, are also entering the market. The government's initiatives and Singapore's stable economic environment are expected to attract more foreign talent and demand for properties.

images.alt_text: Launch of The Clement Canopy, a 505-unit condominium project in Clementi.
Potential buyers at the launch of Grandeur Park Residences near Tanah Merah MRT station.

site_title: Mismatch in price expectations breaks sales
summary: In 2018, the en bloc sales market in Singapore is expected to experience a trend of more protracted or failed collective sales due to a mismatch in pricing expectations between sellers and buyers. Despite a strong pipeline of sites, the sales process has become protracted, with sellers exploring follow-up options. The residential market has been recovering since mid-2017, and with a positive medium-term outlook, developers are likely to continue restocking their land inventory. The launch pipeline remains a concern, with only a year-plus of supply, but the sales momentum witnessed in 2017 is expected to be sustained.

images.alt_text: Brookvale Park, a 160-unit development in Sunset Way, was sold to Hoi Hup Sunway for S$530 million.

site_title: Noble gains more support from creditors for its restructuring plan
summary: NOBLE Group Ltd. has secured support from 55% of its senior creditors for its US$3.4 billion restructuring plan, up from 46% on March 14. The plan requires approval by 75% of existing senior creditors representing 75% of its debt. Noble warned of insolvency proceedings if the deal is not approved, and has not made an interest payment on its unsecured credit facility. The company has been negotiating a debt-for-equity swap since selling billions of dollars of assets due to a severe commodities downturn and reporting significant losses.

site_title: Singapore can shine in a post-Brexit world
summary: Singapore is poised to shine in a post-Brexit world, as the city-state's financial and insurance sectors are expected to grow despite uncertainty in global markets. The looming Brexit threat presents opportunities for Singapore to expand its insurance and financial sectors, particularly in Asia. Singapore is already the largest hub for Lloyd's outside of London and is a key reinsurance gateway to Asia Pacific. The country's favorable regulatory environment and growing insurance industry make it an attractive location for insurers and brokers, with potential benefits including increased business and growth opportunities.

site_title: Proptech - the emerging disruption in real estate
summary: Proptech, an emerging disruption in the real estate industry, utilizes blockchain, augmented reality (AR), and artificial intelligence (AI) to transform property transactions and management. Blockchain facilitates secure and transparent transactions, while AR enables visualization and customization of properties. AI extracts insights from data to determine property valuations and predict trends. Despite the potential of proptech, human judgment, touch, and ability to react to dynamic changes remain crucial in the decision-making process. The Singapore government has introduced an Industry Transformation Map to leverage technology and streamline processes for property transactions and facilities management.

site_title: Air China profit misses analyst expectations, shares slump
summary: Air China reported an annual profit of 7.24 billion yuan, missing analyst expectations due to higher-than-expected operating costs. The airline's shares fell 7.4% in Hong Kong and 5% in Shanghai, marking its worst day since February. Fuel costs jumped 29.2% and operating expenses rose 15%, contributing to the profit shortfall. Despite a 5.2% increase in passenger numbers, passenger yield fell 0.45%. The company attributed the results to excess capacity on certain routes and raised ticket prices.

site_title: HSR to generate multiplier effects on local economies
summary: The Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) is expected to create multiplier effects on local economies in Malaysia and Singapore. For cities along the HSR corridor, socio-economic links, investments, and political and institutional factors are crucial for regional economic development. The KL-SG HSR corridor contributed 54% to Malaysia's 2016 GDP and accounted for 46% of total employment, driven by retail, tourism, manufacturing, finance, and construction sectors. To maximize benefits, smaller cities on the corridor should develop unique value propositions through economic development initiatives, similar to cities in Taiwan's HSR corridors.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of High Speed Rail terminal in Jurong East.

site_title: SPH, Kajima break ground on landmark Bidadari project
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Japanese developer Kajima Development have broken ground on a 680-condo, 28,000 sq m mixed-use project in Bidadari, Singapore. The development will be connected to an air-conditioned bus interchange and features a police post, community club, and 6,000 sq m Community Club. The project is expected to be completed in the second half of 2022, with actual launch details and unit numbers yet to be decided.

site_title: US-China trade spat shouldn't rock Asian markets: Maybank economist
summary: Maybank economist Chua Hak Bin believes a US-China trade war won't significantly impact Asian markets if it remains bilateral. Despite concerns about inflation, he notes that deflationary forces, such as technology-driven deflation and demographic changes, will keep inflation in check. Chua also expects trade tensions to be resolved through a compromise between the US and China, with China signaling a measured response to US tariffs. He doesn't foresee a large impact on the global economy, citing strong synchronous global growth that will support Asian currencies and equity markets.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield interviewing advisers for IPO
summary: Cushman & Wakefield, a century-old real estate brokerage, is interviewing advisers to potentially take the company public as early as this year. The TPG-backed firm has been expanding under CEO Brett White and has seen its closest peers climb 57% and 76% in value since Bloomberg first reported talks of an IPO. A two-year hiatus in US IPOs for real estate services firms ended in 2017, with six companies listing to raise $2.5 billion. The decision to list this year is influenced by market conditions and the company's performance.

site_title: Diverging outlooks for Japan's office and retail real estate
summary: Japan's office and retail real estate markets are expected to diverge in 2018. The economy is in good health, driven by exports and corporate capital expenditure, but real wages remain stagnant, affecting consumer spending. Office demand remains solid, but vacancy rates in Tokyo are forecast to rise by 3 percentage points by the end of 2019, leading to a 8% drop in Grade A rents. In contrast, retail sales are recovering due to a growing e-commerce sector, and luxury retailer demand may pick up, leading to rents bottoming out.

site_title: Househunt March 2018
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Key real estate news includes a discussion on Good Class Bungalow prices in Singapore, with prices remaining high. In the US, mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines. A wave of condo launches in Singapore's prime projects above S$3,000 psf is expected to test demand. Manhattan rents reached a record, with further increases predicted. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset in Seoul, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy.

site_title: SGX lowers entry for dual class share listing, safeguards up
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has lowered the entry threshold for dual-class share (DCS) listings to $300 million, from an earlier proposed $500 million. Companies seeking to list under the DCS structure must meet SGX's main board entry criteria and demonstrate the need for the structure to succeed. Proposed safeguards include limiting multiple vote shares to 10 votes and requiring MV shareholders to cease holding the shares if they cease being directors or sell/transfer them. The consultation period is open until April 27, with SGX planning to adopt the DCS structure shortly after June.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Entering a brave new world
summary: The Singapore residential property market has reversed its four-year decline, with prices appreciating 1% in 2017, following a 3.1% decline in 2016. The market is shifting towards a "brave new world" with the integration of technology, including blockchain, augmented reality, and artificial intelligence. The government has also launched an Industry Transformation Map to streamline processes and the office space is becoming more accommodating of co-working operators. Meanwhile, global e-commerce giants are taking up physical space, disrupting the retail scene. Developers and professionals must adapt to these changes to stay ahead.

site_title: Brexit and the City: the real estate agent's view
summary: London's commercial property market remains uncertain due to Brexit, but recent data suggests a mixed outcome. A Brexit tracker shows no evidence of a mass exodus of jobs or business, and commercial property prices in the City of London reached a 2016 high in the third quarter of 2017. Investors are seeking clarity on Britain's future status, and deals are taking longer to sign. Experts warn of potential risks, but also note that occupational confidence is a longer-term concern, and some investors are holding out for better Brexit terms.

site_title: Half the forecast number of finance jobs to exit Britain post-Brexit
summary: Around 5,000 finance jobs in Britain are expected to move out or be created overseas by March 2019 due to Brexit, half the number forecast six months ago, according to a Reuters survey of firms employing the bulk of workers in international finance. 76 companies said they would have to move staff or restructure their businesses, while 29 said Brexit would have no impact.

site_title: BMW sued in US over diesel emissions
summary: BMW has been sued in the US over "defeat devices" installed in tens of thousands of vehicles to cheat diesel emissions tests. The case, filed in New Jersey, targets BMW X5 and 335D model diesel cars sold between 2009 and 2013, with emissions up to 27 times higher than allowed. The lawsuit claims BMW misled customers and failed to disclose the "defeat devices" and their manipulative software. The attorneys are seeking reimbursement for their clients and this case will become a class-action suit once certified by a judge.

site_title: Anbang's ex-chairman contests charges as trial begins
summary: The former chairman of Anbang Insurance Group Co Ltd, Wu Xiaohui, contested all charges in a high-profile trial in Shanghai, accused of fundraising fraud and embezzlement. Prosecutors alleged Wu concealed control, faked financial statements, and oversold 724 billion yuan in insurance products. Wu claimed he did not understand the law and did not know if his actions constituted a crime. The trial began a month after the government seized control of Anbang, owner of the Waldorf Astoria hotel, due to suspected economic crimes.

site_title: Shareholders give thumbs up to Ezion debt plan
