summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, won a majority vote of over 99% from its shareholders in support of a landmark debt refinancing plan. The plan, which seeks to deleverage from debt to equity, will see significant dilution of existing equity and issuance of new shares. Shareholders will hold 35% of the enlarged equity, while existing shareholders will retain 56%. The plan aims to reduce the group's debt by swapping debt to equity and pushing out most principal repayments for bank loans. Despite the plan's approval, Ezion still faces an arduous journey to recovery, with cash burn from non-productive assets to be addressed through divestments and strategic investments.

site_title: Two prominent women named to URA board
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore appointed five new members, including Judy Hsu and Angelene Chan, with effect from April 1, 2018. Chairman Peter Ho will be reappointed, along with seven other members, while five members are stepping down. The new board members include industry experts and executives from prominent companies. The appointments will be for a three-year term until March 31, 2021, and will bring the total number of URA board members to 13.

site_title: Coal clearout puts Rio Tinto on path to greener deals
summary: Rio Tinto has raised $4.2 billion by exiting coal, with the company selling its majority stake in the Kestrel Mine to Adaro Energy and private equity firm EMR Capital for $2.3 billion. This move follows Rio's previous exit from steelmaking coal and leaves the company without coal, a bonus for environmentally-minded investors. The sale is expected to provide more cash for shareholders and help lift Rio's shares, now trading at 6 times forward EBITDA, compared to major peers BHP and Glencore.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund, Saudis to create world's biggest solar power firm
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund and Saudi Arabia are partnering to create the world's largest solar power project, expected to produce up to 200 GW by 2030. The project, valued at $200 billion, will help reduce Saudi Arabia's reliance on oil for power generation and increase its overseas oil shipments. The investment is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 reform plan, which aims to reduce the country's economic dependence on oil. The project's initial phase will cost $5 billion, with SoftBank's Vision Fund investing $1 billion.

site_title: US lost leverage against China when it pulled out of TPP
summary: The US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has lost leverage against China, allowing Beijing to pursue mercantilist policies with fewer checks. The Trump administration's imposition of tariffs on $60 billion worth of Chinese imports may not force China to change its behavior, potentially leading to a trade war that could devastate the global economy. A more effective approach would be for the US to work with other trading partners to pressure China to comply with WTO agreements, and to coordinate a multilateral strategy to address Chinese trade violations.

site_title: New condos can cost up to 13% more than existing neighbours
summary: Singapore's condominium market is expected to experience growth due to developers injecting liquidity into the housing market through land acquisitions. The bullish land prices paid by developers in the past 18 months have led to a rise in prices and sales, with new projects launching at 7-13% higher than comparable condominiums. The mass market condominium segment is expected to see a 30% increase in sales to 8,000 units, driven by improved buyer sentiment and rising demand.

images.alt_text: Amber Park, a 200-unit freehold condominium in East Coast. It is estimated that prices of new condominiums to be launched in 2018 and 2019 could potentially be 7 per cent to 13 per cent higher.

site_title: What ails US-Vietnam trade relationship
summary: The US-Vietnam trade relationship is being held back by several sticking points, including a $32 billion trade deficit and a dispute over Vietnamese catfish exports. The US has designated Vietnam as a "Non Market Economy" (NME), leading to higher customs duties on Vietnamese exports, while Vietnam wants to be recognized as a market economy to gain full normal trading relations. The US is also pressuring Vietnam to address its trade deficit and to deregulate its economy. Talks on a bilateral investment treaty have stalled, and the issue of Vietnamese catfish exports could become a major point of contention.

site_title: Q4 GDP growth revised up to 2.9% from 2.5%
summary: US economic growth slowed less than estimated in the fourth quarter, expanding at a 2.9% annual rate, up from the previously reported 2.5%. The biggest gain in consumer spending in three years partially offset the drag from a surge in imports, which grew at a 14.1% pace. This revision also reflected less inventory reduction than previously reported. Despite this, economists still expect the economy to hit the Trump administration's 3% annual growth target this year, driven by tax cuts and increased government spending.

site_title: mm2-SPH JV to engage in digital editorial, video content creation
summary: Singapore-based entertainment company mm2 Asia has entered into a joint venture with Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to create a lifestyle, entertainment, and news portal under the AsiaOne brand. The venture will hold 51% equity interest, with SPH holding 49%, and will engage in digital editorial and video content creation. This move follows mm2's recent acquisition of Cathay's cineplexes subsidiary and its analyst-favored market valuation. The joint venture will have a paid-up capital of S$1 million.

site_title: Local banks need to match S'pore's green push
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have been scrutinized for financing coal projects in the region, with a study claiming they have provided US$2.29 billion in loans since 2012. The banks argue that coal helps local communities gain access to electricity, but environmental advocacy group Market Forces counters that renewable energy is cheaper and no longer needed for coal. To address this, the banks must set clear limits on coal financing and prioritize renewable projects, and Singapore's financial sector is expected to play a critical role in spearheading innovation in sustainable finance.

site_title: China's largest banks feel wind in their sails as profits rebound
summary: China's largest banks reported their best profit growth in three years, driven by regulatory clampdowns on shadow financing and high leverage, which reduced competition for state-backed lenders. Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) led the recovery, with a 4.1% increase in net profit, followed by China Construction Bank and Agricultural Bank of China. Analysts predict that the large banks, with their strong macroeconomic environment and improving loan quality, will continue to thrive as the market interest rates rise.

site_title: Co-working goes from fad to fixture
summary: Co-working spaces have become a staple in modern workplaces, shifting from traditional offices to flexible, chic spaces. A 2018 survey by Colliers International found 91% of top 200 Asia occupiers were considering flexible workspace. The sector's growth is driven by startup culture and the government's push for innovation and enterprise. Major markets, including Singapore, have seen significant expansion from local and mainland Chinese operators, with WeWork also entering the market, following a bankruptcy. The demand for flexible workspace is expected to continue, with up to 30% of the overall market in some regions attributed to co-working.

site_title: Sasseur Reit debuts on SGX mainboard at S$0.805
summary: Sasseur Reit, a China outlet mall operator, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$0.805 per unit, above its IPO price of S$0.80. The trust raised S$396 million in gross proceeds, making it the largest IPO in Singapore this year. Sasseur Reit is the first outlet mall Reit to be listed in Asia, with a forecast distribution yield of 7.5% for 2018 and 7.8% for 2019. The trust's IPO attracted over 3.7 times the available units, with DBS Bank purchasing 543,900 units as part of a stabilising action.

site_title: China's expansion stayed strong in Q1, but outlook cloudy: survey
summary: China's economy remained strong in Q1, with hiring near a record high, but two key growth engines, property and commodities, are showing signs of cooling, according to a private survey by China Beige Book International. Revenue looked strong, but profit growth weakened across most sectors, while investment and cash flow softened. This cloudy outlook raises concerns for policymakers, who may face challenges in sustaining growth. The survey covered thousands of Chinese firms and provided a snapshot of the country's economic health.

site_title: Fair housing groups file lawsuit against Facebook
summary: Fair housing groups in the US have filed a lawsuit against Facebook, alleging the social network discriminates against certain groups, including women, disabled veterans, and single mothers, in its advertising targeting system. The lawsuit claims Facebook allows advertisers to exclude certain demographics, while including others, resulting in discriminatory ads. This comes as Facebook faces an international crisis over data misuse affecting 50 million users. The lawsuit seeks to hold Facebook accountable for its alleged discriminatory practices.

site_title: Indonesian panel approves Warjiyo to be central bank chief
summary: Indonesia's parliamentary commission has endorsed Perry Warjiyo to be central bank governor, paving the way for his likely appointment by the full legislature next week. Warjiyo, a Bank Indonesia deputy governor, was deemed "appropriate" for the role by commission chairman Melchias Markus Mekeng, who also urged him to maintain currency stability. Warjiyo emphasized that the central bank can support economic growth and financial stability simultaneously, contradicting the past practice of prioritizing stability over growth. His appointment, if approved, would succeed Agus Martowardojo's five-year term in May.

images.alt_text: Mr Warjiyo has said that the central bank can support both economic growth and financial stability at the same time.

site_title: Why aren't US bond investors panicking?
summary: US bond investors remain calm despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, with 10-year bond rates falling to levels below February's peak and 30-year rates below 2017's peak. The recent market turbulence, triggered by US President Donald Trump's trade war with China, has not led to panic among investors. Economists warn of inflationary pressure due to tax cuts and government borrowing, but financial markets do not share this concern, suggesting a false alarm in the global economic expansion. The message from the US government bond market has become increasingly reassuring.

site_title: SIA upscales regional cabin products with US$350m investment
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) is investing US$350 million in new cabin products for its 20 Boeing 787-10 aircraft, aiming to strengthen its premium positioning in the market. This follows a US$850 million facelift of its 19 A380 aircraft and new seat concepts for its 777-9 aircraft, including a refreshed first class. The upgrades are part of SIA's efforts to enhance its regional premium offerings and compete in an increasingly competitive market.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is investing US$350 million in new cabin products for its 20 Boeing 787-10 aircraft as it seeks to strengthen its premium positioning in an intensely competitive market.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Industrial property market thawing
summary: The Singapore industrial property market appears to be thawing, with prices potentially recovering as early as the second half of 2018. After a 5.7% year-on-year decline in 2017, the rate of decline in industrial property prices has slowed down, with the price index slipping 0.6% quarter-on-quarter in Q4 2017. The vacancy rate of factory space has stabilized at 11.1% in the last nine months, and new drivers of industrial space demand, such as improved manufacturing output and growing technology adoption, are expected to support future growth.

site_title: H&M has a problem: US$4.3b of unsold clothes
summary: H&M reported a US$4.3 billion pile of unsold clothes, a significant problem for the Swedish fashion retailer. The issue began emerging last year, when it reported a drop in sales, and has continued with a 7% increase in unsold stock in the past year. Analysts have criticized poor inventory management and underwhelming product offerings, leading to a decline in operating profit and a drop in shares. The company is struggling to adapt to the changing global apparel market, where online shopping and changing consumer demands are driving the industry.

site_title: A considered approach to dual class share listings
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is finalizing its listing rules for dual-class share (DCS) structures, a move aimed at supporting the growth of enterprises while protecting minority shareholders. The proposed rules include safeguards against expropriation and entrenchment, such as requiring management shareholders to declare all concert parties holding one-vote shares. SGX will also impose stringent eligibility criteria and a "one share-one vote" structure as the default, with DCS structures being the exception. The regulator aims to balance the needs of companies with DCS structures, ensuring they are easily identifiable on trading screens and providing investors with a clear understanding of the structure.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Sterling buffeted by Brexit headlines and retail data
summary: The euro reached a six-week high against the Swiss franc due to investors' growing optimism about global markets in the second quarter. The European Central Bank (ECB) hinted at potentially ending its stimulus scheme before the end of 2018, but no decision was made. The euro was also boosted by carry trades, with investors betting on higher-yielding currencies like the Australian dollar. Sterling was affected by mixed Brexit news, with optimism about a potential Irish border solution offset by disappointing retail sales data.

site_title: Singapore prime office rents up 3% in Q1; demand to stay strong: JLL
summary: Singapore's prime office rents rose 3% in Q1, with average rents for Grade A space reaching S$9.51 per sq ft. Leasing momentum remained strong, with over 60% of available space pre-committed. The Marina Bay sub-market saw a 3.3% increase, while the remaining sub-markets posted rent growth between 2.7% and 3%. The market is expected to stay robust in 2018, driven by companies upgrading their premises, but leasing activity may shift towards smaller occupiers or those with longer lease commencement dates.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Living with online retail this Weekend
summary: Brick-and-mortar retailers have adapted to online competition by redefining the physical shopping experience. This is explored in Weekend magazine's edition, which also features articles on hair loss solutions, design concepts, and healthy eating. Additionally, articles highlight various businesses, such as Thevar 2.0 and The Social Kitchen, that are driving innovation in the food industry. The magazine also discusses topics like corporate purpose, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Office, retail recovery may boost shophouse segment
summary: Singapore's shophouse market is expected to benefit from the recovery of the office and retail sectors in 2018, driven by demand from high net worth individuals and family offices. Shophouses, typically narrow, long terraced houses, offer an attractive and exclusive feel for small-to-medium businesses. With a median price of S$3,301 psf in 2017, shophouses have shown capital appreciation potential and value stability, with some units selling for up to 47% more than their purchase price. The market is expected to attract significant foreign interest, with the shophouse market remaining unencumbered by cooling measures.

images.alt_text: The conservation shophouse market has seen several high-priced transactions in the past six months and is expected to continue attracting buying interest given limited supply and interest in this asset class by foreign buyers as well as property funds.

site_title: DBS chief Piyush Gupta collected S$10.3 million salary in 2017
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta reported a 23% increase in his 2017 salary to S$10.3 million, as the bank posted a new high of S$11.9 billion in income and a record S$4.39 billion net profit. Gupta attributed the improvement to a return on equity (ROE) of 9.7% and plans to reach 13%, citing factors such as higher interest rates, reduced capital requirements, and lower costs from digitalisation. The bank also announced a special dividend and raised its annual payout.

site_title: Changi Airports International's Russia, Brazil airports clinch top accolades
summary: Changi Airports International's (CAI) airports in Russia and Brazil have received top accolades. CAI's Russian airports won four awards, including Sochi International Airport's best airport by size and region in Europe, while Anapa International Airport won the best regional airport for the fourth consecutive year. Tom Jobim International Airport in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, was named the best airport for operational efficiency and most punctual airport in Latin America. These wins reflect CAI's commitment to improving airport services and infrastructure to meet growing demands in the global aviation industry.

site_title: IEV auditors flag 'material uncertainty' concerns
summary: IEV Holdings, an offshore engineering services provider, has faced "material uncertainty" concerns raised by its independent auditors, Deloitte & Touche. The company reported a net operating cash outflow of RM11.1 million in the 2017 financial year and had current liabilities exceeding current assets by RM6.3 million. Despite projected net cash inflow for 2018, auditors noted that the company may have insufficient cash to fulfill obligations if it fails to secure ongoing projects. This raises significant doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern.

site_title: Reputational fears push more firms to ban crypto ads
summary: Internet companies are banning cryptocurrency advertising due to reputational fears of duping or leaving users penniless. Twitter, Google, and Facebook have already cracked down, with other companies like LinkedIn, Snapchat, and Baidu following suit. Regulators struggle to regulate the industry, and traditional advertising routes are not under threat. Despite a slump in virtual currency prices, companies are taking matters into their own hands to protect their reputation. Analysts expect online platforms to loosen blanket bans once authorities provide guidance on regulating virtual currencies and the Blockchain technology underpinning them.

site_title: Hyflux reaches settlement in claims over project works done by Shanghai unit
summary: Hyflux Ltd reached a global settlement agreement with a Chinese entity over non-water industrial project works, withdrawing arbitration proceedings. The settlement resolves claims related to works carried out by Hyflux's Shanghai unit. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. With the settlement, the Chinese claimant has agreed to drop its claims, bringing an end to the dispute.

site_title: Technology, co-working led leasing demand in 2017
summary: The office market in Singapore ended 2017 with a strong note, with island-wide net absorption reaching 783,621 sq ft in Q4 2017, totaling 2.1 million sq ft for the year. This was driven by technology and co-working leasing, supporting an earlier-than-expected recovery in office rentals. However, the sustainability of this demand remains uncertain, and further analysis is needed to understand the quality and quality of demand.

site_title: Supply of executive condos needs to be increased to meet red-hot demand
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market faces a shortage of unsold units, with fewer than 200 launched but unsold EC units available. The demand for ECs is expected to increase significantly due to rising private property prices, making ECs an attractive option for middle-income buyers. With only one EC project set to launch in April, the upcoming Rivercove Residences EC is expected to be well-subscribed. To address the shortage, authorities should consider increasing the supply of EC sites to ensure affordable lifestyle living options for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of Parc Life, a 628-unit executive condo at Sembawang Crescent. ECs allow buyers to own a product that is similar in terms of amenities and lifestyle to those of private condos.

site_title: Chinese soyabean supplier United Food expects loss for FY17
summary: Chinese soybean supplier United Food Holdings expects a loss for the fourth quarter and full FY17, citing a significantly lower loss compared to the previous year. The company posted a net loss of 229 million yuan in 2016, narrowing from 974 million yuan in 2015. Despite this, the current loss is expected to be lower, providing a glimmer of hope for the company's financial performance.

site_title: Tesla says cause of Model X crash not yet known as pressures mount
summary: Tesla stated that the cause of a Model X crash in California, which killed the driver, remains unknown as authorities work to retrieve the vehicle's logs. The company did not disclose whether Autopilot was engaged at the time of the crash. Tesla is under increasing pressure following the incident, which adds to the scrutiny of CEO Elon Musk's company. The investigation is ongoing, and Tesla will provide updates as more information becomes available.

site_title: Recruiters pounce on Uber employees
summary: Tech giants Google and Facebook have offered job opportunities to former Uber employees in Southeast Asia, following Grab's acquisition of Uber's business. The offers, which include roles in digital fields and support functions, come as Grab struggles to integrate the 500-plus former Uber employees. Recruiters predict that Grab may face layoffs, especially in shared services, and that the jobs offered may not align with the staff's expectations. The "war for talent" is underway, with companies competing for the attention of skilled workers, particularly in digital roles such as software developers and data analysts.

site_title: Turner unveils streaming sports service in challenge to ESPN
summary: Turner Broadcasting has announced the launch of Bleacher Report Live, a standalone streaming sports service set to challenge ESPN. The service, available online, will offer flexible pricing options and access to live games, including the UEFA Champions League, NBA, and collegiate basketball. It will be the first to allow fans to purchase and watch live NBA games in progress at a reduced price. The move aims to win over younger audiences and "cord cutters" as ESPN prepares to launch its own streaming network, which will be available for $4.99 per month.

site_title: Trump urges pressure against North Korea after Kim's China trip
summary: US President Donald Trump urged continued pressure against North Korea after Chinese President Xi Jinping confirmed that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed openness to disarmament talks during a surprise visit to Beijing. Trump tweeted that Kim might "do what is right for his people and for humanity" and give up nuclear weapons, while maintaining maximum sanctions. The visit marks a significant shift in the diplomatic landscape ahead of a potential Trump-Kim summit. China's support for Kim's efforts and its willingness to engage in talks with the North Korean leader may lead to a more collaborative approach to resolving the issue of denuclearization.

site_title: SMEs more upbeat about business prospects in Q2, Q3
summary: Singapore SMEs are feeling more optimistic about their business prospects, with the SBF-DP Info SME Index rising to 51.8 in Q2 and Q3 2018, indicating strong sales and profit expectations. All industries have scores above 50, with Business Services being the most optimistic. SMEs expect their turnover to rise and profitability to improve, with scores of 5.38 and 5.28 respectively, the highest since 2015. Access to financing has also improved, with a score of 5.26. However, experts caution that global trade tensions could affect growth.

images.alt_text: Optimism seems to be on the rise for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with expectations of strong sales and profit performance in the next two quarters.

site_title: Broccolini Construction to build tallest residential tower in Montreal
summary: Broccolini Construction Inc plans to invest C$300 million to build the tallest residential tower in Montreal, a 56-story mixed-use building with 400 condominium units. The tower will replace their 50-story mixed-use building, L/Avenue, and is part of the trend of developers adapting to the market by incorporating retail, condos, and offices. The tech sector's growth has driven tenant demand for office space in Montreal, making it the country's third-hottest commercial market.

site_title: Clicks and bricks paving way for future of retail
summary: Singapore's retail scene is evolving as structural shifts in consumer demand and competition accelerate. Retailers are integrating physical and online realms, with 78.2% of respondents indicating plans to open more outlets locally and overseas in 2018. The average annual occupancy for island-wide retail slipped to 92.2% in 2017, but island-wide prime retail rents remained relatively firm. Retailers are focusing on the 'human touch' aspect of physical stores, with 69% of consumers valuing value for money, good customer service, and quality products. Seamless online-offline relationships are key to the future of Singapore retail, with 20% of respondents marketing products on established e-commerce platforms.

images.alt_text: An employee scanning a handbag's bar code at the Reebonz headquarters. The local online luxury product retailer has been setting up pop-up stores in malls and subsequently set up a showroom within its eight-storey building in Tampines in March 2017.

Local fashion retailer Love, Bonito (above) set up its first physical store right in the heart of the Singapore's shopping belt, Orchard Road. Clearly, the value proposition of having physical shops remains a key consideration for local retailers in their business strategy.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit by tech sell-off
summary: European stocks fell 1.1% in early trading due to a tech sell-off, with tech stocks leading sectoral decline. Concerns over regulatory crackdowns and negative headlines from companies like Facebook and Tesla contributed to the sell-off. Chipmakers ams, STMicro, and Infineon were among the biggest decliners, while banks Commerzbank, UBS, and Credit Suisse also fell. The decline was attributed to stretched valuation metrics and underlying misalignment with fundamentals.

site_title: Slow and powerful: Mystery train from N Korea
summary: A mysterious train carrying 21 cars, painted drab green and with tinted windows, was spotted in Beijing's central train station on March 26, 2018. The train was later confirmed to be carrying North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, who arrived for secret talks with Chinese counterpart. The train's design and features suggest it is a bulletproof private transport, a preference of North Korean leaders. The exact nature of the talks is not publicly disclosed.

site_title: Around 5,000 finance jobs to move out of Britain or created overseas by March 2019 post-Brexit: poll
summary: Around 5,000 finance jobs in the UK are expected to be moved or created overseas by March 2019 due to Brexit, down from a previously forecast 10,000 jobs. A Reuters survey of 119 firms found that 76 companies would have to restructure or move staff, while 29 expect no impact. The number of jobs to be moved or created overseas is expected to be 4,798, with 173 roles to be created by insurers and 304 jobs to be created by asset managers.

site_title: Launch of Nasa's new flagship space telescope is delayed - again
summary: NASA has postponed the launch of the James Webb Space Telescope to May 2020, its fifth delay since 2013, due to issues with the telescope's components, including the sun shield and heat shield. The delay may increase costs beyond the $8 billion funding cap, requiring reapproval by Congress. The telescope's development has been plagued by technical issues, with engineers working 24/7 to fix problems. The delay will impact not only the JWST but also other NASA missions, including the Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope.

site_title: First Van Gogh in 20 years to go under hammer in Paris
summary: A Van Gogh painting, "Women Mending Nets in the Dunes", is set to be auctioned in Paris in June for approximately €5 million. The painting, created early in the artist's career, is the first Van Gogh piece to be sold in France in over 20 years. The art market's boom and increasing prices for artists like Van Gogh make it difficult to predict when bidding will stop, with experts expecting a high price due to its rarity and historical significance.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Two Singaporean stocks are upgraded: Capitaland Retail China Trust to "buy" with a fair value of S$1.66, and Sembcorp Marine to "buy" with a target price of S$2.90. ComfortDelGro is downgraded to "reduce" due to the potential loss of Uber's South-east Asia business to Grab, which could harm the taxi company's earnings. Analysts expect retail sales growth in China to remain healthy, supporting the upgrades. The moves come as Singapore stocks notch a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with some analysts warning of potential sector recovery.

site_title: Investors in Vietnam learn to live with anti-graft crackdown, some embrace it
summary: Foreign investors in Vietnam are becoming more optimistic about the country's business climate despite a crackdown on corruption. The anti-graft campaign, led by General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, has slowed dealmaking, but foreign direct investments reached record highs in 2017, totaling $17.5 billion. The campaign has also shed light on deep-seated graft within state-owned enterprises, leading to the prosecution and imprisonment of over 100 people. While some business risk analysts see the crackdown as a "good signal" to investors, others note that the business environment remains challenging, with inconsistencies and unfair practices persisting.

site_title: 172kg pageant queen manages to bring attention to rare disorder
summary: Anna Hankins, a 172kg pageant queen from Mississippi, competed in the state level of the Miss Amazing competition, a pageant for girls and women with disabilities. Despite her physical appearance, Hankins managed to bring attention to her rare disorder, hypertrichosis, which causes excessive hair growth. Her participation in the pageant showcased her confidence and self-acceptance, inspiring others to do the same. Hankins' story highlights the importance of inclusivity and body positivity, encouraging people to look beyond physical appearance and celebrate individuality.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens lower as tech stocks, Amazon drag
summary: The Nasdaq Composite index opened lower on Wednesday due to losses in tech stocks, particularly Apple, Intel, and Amazon, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average rose due to gains in financial and healthcare stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 44.85 points, while the S&P 500 lost 0.93 points.

site_title: BH Global unit partners Singapore startup Horangi to boost cybersecurity offerings
summary: BH Global's unit Athena Dynamics partners with Singapore-based cybersecurity startup Horangi Cyber Security to boost its cybersecurity offerings. The strategic partnership aims to enhance certified Vulnerability Assessment and Penetration Testing services. Horangi's cybersecurity products will expand Athena Dynamics' client solutions, addressing emerging cyber threats. The tie-up is described as "highly strategic" by Horangi's CEO, fulfilling an imminent need to address fast-emerging cyber threats.

site_title: China's economic growth stayed strong in Q1
summary: China's economic growth remained strong in Q1, with hiring near a record high, despite a slowdown in key sectors like property and commodities. A private survey showed profit growth weakened across most sectors except manufacturing, while investment and cash flow softened. The outlook for 2018 remains cloudy, with the property sector cooling and the retail sector struggling. Economists expect China's growth to slow to 6.5% this year, with policymakers facing pressure to address these challenges.

site_title: Ezion shareholders vote in favour of debt refinancing plan
summary: Ezion Holdings shareholders voted 99.22% in favour of a debt refinancing plan that swaps debt for equity, diluting existing equity holders. Holders of S$575 million in securities will hold 35% of the enlarged equity if they exercise options, while existing shareholders will retain 56%. The plan also involves issuing new shares and options to settle fees and an incoming investor. This move aims to deleverage the company and reduce its debt burden.

site_title: Libra completes S$12m purchase of tourism business, geared at diversification shift
summary: Libra Group has completed a S$12 million acquisition of a 51% stake in YC Capital Consolidated, a Malaysia-based tourism and retail business, marking a new asset-light growth diversification strategy. The company acquired the business from its CEO, Chu Sau Ben, in an all-share transaction. Libra will recognize nine months of revenue and profit from YC Capital for fiscal 2018, with net profit expected to increase. This move is seen as a shift towards diversification and growth.

site_title: Saudi Arabia and SoftBank plan world's largest solar project
summary: Saudi Arabia and SoftBank Group Corp signed a US$200 billion solar power development, the world's largest project, to diversify the economy and reduce dependence on oil. The 200-gigawatt project, planned for the Saudi desert, would triple the country's electricity generation capacity and create up to 100,000 jobs. SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son envisions the project will shave US$40 billion off power costs and reach its maximum capacity by 2030. The deal deepens SoftBank's ties with Saudi Arabia, advancing Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman's ambition to diversify the economy.

site_title: China Kangda swings into the red for FY17 as its chickens die at a faster rate
summary: China Kangda Food Company reported a net loss of 12.8 million yuan for FY17, compared to a net profit of 7.55 million yuan in FY16. The company attributed the loss to a higher mortality rate of its chickens due to bad weather and increased administrative costs. Revenue rose 5.8% to 1.34 billion yuan, while the fair value gain from biological assets fell to 1.61 million yuan from 37.8 million yuan in FY16. The company has invested in breeding "free rearing" rabbits to meet market demand.

site_title: Second Chance posts flat net profit for Q2; revenue falls 11%
summary: Second Chance Properties posted a flat net profit of S$1.96 million for its Q2, with revenue falling 11% to S$6.81 million. Pre-tax income decreased 10% to S$2.07 million, while the company reduced its income tax expense. The results reflect a weaker performance, but the company's management is expected to review its strategies to boost revenue and improve profitability.

site_title: YuuZoo says it has 'in principle' agreement with auditor to resolve S$8m query
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has reached an "in principle" agreement with its auditor RT LLP to assess the validity of an S$8 million income query, resolving a regulatory issue. The Singapore Exchange had suspended trading of YuuZoo's shares after missing a disclosure deadline tied to the query. The company provided updated evidence to the auditor, addressing queried numbers related to an available-for-sale balance and revenue from network development and franchise sales. The agreement aims to resolve the issue, but details of the terms remain undisclosed.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive along with Wall Street
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.50% on Wednesday, mirroring a decline on Wall Street, as the tech sector took a hit. The Hang Seng Index fell to 30,022.53, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The market's downward spiral follows a similar trend seen last week.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed safeguards for dual class share listings on its main board, entering the final consultation stage. Singapore Airlines is spending US$350m on new seats for its 787-10 aircraft, while Alliance Mineral Assets discussed potential funding with Burwill. Meanwhile, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: US Q4 GDP growth revised up to 2.9%
summary: US economic growth in Q4 2017 revised up to 2.9% from 2.5%, driven by a 4.0% increase in consumer spending, the largest in three years. Imports grew at a 14.1% pace, offsetting some of the drag from a surge in imports. The upward revision also reflected less inventory reduction than initially reported. Despite signs of economic slowdown, analysts still expect the economy to hit the 3% annual growth target this year, driven by tax cuts and increased government spending.

site_title: Oxley sells Irish block for 164m euros on 300-year lease
summary: Oxley Holdings has sold a 300-year lease of No 1 Dublin Landings for 164.20 million euros (S$266.87 million) to Sol Estate Propco IE Dublin Landings SARL. Oxley will take 77.53% of the sale price, with a 16.5 million euro deposit paid upfront. The balance will be paid after completion, scheduled for April 2018. The sale was negotiated based on market conditions and surrounding property prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.58 points to 1,857.87. Volume reached 2.082 billion lots worth RM1.818 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 651 to 251.

site_title: DBS' Piyush Gupta enjoys pay jump of 23% to S$10.3m for 2017
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta's 2017 pay jumped 23% to S$10.3 million, the highest since 2015. This follows a 23% drop in 2016 due to lower profits. In 2017, DBS posted a new high of S$11.9 billion in income and a record S$4.39 billion in net profit. Gupta's 2017 pay is the highest among DBS executives, with Gupta's best year so far being 2015 when he took home S$10.9 million.

site_title: JPMorgan looks beyond finance to hire tech, maths grads in Asia
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is diversifying its workforce in Asia by hiring more engineering, neuroscience, and psychology graduates, with 39% of its 2018 class having non-finance backgrounds. The bank aims to adapt to the region's fast-changing economies, where technology and finance converge. This move is part of a broader trend, with other banks also seeking non-finance talent to stay ahead of clients. JPMorgan's hiring efforts are expected to increase diversity and improve problem-solving capabilities in the region.

site_title: Fairhaven at Sophia Road sold for S$57m to Lafe Corp
summary: PROPERTY developer Lafe Corporation has acquired the Fairhaven development on Sophia Road in District 9 for S$57 million. The 15-unit, freehold development has a total site area of around 16,660 sq ft and is zoned for residential use. The acquisition was made after a competitive tender process, considering current market prices and redevelopment potential. Lafe Corp stated that the acquisition will not contribute to any profit or loss and will be funded by internal resources, bank borrowings, or equity fund raising.

site_title: The Orthopaedic Centre plans Catalist IPO as Asian Healthcare Specialists
summary: The Orthopaedic Centre, a Singapore-based orthopaedic specialist group, plans an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist board under the name Asian Healthcare Specialists (AHS). The IPO is expected to raise over S$10 million, with a market capitalization of around S$65 million. The group made a net profit of S$438,000 in the 12 months ended Sept 30, 2017, and plans to use the IPO proceeds to expand the business organically and through mergers and acquisitions. The IPO is managed by RHT Capital and sponsored by UOB Kay Hian.

site_title: Nordea hit by record mortgage client defections in Sweden
summary: Nordea Bank AB has experienced record mortgage client defections in Sweden for five consecutive months, with its Swedish mortgage book contracting 0.9% since September. The trend marks an unprecedented development among Sweden's four biggest banks, with Nordea losing market share despite cutting prices on some loans. The customer exodus coincides with rapid market growth, with smaller online competitors offering cheaper mortgages. Despite recent price reductions, Nordea's portfolio expansion of 0.5% shows it's still losing market share to rivals such as Lansforsakringar Bank and state-owned SBAB.

site_title: Malaysia's economy to get boost from exports, consumption in 2018
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to grow at a 5.5-6% pace in 2018, driven by improving global demand, private consumption, and an export boom. The central bank raised interest rates for the first time in over three years, signaling confidence in the economy. However, risks to exports are identified, including unfavourable shifts in monetary policy and rising trade protectionism. The bank forecasts a 8.4% growth in gross exports and lower headline inflation averaging 2-3%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide on Wall Street fall; won flat
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 1.34% to 2,419.29, weighed down by losses in US stock markets, with Samsung Electronics dropping 2.6%. The won remained flat, and bond yields fell. The currency's movement was influenced by North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's visit to China, signaling easing tensions. Foreigners sold 254 million won worth of shares, while the US dollar rose 0.35% against the won this year.

site_title: Housing ads allow bias, Facebook is told in suit
summary: Fair housing groups filed a lawsuit against Facebook, alleging the platform continues to discriminate against certain groups, including women, disabled veterans, and single mothers, in housing ads. The National Fair Housing Alliance claims Facebook's advertising platform enables landlords and real estate brokers to exclude these groups from receiving rental and sales ads. The lawsuit seeks a plan to remove the ability to exclude groups from housing-related ads and implement community education and outreach to housing providers. Facebook denies the lawsuit is without merit and vows to defend itself vigorously.

site_title: SGX proposes safeguards for dual class share listings on main board
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed detailed rules and safeguards for dual class share (DCS) listings on its main board, paving the way for the structure to be adopted. The proposed safeguards include enhanced voting processes, limiting the number of votes held by multiple vote shares, and an event-based sunset clause requiring these shares to be converted to one-vote shares. The SGX plans to adopt the DCS structure shortly after June, with a lower market capitalization threshold of S$300 million, and all DCS companies will be clearly identified on trading screens.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US apartment vacancy rate up slightly in first quarter: Reis
summary: The US apartment vacancy rate rose to 4.7% in the first quarter, a slight increase from 4.6% in the previous quarter, according to Reis Inc. The national average asking rents edged 0.9% higher and effective rent grew 0.8% for the quarter. Despite a 12,054 unit decline in net absorption, many metros are expected to see higher completions in 2018, with a projected increase in vacancy of no more than 2.5% in any market.

site_title: Anbang chairman accused of 65.2b yuan fraud as trial begins
summary: Wu Xiaohui, former chairman of Anbang Insurance Group, has been accused of masterminding a 65.2 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion) fraud in a Shanghai court. The charges, which date back to 2007, involve unauthorized sales of investment-type policies to prop up the company's capital. Wu allegedly used the funds for personal use, debt repayment, and investment, and could face over 10 years or lifetime imprisonment if convicted. This is China's largest fundraising fraud case, surpassing US$115 billion in excess sales.

images.alt_text: A Shanghai court accused former Anbang Insurance Group Co Chairman Wu Xiaohui of masterminding a 65.2 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion) fraud, using unauthorised sales of investment-type policies to prop up the acquisitive company's capital.

site_title: Customers more satisfied with finance & insurance, healthcare sectors last year
summary: A nationwide survey found customers were more satisfied with the finance and insurance industry and healthcare sector in 2017, driving the overall national score to a new high of 72.9 points. The finance and insurance industry scored 73.4 points, with banking customers who used digital channels showing higher satisfaction and loyalty. The healthcare sector saw improvements in customer satisfaction, particularly in areas such as ease of getting around and waiting experience. In contrast, customers who interacted with contact centers in the life and health insurance sectors reported lower satisfaction scores.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 1.3%
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.34% or 286.01 points to close at 20,031.31, amid Wall Street falls and receding fears of a trade war. High-tech and auto shares led the decline, despite receding investor concerns. The broader Topix index fell 1.02% or 17.57 points to 1,699.56.

site_title: Malaysian bid to redraw electoral boundaries sparks anger
summary: Hundreds of Malaysians protested against a government bid to redraw electoral boundaries, citing allegations of "scandalous" attempt to steal the election. The move, proposed by Prime Minister Najib Razak, aims to reflect demographic changes but critics claim it's a ploy to favor his ruling coalition. The opposition, led by Wan Azizah Wan Ismail, accuses the plan of gerrymandering and vote rigging. The bill is expected to pass with the ruling coalition's majority, despite allegations of corruption surrounding Najib's government.

site_title: China's Fosun aims to invest 20b yuan in technology over 3 years
summary: Fosun International, a Chinese conglomerate, aims to invest at least 20 billion yuan (S$4.2 billion) in technology over the next three years, focusing on biotech, fintech, and AI. The investment is part of its goal to reach 100 billion yuan in technology investments over the next 10 years. The company's billionaire chairman, Guo Guangchang, emphasized the importance of technology in a company's future, citing Fosun's record-high annual profit. The conglomerate is diversifying its investments, increasing focus on India, Africa, and Portuguese-speaking countries.

site_title: Singapore prime office rents rose 3% in Q1, could hit last high in next 12 months: JLL
summary: Singapore's prime office rents rose 3% in Q1, driven by leasing activity and a strong recovery from a 12.7% decline in 2017. Average rents for Grade A office space in the Central Business District reached S$9.51 per sq ft, with Marina Bay maintaining a competitive edge. The market is expected to remain robust, with leasing demand driven by companies upgrading their premises and co-working operators. Grade A office rents could potentially reach their last high of S$10.56 per sq ft within the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: China's largest banks feel wind in their sails as profits rebound
summary: China's largest banks, including Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, China Construction Bank Corp, and Agricultural Bank of China, reported their best profit growth in three years due to improved net interest margins and reduced exposure to shadow financing. The regulatory crackdown on smaller lenders has driven the recovery, with core banking emerging as the winner. Analysts expect the large banks to continue to benefit from rising market interest rates and improving asset quality, with ICBC chairman Yi Huiman predicting asset quality will continue to improve.

site_title: Thai parties call for junta to finally unshackle politics
summary: Thai political parties have called on the junta to lift curbs on campaigning and set a clear poll date, amid growing discontent with the military's four-year rule. The Election Commission has proposed ground rules for the vote, but parties demand permission to campaign freely and guarantees of transparency. Analysts warn that the junta-scripted constitution will limit the next civilian government's powers and potentially pave the way for a non-elected premier. The junta has postponed election dates repeatedly, fueling demands for an election.

site_title: US, South Korea to revise trade pact with currency side-deal, autos concessions
summary: The US and South Korea agreed to revise their six-year-old trade pact with a side deal to deter currency devaluation by Seoul, with concessions for US autos and pharmaceutical companies. The deal includes provisions such as a 20-year extension of the US tariff on pickup trucks, increased transparency of South Korean foreign exchange interventions, and cuts in steel exports to the US. South Korea agreed to cut steel exports by 30% and amend a government health program to ensure a level playing field for US pharmaceuticals producers. The agreement does not require congressional approval and is considered a "side letter" that will not be enforceable with trade sanctions.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves 200b baht rail project to link airports
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a 200 billion baht (S$8.39 billion) high-speed railway project linking three airports: Suvarnabhumi International, Don Mueang International, and U-Tapao. The project aims to alleviate strain on infrastructure due to surging tourist arrivals, with the government expecting 37.55 million foreign visitors this year. The rail link is expected to cost 200 billion baht and will be completed in the future.

site_title: Australia's China scholars air divisions over interference laws
summary: Australia-based academics are divided over proposed laws to criminalize foreign political interference, with some citing "unacceptable interference" from China's Communist Party in Australia's society and politics. The academics claim China's actions have the potential to harm Australia's interests and sovereignty. However, China denies the suggestions, stating it has no intention of interfering in Australia's internal affairs. The debate highlights concerns over Chinese influence in Australia, with some universities accused of curtailing China research due to funding ties to Beijing.

site_title: Singapore shares close down 1.64% on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.64% on Wednesday, closing at 3,382.78, due to trade war fears resuming. About 1.59 billion shares changed hands, with losers beating gainers 318 to 115. Casino operator Genting Singapore slid 1.85% to S$1.06, while Y Ventures Group rose 18.69% to S$0.635 after DBS initiated a "buy" call. The decline comes ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Australia follows Wall Street lead and slide; NZ tumbles
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.7% on Wednesday, mirroring a decline in US stocks due to tech sector concerns. The benchmark closed at 5,789.5 points, down 42.8 points from the previous day. This follows a similar decline in US indices, with concerns about social media and autonomous vehicle regulation affecting technology shares.

site_title: Optimism on the rise for Singapore SMEs; turnover, profit expectations at 3-year high
summary: Singapore SMEs report optimism, with the SBF-DP SME Index rising to 51.8, indicating strong sales and profit expectations for Q2 and Q3 2018. All six industries expect increased turnover, with the highest score since 2015, and improved profitability. The industries with the highest optimism include Business Services, Commerce/Trading, and Transport/Storage. CEO Ho Meng Kit notes that recent trade disputes may pose headwinds, but the positive sentiment is reinforced by supportive domestic policies.

site_title: Hong Kong media firm soars 880% on debut amid IPO frenzy
summary: Hong Kong media firm Most Kwai Chung Ltd surged 880% on its debut, reaching a market value of HK$2.2 billion. The company's IPO was oversubscribed 6,289 times, a record in Hong Kong. This is the city's strongest mainboard debut in over two years. The average retail subscription ratio has tripled to 340 times this year, fueled by retail investors flocking to IPOs.

site_title: Sasseur Reit opens trading debut at S$0.805 after largest IPO in Singapore this year
summary: Sasseur Reit, Singapore's largest IPO this year, made its debut on the Singapore bourse at S$0.805 per unit, above its offer price of S$0.80. The trust raised S$396 million in gross proceeds, with 12 cornerstone investors including JD.com contributing S$182.8 million. Sasseur Reit will offer investors exposure to Chinese outlet malls, with a market cap of about S$944 million and a distribution yield of 7.5% between March 1 and end-2018.

site_title: PSA's Tan Chong Meng among 5 new members joining JTC board
summary: JTC Corporation appoints five new board members, including PSA International's Tan Chong Meng as deputy chairman, effective April 1. The new members are Lam Yi Young, Melvyn Ong Su Kiat, Shafie Shamsuddin, and Michael Sim. Three existing members, including Loo Choon Yong, have stepped down. The appointments come as three members are set to complete their term.

site_title: South Korean economy hit speed bump in Q4, central bank sees 3% 2018 growth
summary: South Korea's economy experienced its worst quarterly performance since 2008 in Q4 2017, with a 0.2% decline in GDP, according to revised central bank data. This followed a 1.5% rise in the third quarter and was lower than the initial 3% estimate. Construction investment fell, while private spending and government expenditure increased. Despite this, the Bank of Korea expects the economy to grow 3% this year, driven by domestic demand and moderate exports. Inflation is seen as a necessary condition for future interest rate hikes.

site_title: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust to acquire 6 office properties in Greater Tokyo for 60.9b yen
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) has entered into agreements to acquire a 98.5% stake in six office properties in Greater Tokyo for 60.9 billion yen (S$753.4 million). The portfolio is expected to contribute a 4.8% net property income yield and be distribution per unit accretive. The acquisition is expected to enhance MGCCT's geographical, tenant, and sector diversification. The trust's CEO, Cindy Chow, believes the entry into Japan will provide a wider pool of acquisition opportunities.

images.alt_text: The Japan portfolio comprises three properties in Tokyo; one in Yokohama; and two in Chiba.

site_title: mm2 Asia, SPH to build lifestyle, entertainment and news portal under AsiaOne brand
summary: mm2 Asia and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) are collaborating to build a lifestyle, entertainment, and news portal under the AsiaOne brand. The joint venture will hold a paid-up capital of S$1 million, with mm2 holding 51% equity and SPH holding 49%. This partnership comes after mm2's previous failed attempt to buy a stake in Golden Village cinema business. The venture will engage in digital editorial and video content creation.

site_title: BMW sued in US over diesel emissions
summary: BMW has been sued in the US over "defeat devices" installed in tens of thousands of its diesel cars to cheat emissions tests. The class-action suit targets the BMW X5 and 335D models sold between 2009 and 2013, which allegedly produced emissions 27 times higher than allowed standards. The lawsuit seeks reimbursement for car purchases, following a similar "dieselgate" scandal involving Volkswagen. BMW has confirmed the raids on its headquarters in Munich and Austria, and has admitted the software was present in some vehicles, with plans to recall them for a software update.

site_title: Trial of Anbang's former chairman starts in Shanghai
summary: The trial of Wu Xiaohui, former chairman of Anbang Insurance Group, began in Shanghai on March 28, 2018. Wu is accused of economic crimes amid a government crackdown on big-spending conglomerates and financial risk. Anbang, which made aggressive overseas acquisitions, was seized by the Chinese government a month prior to Wu's prosecution. The trial is part of a broader effort to lower debt and financial risk in the economy, with Wu facing criticism over Anbang's opaque shareholding structure and high-profile deals worth over $30 billion.

site_title: Slippery start for Venezuela's petro crypto coin
summary: Venezuela's government-backed cryptocurrency, the petro, has faced a "slippery start" due to widespread confusion and lack of understanding among the public. Launched earlier this year, the digital coin was made available to the general public last Friday, but its use is limited by the lack of infrastructure and technical knowledge. Despite the government's hopes that the petro can help alleviate the country's financial woes, experts doubt its success due to Venezuela's economic crisis, including high public debt and hyperinflation.

site_title: Judy Hsu, Angelene Chan among five new members joining URA board
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has appointed five new members, including Judy Hsu and Angelene Chan, to join the board effective April 1, 2018. The new members are Bill Chang, Ong Kim Pong, Khairudin Saharom, and Judy Hsu. Chairman Peter Ho will be reappointed, along with seven other members, while five members step down. The five new board members will serve a three-year term until March 31, 2021, bringing the total number of board members to 13.

site_title: Substantial shareholder Burwill plans to acquire HK$30m of shares in Alliance Mineral
summary: Hong Kong-listed Burwill Holdings plans to acquire approximately HK$30 million of Alliance Mineral Assets shares as part of a corporate exercise. The acquisition was made without the company's consultation. Alliance Mineral Assets reported a widening net loss of A$1.36 million in its second quarter, attributed to higher expenses. The company has also recently terminated the services of its CEO and his wife, citing a loss of confidence in their abilities. Further announcements will be made as material updates become available.

images.alt_text: ALLIANCE Mineral Assets on Wednesday said it has been brought to its attention that its substantial shareholder, Hong Kong-listed Burwill Holdings, had made an announcement on March 26 of its intention to acquire about HK$30 million of the company's shares in connection with a corporate exercise of Burwill.

site_title: Planes and armoured trains: the Kims' foreign trips
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un made his inaugural overseas trip using an armoured train, similar to his predecessors, who preferred rail travel for domestic and international trips. This marked a departure from the usual use of commercial flights. The move was seen as a sign of Kim's growing confidence in his leadership.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday following US tech selloff; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.7% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 22.48 points to 3,416.87, following a US tech selloff. The Trump administration's consideration of a crackdown on Chinese investment in sensitive technologies contributed to the decline. Asian stocks declined, with Japan's Topix index down 2.1% and South Korea's Kospi index falling 1%. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 Index also fell, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 1.4%.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks fall sharply; won volatile on currency side deal
summary: South Korean stocks fell over 1% on Wednesday, tracking US market losses, while the won showed high volatility amid a reported currency side deal between Seoul and Washington. The US and South Korea reached a revised trade pact with a side deal aimed at deterring currency devaluation, and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un pledged to denuclearize the Korean peninsula during a meeting in Beijing, boosting the won. The Kospi stock index dropped 1.27%, while bond yields fell, and shares of steelmakers declined amid worries about the revised trade pact.

site_title: China says North Korea pledges denuclearisation during friendly visit
summary: China confirmed that North Korean leader Kim Jong Un pledged to denuclearize the Korean peninsula during a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing, promising to work towards peace and stability. The pledge, made during Kim's first known journey abroad since assuming power in 2011, comes ahead of planned summits with South Korea and the US. China will uphold its friendship with North Korea, and the US remains in close contact with its allies, seeing the development as evidence of its "campaign of maximum pressure" creating an atmosphere for dialogue with North Korea.

site_title: Panda Green Energy issues profit warning, expects 60% fall in full-year earnings
summary: Panda Green Energy Group issued a profit warning, expecting a 60% decline in full-year earnings to RMB153 million, down from RMB383 million last year. The drop is attributed to a RMB290 million fair value loss on financial instruments and a 28% increase in finance costs. The fair value loss was mainly due to a RMB229 million loss on the issue of shares and warrants.

site_title: Changi Airports International's Russia, Brazil airports clinch top accolades
summary: Changi Airports International's (CAI) airports in Russia and Brazil have won top accolades. CAI's Russian airports, including Sochi International Airport and Anapa International Airport, received awards for best airport by size and region, Europe, and best regional airport. Tom Jobim International Airport in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, was named the best airport for operational efficiency and most punctual airport in Latin America. CAI's CEO, Lim Liang Song, praised the company's efforts in improving efficiency and services at its airports, playing a role in meeting the growing demands of global aviation.

site_title: Embracing change and innovation
summary: A Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) program, The Job of the Chief Executive (JOCE), helps leaders drive organizational change and innovation in the face of technological disruption. Founder and CEO of News & Ads Monitoring Agency, Ooi Kiam Hong, credits the program for helping him develop a long-term growth strategy and refine his company's niche. He emphasizes the importance of individual change, hiring the right talent, and embracing digital transformation to stay competitive.

site_title: In call with Trump, Merkel urges EU-US dialogue on trade
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel called for dialogue on trade policy between the European Union and the US, following US President Donald Trump's temporary exclusion of the EU from higher import duties on steel and aluminum. Merkel and Trump also reaffirmed their solidarity with Britain after a nerve gas attack in England. The two leaders discussed the situation in Syria and North Korea, and Merkel welcomed the coordinated action by European states and NATO allies against Russia's behavior. The call marked a renewed attempt at cooperation between the two leaders, who had not spoken in over five months.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 1.89% and the Topix index dropping 1.84%. The decline followed falls on Wall Street, despite receding fears of a trade war. Investors were discouraged from buying actively, instead choosing to wait for further developments.

site_title: Taxi drivers block traffic in Brussels to protest "Uberisation"
summary: Hundreds of taxi drivers in Brussels blocked roads and lit flares to protest plans to make it easier for ride-hailing apps like Uber to operate in the city. They claim Uber is taking their business unfairly and will lose revenue if the proposed license is implemented, which would tie the driver to the vehicle. Uber argues it already complies with local regulations and says the reform is needed to tackle mobility issues. The protesters demand the government drop the plans, with drivers stating they have children to support.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.9 points to 1,857.55. Losers outnumbered gainers 135 to 55, and volume was 52.53 million lots worth RM15.13 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick day off with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading with losses on Wednesday, following two days of gains and a decline on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.91% to 30,510.38, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.14% to 3,130.57. The losses were attributed to a decline in technology firms on Wall Street.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble again as US tech sell-off spreads
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday, following a sell-off on Wall Street, as technology firms suffered sharp losses amid US-China trade tensions. The Dow and S&P 500 plummeted, with tech giants like Facebook, Tesla, and Google parent Alphabet experiencing significant declines. Despite a visit by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to Beijing, investor confidence remains shaken, with analysts warning of a prolonged trade war. Markets in Asia, including Hong Kong, South Korea, and Japan, fell between 1-3% as investors await further developments in US-China relations.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares fall following Wall Steet slump
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Wednesday due to a sharp decline on Wall Street. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 0.6% to 5,799.9, with technology and materials sectors among the worst performers. Investors awaited further developments on international trade tensions and inflation data, contributing to low volumes. Key sectors affected included technology, materials, and financials, with companies like Xero, Altium, and Woodside Petroleum experiencing significant losses.

site_title: Jho Low baulks at US plan to move seized US$250m yacht
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low is resisting the US Justice Department's plan to move his $250 million yacht, M/Y "Equanimity," from Indonesia to the US. Low's lawyers claim the reduced crew of eight would endanger lives and damage the yacht, and that selling it in the US would not decrease its value. The yacht is one of several assets the US is seeking to recover in its forfeiture lawsuit against Low, who is accused of siphoning $4.5 billion from a government fund. The yacht is currently anchored in Bali, where a lawsuit challenging its seizure is ongoing.

site_title: US investigating fatal Tesla crash in California
summary: US federal investigators are examining a fatal Tesla crash in California, where a 38-year-old man died after his 2017 Tesla Model X collided with a highway barrier and caught fire. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating issues including the post-crash fire and steps to make the vehicle safe for removal from the scene. The investigation comes after Tesla's shares fell 8.2% following the news. This is the second fatal Tesla crash in the US in two years, following a 2016 crash in Florida that found no safety-related defect.

images.alt_text: US federal investigators said Tuesday they were examining a fatal crash last week involving a Tesla electric automobile in California.

site_title: Oil drops on equity weakness, surprise API build
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday after stocks slumped and industry data showed a surprise increase in US crude inventories. Brent crude futures settled at $70.11 a barrel, down 1 cent, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures fell 30 cents to $65.25 a barrel. The API reported a 5.3 million-barrel rise in US oil inventories, exceeding expectations. The dollar rebounded, making dollar-denominated commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies, contributing to the price drop.

site_title: ESR-Reit issues 263m new units at S$0.54 apiece in preferential offering to raise S$141.9m
summary: ESR-Reit has issued 262.8 million new units at S$0.54 apiece in a preferential offering, raising up to S$141.9 million. The new units, listed on the Singapore Exchange, will be traded from March 28 and will have the same rights as existing units. The Reit's unit base now stands at 1.58 billion. Existing unitholders will be entitled to distributions from Jan 1 to March 27, and the new units will be listed and quoted on the mainboard of the Singapore Exchange from March 28.

site_title: Developer nets A$69m with Melbourne units
summary: World Class Global (WCG) has handed over a batch of 134 completed residential units in its Melbourne project, Avant, to buyers for A$69 million in net sales proceeds. This represents 97% of the project's total sales, with the remaining 69 units to be handed over in the next few weeks. The successful settlements indicate the strength of Melbourne's property market, according to WCG's CEO. The project's sales are expected to positively contribute to the group's financial performance for the current quarter.

site_title: SIA spending US$350m on new seats for 787-10s
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is investing US$350 million in new cabin products for 20 Boeing 787-10s, including a revamped business class for regional routes. The 787-10s will feature a new premium seat with direct aisle access, offering a 1-2-1 layout. The first of the 787s arrived at Changi Airport, with Minister for Transport Khaw Boon Wan attending the arrival ceremony. The new seats will be deployed on medium-haul flights up to an eight-hour radius.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oracle's big-money case against Google gets new life
summary: An appeals court revived Oracle's case against Google, ruling that the Java software code used in Android is protected by copyright law. The court overturned a 2014 decision that sent the case back for a new trial, which ended with a jury deciding Google did not unfairly use Java code. Oracle seeks $9 billion in damages, while Google argues that extending copyright protection to code would threaten innovation. The decision could have "devastating effects" on the tech industry, with public interest groups warning of higher prices, fewer choices, and worse products for consumers.

site_title: SPH and Kajima break ground on 680-unit The Woodleigh Residences at landmark Bidadari project
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Japanese developer Kajima Development have broken ground on The Woodleigh Residences, a 680-unit mixed-use project in the new Bidadari estate. The development will feature retail space, a community club, and a neighbourhood police centre, and is expected to be completed in the second half of 2022. Priced above S$2,000 per square foot, the condominium units are likely to be in high demand. The project is part of SPH's diversification strategy into properties, with Lee Boon Yang stating that it will transform the parcel of land into an "oasis for homeowners" with convenient access to parks and amenities.

images.alt_text: The first private residential-cum-retail development that is shaping up in the new Bidadari estate will offer some 680 residential units and close to 28,000 square metres of retail gross floor area.

site_title: Noble not making interest payment due March 29 for US$1.1b revolving credit facility
summary: Noble Group, a commodities merchant, will not make an interest payment of $1.1 billion due on March 29, 2018, as part of its restructuring process. The company is addressing all unsecured indebtedness, including the revolving credit facility, under a restructuring support agreement. ING Bank has received credit approval and acceded to the agreement, and 55% of existing senior creditors have accepted the plan. The company expects increased creditor participation and has extended the deadline for new money debt subscriptions to April 11, 2018.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Sasseur Reit, Sembcorp Marine
summary: Noble Group delayed making an interest payment on its $1.1 billion unsecured revolving credit facility due to restructuring efforts. Sasseur Reit's IPO started trading on Wednesday, with the offering receiving over 3.7 times the available units. Sembcorp Marine secured a contract from TechnipFMC to build a floating production vessel. These developments may impact trading of Noble Group, Sasseur Reit, and Sembcorp Marine shares.

site_title: Foxconn unit to buy Belkin for US$866m
summary: Foxconn's FIT Hon Teng Ltd agreed to buy Belkin International Inc for US$866 million, expanding into branded goods. Belkin, a maker of consumer electronics, will give FIT access to 700 patents and a strong research and development capacity. Billionaire Terry Gou, Foxconn's owner, aims to capture more of the value chain in branded groups. The deal follows Gou's previous investment in Sharp Corp and expansion into artificial intelligence and big data. Belkin had sales of US$789 million in the fiscal year ended September 30.

site_title: Apple goes back to school with new iPad, apps
summary: Apple unveiled new applications and a discounted iPad tablet aimed at the education market, aiming to regain momentum lost to Google in the classroom technology space. The company showcased a free curriculum called Everyone Can Create and introduced Schoolwork, a new app that helps teachers create assignments and track student progress. The move is part of Apple's efforts to strengthen its presence in the education sector.

site_title: Cut the cutlery if you don't need it, says foodpanda
summary: Foodpanda, a Singapore-based food delivery service, has launched a campaign encouraging customers to opt out of disposable cutlery with their orders. The initiative, which began in January 2018, aims to reduce waste and promote sustainability. Since its launch, more customers have been opting out of disposable cutlery, contributing to a shift towards a zero-waste future.

site_title: Turner unveils streaming sports service in challenge to ESPN
summary: Turner Broadcasting unveiled a standalone streaming sports service, Bleacher Report Live, to compete with ESPN. The service will offer flexible pricing options, including access to live games for purchase or subscription. Bleacher Report Live aims to be a "hub" for sports content discovery and will provide access to a variety of live games. The launch is set for next month, marking a direct challenge to ESPN.

site_title: Singapore sees Asia as silver lining amid US-China trade war
summary: Singapore views Asia as a growth opportunity despite escalating US-China trade tensions, according to Economic Development Board chairman Dr Beh Swan Gin. Asia's strong demand in China, Southeast Asia, and India is expected to mitigate potential downsides. Singapore's economy, heavily reliant on trade (212% of GDP), is diversifying, with new investments in the pharmaceutical industry. The city-state remains optimistic, with Dr Beh stating that Asia's long-term attractiveness for companies is unlikely to be threatened, and Singapore's role as a leading hub for advanced activities will endure.

site_title: China and North Korea seek improved ties
summary: China and North Korea are seeking to improve ties after the US-North Korea summit, with China working to mend relations with Pyongyang while continuing to cooperate with the US on economic sanctions. China has been publishing articles in state media expressing support for North Korea's interests, positioning itself as a "resolute" supporter who will secure Pyongyang's interests. This move is seen as a response to being excluded from the US-North Korea talks, and aims to safeguard China's own interests while helping to facilitate a resolution to the North Korean nuclear issue.

site_title: 8M buys shophouses, commercial building for S$82.5m
summary: 8M Real Estate, a Singapore-based investment property company, has acquired a portfolio of nine conservation shophouses and a commercial building in District 1 near the Singapore River for S$82.5 million. The properties, held by Lee Brothers (Wee Kee), include 61 and 77 Boat Quay, and a corner block of four shophouses at 27, 29, 31, and 33 New Bridge Road. The acquisition will boost 8M's portfolio to over 40 conservation shophouses worth S$500 million.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore needs spirit of innovation, creativity to reinvent itself
summary: Singapore's economy, with the fourth highest GDP per capita, faces a bleak future due to a labor shortage and increasing competition from regional adversaries. The country's 18-year-olds, who contributed to its success, are now 70, leaving a gap in the workforce. To reinvent itself, Singapore must adopt a spirit of innovation and creativity, leveraging technology to drive growth. The country's economic policies and demographics must be revised to address the labor shortage and stay competitive in the global market. A new generation must be encouraged to fill the gap in the workforce.

site_title: Clear, reliable policy direction in Asean needed to attract renewables investment: IRENA
summary: Asean countries need clear policy and regulatory frameworks to attract renewable energy investments, according to IRENA director-general Adnan Z Amin. The region aims to generate 23% of its energy from renewables by 2025, requiring $27 billion in annual investments. Currently, financing for renewables projects in the region is largely underpinned by public and development finance, hindering private sector investment. A clear policy framework is needed to create market opportunities and attract institutional investors, with Singapore seen as a hub for innovative finance in the region.

site_title: Indonesia imposes extra capital requirements on top banks
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) has ordered the country's largest banks to set aside additional capital, ranging from 1% to 3.5% of risk-weighted assets.
