The move aims to bolster banks' ability to absorb losses and prevent failures. The requirement applies to systemically important banks and must be met by January 1, 2024. The measure may conflict with government efforts to boost lending and economic growth, which has slowed in recent years.

site_title: US: Tech selloff hits stocks; Nasdaq slumps 2.9%, Dow -1.4%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index down 2.9% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.4%. The tech-rich Nasdaq was hit by negative stories surrounding Facebook, Tesla Motors, Twitter, and Alphabet, with the latter's parent company Google sinking 4.6% after a US appeals court revived Oracle's lawsuit. Analysts attributed the decline to a "cascade of negative stories" and warned that the market may continue to decline as investors are hesitant to step in and catch a falling knife.

site_title: Datapulse board questions suitability of Ng Bie Tjin as proposed new director
summary: Datapulse Technology's board questioned the suitability of proposed new director Ng Bie Tjin due to her inability to identify and evaluate new business opportunities. The company cited her apology letter to co-founder Ng Cheow Chye and her handling of financial records as concerns. Ng Bie Tjin is the daughter of Datapulse's co-founder and owns a 16% stake in the company. She is seeking to oust the current board members, citing a lack of transparency, and has filed requisition notices for an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: SembMarine unit bags FPSO contract from TechnipFMC
summary: SEMBCORP Marine Rigs & Floaters, a unit of SembCorp Marine, has secured a contract from TechnipFMC to build a floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel for the Energean-operated Karish and Tanin deepwater field developments in the Eastern Mediterranean. The 227m-long vessel will have an oil storage capacity of 800,000 barrels and gas production capacity of eight billion cubic metres per annum. The contract is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2020 with no material impact on SembMarine's net tangible assets and earnings per share.

site_title: Euro falls as concerns about low inflation resurface
summary: The euro fell 0.3% to US$1.2405, reversing gains made on Monday, amid concerns about weak inflation and a slowdown in company borrowing in the eurozone. Data showed lending to eurozone companies slowed last month, and European Central Bank governing council member Erkki Liikanen suggested underlying eurozone inflation may remain lower than expected. The US dollar rallied 0.4% against the euro, while safe-haven Japanese yen also declined.

site_title: Time to relook total expense ratios of funds in CPF Investment Scheme
summary: The Singaporean government has announced plans to cap sales charges on unit trusts and investment-linked insurance funds in the CPF Investment Scheme at 1.5% from October 1, 2018, and eliminate them entirely by October 2019. The move aims to reduce costs for investors and align the interests of advisers and clients. However, experts argue that the main drag on returns is the total expense ratio (TER) of funds, which should be capped at a lower level. The government has previously reduced the cap on TERs in 2014, but it remains too high for a low-return environment.

site_title: For a merger to succeed, don't forget the people
summary: Grab's acquisition of Uber's Southeast Asian business has raised concerns over the integration of employees, with over 500 Uber staff facing uncertainty over their roles. Despite top management promising new roles at Grab, there is no explicit pledge from the company, and one contract employee described the process as "stressful" and "emotional." Experts warn that poor people management can make a merger look poorly planned and executed, and that a clear communication plan is crucial for success. The Competition Commission of Singapore is also reviewing the merger, which may impact its approval.

site_title: Central bankers looking beyond dollar as reserves
summary: For the first time in a decade, central banks are looking beyond the US dollar to build their currency reserves, driven by US protectionism and the European Union's economic resurgence. A resurgent euro and the pursuit of free-trade deals in Asia and Latin America have made the case for diversification stronger. As President Trump threatens a trade war with China, central banks are seeking alternative safe-haven assets, potentially leading to a shift away from the dollar and towards the euro.

site_title: Changi visitor traffic up 5.6% in Feb on CNY boost
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore saw a 5.6% increase in visitor traffic in February, driven by the Chinese New Year break. The airport handled 4.93 million passengers, with travel to and from South-east Asia and North-east Asia accounting for over half of the growth. Traffic to and from China and India grew the fastest among Changi's top 10 country markets.

site_title: MetLife unit struck US$16b in real estate deals last year
summary: MetLife Investment Management, a unit of MetLife Inc, completed US$16 billion in global real estate transactions last year, including US$14 billion in commercial-mortgage originations. This brings the total managed loans to a record US$57 billion. The stable market for real estate financing and continued demand from institutional investors and Asian buyers in the US helped drive the strong year. The asset manager's strategy of doing smaller slices of different transactions will help meet the needs of its multiple clients.

site_title: Acromec inks MOU to build waste-to-energy plant
summary: Acromec, an engineering firm, has signed a memorandum of understanding with HL Plus to build, own, and operate an organic waste-to-energy plant in Singapore. The plant will convert 70 tonnes of chicken manure daily into biogas, generating electricity for the farm at a rate no higher than Singapore Power charges. Acromec's subsidiary, Acropower, will benefit from the sale of electricity, while Chew's Agriculture will pay an annual rental fee to Acropower. The project marks Acromec's advancement into the renewable energy sector and aims to replicate the model across Singapore and the region.

site_title: Clear, reliable policy direction in Asean needed to attract renewables investment: IRENA
summary: Asean countries need clear policy and regulatory frameworks to attract renewable energy investments, according to IRENA director-general Adnan Z Amin. The region's renewable energy investments have been hindered by financing issues, with 92% of global renewables funding coming from the private sector, unlike in other regions. IRENA estimates that Asean needs $27 billion in annual investments to reach its 2025 target of 23% renewable energy mix. Clear and reliable long-term policies are crucial to create a market opportunity for private sector investment.

images.alt_text: "Basically what we're lacking right now is a sense of government resolve and a sense of adequate, reliable policy framework that allows the private sector to come in," says Mr Amin.

site_title: Dubai's Nexus Financial Services quits Singapore
summary: Dubai-based financial services firm Nexus Financial Services has closed its Singapore operations, exiting the market to focus on its core Middle East operations. The decision was made after a review process, with the firm citing strong synergies between its offerings in Singapore and the Middle East. Nexus had 120 staff members in Singapore, but the number has decreased. Clients with insurance policies and investments will not be affected, as their contracts will continue as per the applicable terms and conditions. The firm's independent financial advisers will also migrate to other firms.

site_title: Angry Birds maker Rovio cuts boardroom pay
summary: Rovio, the maker of Angry Birds, has proposed cutting the pay of its chairman and vice chairman due to a 50% drop in its market value. Chairman Mika Ihamuotila's pay would be reduced to 9,500 euros from 12,000 euros, while vice chairman Kaj Hed's pay would be cut to 7,500 euros from 10,000 euros. This decision comes after Rovio's sales are expected to fall this year, citing tough competition and high marketing costs. The company will hold its first annual general meeting on April 16 to vote on the proposed pay cuts.

site_title: Gearing up for a future workforce of man and machine
summary: Singapore business leaders expect humans and machines to work together within five years, but only 21% believe their companies are well-equipped for digitalization. The top obstacles cited are lack of digital vision and strategy, workforce readiness, and technology constraints. Despite differing views on new technologies, 92% of respondents aim to transform their businesses to a software-defined business, and 83% plan to use AI to pre-empt customer demands. Experts emphasize the need for business leaders to adapt to the changing digital landscape, embracing learning and disruption to drive innovation.

site_title: GSK buys out Novartis in US$13b consumer healthcare shake-up
summary: British pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is acquiring Novartis' 36.5% stake in their US$13 billion consumer healthcare joint venture, gaining full control of products such as Sensodyne toothpaste and Panadol headache tablets. This move follows GSK's decision to drop out of the bidding for Pfizer's consumer healthcare business, which was expected to fetch up to US$20 billion. GSK will also conduct a strategic review of its consumer nutrition products, including Horlicks.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE snaps four-session losing streak
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index rebounded 1.5% on Tuesday, ending a four-session losing streak, amid signs of averted global trade tensions. The index closed at 6,994.85 points, with nearly all constituents rising. A stronger dollar and hopes of US-China negotiations boosted the market. Shares in companies like Ferguson and GlaxoSmithKline rose, while the FTSE is now down about 9% in 2018.

site_title: Germany said to be at odds with France over tariffs on US cars
summary: Germany is at odds with France over tariffs on US cars, with Germany willing to make concessions to avoid a trade war. A German government official said the EU should lower tariffs on goods including cars to reach a deal with the US. However, a French government official stated that France doesn't want the bloc to make any concessions, putting pressure on Germany to find an alternative solution. This divide risks alienating other EU countries, including France, and may jeopardize efforts to avert a trade war.

site_title: Kim's Beijing visit underlines 'change is in the air'
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is visiting Beijing, his first foreign trip since taking power in 2011, amid recent developments in the Korean peace process. The visit comes at a time of strained relations with China, which has increasingly supported international sanctions against Pyongyang. Chinese President Xi Jinping has described North Korea's military provocations as a threat to his country's national security. The trip is seen as a potential boon for China, allowing Xi to assess Kim's expectations and goals in upcoming meetings with South Korean and US presidents.

site_title: Foreign banks are back. Are Singapore banks doing enough?
summary: Singapore's Big 3 banks, DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank (UOB), face increased competition from foreign banks expanding in the country. Recent moves by HSBC, Maybank, and Julius Baer, including new branch openings and hires, signal a resurgence of foreign banks in Singapore. To counter this, local banks may focus on acquisitions, poaching senior bankers, and diversifying their services, such as lifestyle finance. Despite these challenges, the strong economic growth of Singapore and Asean is expected to mask some market share redistribution and increased costs.

site_title: AkzoNobel to sell chemicals arm for 10.1b euros to Carlyle, GIC
summary: AkzoNobel, the world's leading paintmaker, is selling its chemicals arm to US-based investors Carlyle Group and Singapore's GIC for 10.1 billion euros. The deal is part of the company's strategy to bolster its operations, following a failed hostile takeover bid by PPG and a dropped merger with Axalta. The chemicals arm, which owns brands such as Dulux and Trimetal, was split off in 2017 to increase the company's focus on its core paint business. The sale is expected to be completed by the end of 2018.

site_title: Preparing the next generation for new jobs
summary: Experts at a dialogue session organized by Dell EMC emphasize the need for the next generation of workers to be adaptable and self-directed in the face of an uncertain future workplace. While some job losses may occur, new jobs will be created, with a focus on skills such as empathy, speed, and proficiency in algorithms. Technology has also enabled more opportunities for individuals to create their own careers, with a focus on personal satisfaction and fulfillment. Experts stress the importance of self-directed learning, collaboration, and empowerment in preparing workers for the future.

site_title: Private equity's rising deal values
summary: Private equity funds generated a 19% increase in global buyout value to $440 billion in 2017, despite a 2% growth in deal count to 3,077 deals. The disconnect between deal value and count reflects a lack of attractive targets, as funds face high valuation multiples, stiff competition, and uncertain macroeconomic outlooks. Despite ample capital, funds are being selective and some are staying on the sidelines. The market is also experiencing a shift towards corporate competition for assets, with rising average purchase price multiples and a broader scope for acquisitions.

site_title: SMRT's 2017 after-tax profit sinks 68%
summary: SMRT Corp, a Singapore-based rail operator owned by Temasek, reported a 67.9% drop in 2017 after-tax profit to S$26 million, possibly a two-decade low. The company attributed the decline to increased resources dedicated to repairs and maintenance works. This drop follows a similar 68% decline in 2017 pre-tax profit. The sharp decline in earnings highlights the challenges faced by SMRT Corp in maintaining its operations and competitiveness in the rail industry.

site_title: Macron wants France to ace AI 'arms race'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron aims to boost France's artificial intelligence capabilities to avoid falling behind China and the US, and has set a "major offensive" to launch this week. Macron wants to leverage France's math strength to gain an economic advantage, following a report led by Cedric Villani, a Fields Medal winner. France's investment in AI will be significant, with funds comparable to what's at stake, as the global AI landscape is seen as an accelerating "arms race."

site_title: Lending to eurozone companies slows in potential headache for ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reported a slowdown in lending to eurozone companies in February, with a 3.1% growth rate, down from a post-crisis high of 3.4% previously. The ECB's quantitative easing scheme, which has purchased nearly $4.1 trillion in debt, may be winding down sooner than expected if the slowdown continues. Policymakers, including Finnish central bank governor Erkki Liikanen, are cautioning against further tightening monetary policy until inflation rates exceed 2% in expectations.

site_title: Fighting cancer through awareness and screening
summary: The National University Cancer Institute, Singapore (NCIS) marked its 10th anniversary with a record-breaking cancer awareness event, collecting 10,125 ribbons representing different types of cancer. The event aimed to raise awareness and encourage early screening, with NCIS distributing free colorectal cancer screening kits and offering subsidized breast cancer screenings. The institute also raised funds for needy cancer patients and cancer research. The event was attended by 530 members of the public and set a new record for the largest collection of ribbons in Singapore.

site_title: Building firms of the future with JOCE™
summary: The Job of the Chief Executive (JOCE) programme is returning for its 38th year, focusing on helping CEOs develop strategies to thrive in an uncertain future. The five-day course, held from July 15 to 20, will equip participants with tools and insights to build a competitive human capital strategy, lead organizational change, and foster innovation. With over 1,300 trained senior management personnel from diverse industries and countries, JOCE aims to provide real-world solutions to business challenges. This year's program will focus on Asia's dynamic environment, offering practical insights and solutions to attendees.

site_title: GM Korea threatens bankruptcy unless revival plan gets support
summary: GM Korea threatens bankruptcy if its labour union fails to agree on a restructuring plan by April 20. The company needs employees' support by the end of March to stay afloat, with $600 million in payments to vendors and employees at risk if no agreement is reached. GM Korea is seeking concessions to revive its business, which has been hurt by mounting losses, and plans to submit a turnaround proposal to the government. The company also intends to manufacture US market-targeted vehicles in its South Korean plants.

images.alt_text: GM is seeking concessions from the union to revive its South Korean business that's been hurt by mounting losses.

site_title: Twitter bans cryptocurrency ads on fraud fears
summary: Twitter has banned ads for initial cryptocurrency offerings and sales of virtual currency tokens, following Google and Facebook's lead, to protect users from fraud. The ban sent the value of bitcoin below $8,000. The new policy excludes ads for cryptocurrency exchanges and secure "wallet" services offered by public companies. Twitter plans to modify its policy as the digital currency market evolves. The ban comes amid concerns over the use of virtual currencies for money laundering and deception.

site_title: Indonesia's Go-Jek poised for imminent Southeast Asia expansion
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing company Go-Jek plans to expand to another Southeast Asian country in the "next few weeks", according to an internal email. The company aims to launch in three other countries by the middle of the year, following Uber's sale of its Southeast Asian business to Grab. Go-Jek is backed by Google and Tencent, and its expansion is seen as a response to the consolidation of the Southeast Asian ride-hailing market. The company believes its global partnerships will provide sufficient support for its international growth.

site_title: A*Star takes new targeted approach to R&D
summary: A*Star, Singapore's research agency, is transforming its research management system to better align with shifting needs and increasing competition. The new approach will evaluate different types of research and development activities differently, with upstream research focused on publication metrics and industry-oriented projects on collaboration. Funding will be competitive and merit-based, starting from April 1. The changes do not affect existing projects and will be implemented through five new constructs: technology centers, research institutes, knowledge creation activities, programs, and national platforms.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

At a press conference yesterday, A*Star chairman Lim Chuan Poh gave the hypothetical example of two projects - a "knowledge creation" or upstream scientific research project, and an industry-oriented one - currently assessed with similar metrics.

site_title: Trump's Washington awash in conflicts of interest
summary: The Trump administration is marred by numerous conflicts of interest, with no Congressional Committee investigating the issue. Notable examples include Deputy Finance Chairman Elliott Broidy's payments to Saudi and UAE officials to influence US foreign policy, and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross's recent divestment of his business investment in a Chinese shipping company. Other officials, such as Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke and Environmental Protection Agency chief Administrator Scott Pruitt, have also been accused of abuse and entitlement, with some spending public funds on luxury items. The Trump family's business interests and lack of separation from the White House have raised concerns, with the non-profit group Citizens for Ethics and Responsibility in Government (CREW) suing Trump for violations of the emoluments clause of the US Constitution.

site_title: 3 Michelin-star 'Demon Chef' to open Forbidden Duck in Singapore
summary: Three Michelin-starred chef Alvin Leung, known as the "Demon Chef," is set to open a Cantonese restaurant called Forbidden Duck in Singapore by April. The restaurant, located at Marina Bay Financial Centre, will serve signature Peking-style and slow-cooked roast duck, as well as classic Cantonese fare and dim sum. Leung, who has several restaurants worldwide, including three Michelin-starred Bo Innovation in Hong Kong, will offer an exclusive eight-course dinner menu featuring his signature dishes and a collaborative menu with fellow Hong Kong chef Liu Ching Hai.

images.alt_text: Chef Alvin loves duck, and has always wanted to own a Peking duck restaurant.
"There are lots of Michelin star chefs opening in Singapore, like Robuchon, Sebastien Lepinoy and Tetsuya Wakuda. So I want to be a part of that." - "Demon Chef" Alvin Leung (above)

site_title: Profit-taking causes oil prices to slip after last week's rally
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday, with Brent crude futures falling 33 cents to $70.12 a barrel and US WTI crude futures losing 33 cents to $65.55 a barrel. The decline was attributed to profit-taking after last week's rally, but concerns about Saudi-Iran tensions kept losses in check. The rally was the strongest since July, with Brent gaining 6.4% and WTI rising 5.7% last week.

site_title: UK employers concerned about migration curbs
summary: UK employers are concerned about restrictions on EU workers following Brexit, citing reliance on EU labor and potential skills shortages. A government-commissioned study found that employers are fearful about the future migration system and many have built business models around the availability of EU migrant labor. The decline in EU net migration since the Brexit referendum has been attributed to deterrence by EU citizens, a less favorable exchange rate, and improved job opportunities in their home countries.

site_title: Ezion's road to redemption starts with shareholders' meeting today
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, is seeking shareholders' approval for a debt refinancing plan at an extraordinary general meeting. The plan, which involves issuing new shares to creditors, aims to pare debts to a manageable level and allow the group to ride out a prolonged sectoral downturn. In return, shareholders will receive warrants. The company's success relies on the support of all stakeholders, and the outcome of the meeting will determine the group's future prospects.

site_title: London housing market shows signs of sliding into doldrums
summary: London's housing market is showing signs of a decline, with prices forecast to fall by mid-2018. According to Hometrack, Brexit and tax changes are forcing vendors to cut asking prices, resulting in the fastest pace of price drops since the global financial crisis. House prices are growing at their slowest pace in seven years, and prices fell in 42% of postcodes in February. The report also found that London home prices rose 1% year-on-year in February, the smallest increase since 2011.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Grab acquires Uber's South-east Asia business, phasing out the Uber app in the region. This deal may lead to a renegotiation of ComfortDelGro's proposed tie-up with Uber. The merger could create a dominant market leader in the ride-hailing app market, potentially affecting the review and sanctioning of the Grab-Uber deal.

site_title: A Facebook lesson for startups and data-driven firms
summary: Singapore's data-driven companies and startups must prioritize proper data management practices following the Facebook data breach scandal, according to industry observers. A recent survey found 39% of Asia-Pacific respondents reported a cybersecurity breach in the past year. Strong legislation, such as Singapore's Personal Data Protection Act, may contribute to the cautious approach of many startups. Industry guidelines and clear consent from consumers are also essential for maintaining user trust and preventing reputational damage.

site_title: BOE considered bank capital buffer hike but waiting to watch risks
summary: The Bank of England considered increasing the countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) to 1.5% of a bank's risk-weighted assets to counter growing lending in Britain, but decided to wait until June to make a decision. The Financial Policy Committee (FPC) argued that risks had increased since the current 1% CCyB rate was set in Q1 2016. The decision was made following a review of the UK's economic outlook.

site_title: Thai Cabinet approves 200b baht rail project to link airports
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a 200 billion baht (S$8.39 billion) high-speed railway project linking three airports: Suvarnabhumi, Don Mueang, and U-Tapao. The project aims to alleviate strain on Thai infrastructure due to surging tourist arrivals, with 37.55 million foreign visitors expected this year. The rail link is expected to boost tourist receipts, accounting for about 12% of Thailand's gross domestic product.

site_title: Lian Beng unit heads for Catalist listing
summary: Lian Beng Group has announced the restructuring of its businesses, spinning off its property development unit, SLB Development, to be listed on the Catalist Board of the Singapore Exchange. SLB will focus on various property development projects, including residential, mixed-use, industrial, and commercial developments, both in Singapore and China. The unit posted S$87.6 million in revenue and S$15.8 million in net profit in FY 2017. The listing aims to diversify the business and better manage exposure to market fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: GIC-backed Indian lender makes market debut at 27% premium
summary: Bandhan Bank, an Indian lender focused on under-banked markets, made its market debut at a 27% premium to its issue price of 375 rupees, closing at 476.85 rupees. The bank is backed by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, which sees strong growth potential in India's financial services sector. GIC has a 16.7% stake in the bank, with a fund multiple of at least 11 times its initial investment, indicating a significant return on investment.

site_title: Xiaomi CEO slams iPhone while unveiling its cheaper MIX 2S
summary: Xiaomi unveiled its latest top-tier smartphone, the MIX 2S, at a launch event in Beijing, targeting Apple and Samsung with a price tag of 3,299 yuan (S$687). The phone boasts a six-inch bezel-less screen, ceramic body, Qualcomm's latest processor, and dual cameras, undercutting the iPhone X's price. Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun took potshots at Apple's iPhone X, highlighting the phone's heat issues and lower camera performance. The MIX 2S is part of Xiaomi's aggressive expansion into overseas markets, including the US and Europe, where the company aims to challenge Apple's dominance by 2019.

site_title: Columbia Threadneedle multi-asset strategy aims for consistent income
summary: Columbia Threadneedle's global multi-asset income fund is shifting its portfolio to 55% equities, up from 50% 18 months ago, to deliver consistent regular income with less volatility than an equity-only strategy. The fund, led by portfolio manager Maya Bhandari, aims to capitalize on synchronized global growth and reflation, while managing geopolitical risks. It invests in equities after assessing leverage and dividend cover, and also holds high-yield corporate debt with a short average duration. The fund targets a 5% annual income, supplemented by a covered call option, and has a history of delivering 6.9% returns over two years.

site_title: Oxley Holdings snaps up freehold Ampas Apartment for S$95m
summary: Oxley Holdings has agreed to purchase the freehold Ampas Apartment for S$95 million. The developer plans to redevelop the site into a 26-storey residential development with a minimum of 120 units. The acquisition is subject to obtaining outline planning permission and is expected to have minimal impact on the company's earnings per share. The purchase will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: Earth-bound Chinese spacelab plunging to fiery end
summary: A Chinese space station, Tiangong-1, is set to break up as it hurtles to Earth on or around April 1, with the European Space Agency predicting most of it will burn up due to extreme heat. The station, weighing at least 7 tonnes, had ceased functioning in March 2016 and is expected to make an "uncontrolled reentry." The chances of human injury are considered vanishingly small, with the odds of being struck by space debris estimated at 1 in 1.2 trillion.

site_title: Startup aims to disrupt Sweden's banks
summary: A Swedish startup, Enkla, is challenging the country's strict banking regulations by offering lower interest rates on mortgages online. Licensed by the regulator, Enkla will provide three-year mortgages at 0.95% compared to 1.6-1.9% from traditional banks. The startup aims to take a 3.5% share of Sweden's mortgage market, potentially disrupting the US$380 billion industry dominated by four banks. Enkla's innovative approach could lead to a shift in the market, with its co-founder stating the company wants to be a "responsible disrupter" and "banks' best friends" in a few years.

site_title: Europe: Trade detente hopes turbocharge European shares
summary: European shares surged on Tuesday, led by a 7.8% jump in Casino, after signs of a trade detente between the US and China boosted investor confidence. The STOXX 600 index rose 1.4%, with Germany's DAX leading the gains at 1.8%. The positive market trend follows a recent decline due to US-China trade tensions, with investors now looking to a potential easing of trade restrictions.

site_title: Maritime market appears to be slowly recovering
summary: Maritime market appears to be slowly recovering, according to independent research firm Maritime Strategies International (MSI). The firm's forecast predicts positive growth for most shipping markets, with compound annual growth rate for seaborne cargo growth showing improvement across sectors between 2013 and 2017, set to be equalled or bettered over the next four years. However, MSI warns of "complex and nuanced trading conditions" that could derail the recovery.

site_title: Indonesia imposes extra capital requirements on top banks
summary: Indonesia's Financial Services Authority (OJK) ordered the country's largest banks to set aside additional capital, ranging from 1% to 3.5% of risk-weighted assets, to bolster their ability to absorb losses and protect against bank failures. The move may conflict with efforts to boost lending and the economy, which has seen credit growth fall to single digits in the past two years. The new capital requirement must be met by January 1, and banks can meet it through raising fresh capital or laying out a plan to OJK for approval.

site_title: Markets perk up as trade tensions ease
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 26.89 points, or 0.79%, to close at 3,439.35, breaking a four-day losing streak. Easing trade war tensions boosted technology and manufacturing stocks, with Venture Corporation and Valuetronics among the top gainers. However, ComfortDelGro shed 0.98% after the merger of Uber and Grab's South-east Asia operations was announced. The US and China's negotiations to stave off a trade war also lifted markets across the Asia-Pacific, with Hong Kong, Seoul, and Tokyo also seeing gains.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Indonesia's Go-Jek poised for imminent Southeast Asia expansion
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing company Go-Jek plans to announce its first expansion to another Southeast Asian country within the next few weeks, with three more countries targeted by the middle of the year. The move comes after Uber's sale of its Southeast Asian business to Grab, and is seen as a strategic opportunity for Go-Jek to solidify its market leadership. Backed by Google and Tencent, Go-Jek has secured significant funding for international expansion and is confident in its ability to become a global player.

site_title: DBS brings back Hack2Hire to recruit 100 techies
summary: DBS is reviving its Hack2Hire recruitment program to hire up to 100 tech professionals, doubling the number of hires from last year. The program aims to recruit developers, data scientists, system engineers, scrum masters, and other tech skill sets. Candidates will undergo a two-stage process, including an online technical assessment and a live hackathon session. Successful candidates will receive a job offer on the same day. DBS aims to leverage technology to reimagine banking and provide fresh perspectives and skill sets to its teams.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Orange to roll out solar project targeting African consumers
summary: Orange SA plans to distribute up to 20,000 solar kits in four African countries, partnering with BBOXX, to provide off-grid solar power. The company aims to target 400,000 to 500,000 solar kits in the next five years. This expansion follows Orange's efforts to boost revenue in Africa, where mobile payments and data services already account for 20% of its revenue. The move is part of a growing trend of companies offering solar solutions to African consumers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

LTC Corporation has accepted a buyout offer from Mountbatten Enterprises, with the group acquiring 126.6 million shares representing 80% of the company. AEM Holdings' largest shareholder is distributing most of its shares, reducing its stake to 4.28%. Aspial Corporation has updated its 5.5% notes, offering a higher interest rate of 5.9% per annum. Midas Holdings' subsidiary has given an unauthorized guarantee to an unrelated third party. Oxley Holdings has agreed to purchase a freehold property Ampas Apartment for S$95 million. These deals mark significant developments in the corporate sector.

site_title: Trek 2000 auditors flag disclaimer of opinion
summary: TREK 2000 International, a security solutions firm, has had its auditors flag a disclaimer of opinion over its financial results for the year ended Dec 31, 2017. The auditors, Moore Stephens, were unable to perform necessary procedures due to ongoing reviews and investigations into accounting discrepancies and past transactions. The company sold Racer Group in 2017, resulting in a net loss of US$1.3 million. An external review and internal investigations are ongoing. The disclaimer affects the financial statements for the current and preceding years.

site_title: March US consumer confidence cools from record heights
summary: US consumer confidence cooled in March, retreating from an 18-year high, with the index falling 2.3 points to 127.7. Despite this, the present conditions index remained high, and expectations index remained strong. Weakest households, making less than $15,000 per year, saw the lowest index level since October. Consumers are less optimistic about future job markets, with expectations of more jobs dropping 3.3 points. The survey suggests the economy's good run will extend, but some analysts expect a correction that may signal a slowdown in spending growth.

site_title: SIA planning new seats for the 777-9
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is conceptualizing new cabin products for its upcoming Boeing 777-9s, featuring a revamped First Class. SIA has ordered 20 777-9s, primarily replacing 777-300ERs, with deliveries starting from FY2021/2022. SIA CEO Goh Choon Phong stated that the new First Class will set an industry standard.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: First batch of Melbourne units nets developer World Class Global A$69m
summary: World Class Global (WCG) has received A$69 million in net sales proceeds from the first batch of 134 completed residential units in its Melbourne project, Avant. This represents 97% of the total units sold, with 444 units sold to date, generating A$256.4 million in sales. The developer expects the sales to contribute positively to its financial performance for the current quarter.

site_title: Bank of England considered bank capital buffer hike but waiting to watch risks
summary: The Bank of England considered increasing the countercyclical capital buffer (CCyB) for UK banks but decided to wait until June, citing easing risks of a Brexit hit to the financial services industry. The Financial Policy Committee argued that a "measured increase" in the CCyB rate could be accommodated by banks without tightening credit conditions. However, the committee also noted arguments for keeping the CCyB at 1% and stressed the need for a gradual approach to raising the rate.

site_title: Sasseur Reit IPO is more than 3.7 times subscribed
summary: Sasseur Reit's initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore is more than 3.7 times subscribed, with 2,832 valid applications for 51.4 million units. The offering, priced at S$0.80 per unit, will raise S$396 million in gross proceeds. The Reit, which will list on the Singapore Exchange, offers exposure to Chinese outlet malls and forecasts a 7.5% distribution yield between March and end-2018, and 7.8% in 2019.

site_title: Lian Beng unit heads for Catalist listing
summary: SLB Development, a unit of Lian Beng Group, plans to list its shares on Singapore's Catalist board. The preliminary offer document has been released, but details on the number and issue price of shares remain undisclosed. SLB Development reported S$87.6 million in revenues and S$15.8 million in net profit for FY 2017, with a pre-invitation earnings per share of 2.35 Singapore cents. The company develops residential, mixed-use, industrial, and commercial properties, primarily in Singapore and China.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Heavenly music for Easter weekend
summary: The University of Cambridge's St John's College choir is performing in Singapore for Easter weekend, with a stop at St Andrew's Cathedral on Easter Sunday. The choir, known for its traditional English music, will also perform at a local school and hold workshops. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and British High Commissioner Scott Wightman will be in attendance. This is part of a two-stop tour in Asia, following a performance at Hong Kong City Hall. The event is a rare occurrence for the choir during Eastertide.

site_title: EDF to invest 8 billion euros in power storage
summary: French state-owned utility EDF plans to invest 8 billion euros (S$13.03 billion) between 2018 and 2035 to become a European market leader in electricity storage, aiming to develop 10 gigawatts of additional storage capacity worldwide. EDF will focus on smoothing out the intermittence of renewable energy and guaranteeing grid performance. The company also plans to develop a portfolio of 1.2 million off-grid clients in Africa by 2035 through local partnerships.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as trade war tensions ease
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending their rally as trade war tensions eased. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 46.77 points, or 0.19%, to 24,249.37, while the S&P 500 gained 5.02 points, or 0.188825%, to 2,663.57. The Nasdaq Composite rose 0.47% to 7,254.35. The easing of trade war tensions and positive investor sentiment contributed to the gains, despite ongoing uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's central bank is expected to tighten monetary policy in April for the first time in six years due to solid economic growth and improving labor market. Meanwhile, 21 individuals in Singapore made Forbes' 30 Under 30 Asia list, and SMRT's 2017 after-tax profit sank 68% to S$26m. DBS plans to hire 100 techies via a hackathon, and A*Star is taking a new approach to managing R&D activities. Singapore shares rose 0.79% on Tuesday, snapping a four-day losing streak.

site_title: Prominent oncologist and Talkmed CEO Ang Peng Tiam resumes medical duties
summary: Renowned oncologist and Talkmed CEO Ang Peng Tiam has resumed his medical duties after an eight-month suspension by the Singapore Medical Council (SMC). The SMC found him guilty of two charges, including making false representations to a patient about the effectiveness of treatment and failing to offer surgery as an option. The patient, a 55-year-old lung cancer sufferer, died after treatment. Ang Peng Tiam's suspension was related to a complaint filed by the patient's daughters.

site_title: How new EU data protection law will impact Singapore firms
summary: The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will significantly impact Singapore firms, as they will be subject to the regulation if they collect, share, or sell data within the EU. Fines of up to S$29.8 million or 4% global annual turnover, whichever is greater, can be imposed for non-compliance. The GDPR aims to protect personal information of individuals, and Singapore businesses must adopt stronger cybersecurity measures to protect customer data. To achieve GDPR compliance, organizations should know their data, handle it with care, implement efficient cybersecurity strategies, continuously monitor, and plan their response in case of a breach.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Tuesday, rising 2.54 points to 1,862.45. The index saw 2.035 billion lots traded worth RM1.937 billion, with gains outnumbering losses 463 to 433.

site_title: MAS expected to tighten monetary policy in April: poll
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to tighten monetary policy in April for the first time in six years, according to a Reuters poll of economists. Nine analysts predict a slight increase in the appreciation rate of the Singapore dollar's policy band, marking the central bank's first policy tightening since April 2012. The decision comes as the economy shows signs of growth and the labor market improves, supporting a moderate rise in core prices.

site_title: Courts Asia gets nod from noteholders to relax covenants on debt due 2019
summary: Courts Asia, a furniture and IT retailer, has received over 80% of votes in favor of relaxing certain terms on notes due 2019. The move aims to lower the threshold for its minimum consolidated tangible net worth to S$120 million and reduce the minimum ratio of Ebitda to interest expense to 1.5 times. The changes are necessary to accommodate new accounting standards, which have impacted the company's financials. The proposed changes have been approved by 83% of note holders, exceeding the 75% required for approval.

site_title: Tan Ching Yee to chair Acra, among other board changes
summary: Tan Ching Yee has been appointed chairman of the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) board, effective April 1, succeeding Lim Soo Hoon. Lim oversaw major amendments to the Companies Act in 2014 and introduced beneficial ownership requirements in 2017. The board will also see four new members, including a CEO from the Ministry of Health, and five re-appointed members, including the accountant-general. The Acra board comprises 16 members and will start its new term on April 1.

site_title: Glaxo to buy Novartis consumer venture stake for US$13b
summary: GlaxoSmithKline agreed to buy Novartis's 36.5% stake in their consumer healthcare joint venture for $13 billion, with the deal expected to close in the second quarter. This comes after Glaxo withdrew from bidding for Pfizer's consumer unit, citing a potential transaction to buy out the Novartis holding. Novartis CEO Vas Narasimhan stated the sale will strengthen the company's ability to drive shareholder returns and make acquisitions.

images.alt_text: GlaxoSmithKline (GSX), the UK pharmaceutical giant, agreed to buy Novartis's stake in its consumer healthcare joint venture in a US$13 billion deal a week after withdrawing from the bidding for Pfizer's consumer unit.

site_title: 24 in Singapore make Forbes' 30 Under 30 Asia list in 2018
summary: Twenty-four individuals from Singapore made Forbes' 30 Under 30 Asia list in 2018, tied for fifth place with Japan. The honorees include tech executives, entrepreneurs, and innovators in various fields such as consumer technology, healthcare, retail, and energy. Notable Singaporeans on the list include Chope's COO Dinesh Balasingam, healthcare startup founder Esther Wang, and energy retail marketplace founder Julius Tan. The list recognizes young disruptors and innovators across Asia who are under 30.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.79% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.79% on Tuesday, snapping a four-day losing streak, as trade war tensions eased. The Straits Times Index gained 26.89 points to 3,439.35, with technology and manufacturing stocks driving gains. Electronics provider Venture Corporation and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose. However, ComfortDelGro, a taxi giant, fell after investors reacted to the Grab-Uber merger announcement.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Midas' audit committee flags unauthorised debt guarantee by unit
summary: The audit committee of Midas Holdings has found that a subsidiary, Dalian Huicheng Aluminium Co Ltd, provided an unauthorized debt guarantee to an unrelated Chinese company, Chongqing Huicheng Aluminium Co, Ltd. The guarantee was made for two years after the debt fulfillment period and was not reported to the board of directors. The committee noted that the transaction does not benefit the group and was not disclosed. This discovery comes as the company's CEO, Patrick Chew, resigned on March 22 due to "health reasons and legal troubles surrounding the group".

site_title: Saudi Aramco chief says IPO on track for 2018
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser said the company's highly anticipated IPO is on track for 2018, but no fixed date or venue has been set. The IPO, which would value the company at $2 trillion, is a key part of Saudi Arabia's "Vision 2030" reform program. Despite concerns from energy minister and British officials, Nasser stated there is "a lot of demand for the listing" and the process is complex, requiring time. The listing is planned for the second half of 2018, although a US listing has been reported as a possibility.

site_title: China's censors, investors swoop as Kim rumours rage
summary: Chinese censors removed unflattering references to Kim Jong-un from social media, while investors bought shares with "Jin" in their name, seeing it as a reference to "gold" and potentially a sign of his visit to Beijing. The capital was under tight security, with speculation that Kim Jong-un was visiting Beijing fueled by a reported arrival of a special North Korean train. State media and officials denied any visit, but Chinese investors seized on the rumors, causing shares of companies with "Jin" in their name to surge.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise as US-China trade worries ease
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 14.98 points, or 0.61%, to 2,452.06 on Tuesday, driven by easing US-China trade tensions. The won strengthened to 1,070.3 per dollar, up 1.01% from its previous close. This follows a 0.96% gain for the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index and a 2.65% rise for Japanese stocks. The KOSPI is down 1.2% so far this year, but foreigners were net buyers of 14,168 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for second straight day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a second consecutive day, driven by easing fears of a US-China trade war. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.79% to 30,790.83, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index surged 2.20%. This follows a surge on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Viking seeks S$5.07m in claims from Keppel Singmarine in legal spat
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine has sued Keppel Singmarine for at least S$5.07 million in claims related to subcontracting works for a heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, and refrigeration system. The works were for the design, supply, and installation of the system, with Viking HVAC being the subcontractor. Additionally, Viking is claiming damages for the prolongation of the contract period. This dispute is the latest in a legal spat between the two companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce on easing trade war worries; NZ rises too
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by a surge in base metal and oil prices, as trade war fears eased following reports of US and China's willingness to renegotiate tariffs and trade imbalances. This follows a 2% slide on Friday and a 0.5% drop on Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks jump as fears ease on trade, Japan scandal
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 2.65% and 2.74% on Tuesday, driven by easing fears of a global trade war and a lack of damaging revelations from testimony about a cronyism scandal affecting Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,317.32, while the Topix index rose to 1,717.13. Investors were encouraged by rallies in US stocks and a cap on the yen, and analysts attributed the market's buoyancy to relief that the testimony revealed little that would harm Abe. Key stocks such as Toyota, Nissan, and Panasonic also gained.

site_title: Brookfield property to buy rest of US mall owner GGP
summary: Brookfield Property Partners LP agreed to buy the remaining shares of GGP Inc, gaining full control of the second-largest US mall owner. The deal, valued at $15 billion, offers GGP shareholders $23.50 per share in cash or a combination of Brookfield units and shares of a new real estate investment trust. The acquisition comes amid the retail industry's struggles with e-commerce, with Brookfield focusing on revamping shopping centers to capitalize on urban land.

site_title: A*Star to take new approach to managing R&D activities
summary: A*Star to overhaul research management, introducing a new system that assesses research activities differently. The new approach will evaluate upstream research based on publication metrics and industry-oriented projects on industry collaboration. Upstream research activities and multidisciplinary programmes will be funded through competitive merit-based funding, starting from April 1. The changes will not affect existing programmes and will categorize research units into five constructs: technology centres, research institutes, knowledge creation activities, programmes, and national platforms.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Indonesia Q1 GDP growth seen at 5.1% y-o-y: Center bank deputy governor
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to grow 5.1% in the first quarter of 2018, according to Bank Indonesia deputy governor Mirza Adityaswara. The country's trade deficit in January-February was due to rising imports of raw materials and intermediary goods. Bank Indonesia maintained its policy rate unchanged, citing sufficient support for the economy. The central bank's 2018 growth outlook is 5.1-5.5%. This growth rate is slightly lower than the 5.19% expansion in the last three months of 2017.

site_title: US Republicans press for F-35 fighter jet sale to Taiwan
summary: US Republicans have urged President Trump to allow the sale of Lockheed Martin's F-35 fighter jets to Taiwan, citing the need for the island to defend itself against China's aggressive military posture. The proposed sale could increase tensions with Beijing, which has already expressed outrage over US legislation encouraging senior officials to meet Taiwanese counterparts. The move is part of the US military's new national defence strategy, which prioritizes countering China and Russia.

site_title: Two Indonesian state firms to raise 8t rupiah by selling private equity funds
summary: Indonesian state firms PT Waskita Karya and PT Jasa Marga plan to sell private equity funds worth 8 trillion rupiah (S$762.8 million) to strengthen their finances. The move comes amid concerns over the balance sheets of state-owned enterprises (SOEs) involved in large-scale infrastructure projects. Some pension funds have expressed interest in investing, and the funds will be used to support ongoing infrastructure projects. This is part of the government's economic agenda, with infrastructure development being a core focus.

site_title: Troubled China conglomerate said to put all properties on block
summary: CEFC China Energy Co, a troubled Chinese conglomerate, plans to sell its entire global property portfolio worth over 20 billion yuan (S$4.17 billion), including office buildings, hotels, and residential apartments. Almost 100 projects are up for sale, mostly in big Chinese cities and Europe. The sale comes after the Shanghai government took control of the firm and creditors formed a committee to review asset disposals. This move follows other Chinese conglomerates, such as HNA Group Co and Anbang Insurance Group Co, selling holdings after coming under scrutiny.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.8% higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index up 26.35 points to 3,438.81, following gains on Wall Street as trade tensions eased. About 86 million shares changed hands, with HLH Group rising S$0.002 to S$0.007. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all rose, while regional markets such as Japan's Topix, Australia's S&P/ASX 200, and South Korea's Kospi index also increased.

site_title: AEM's shareholder Orion Phoenix distributes 8.7m shares in specie to limited partners
summary: AEM Holdings' largest shareholder, Orion Phoenix, distributed approximately 8.7 million shares to 13 limited partners, reducing its stake to around 4.28%. This move was seen as a demonstration of confidence in AEM's potential and business outlook. As a result, James Toh Ban Leng, co-founder of New Earth Group, became the single largest shareholder with a 7.75% stake, while Loke Wai San, executive chairman, retained a 1.99% stake. Both Toh and Loke have committed to holding onto their shares in the near future.

site_title: SIA starts work on new concepts for its Boeing 777-9s
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has begun conceptualizing new cabin products for its upcoming Boeing 777-9s, with CEO Goh Choon Phong promising a "new First Class" that will set an industry standard. The airline has ordered 20 777-9s, primarily replacing 777-300ERs, with deliveries starting from FY2021/2022. SIA has also rolled out a revamped regional business class on its 787-10 aircraft, which will be deployed to Asia-Pacific routes and expected to increase capacity and fuel efficiency. The airline believes sufficient demand will absorb the capacity increase.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: GIC-backed Indian lender makes market debut at 33% premium
summary: Bandhan Bank, a Kolkata-based private lender, made its market debut at a 33% premium to the issue price of 375 rupees, trading at 472.25 rupees. The bank counts Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC as an investor, with GIC affiliate Caladium holding a 16.7% stake. GIC's chief investment officer expressed confidence in Bandhan's growth potential, citing its vision to be an inclusive, world-class bank serving under-banked markets in India.

site_title: Financial industry body presses China to further reform capital markets
summary: China needs to further open its capital markets and create a level playing field for foreign investors, according to Asia Securities Industry & Financial Markets Association (ASIFMA) CEO Mark Austen. ASIFMA's White Paper suggests policy changes, including loosening investment quotas and repatriation limits, breaking up Beijing's monopoly on forex trading platforms, and introducing more shorting activities. The planned inclusion of China's "A-shares" into the MSCI emerging market index this year is seen as a catalyst for further reforms, bringing additional money and foreign appetite for China.

site_title: Singapore biopharma firm ASLAN files for listing on Nasdaq
summary: Singapore-based biopharma firm ASLAN Pharmaceuticals has filed for a proposed initial public offering (IPO) on the US stock market, specifically on the Nasdaq. ASLAN, which develops drugs for cancer types common in Asia, has been listed on the Taipei Exchange since 2017. The company's IPO filing was made with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, with Leerink Partners and Piper Jaffray & Co as joint book-running managers. Details on the number of ADSs to be offered and the price range are yet to be determined.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.71 points to 1,862.62. Volume was 65.28 million lots worth RM28.21 million, with 198 gainers outnumbering 41 losers.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as trade war fears ease;NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 5,824.6, tracking a surge in US stocks, as reports of US-China trade talks raised hopes of avoiding a destructive trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average posted its third-biggest point gain ever. Australian financials and materials stocks led the rally, with Commonwealth Bank and BHP rising 0.7% and 0.5% respectively. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.8% to 8,500.91.

site_title: Singapore shares enter Tuesday afternoon trade on higher ground; STI up 0.6% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 19.67 points to 3,432.13. The index saw a marginal increase of 1.26 points before the midday break, with 638.6 million shares worth S$603.5 million traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 205 to 132, with active stocks including OCBC Bank and DBS.

site_title: Sweden finds holes in its world-beating bank rules
summary: Sweden's mortgage market is being disrupted by a startup, Enkla, which offers lower interest rates and more transparent loan terms than traditional banks. Enkla, licensed to operate in Sweden, will not be subject to the same regulations as banks until 2019 and will allow borrowers to avoid amortisation requirements. Analysts predict Enkla could capture 3.5% of Sweden's mortgage market, threatening the dominance of four banks that control 75% of the market. The startup aims to be a "responsible disrupter" and deliver higher yields at a lower risk, potentially forcing traditional banks to adapt to new funding models.

site_title: GM says South Korean unit will file for bankruptcy if no union concessions by April 20
summary: General Motors (GM) warned its South Korean unit, GM Korea, will file for bankruptcy if the union does not agree to cut labor costs by April 20. The automaker needs $600 million in operating funds by the end of April to present a turnaround plan to the government. GM Korea, which employs nearly 16,000 people, is facing a cash crisis and has applied for redundancy packages for around 2,500 workers. The union has agreed not to demand a pay rise this year, but wants a future production plan and job security.

site_title: DBS looking to hire 100 techies, again via hackathon
summary: DBS is reviving its Hack2Hire program, aiming to recruit up to 100 tech talent with a wider range of skillsets, including scrum masters, UI designers, and solution architects. The program consists of an online technical assessment and a hackathon session, with successful candidates offered a job on the same day. This is a significant expansion from last year's recruitment of developers, data scientists, and system engineers.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: SMRT's 2017 after-tax profit sinks 68% to S$26m
summary: SMRT Corp, a Temasek-owned rail operator, reported a 68% drop in its 2017 after-tax profit to S$26 million, possibly a two-decade low. Revenue declined 2.4% to S$791 million, while operating expenses rose 6.9% due to higher maintenance costs. Despite a 2% increase in ridership, the company aims to improve rail reliability on its key lines, aiming for one delay per 300,000km.

site_title: 3 Michelin-starred 'Demon Chef' Alvin Leung to open Forbidden Duck in Singapore
summary: Three Michelin-starred chef Alvin Leung, known as the "Demon Chef," is set to open his Cantonese restaurant Forbidden Duck in Singapore by April 2018. Leung, 57, will serve signature Peking-style and slow-cooked roast duck alongside classic Cantonese fare and dim sum at Marina Bay Financial Centre. This marks the chef's first restaurant in Singapore, following openings in Hong Kong and the UK. Leung, a self-taught chef, is known for his unique cooking style and has previously opened other restaurants, including Forbidden Duck in Hong Kong and Plato 86 in Wan Chai.

site_title: Asia: Markets surge on receding trade war fears, 'Kim visit'
summary: Asian markets surged on Tuesday as fears of a US-China trade war receded, with the Dow and S&P 500 rising almost 3% and the Nasdaq 3.3%. Speculation about a secret visit by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to Beijing also lifted spirits, boosting the South Korean won. Markets continued their gains as high-level talks between the US and China aimed to find an agreement, with analysts predicting a possible nuclear deal with Donald Trump.

site_title: Foxconn unit buys Belkin for US$886m in push into brands
summary: Foxconn's unit, FIT Hon Teng Ltd, agreed to buy Belkin International Inc for US$886 million, expanding into branded goods. Belkin, a maker of Wi-Fi routers and mobile device chargers, owns over 700 patents. The deal gives FIT access to strong research and development capacity, as billionaire Terry Gou seeks to capture more of the value chain in branded goods. This is the latest move by Gou, who also led a deal for control of Japan's Sharp Corp in 2016 and is investing in artificial intelligence and big data.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won rebound on easing US-China trade tensions
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 11.56 points, or 0.47%, to 2,449.63, following overnight gains on Wall Street. The Korean won and bond yields also rose, driven by rekindled hopes of easing US-China trade tensions. The won was quoted at 1,074.8 per dollar, 0.59% firmer than its previous close. The positive market trend was seen as a result of traders brushing off new Trump threats, which extended the stocks rally.

site_title: GM Korea threatens bankruptcy unless revival plan gets support
summary: General Motors Co. is threatening to file for bankruptcy of its South Korean unit unless a revival plan gets union support within four weeks. The company needs employees' support by the end of March, with a deadline to submit a turnaround proposal to the government on April 20. GM is seeking concessions from the union to revive its South Korean business, which has been hurt by mounting losses. The company will file for bankruptcy if its plan doesn't get union support, and will make $600 million in payments to vendors and employees if the plan is approved.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co said it intends to file its South Korean unit for bankruptcy if its labour union fails to agree on a restructuring plan that needs to be outlined within the next four weeks, putting pressure on employees and the government to help it stay afloat in the country.

site_title: JTC launches 2 sites under Industrial Government Land Sales Programme
summary: JTC Corporation launched two industrial sites under the Industrial Government Land Sales Programme for the first half 2018. The 0.88-hectare site at Woodlands Industrial Park E7/E8 is zoned for Business-2 development and has a 20-year tenure. The 0.45-hectare site at Tuas South Link 3 (Plot 19) is also available for sale. Both sites are expected to close tender on May 22.

site_title: Acromec unit eyes renewable energy, inks MOU to build waste-to-energy plant
summary: Acromec's subsidiary, Acropower, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with HL Plus to build a waste-to-energy plant on a future poultry farm site in Neo Tiew Road, Singapore. The plant will convert organic waste, including 70 tonnes of chicken manure daily, into biogas to generate electricity. Acropower will build, own, and operate the plant at its own costs, and HL Plus will acquire Chew's Agriculture, which will provide the waste for the plant. The deal is part of Acromec's renewable energy strategy, which aims to replicate the model across Singapore and the region.

site_title: World's most valuable distiller tends to underplay heady growth
summary: Kweichow Moutai Co, the world's most valuable distiller, is likely to report revenue growth significantly higher than its forecast for the second consecutive year. Analysts estimate revenue will jump 53-59.5 billion yuan (S$12.4 billion) in 2017, surpassing the company's 15% forecast. This trend is unusual, with the company's previous forecasts consistently being exceeded. Moutai's growth is attributed to its popular liquor finding widespread popularity among China's middle class.

site_title: Deutsche Bank seeks to replace CEO with Goldman executive: report
summary: Deutsche Bank is reportedly seeking to replace CEO John Cryan amid a boardroom dispute over the bank's future, with Goldman Sachs executive Richard Gnodde being considered for the role. Gnodde, a vice-chairman at Goldman Sachs, has allegedly been approached but turned down the proposal. Other potential replacements include Jean Pierre Mustier and Bill Winter. The move comes after Deutsche Bank warned of costs for 2018 and announced a bonus pool of over 2 billion euros to retain staff during a major overhaul.

site_title: Arizona governor suspends Uber's ability to test self-driving cars
summary: Arizona Governor Doug Ducey suspended Uber's ability to test self-driving cars on public roads following a fatal pedestrian crash last week. The crash, which killed a 49-year-old woman, was deemed "disturbing and alarming" by the governor. This decision marks a setback for Uber's autonomous vehicle testing in the state, which had been a prime testing ground due to Arizona's open roads and favorable regulatory environment. The suspension comes after Governor Ducey welcomed Uber to the state in 2016.

site_title: China's January-February industrial profit growth strong, but pace slows from 2017
summary: China's industrial profit growth picked up pace in January-February, rising 16.1% year-on-year to 968.9 billion yuan, but still fell short of the 2017 average. This slowdown may deter investment and pressure China's stock markets, which have been affected by trade war fears with the US. Weaker earnings growth also complicates Beijing's debt reduction efforts, with liabilities increasing 6% year-on-year. Despite this, analysts expect industrial profits to achieve double-digit growth for the rest of the year.

site_title: MMP Resources responds to SGX on fiscal 2017 results
summary: MMP Resources has responded to the Singapore Exchange's queries about its FY2017 results, citing a revenue disparity between the full year and the nine months ended Sept 30, 2017. The company attributed the difference to the classification of earnings from its ski operations business as "other income." MMP also disclosed the completion of two retail and food and beverage businesses, but clarified that this was announced in its half-year results. The company's administrative expenses increased, and it disclosed a loan to Alliance Brands Limited for its subsidiary Operation Alliance Global Limited.

site_title: White House investigating loans to Kushner's business, says official
summary: The White House is investigating loans totaling over $500 million to Jared Kushner's family real estate business, potentially violating criminal laws or regulations. The loans, extended by Citigroup and Apollo Global Management in 2017, raise serious ethical questions. Kushner, a senior adviser to President Trump, previously resigned from his business and sold his stake in a family trust to avoid conflicts of interest. The Office of Government Ethics has begun the process to determine if any laws or regulations were violated, following a report by The New York Times.

site_title: US regulator, state attorneys look for answers from Facebook
summary: US regulators, including the Federal Trade Commission, have opened an investigation into Facebook's handling of user data, which was accessed by Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy. The company has faced pressure from state attorneys, lawmakers, and advertisers, who are demanding answers and greater transparency. Facebook shares have fallen 13% since the scandal was revealed, and the company has lost over $70 billion in market value. The FTC investigation could result in fines of thousands of dollars per day, and lawmakers are calling for Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to testify at a congressional hearing.

site_title: Aspial invites holders of S$100m 2018 5.5% notes to exchange for new notes
summary: Aspial Corporation invites holders of its S$100m 2018 5.5% notes to exchange existing notes for new notes with a higher interest rate of 5.9% per annum, payable semi-annually. The company offers a one-time fee of 0.5% or 0.25% for early exchange submissions by April 9 or 13, respectively. The new notes will be fungible and consolidate into the same series, with additional notes to be issued for sale to investors subject to market conditions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on easing trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday as concerns over a possible global trade war eased, following a rally on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.91%, while the broader Topix index rose 0.91%. The gains were attributed to easing trade war fears, despite US President Trump's recent threats.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Datapulse, Tan Chong International, Ho Bee Land
summary: Datapulse Technology's directors assured minority shareholders of good governance as the company seeks corporate recovery through diversification. The company holds an EGM on April 20 and has a net cash position of S$87.1 million. Tan Chong International recorded a 163% jump in profit to HK$501.92 million, despite a 5.3% drop in revenue. Ho Bee Land agreed to invest up to S$64.8 million in a European property fund and will consider an additional S$50 million investment.

site_title: Total tab for Mandarin Gardens could hit S$4b
summary: The Mandarin Gardens condominium in Singapore could sell for up to S$4 billion if a successful buyer tops up the lease and pays a differential premium. The asking price is S$2.48 billion, and owners approved a collective sales agreement. A consortium of developers is expected to bid on the land, which includes a S$325.4 million top-up for a fresh lease and an estimated S$1.28 billion differential premium. The sale would break the record for the largest en bloc sale in Singapore by dollar value.

site_title: Datapulse 'committed' to good governance amid diversification plans, say directors
summary: Datapulse Technology directors have assured minority shareholders that the board is committed to good governance despite plans to diversify from its loss-making media storage business. The company aims to use its acquisition of Wayco as a platform to enter the hair-care products market through distribution, direct sales, and marketing. Following the sale of its Tai Seng factory, the business is dormant, and the company has a net cash position of S$87.1 million. An extraordinary general meeting will be held on April 20 to vote on the proposed diversification and changes to the board.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.43% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of an averted US-China trade war. The Hang Seng Index rose 436.98 points to 30,985.75, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. The news of talks between the two sides lifted market sentiment, leading to strong gains in Asian markets.

site_title: McCain to release 'no-holds-barred' verdict on Trump
summary: Veteran US Senator John McCain is set to release a new memoir, delivering a "no-holds-barred" verdict on President Donald Trump's presidency. Despite being a Republican, McCain has been a vocal critic of Trump, questioning the nomination of a CIA official involved in torture. McCain has continued to voice his concerns about Trump's leadership, despite undergoing treatment for brain cancer since last summer. The memoir is expected to provide a candid assessment of McCain's experiences with Trump.

site_title: ComfortDelGro tells its cabbies to delete Uber app
summary: ComfortDelGro, a taxi giant, has instructed its 23,000 drivers to delete the Uber app due to the sale of its South-east Asian business to Grab. The move comes as Uber exited the region. Drivers are concerned about their livelihoods and lack of notice from ComfortDelGro, with some expressing uncertainty about using the rival JustGrab app. The National Taxi Association and the National Private Hire Vehicles Association have conveyed drivers' concerns to the Land Transport Authority and the Competition Commission of Singapore.

site_title: Novartis chief aims to double China sales on faster drug approvals
summary: Novartis CEO Vas Narasimhan aims to double the company's sales in China over the next five years, driven by faster approvals for cutting-edge cancer drugs. The company hopes to win a "couple" of approvals in 2018 and has already secured agreements for eight of its drugs. China's regulatory overhaul has opened the market to breakthrough therapies, providing a boost to foreign companies like Novartis. The company plans to include China in all late-stage trials, with annual sales now accounting for about $2 billion.

site_title: Guo Shuqing named central bank's Party chief and vice-governor
summary: China's Guo Shuqing has been appointed as both the Communist Party chief and deputy governor of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), a dual role considered unusual in the country. This appointment allows Guo to coordinate policymaking and implementation between the PBOC and the newly established China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission. The move is seen as a key step in advancing Beijing's financial reforms and ensuring the central bank's alignment with the Communist Party's agenda, under the guidance of President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Brexit campaigners breached UK vote rules, lawyers say
summary: Brexit campaigners, Vote Leave, allegedly breached UK vote rules by channeling £625,000 to a data analysis firm to mask a payment to Canadian firm AIQ, according to a 50-page document by lawyers Bindmans. The case centers on a £2.7 million payment by Vote Leave to AIQ, which lawyers argue was made to mask the donation. The case requires an urgent investigation to determine if it should be referred to state prosecutors, with top Vote Leave figures potentially implicated.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as euro surge, Russian tensions weigh
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Monday, their lowest level since February 2017, as a surge in the euro and diplomatic tensions with Russia offset hopes for a more selective US trade policy. The US expels 60 Russian diplomats, joining European countries punishing Russia for a nerve agent attack. Stocks exposed to Russia were mixed, while Italian bond yields rose due to political uncertainty.

site_title: Australian premier Turnbull's political survival will depend on domestic issues
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's political survival is uncertain, largely due to domestic issues. His government faces economic headwinds, including stagnant growth, infrastructure problems, and sliding living standards. The government's proposed business tax cut is also a contentious issue, with economists debating its potential impact. Turnbull's personal scandals, including his former deputy Barnaby Joyce's controversies, continue to weigh on his administration. With a one-seat majority, Turnbull's hold on power is precarious, and domestic matters are likely to be key to his survival.

site_title: Changi Airport's passenger traffic in February up 5.6% on CNY boost
summary: Changi Airport reported a 5.6% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in February, driven by the Chinese New Year break. The airport handled 4.93 million passengers, with travel to and from South-east Asia and North-east Asia accounting for over half of the growth. Airfreight throughput remained stable at 1.4%. Changi Airport Group attributed the growth to strong demand from top markets like China and India.

images.alt_text: Changi Airport handled 4.93 million passengers in February, a 5.6 per cent year-on-year increase.

site_title: US: Stocks rally as trade war fears recede; Dow +2.8%
summary: US stocks surged on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 2.8% to 24,202.60, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 2.7% and 3.3%, respectively. The rally followed a Wall Street Journal report suggesting that the US and China are in talks to resolve the trade conflict, with President Trump unveiling tariffs on up to $60 billion of Chinese imports last week. Investors are optimistic about negotiations behind the scenes, with tech shares leading the gains.

site_title: Abe 'not involved' in doctoring documents: key official
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's office was not involved in falsifying documents related to a land sale scandal, according to a key official's parliamentary testimony. Finance Ministry official Nobuhisa Sagawa said only his office altered key documents, and no one, including Abe, his cabinet secretary, or finance minister, ordered the changes. The scandal surrounds the 2016 sale of state-owned land to a nationalist school operator, which has eroded Abe's popularity, with public support plummeting by double digits amid opposition calls for his resignation.

site_title: Buyout group holds 80.9% stake in LTC Corporation
summary: A buyout group, Mountbatten Enterprises, acquired 126.6 million shares, representing 80.9% of LTC Corporation, in a voluntary cash offer. The offer price is S$0.925 per share, a 44.5% premium over the stock's last close. The proposed takeover is conditional on receiving acceptances that would result in the group holding at least 90% of issued shares, but the condition can be reduced to more than 50% if necessary. LTC Corporation's shares closed 0.5% higher at S$0.92 per share on Monday.

site_title: Beijing fest pulls award-winning gay film amid content squeeze
summary: The Beijing International Film Festival has pulled award-winning gay romance film "Call Me By Your Name" from its program, reportedly due to China's complex relationship with gay themes.
