This comes after US President Donald Trump announced plans for tariffs on up to $60 billion of Chinese goods, prompting China to declare plans to levy additional duties on US imports. The US claims China engages in unfair trade practices, including forcing American investors to turn over key technologies. China has defended its interests, citing US flouting of trade rules.

site_title: One of America's oldest gun makers Remington files for bankruptcy
summary: Remington Outdoor Co Inc, one of America's oldest gun makers, filed for bankruptcy protection, listing assets of $500-1 billion and liabilities of $500-1 billion. The company aims to reduce its $950 million debtload through a debt-cutting deal with creditors. The move comes amid mounting public pressure for greater gun control. Remington announced the deal in February, which will transfer control of the company to creditors, following a deal that will transfer control of the company to creditors.

site_title: TPG Is said to near deal for US$1.1b Indian hospital chain Fortis
summary: A consortium led by TPG is nearing a deal to gain control of Fortis Healthcare, India's second-largest private hospital chain, for US$1.1 billion. The consortium, also including Manipal Health Enterprises, will issue new stock to TPG and Manipal, making them the largest shareholders. The deal is conditional on approval from the Competition Commission of India and could value SRL, a medical diagnostics provider, at 34-40 billion rupees. The acquisition comes amid allegations of financial irregularities against Fortis' founders and could be used to fund debt repayment and the purchase of RHT Health Trust's assets.

site_title: Doing business in a geo-protectionist environment
summary: Singapore companies can combat rising economic nationalist tendencies when expanding abroad by prioritizing collaborations with open countries, targeting strategic assets, and implementing flexible internationalization strategies. Experts recommend focusing on value-added services, leveraging free trade agreements, and fostering innovation to stay competitive. Companies should also consider alternative strategies such as joint ventures, local subsidiaries, and diversifying expansion outside of the US and China. By adopting these approaches, Singapore businesses can navigate the increasingly protectionist environment and capitalize on emerging opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Rowsley inks S$130m credit facility agreement
summary: Rowsley Ltd has entered into a S$130 million credit facility agreement with Malayan Banking Berhad, Singapore Branch. The agreement includes a S$100 million 18-month term loan and a S$30 million revolving loan. The term loan will be used to redeem S$100 million of outstanding notes, which will be canceled upon redemption. This move is expected to eliminate the company's outstanding debt.

site_title: ETF investors outsmart hedge funds that miss out as gold rebounds
summary: Hedge funds failed to predict a gold price rebound as trade tensions between the US and China led to a 3.3% jump in gold futures. ETF investors, however, successfully anticipated the move, boosting their gold holdings to nearly five-year highs. The outperformance of ETF investors highlights their focus on market sentiment and geopolitical news, rather than traditional economic indicators. Gold prices have jumped 28% since 2015, defying conventional wisdom that rising interest rates should decrease demand for the metal.

site_title: HLH to sell hotel in Cambodia mixed-use project for S$15.7m
summary: HLH Group Limited has entered into a sales and purchase agreement to sell its 98-room hotel in Cambodia's D'Seaview project for S$15.7 million. The project, a mixed-use development, consists of 737 residential units and 67 commercial units, including a boutique hotel. The sale is part of the group's efforts to focus on its core businesses.

site_title: Brexit delivers longer blow to bank sentiment than global crisis: survey
summary: A survey by the CBI and PwC found that Brexit has had a longer-lasting negative impact on the UK's finance industry than the global financial crisis, with optimism dropping to levels not seen since 2007-9. Despite growth in business volumes and employment, firms are concerned about the sector's future, particularly the uncertainty of London's access to EU markets after Brexit. The survey's measure of optimism was -17% in January-March, the lowest since the financial crisis, and marked the eighth quarter of falling optimism in the last nine quarters.

images.alt_text: The prospect of quitting the EU has hurt sentiment in Britain's finance industry for longer than the global financial crisis that plunged economies into recession and destroyed some of the world's biggest banks, a survey found on Monday.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia shakes up executive team amid inquiry
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia announced changes to its senior executive team amid an ongoing judicial inquiry into money laundering allegations. Melanie Laing, Kelly Bayer Rosmarin, and David Whiteing will depart in the coming months. The changes come ahead of Matt Comyn taking over as CEO in April, replacing Ian Narev who stepped down last August following a money-laundering lawsuit. The bank's shares were 0.8% lower on the announcement, as the finance sector faces intense scrutiny following years of scandals.

site_title: Former Catalan leader Puigdemont detained by German police
summary: Former Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont was detained by German police on March 25, 2018, while attempting to return to Belgium from Denmark. He faces charges of rebellion in Spain for his role in declaring independence and will have an initial court hearing on Monday. The detention brings his eventual return to Spain to face trial a step nearer, with German authorities stating they will apply the rules. The move has been welcomed by pro-Spain party Ciudadanos and criticized by separatist leaders, who claim Spain is seeking revenge and repression.

site_title: Noble directors say proposed restructuring will result in 'fair and equitable treatment of all shareholders'
summary: NOBLE Group Limited has proposed a restructuring plan, supported by its board of directors, which aims to provide a "fair and equitable treatment of all shareholders". If shareholders approve the primary restructuring, the company will issue shares to those who vote in favor. However, if not, the alternative restructuring will involve selling assets to a new Noble entity and issuing shares to consenting shareholders. The company has chosen to implement the alternative restructuring in the UK due to cost and process advantages.

site_title: Chinese airlines tipped for record profits on tourism boom, yuan gains
summary: China's three largest airlines, China Southern, Air China, and China Eastern, are expected to report record profits this week due to a tourism boom and foreign exchange gains. The airlines saw a 12.8% increase in domestic trips and 5.7% growth in overseas trips in 2017. Foreign exchange gains of about 10% against the US dollar since 2017 have also contributed to the profit growth. Analysts expect China Southern to report a 6.4 billion yuan net income, its highest in 11 years, and Air China to report its biggest profit since 2010.

images.alt_text: Analysts estimate China Southern Airlines, the country's largest carrier by passenger numbers, will report net income on Monday of about 6.4 billion yuan (S$1.33 billion), its highest in 11 years as a listed firm, showed data from Thomson Reuters.

site_title: Annica to acquire stake in new owner of waste tyre pyrolysis plant in Malaysia
summary: Annica Holdings has entered into a non-binding MOU to acquire a 25.79% stake in Green Pluslink Sdn Bhd, the new owner of a waste tyre pyrolysis plant in Malaysia. Annica will pay up to S$4.2 million for the shares in a mix of ordinary shares and promissory notes. This deal continues Annica's corporate strategy to diversify into recycling, renewable, and green technology. The acquisition is expected to relocate GPL's production lines to achieve better economies of scale.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Rowsley, HLH Group, Far East Group
summary: Noble Group's board of directors approved a restructuring plan, which may impact shareholder treatment. Rowsley secured S$130 million in new credit facilities to redeem debt. HLH Group sold a hotel in Cambodia for S$15.7 million. Far East Group is disposing of a property for about S$27 million to utilize net proceeds for working capital and future investments.

site_title: Sinopec to pay record dividend as refining pushes up profit
summary: Sinopec, China's largest refiner, announced a record-high dividend payout of 0.5 yuan per share for 2017, a 10% increase in full-year profit. The company's refining and chemicals segments drove the profit increase, despite oil's volatility. Sinopec's upstream assets suffered impairments of 22 billion yuan, but the company aims to shift focus towards natural gas production to support President Xi Jinping's drive towards cleaner energy. The company's shares fell 2.2% despite the profit increase.

site_title: China's first ever yuan oil futures begin trading in Shanghai
summary: China launched its first yuan-denominated oil futures contract on the Shanghai International Energy Exchange, trading at 440.20 yuan a barrel. This move aims to challenge US and European benchmarks and grant China greater pricing power. The contracts, open to foreign investors, end years of delays since China's first attempt in 1993. The launch marks a significant step for China's energy market, allowing it to wield more influence in global oil pricing.

site_title: Airport builder Limak Investments revives IPO plan
summary: Limak Investments, a Turkish conglomerate building Istanbul's new six-runway airport, is reviving its initial public offering (IPO) plan. The company, which has 65,000 employees and operations in 17 countries, is considering an IPO later this year or next amid a boom in Turkish share sales. Limak's airport project in Istanbul will have an initial capacity of 90 million passengers and is expected to be one of the largest in the world. No advisers have been chosen for the IPO yet, with the company's chairwoman Ebru Özdemir stating that all its companies are ready for the sale.

site_title: Prague pedestrians tread unaware on Jewish graves
summary: Thousands of pedestrians daily unknowingly walk across a pavement in Prague's Wenceslas Square made from tombstones taken from a derelict Jewish cemetery. The Communist-era pavement, built in 1985, features blue-grey stones with Hebrew inscriptions, a legacy of the regime's anti-Semitic policies. Despite repeated complaints from Jewish representatives, authorities have failed to address the issue, with some residents showing indifference to the historical significance of the stones.

site_title: Boeing completes Dreamliner family with first 787-10 delivery to Singapore Airlines
summary: Boeing completed the Dreamliner family with the delivery of its first 787-10 to Singapore Airlines on March 25, 2018. The aircraft, valued at $326 million, is 68 meters long and seats 330 passengers, making it the largest in the family. The delivery marks the end of a family of lightweight jets that Boeing is betting on for its future. The 787-10 is built exclusively at Boeing's North Charleston plant and competes with Airbus's A330neo in the market for mid-size wide-body planes.

site_title: Uber to sell S-E Asian ops to Grab: sources
summary: Uber Technologies Inc has agreed to sell its Southeast Asian ride-hailing business, including Uber Eats, to rival Grab, with Uber retaining a stake of 25-30% in the new combined business. This marks Uber's operational exit from the region. The deal, expected to be announced in Singapore, cements Uber's withdrawal from a major market.

site_title: Singapore Airlines looking to deploy new Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner on Nagoya, Fukuoka flights
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to deploy its new Boeing 787-10 Dreamliner on flights to Nagoya and Fukuoka, Japan, following its delivery on Sunday. The airline will operate the plane from May, replacing its Airbus A330-300 on the routes. The 787-10 can carry 14% more passengers than the earlier variant and features the airline's new regional cabin products. The airline will initially use the plane on selected Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur flights for crew training before introducing regular services to Perth and Osaka.

site_title: Facebook's grip on political ads may defy stain of data leak
summary: Facebook's campaign ad spending is expected to rise to an estimated $600 million in the US this year, with the platform accounting for three-fifths of digital ad spending. Despite data breaches and scrutiny over Russian election meddling, Facebook's grip on political ads is unlikely to weaken, with consultants predicting that advertisers will continue to target voters on the platform. The company has pledged to increase transparency, including requiring advertisers to disclose their identities, but lawmakers and regulators remain concerned about the lack of oversight in online ad buying.

site_title: Qantas sets aviation milestone as Perth flight lands in London
summary: Qantas has successfully launched the world's first non-stop passenger service between Australia and London, reducing travel time from 12 1/2 days to 17 hours. The direct flight from Perth to London marks a major milestone for the airline and paves the way for longer routes to Europe. Business travelers are expected to drive demand for the shorter flight, with mining companies and financial services firms already booking seats. While challenges remain, Qantas aims to capitalize on the route's potential by offering premium services.

site_title: Singapore pharma on recovery path after worst output in decades
summary: Singapore's pharmaceutical sector is expected to recover in 2018, driven by increased output from major global drugmakers and advancements in automation. The sector, which accounts for 3% of Singapore's GDP, is forecast to experience a "robust" year, according to the Economic Development Board. The sector's output dropped 15.6% in 2017, the largest annual contraction since 1993, but is expected to rebound as new facilities and technologies are introduced. The recovery is seen as a positive factor for Singapore's economic growth, with the sector expected to remain robust for the next few years.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen remains high
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.87% due to a high yen against the US dollar amid fears of a global trade war. Investors also monitored a cronyism scandal involving Japan's premier. The broader Topix index edged down 0.7%. The yen's value was influenced by US President Trump's threats to extend a trade war, despite US stocks reaching fresh records.

site_title: Thai politics: No country for young men?
summary: A Thai billionaire, Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, has launched a new party, Future Forward, to appeal to the youth vote in an election expected in 2019. However, he faces significant obstacles due to unfavourable election laws and government attitude. Despite this, he remains hopeful, saying "a little hope is better than no hope at all." His party's emergence coincides with the junta's registration of parties ahead of the election, and analysts note that political success in Thailand depends on appeasing the military and royalist elite.

site_title: Changi helps youths spread their wings
summary: Changi Airport's philanthropic arm, Changi Foundation, focuses on community development through various initiatives. The airport views itself not just as a travel hub but as a place for community gathering. Changi Foundation aims to spread its impact to youths, providing opportunities for them to develop their skills and grow. The airport's corporate giving efforts demonstrate its commitment to the local community and its role as a hub for social development.

site_title: Singapore startup rings up GST refunds on mobile
summary: A Singapore startup, Tourego, has launched the world's first fully-mobile tax refund solution, allowing travellers to claim Goods and Service Tax (GST) refunds using their phones. The app, available on both Android and iOS systems, is currently for use only in Singapore and has attracted a number of investors. The company aims to double the number of retailers and downloads in the coming months, but faces competition from larger tax refund operators. Despite this, Tourego welcomes the innovations brought by its competitors and plans to introduce the app in other countries within a year.

images.alt_text: Tourego lets travellers to Singapore claim GST refunds with their phones. It is exploring ways to eliminate queuing at airport refund kiosks.

site_title: Caution the watchword as US-China trade tensions hang over MAS policy
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority is expected to tighten monetary policy in April, but may hold back if the risk of "tit-for-tat protectionism" intensifies between the US and China. The country's central bank uses the exchange rate as its main tool to balance inflation and economic growth. Rising trade tensions have shifted the needle, with economists warning that a full-blown trade war could defer policy normalization. Economists expect a gradual tightening of policy, but caution against a more aggressive approach given the potential impact on Singapore's small, open economy.

site_title: Bullish equity trend intact unless consumer sentiment falls sharply
summary: The US equity market remains bullish despite recent trade war-related sell-downs, as consumer sentiment remains at a multi-decade high. The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index has been rising firmly since 2011, mirroring the S&P 500 index's record high. As long as the index stays above its multi-year uptrend line, the market is expected to continue ascending. However, a sharp reversal in the index below 116 would signal a bearish trend, and a drop in the index below the 200-day moving average at 2,600 points would be a key level to watch for a rebound.

site_title: 315 units of CDL's new project The Tapestry sold at launch
summary: CDL's new project, The Tapestry, saw 315 units (70% of 450 units) sold at launch, with an average price per square foot of S$1,310. The property, comprising 861 units, features various unit sizes and prices ranging from S$596,000 to S$2.1 million. The remaining 411 units will be released progressively, with completion expected in 2021. The majority of buyers (76%) are Singaporeans, while 24% are Permanent Residents and foreigners.

site_title: Ride-hailing apps run Indonesian tuk-tuks off road
summary: US-based ride-hailing apps Uber, Google-backed Go-Jek, and Singapore's Grab are dominating Indonesia's ride-hailing market, displacing traditional three-wheeled bajaj taxis. Auto-rickshaw driver Zainuddin, who once made a decent income, now faces financial struggles due to the rise of these apps. The competition has significantly impacted the bajaj taxi industry, leading to a decline in their fortunes.

site_title: John Williams seen as top candidate for president of New York Fed: sources
summary: John Williams, 55, an economist and Federal Reserve official, is a top candidate for president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to sources. If appointed, he would succeed William Dudley, who is set to retire this summer. Williams' selection is not final and must be approved by the Fed's Board of Governors in Washington. His regulatory record will be scrutinized, particularly given the New York Fed's role in Wall Street oversight.

site_title: Shenhua profit rises to five-year high as China curbs boost coal
summary: Shenhua Energy Co, China's largest coal miner, reported a five-year high profit of 47.8 billion yuan in 2017, driven by robust demand and government efforts to curb overcapacity. Revenue rose 35.8% to 248.7 billion yuan. Coal prices surged last year, averaging 36% higher at the Qinhuangdao port, but may decline about 5% this year. The company targets output of 290 million tonnes and coal sales of 430 million tonnes for 2018.

site_title: Sony employees' ideas get in-house incubator
summary: Sony's in-house incubator, Seed Acceleration Program, has successfully produced 13 products and services since its launch four years ago. The program aims to promote new businesses proposed by Sony employees, including the "toio" toy platform, which allows children to build and operate robots or vehicles. The incubator has garnered attention for its unconventional ideas, such as turning analogue watches into smartwatches. The program has led to significant revenue, with Sony forecasting an operating profit of 720 billion yen for the year ending March, the best ever in its 72-year history.

site_title: Trade chambers plan to fly the Singapore flag abroad
summary: Singapore's trade chambers plan to increase their international participation, with over 600 companies participating in the Singapore Manufacturing Federation's internationalisation programme last year. The number of participants is expected to increase by 20-30% annually. With Singapore chairing the Asean grouping this year, trade bodies are focusing on Asean markets and collaborating with each other to support local companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), in venturing abroad and generating revenue. The government-backed International Marketing Activities Programme also funds up to 70% of companies' activities at overseas events.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Keystone Cable focuses on regional growth
summary: Keystone Cable, a 140-strong privately owned cable manufacturer in Singapore, is focusing on regional growth in Southeast Asia. The company, led by General Manager and Director Josephine Wang, has expanded operations to seven markets in the region, including Cambodia, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Keystone has developed its own line of products, including structured cabling solutions and prefabricated cables, to cater to smart city and prefabrication trends. The company prioritizes staff training and career mobility, recognizing the importance of investing in its workforce to remain competitive in the industry.

images.alt_text: Keystone has a range of projects here, which has seen it supply cables for the construction of attractions such as the Gardens by the Bay and the Singapore Flyer to utilities contracts with SP Group, say Ms Wang and Ms Yu.

site_title: How Trumpism has come to define the GOP
summary: President Donald Trump has successfully pushed ahead with key parts of his vision, remaking the Republican Party and the country on issues such as trade, immigration, and spending. Despite persistent unpopularity and chaos in the White House, Trump has used legislation and unilateral actions to cast aside years of Republican orthodoxy, including tariffs, harsh crackdowns on illegal immigrants, and costly policies that have contributed to the growing national debt. The Republican Party has shifted towards Trumpism, with 59% of registered Republican voters identifying as supporters of Trump rather than the party.

site_title: High-end watchmakers make more of a push online
summary: High-end watchmakers are shifting their focus to online sales, driven by booming luxury goods sales and changing consumer behavior. Brands such as Tag Heuer, Bulgari, and Hublot are investing in e-commerce, with some aiming to fully build out their own shoppable sites over the next 18 months. The trend is expected to continue, with web sales projected to make up a quarter of global luxury goods sales by 2025. Despite some limitations, such as the need for in-store sales for certain watches, the industry is embracing online growth, with many brands seeing the potential for increased revenue and customer engagement.

site_title: Drilling in 'Australia's Galápagos' raises hopes of jobs
summary: The Norwegian oil giant Statoil plans to start drilling in Australia's Great Australian Bight, a pristine ocean known for its unique marine life and fisheries, by the end of 2019. The drilling project has sparked fears of environmental damage and the risk of a catastrophic oil spill, which could harm the local fishing and tourism industries worth billions. Despite the potential economic benefits of the project, including jobs and economic growth in the region, opposition to the drilling plan has been strong, with six town councils and environmental groups raising concerns about the risks to the marine ecosystem.

site_title: Overproduction threatens Andes superfood haven
summary: Overproduction of Andean superfoods, including quinoa, amaranth, and calafate, threatens their unique nutritional properties and global demand. As prices rose 202% between 2011 and 2015, producers are struggling to meet demand, leading to concerns about soil composition and processing methods. Experts warn that these grains, fruits, and berries can help prevent chronic diseases, but their commercial processing can destroy their nutrients, and labeling by origin is essential for consumers to identify authentic products.

site_title: Abe apologises amid cronyism scandal, vows to revise constitution
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe apologized for causing anxiety and loss of confidence in his government amid a suspected cronyism scandal and cover-up. Abe faces his biggest crisis since taking office in 2012 as suspicions swirl about a sale of state-owned land at a huge discount to a nationalist school operator. Abe has denied involvement, but public opinion polls show his cabinet's support sinking to 31%. He vowed to revise Japan's pacifist post-war constitution, which could dash his hopes of winning a third term as ruling premier.

site_title: Making a fast buck out of misery
summary: Speculators in post-Hurricane Harvey Houston are buying and selling flooded homes, profiting from the city's recovery. In Canyon Gate, a Houston suburb designed to flood, speculators like Nick Pelletiere are snapping up homes at discounted prices, often with little effort to inform buyers of the risks they face. Despite the neighborhood's history of flooding, many homes are being sold for significantly lower prices than before the storm, with investors betting on Houston's recovery. The influx of speculators has raised concerns about the long-term consequences of rebuilding in flood-prone areas, and the impact on residents who may be forced to sell their homes or rebuild elsewhere.

site_title: US unafraid of trade war, will proceed with China tariffs: Treasury secretary
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin stated that the US will proceed with implementing $60 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports, despite China's threat of retaliatory tariffs. Mnuchin said the measures will benefit the US economy long-term, and he has had "very productive conversations" with the Chinese vice premier. China warned it's not afraid of a trade war, but Mnuchin expressed cautious hope for a deal. The US tariffs target sectors where Beijing is accused of stealing American technology, and Mnuchin believes this will lead to long-term economic growth.

site_title: Airbus A330neo dropped from American Airlines wide-body contest
summary: Airbus has lost the contest to sell its A330neo jetliner to American Airlines Group, with the US carrier opting for more Boeing 787s instead. Airbus cited that the competition priced its aircraft lower, while American Airlines is reluctant to operate a small fleet of A350s. This setback deals a blow to Airbus's efforts to boost wide-body sales in the US market. The loss comes as the company continues to pursue sales campaigns for the A330neo with over 100 airlines.

site_title: Sri Lankan politicians, cops seen in anti-Muslim riots
summary: Anti-Muslim riots in Sri Lanka's Kandy district were fueled by fringe Buddhist extremists and hate speech on social media, with police and politicians backing the violence. The riots, which lasted for three days, destroyed scores of mosques, homes, and businesses, and saw elite police units assault Muslim clerics and leaders. The government declared a state of emergency and blocked social media, but critics say the violence was a sign of the government's loss of control and rising Buddhist nationalism in the region.

site_title: Quackery and superstition driving illicit trade in wildlife
summary: The illicit trade in wildlife is a multi-billion-dollar industry, driven by superstition and quackery, with products such as powdered chimpanzee bone, gecko saliva, and rhino horn being sold as cures for various ailments. Many of these products are derived from endangered or threatened species, with rhino horn being a prime example, with demand fueled by unproven claims of its medicinal properties. The trade is estimated to be worth $19 billion annually, with experts condemning the practice and calling for a shift in public perception to protect endangered species.

site_title: US$ hit by fears of rising trade tensions
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-month low against a basket of major currencies due to concerns over escalating trade tensions. The dollar index dropped 0.48% to 89.427, its biggest weekly decline in five years. Investors worry that rising trade tensions could harm global growth. The decline follows a fresh tariff salvo by US President Trump on Canada.

site_title: Trump slump back in focus, Dow in correction territory
summary: The "Trump Slump" has returned, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling by over 5% for its worst week since January 2016. Markets are at risk of further declines due to ongoing trade tensions with China and Iran. The Dow closed at its lowest point of the year at 23,533. Treasury yields and housing data are also expected to pose economic threats.

site_title: Opportunistic Vettel steals victory from Hamilton
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Australian Grand Prix, overtaking Lewis Hamilton during a virtual safety car period. Vettel, who started from third place, capitalized on the safety car to take the lead and hold off Hamilton's late charge. Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen finished third, and Mercedes boss Toto Wolff attributed his team's loss to a software bug. Hamilton was left frustrated, having been blocked by traffic earlier in the race and ultimately forced to settle for second place.

site_title: Vettel holds off Hamilton to win thriller
summary: Sebastian Vettel won the Australian Grand Prix, holding off Lewis Hamilton in a thrilling duel. Vettel, driving for Ferrari, started the race behind Hamilton but took the lead on a pit stop under Virtual Safety Car conditions. He held off Hamilton for his second straight win in Melbourne and third overall. Kimi Raikkonen finished third, securing a podium for Ferrari. Vettel's victory gave him his 48th win in 200th grand prix and put him in a duel with Hamilton for five world titles.

images.alt_text: Ferrari's Vettel (right) leading Mercedes' Hamilton during the F1 Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne on Sunday.

site_title: Mandarin Gardens condominium approves asking price of S$2.48b
summary: Mandarin Gardens condominium has approved its asking price of S$2.48 billion, paving the way for a potential collective sale. Developers could pay over S$4 billion, including top-up costs and development charges. The 99-year leasehold estate aims to collect 80% of owner signatures within three months. If successful, Mandarin Gardens could break the record for the largest en bloc sale by dollar value, surpassing the S$1.3388 billion sale of Farrer Court in 2007.

site_title: Dropbox shares close up 35% in biggest tech debut since Snap
summary: Dropbox's shares closed at $28.42, up 35% in its first day of trading, marking the biggest tech IPO since Snap in March. The stock opened at $29 and soared to a high of $31.6, with a market valuation of $12.67 billion. Despite weakness in the wider US stock market, investors saw Dropbox as a "next-generation tech company" with a proven business model, citing its solid first-day pop.

site_title: WeWork to open offices in four regional cities as part of Asian push
summary: WeWork plans to open offices in Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, Bangkok, and Manila by end-2018 as part of its $500 million effort to grow in South-east Asia and South Korea. Singapore will serve as the regional headquarters, and WeWork aims to cater to freelancers, startups, and large companies with flexible workspace options. The company faces competition from local players and international competitors, but believes its global brand and network will help it differentiate itself. WeWork will also offer its "Powered by We" service to manage space for other businesses.

site_title: China's space lab set to crash to Earth in a week
summary: China's space lab, Tiangong-1, is set to crash into Earth in a week, likely disintegrating over the skies of Spain, Portugal, France, and Greece. Launched in 2011, the 19,000-pound station will experience an uncontrolled re-entry, with parts surviving to crash into the ocean. The craft is currently spinning at 17,500 mph and will slow down, accelerating toward Earth as it encounters thicker air, causing friction and potentially disintegrating. Some components may survive, weighing up to 220 pounds, but the majority is expected to burn up or fall into the ocean.

site_title: Ride-hailing apps run Indonesian tuk-tuks off road
summary: US-based ride-hailing apps Uber, Google-backed Go-Jek, and Singapore's Grab are dominating Indonesia's ride-hailing market, threatening the fortunes of traditional three-wheeled bajaj taxis. Since their introduction, bajaj drivers have seen their income decline by 70-80%. Go-Jek alone claims 900,000 drivers and 15 million weekly active users, with plans for an initial public offering to expand its services. The Southeast Asian ride-hailing market is expected to reach $20 billion by 2025, with Indonesia accounting for 40% of it.

site_title: Uber agrees to sell Southeast Asia business to Grab after costly battle
summary: Uber has agreed to sell its Southeast Asian business to Grab, marking the US company's second retreat from Asia. The deal, potentially worth billions, will put pressure on rivals such as Go-Jek. As part of the transaction, Uber will receive up to 30% of the combined business. The sale comes after a costly battle and follows a similar deal in China where Didi Chuxing bought out Uber's China business. The move marks a significant consolidation in the industry in Southeast Asia, home to 640 million people.

site_title: VW boss says 'risk of jail' justifies mega salary
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller defended his 10-million-euro salary, citing the risk of "one foot in jail" as justification. Mueller, who took home 40% more than the previous year, said he didn't understand the fuss about CEOs' pay packets. The comments come as the company grapples with the fallout from a huge emissions cheating scandal. Mueller's remarks have sparked criticism, with many questioning the disconnect between his high salary and the company's environmental issues.

site_title: Far East Group to sell Lavender Street property for S$27m
summary: Far East Group, an industrial refrigeration systems distributor, plans to sell its Lavender Street property in Singapore for approximately S$27 million. The site, which serves as the group's regional headquarters, has a net book value of S$4.2 million. The proceeds will be used for working capital, business expansion, and future investments. An extraordinary general meeting will be held to obtain shareholders' approval for the proposed disposal, which will be fully satisfied in cash.

site_title: UK regulators search Cambridge Analytica offices
summary: British regulators searched Cambridge Analytica's London offices after a judge approved a search warrant, amid investigations into claims the firm illegally harvested Facebook data for political ends. The data watchdog, led by Elizabeth Denham, is investigating claims of data misuse, including allegations of involvement in the 2016 Brexit referendum campaign. Whistleblower Brittany Kaiser revealed the firm conducted data research for Leave.EU, and Cambridge University is conducting a review of the episode. Cambridge Analytica denies wrongdoing and has licensed the data from a research company, while Facebook's stock market value has plunged amid the crisis.

site_title: 315 units of The Tapestry in Tampines snapped up
summary: In Singapore, 315 out of 450 units of The Tapestry, a 99-year leasehold property, were sold over the weekend, with an average price per square foot of S$1,310. The units, ranging from 441 sq ft to 1,765 sq ft, were priced from S$596,000 to S$2.1 million. The remaining 411 units will be released progressively, with 76% of buyers being Singaporeans, 24% permanent residents and foreigners.

site_title: CapitaLand tops buybacks; directors continue acquisitions
summary: CapitaLand topped the list of companies with the most share buybacks, with a total of S$23.2 million spent on buying back shares since February 20. The company has now bought back 30.8 million shares under its current mandate, which expires on April 23. This follows a previous week's buyback of S$65.3 million. The Straits Times Index (STI) continued its performance, gaining 3% compared to its average decline of 1.5% for the benchmarks of Japan, Hong Kong, Australia, and the US.

site_title: North Korea agrees to inter-Korean talks next week: Seoul
summary: North Korea agreed to hold high-level talks with South Korea next week to discuss logistics for a rare inter-Korean summit, set for late April. The talks will take place in the border truce village of Panmunjom, with Seoul's delegation led by Unification Minister Cho Myoung Gyon and North Korea's delegation led by Ri Son Gwon. The move follows a rapid rapprochement on the Korean peninsula, sparked by the Winter Olympics, and is seen as a step towards a potential summit between US President Donald Trump and Kim Jong Un by the end of May.

site_title: China to open financial sector further amid reforms
summary: China will further open its financial sector while prioritizing risk prevention through regulation and supervision, according to new central bank governor Yi Gang. Yi emphasized the importance of balancing financial opening with risk control, stating that areas with more openness are more competitive and less prone to risks. China will lift foreign equity ownership ceilings in certain sectors and dismantle ownership limits in three years, but will maintain supervision. The central bank will also open its bond market and roll out a cross-border yuan settlement system to facilitate global payments.

site_title: Britain will find it hard to freeze Russian assets
summary: The UK government faces significant challenges in freezing Russian assets due to the large amount of money invested in UK property and other assets. The holders, including oligarchs and thousands of Russian bankers and businesspeople, must be proven to have links to criminal behavior. Despite the UK's ability to make "unexplained wealth orders" and consider adopting the US Magnitsky Act, the government must act within the law and apply due process, potentially putting innocent Russians at risk.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market saw mixed results last week, with the Baltic Dry Index stalling mid-week and recovering by the end of the week. Capesize rates dropped below $6.00 on the West Australia/China run but recovered to finish in the low $6.00s. Period rates were higher than spot values, with a 2015-built Capesize fixed at $21,000 daily. Panamax rates remained stagnant, with larger Post-Panamax types struggling to find suitable trades. Supramax/Ultramax rates remained in positive mode, especially in the Asian basin. The handy sector also saw positive territory, with East coast South America market recovering from recent easing in rates.

site_title: Aussie cowboys join Sydney rally against coal and gas mining
summary: Thousands of Australians, including farmers on horseback, rallied in Sydney to protest coal and gas mining developments in rural regions. The "Time2Choose" rally called for authorities to prioritize renewable energy projects over mining, citing environmental concerns and damage to productive land. Campaigners expressed fears of groundwater contamination from fracking and the impact on agriculture. The issue has gained momentum amid rising energy bills and supply shortages, with some blaming onshore gas moratoriums for price spikes.

site_title: Classic and Tampines are perfect venues for regional majors
summary: Singapore to lose several golf courses due to high-speed rail system developments. The Jurong Country Club and Raffles Golf and Country Club will close by July and April respectively. Meanwhile, Keppel Club and the Marina Bay Golf Course will be relocated in the coming years. However, two redesigned courses in the east, Classic and Tampines, are set to establish Singapore on the world golfing map.

site_title: Tesla, SpaceX pages vanish as Musk joins #DeleteFacebook crusade
summary: Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, joined the #DeleteFacebook crusade after being asked to remove his company's Facebook pages. He initially responded to a Twitter user by saying he would delete the page, calling it "lame anyway." As a result, both facebook.com/tesla and facebook.com/spacex are no longer available. Musk's actions follow his earlier tweet about deleting his own Facebook page.

site_title: Siemens nominates Roland Busch as chairman of Siemens Alstom
summary: Siemens has nominated Roland Busch as chairman of Siemens Alstom, a joint venture rail company formed to compete with Chinese conglomerates. The joint venture, with 50% owned by Siemens and Alstom providing Henri Poupart-Lafarge as CEO, aims to improve competitiveness. Busch will serve as chairman, with Yann Delabriere appointed as vice chairman, while Alstom's current lead director will join Siemens' board.

site_title: China should not seek high growth as financial risk mounts: party official
summary: China's deputy director of the Office of the Central Leading Group on Financial and Economic Affairs, Yang Weimin, warned that the country should focus on high-quality economic growth rather than rapid expansion due to accumulating financial risks. In the past 30 years, China achieved high-speed growth, and Yang believes it can achieve another 30 years of high-quality growth. This shift in focus aims to mitigate the dangers of financial risks and ensure sustainable economic growth.

site_title: Hedge funds cut bullish hog wagers days before China tariffs
summary: Hedge funds significantly reduced their bullish wagers on US hog prices before China announced retaliatory tariffs on US pork. The reduction in net-long positions dropped to 8,029 futures and options in the week ending March 20, the lowest in over two years. Just three days later, China's tariffs sent hog prices tumbling in Chicago, validating the hedge funds' decision.

site_title: Nissan slows output after US demand drop led to bloated supply
summary: Nissan Motor is slowing production at several US assembly plants to manage a bloated supply of vehicles on dealers' lots. The company aims for a 50- to 60-day supply by August, after reaching 86 days of inventory in September last year. Nissan increased incentive spending and shipped more cars to rental companies to reduce inventory. The move comes after the company cut its earnings forecast due to weaker US demand, which has slowed down for the first time since the global recession.

site_title: Motor racing: F1 deals with halo safety device glitches
summary: Formula One teams are addressing issues with the new cockpit protection halo device, introduced to protect drivers from flying debris. Concerns arose over visibility of grid starting lights and impaired on-board camera shots. The FIA adjusted the start light gantry in Melbourne to alleviate visibility concerns. Drivers also expressed issues with the halo's interference in camera shots, with 50% of the useful screen being black. The FIA and teams are working to resolve these issues, with some speculating about potential design changes to the halo.

site_title: Of Trump's women and global trade
summary: US President Donald Trump is deflecting criticism by blaming global trade for his country's economic woes, rather than acknowledging the role of the billionaire class in hollowing out America's Treasury. His administration's steel tariffs are part of this strategy, which plays into lower-class white Americans' sense of isolationism and distracts from the true culprits: the hyper-rich in the US. Trump's relationships with key women, including his daughter Ivanka and wife Melania, are also showing signs of strain.

site_title: US lawmakers formally ask Facebook CEO to testify on user data
summary: US lawmakers have formally requested Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's testimony at a congressional hearing regarding the misuse of 50 million users' data by Cambridge Analytica, a British political consultancy. The hearing aims to examine the harvesting and sale of personal information from Facebook users without their notice or consent. The move follows allegations that Cambridge Analytica improperly accessed users' information to build profiles on American voters, potentially influencing the 2016 US presidential election. The hearing will scrutinize Facebook's handling of user data and its compliance with company policies.

site_title: China says ready to defend its interests in US trade spat
summary: China is prepared to defend its interests in a US trade spat, with Vice Premier Liu He stating that China has the strength to protect its national interests. China has already planned to levy additional duties on up to $3 billion of US imports in response to US import tariffs on steel and aluminum. The US plans to impose tariffs on up to $60 billion in Chinese goods for alleged intellectual property theft, sparking concerns of a trade war that could harm the global economy.

site_title: Fed policymakers say they are watching trade risks closely
summary: Federal Reserve officials are monitoring trade risks closely, particularly after the US and China unveiled plans for new tariffs. The Fed is cautious about the impact of tariffs on the US economy, with some policymakers expressing concern about the potential for a trade war. Despite this, the Fed remains committed to its interest rate hike policy, with several officials predicting three additional hikes this year. The central bank will wait to see how the new tariffs unfold before deciding on any policy response.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve officials on Friday said they want to see more details about new tariff policies before deciding whether any policy response is warranted, holding to their view that more interest rate hikes are needed.

site_title: Europe steps up pressure on Russia over spy attack
summary: European countries are taking further action against Russia over the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal in England. EU leaders agreed to recall the bloc's ambassador from Moscow, and several member states are considering expelling Russian intelligence agents posing as diplomats. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said coordinated actions are necessary, but divisions remain over the extent of the response. France's Emmanuel Macron described the attack as an "attack on European sovereignty," and the EU is expected to take further measures as early as Monday, including expelling diplomats.

site_title: New centre for robotics and automation to join startup hub
summary: A new robotics centre, Launchpad Robotics Centre, has been set up in JTC Launchpad at One-North, Singapore, to support startups in the robotics and automation sector. The centre, launched by Senior Minister of State Koh Poh Koon, offers a maker space, co-working space, and robotics display area, providing access to equipment and expertise. The centre aims to grow the startup scene and robotics landscape in Singapore, with plans to expand to a 260,000 sq ft facility near Jurong Innovation District.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Genting Singapore to hold an extraordinary general meeting on April 17 to seek shareholders' approval for a domicile change from the Isle of Man to Singapore and a name change to Genting Singapore Limited. Dyna-Mac Holdings' independent auditors highlighted uncertainty over new contract awards as a key going concern issue. Hiap Seng Engineering secured two contracts worth S$53 million in Singapore, while Gaylin Holdings expects a net loss for FY 2018 based on preliminary financial results.

site_title: Mortgage rates recommence their upward trajectory
summary: Mortgage rates rose to 4.45% for 30-year fixed-rate loans, 3.91% for 15-year fixed-rate loans, and 3.68% for 5-year adjustable-rate loans, according to Freddie Mac. The Federal Reserve's benchmark rate increase to 1.75% is driving bond yields higher, influencing mortgage rates. Experts predict rates will continue to rise in the coming week, with some warning that buyers should prepare for higher rates. Despite this, existing home sales increased 3% month-over-month in February, and the US housing market remains resilient.

site_title: Qantas sets aviation milestone as Perth flight lands in London
summary: Qantas has achieved a major milestone by launching direct flights between Perth and London, reducing travel time from 12 1/2 days to 17 hours. The route marks the first nonstop passenger service between the continents and is a key test for Qantas' planned ultra-long-haul network by 2022. The airline is targeting business travelers who are willing to pay a premium for the shorter flight, with mining companies and financial services firms expected to benefit from the increased connectivity. Qantas aims to make money from the daily service by offering top-tier passengers.

site_title: Qualcomm re-elects board of directors with tepid support
summary: Qualcomm re-elected its 11-member board of directors with weak support from shareholders, who expressed concerns over the company's strategy following its successful defense against a US$117-billion hostile bid from Broadcom. The re-election was largely uncontested, with Qualcomm CEO Steve Mollenkopf and several directors receiving support in the range of 40-50%. The move was seen as a relief after US President Donald Trump blocked the deal, citing national security concerns. Despite this, Qualcomm's shares closed down 1.9% on Friday, amid investor concerns about the company's future prospects.

site_title: US core capital goods orders, shipments surge in February
summary: US core capital goods orders and shipments surged in February, rebounding from two straight monthly declines, suggesting further gains in business spending on equipment in the first quarter. Orders rose 1.8% and shipments increased 1.4%, boosting economists' estimates of economic growth, despite concerns over a potential trade war. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and forecast of future increases also contributed to the upbeat economic picture.

site_title: Indonesia coal miner sues Noble Group for more than US$260m
summary: Indonesian coal miner PT Atlas Resources is suing Noble Group for over US$260 million, seeking to cancel marketing deals and unwind equity transactions. The lawsuit, filed in a Central Jakarta court, claims losses due to Noble's default on notes and alleged inflation of profits. The move may jeopardize Noble Group's remaining business, which is restructurering under a debt-for-equity plan. The company plans to contest the claims, but the lawsuit adds to its crisis, with market value plummeting to less than US$94 million.

site_title: Plant Pharma
summary: Researchers at the National University of Singapore are developing synthetic cannabinoids to replicate the therapeutic effects of cannabis without its psychoactive properties. Led by associate professor Yew Wen Shan, the team is working to biosynthesize cannabinoids using microbes like yeast, aiming to produce high-quality, pure compounds for pharmaceutical companies. The project is part of Singapore's $25 million Synthetic Biology Research and Development Programme, which also targets diseases like Parkinson's disease, cancer, and diabetes. The goal is to create cannabinoids that can be used as medicine, with potential applications in treating various conditions, including epilepsy and chronic pain.

site_title: Reits
summary:
Here's a summary of the article content in 100 words or less:

US mortgage rates have risen after five consecutive weeks of declines, while Singapore's Q3 condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents have hit a record, with more increases expected. In the UK, homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Goldman Sachs has acquired 262 billion won hotel and retail assets in Seoul. New World is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy. These trends indicate a mixed real estate market.

site_title: Trump signs budget deal after raising government shutdown threat
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a $1.3 trillion spending bill, ending a government shutdown threat he made earlier. Trump had threatened to veto the bill due to his dissatisfaction with immigration issues, despite the bill increasing military funding. He stated that he would "never sign another bill like this again" and criticized lawmakers for not reading the bill. The bill includes $1.6 billion for a six-month border wall project, but Trump had sought $25 billion. The signing ends a suspenseful episode, with Trump set to fly to Florida for a weekend at his private resort.

site_title: Juncker backs top aide in EU promotion row
summary: European commission President Jean-Claude Juncker insisted that his top aide Martin Selmayr "will not step down" despite a promotion scandal. Leaders of France and Germany expressed appreciation for Selmayr's work, which led to Juncker stating he would resign if Selmayr was forced out of his new job as secretary general of the commission.

site_title: Singapore's silver linings playbook for the storm clouds ahead
summary: Singapore's economy may be affected by the US-China trade tensions, with economists predicting potential losses despite possible trade diversion. As a small trade-dependent country, Singapore's exports to China are significant, making it vulnerable to trade disruptions. Economists are divided on whether tensions will escalate or ease, but most agree that Singapore's economy will be impacted. The country's reliance on trade makes it essential to monitor the situation closely and consider diversifying its trade relationships.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Opel workers demand German investment plan from PSA
summary: German carmaker Opel's works council has demanded "constructive proposals" from parent PSA to invest in German sites after being excluded from a production and investment plan for European sites. Opel workers are seeking a commitment to honour a collective wage bargaining agreement unconditionally. The decision follows Opel's exclusion from PSA's investment plan, which focuses on French, Polish, and Hungarian sites. Opel aims to invest in German sites and introduce new models, but must create competitive structures. A meeting between Opel and PSA is pending to discuss the proposals.

site_title: Teaching the next generation the value of money
summary: A lack of financial literacy among the next generation is a pressing concern, as schools do not teach the value of money and good money management. Parents must take responsibility in imparting these values to their children. Key strategies include starting work at a young age, avoiding excessive consumerism, and teaching the importance of responsibility and accountability. Additionally, understanding compound interest and living below one's means can also help children develop healthy financial habits. By passing on these values, parents can help their children lead a productive and fulfilling life.

site_title: OrangeTee & Tie teams up with Carousell on property listings
summary: Singapore's third-largest property agency, OrangeTee & Tie, has teamed up with homegrown online marketplace Carousell to boost property listings by 20,000. The collaboration, announced on March 23, 2018, allows OrangeTee & Tie's over 4,000 agents to list their properties on Carousell for free for three months. After this period, agents will need to sign up as Carousell pro members to keep their listings and reviews accessible, with special rates available for three months. The partnership aims to increase Carousell's property listings to 30,000 and agent usage to 5,000.

site_title: UPP gets to regain majority stake in Canada wood firm Taiga
summary: Singapore-listed UPP Holdings is regaining a majority stake in Canada's Taiga Building Pro-ducts for C$27.7 million, including debt acquisition. UPP will hold 64.8% of Taiga after completing the acquisitions, regaining its majority stake. The deal includes the purchase of 9.2 million preferred shares and 10 common shares, and the acquisition of C$13.8 million of debt owed by Taiga to Genghis Sarl. The purchase consideration was derived from the price per Taiga share of C$1.50.

site_title: Rowsley shareholders vote in favour of healthcare acquisition; to be renamed Thomson Medical Group Limited
summary: Rowsley shareholders have voted in favour of a healthcare acquisition, led by Peter Lim, and will be renamed Thomson Medical Group Limited. The acquisition includes a 100% stake in Thomson Medical and a 70.35% stake in TMC Life Sciences Berhad. Shareholders approved resolutions for bonus issuance, director appointments, and the change in name. The acquisition will be completed subject to other conditions, with Thomson Medical Group Limited becoming one of Singapore's largest listed healthcare players.

site_title: US: Wall Street nosedives as investors flee on trade war fears
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday, with the Dow falling 424.69 points, or 1.77%, to 23,533.2, as investors fled risk ahead of a potential US-China trade war. The S&P 500 lost 55.43 points, or 2.1%, to 2,588.26, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 174.01 points, or 2.43%, to 6,992.67. Investors are concerned about the escalation of the trade war, which could be a major headwind for the market, with President Trump's plans for tariffs on up to $60 billion in Chinese goods.

site_title: STI loses 2% on Friday on trade war jitters
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 2% on Friday due to escalating US-China trade tensions, with a cumulative drop of 2.6% for the week. Trading volume was heavy, with 1.9 billion shares changing hands. Analysts attributed the decline to global equity market corrections. The STI finished at 3,421.39, marking its lowest close in over a month.

site_title: Scouring the markets for precious winners as tariff fires burn
summary: Trade tensions continue to affect global markets, with technology stocks and credit suffering. However, traditional havens such as the yen, gold, and US Treasuries are rising, while stocks that act like bonds, like Japanese bonds and Australian stocks, are also performing well. The yen has strengthened to its highest level since November 2016, and Japanese bonds have seen their yields drop to historic lows. Meanwhile, China's government has introduced tariffs on US imports, benefiting domestic seed producers and pig breeders.

site_title: Emas Offshore sinks further into the red for H2 2017, FY2017
summary: Emas Offshore, an offshore oil and gas services provider, reported a net loss of US$687.5 million for its second half FY2017, down 36% from the same period last year. Revenue declined 36% to US$56 million, and the company's total assets decreased to US$466.5 million, while liabilities increased to US$1.13 billion. The Oslo Stock Exchange has upheld its resolution to delist the company, and Emas Offshore will appeal the decision. The company's financial performance is expected to remain challenging due to a weak market environment and over-supply of offshore vessels.

site_title: Singapore working with firms to seek exclusions from US steel tariffs
summary: Singapore is seeking product exclusions from US tariffs on steel and aluminium, working closely with companies and US departments. The country is concerned about the impact of trade tensions on international supply chains and global growth. Singapore's Trade and Industry Ministry emphasized the importance of free and connected markets, urging against protectionist practices that could disrupt global commerce. The move comes amid escalating trade tensions between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: EY highlights Dyna-mac's going-concern issue
summary: EY, the independent auditors of Dyna-Mac Holdings, have highlighted uncertainty over new contract awards as a key going-concern issue for the offshore and marine group. Dyna-Mac posted a net loss of S$57.91 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2017, and its management believes the group can tap further financing by pledging encumbered fixed assets. However, the auditors have alluded to risks that may challenge the group's going-concern assumption, including the need to win new contracts to generate required cash flows and potential asset divestments.

site_title: Share my plate at restaurants? I don't think so
summary: A shift towards sharing meals has become increasingly popular, with many restaurants offering small plates and communal dining experiences. This trend is attributed to the rise of foodie culture and the influence of global cuisine. However, the author of the article, who prefers traditional, individualized dining, questions the benefits of sharing meals, citing issues with pacing, etiquette, and personal preference. The author argues that the old model of a three-course meal has a mathematical elegance and allows for a more refined dining experience, whereas sharing meals can lead to a chaotic and rushed experience.

site_title: Under new rules, secret buyers of UK luxe properties face jail
summary: The UK government has introduced draft laws that could jail secret buyers of luxury properties, with punishments of up to two years in prison and unlimited fines. The new rules aim to crack down on money laundering by requiring foreign companies owning or buying property to disclose their ultimate owners. The move follows concerns over the origin of billions of pounds of funds used to buy luxury properties in London, with investors from Russia, China, and the Middle East suspected of using shell companies to hide their identities.

site_title: Good gets better
summary: Samsung's Galaxy S9 Plus is a refined, luxurious smartphone with a glass-and-metal design that sets the standard for future phones. The device features a fingerprint scanner at the bottom of the camera, a dual speaker system, and a mechanical shutter in the primary lens. Performance is sharp and quick, with six gigabytes of RAM and a powerful Exynos 9810 processor. However, the camera still struggles with overprocessing and oversaturation, and the front-facing camera's AR Emojis feature falls short. Despite this, the phone remains a compelling device with a strong foundation, making it one of the best handsets available.

images.alt_text: Performance on the phone is predictably sharp, quick and snappy, as befits a phone powered by Samsung's latest Exynos 9810 processor, paired with six (!) gigabytes of RAM.

site_title: Dairy Farm to hold 18.25% stake in Robinsons Retail Holdings
summary: Dairy Farm International Holdings will hold an 18.25% stake in Robinsons Retail Holdings through a partnership announced on March 23, 2018. The partnership aims to leverage the combined strengths of both groups and create a new platform for growth. Dairy Farm will combine its interest in Rustan Supercenters with RRHI.

site_title: Independent fact-checking council can combat deliberate online falsehoods, say SPH, CNA
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and Channel NewsAsia (CNA) have suggested setting up an independent fact-checking body to combat deliberate online falsehoods. The body should include media players and industry practitioners, and sit independently from government and commercial entities. SPH also raised concerns about potential legislation for fake news, suggesting it should focus on online content distributors rather than content producers. The proposed legislation should require online platforms to take responsibility for content they publish and promote, and to act faster in removing falsehoods.

site_title: Steve Wynn sells stake in the company he founded
summary: Steve Wynn sells his entire 11.8% stake in Wynn Resorts for $2.1 billion, exiting the company he founded 16 years ago. Macau casino operator Galaxy Entertainment buys a 5% stake in Wynn Resorts, acquiring 5.3 million shares at $175 per share. The move comes after Wynn resigned as CEO following allegations of unwanted advances, and marks a significant shift in the company's ownership. Galaxy CEO Francis Lui sees potential for collaboration on future development opportunities, particularly in Asia.

site_title: How (not) to deal with fake news
summary: The article discusses the challenges of combating fake news, citing the US experience with Prohibition as a cautionary tale. Suppressing fake news through bans and penalties raises concerns about oppression, censorship, and unintended consequences. Alternative approaches include promoting critical thinking, education, and openness in government, as well as penalizing hate speech while encouraging fact-based debate. A balanced approach is recommended, prioritizing the development of a critical, informed public over restrictive measures that may stifle free expression and hinder informed decision-making.

site_title: BreadTalk to partner PT Pura Indah Berkat to expand Toast Box chain in Indonesia
summary: BreadTalk International, a subsidiary of BREADTALK Group, has entered into a joint venture agreement with PT Pura Indah Berkat to expand its Toast Box chain in Indonesia. The JV will be 70% owned by BreadTalk International and 30% by PIB, with the first outlet scheduled to open in central Jakarta in 2018. The partnership aims to bring BreadTalk's quality Nanyang coffee, toast products, and local delicacies to the Indonesian market.

site_title: China hits back at the US where it hurts - in the pork belly
summary: China retaliates against US import tariffs with 25% tax on US pork imports, targeting around $3 billion in products. The move comes in response to US duties on steel and aluminum. The tariffs won't significantly impact China's US pork imports, which account for only 14% of its purchases. China's pork industry is already seeing consolidation, with small farms shutting down due to environmental concerns.

site_title: Markets savaged as US-China tariff brinkmanship escalates
summary: US and China escalate trade tensions with proposed tariffs, sparking market volatility. The US has announced 25% tariffs on Chinese technology products worth $50-60 billion, while China has proposed retaliatory tariffs of 15-25% on 128 US products. Asian stock markets fell, with the Straits Times Index down 2% and the Shanghai Shenzhen CSI 300 Index down 2.87%. Analysts warn of heightened volatility but see potential for value stocks to rise. Economists expect China's growth to be limited by US tariffs, but risks remain of further escalation.

site_title: How technology will affect your fund management job in the next decade
summary: The fund management industry faces a challenging future due to increased regulation and investors shifting to lower-cost products. To adapt, asset managers are turning to technology and data-mining to reduce expenses and win client business. The industry expects a surge in demand for data scientists, with 340 data scientists across 160 major firms, up from 45 at the start of the decade. By 2025, data management employees are expected to see their compensation quadruple, while those requiring "fundamental retraining" may need to adapt their skills to remain relevant.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher despite trade war threat
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, recovering from a 700-point drop on Thursday due to trade war concerns. Beijing announced retaliatory measures against the US, but spared key sectors such as aircraft and soybeans. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.4% to 24,062.16, while Asian and European stocks remained under pressure. Despite US President Donald Trump's new threats, traders seemed to brush off the uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records.

site_title: Public tranche in Ayondo IPO nets subscription of 4½ times
summary: Ayondo, a social trading broker, has successfully completed its initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore, attracting 4.5 times more applications than available shares. The company received 875 valid applications for 40.36 million shares, with 561 applicants securing shares. The IPO is expected to start trading on March 26, with a market capitalization of S$130.7 million. Ayondo had previously attempted a reverse takeover last year but failed to meet conditions. The company's largest shareholder, Luminor Capital, has maintained its investment.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US new home sales fall for third straight month in February
summary: US new home sales fell 0.6% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 618,000 units, marking a third straight decline. The Midwest and West experienced steep declines, while the Northeast and South rebounded. The median new house price rose 9.7% to $326,800, and it would take 5.9 months to clear the supply of houses on the market at February's sales pace. Rising mortgage rates and an acute shortage of homes are contributing to the slowing housing market.

site_title: Noble Group slapped with another lawsuit - this time seeking over US$260m
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodity trader, is facing another lawsuit, this time seeking over $260 million from Indonesian coal miner PT Atlas Resources. The lawsuit also seeks to cancel marketing deals and unwind equity transactions between the two companies. Noble Group has not been served and plans to contest the claims, amid a three-year crisis that has led to billions of dollars in losses. The company's restructuring plan, which aims to hand control to creditors, is now under threat.

site_title: New CEO cooking up a fresh strategy at struggling LifeBrandz
summary: Newly appointed CEO Hiroyuki Saito aims to turn around struggling Singapore-based entertainment group LifeBrandz by mid-2019. He plans to transform the company through digital businesses and an expansion into the Japanese food and beverage scene, with a focus on high-end sushi restaurants in San Francisco and New York. Saito also plans to acquire existing Japanese restaurants in Singapore and partner with famous Japanese chefs. The company has recently reported a widening second-quarter net loss, but Saito is confident that his new strategy will put the group back in the black by mid-2019.

images.alt_text: Mr Saito has reinvented LifeBrandz as an investment holding company that last year paid S$850,000 for Japanese travel firm e-Holidays.
Annabeth Leow

site_title: Stuck in a loveless relationship with your job
summary: A significant number of workers experience dissatisfaction in their jobs, feeling stuck in a rut due to a lack of motivation, career alignment, or competency and bandwidth issues. Experts suggest that getting stuck is a common phenomenon, even among high-performers, and that individuals must take responsibility to move forward. To escape, workers can reevaluate career options, switch portfolios or projects, or seek advice from trusted mentors and peers. A clear goal and careful planning are also essential in making an informed decision about whether to stay or leave a job.

site_title: Trump's unfair tariffs will achieve little, and hurt many
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on $60 billion worth of Chinese goods, sparking concerns about a trade war. Critics argue that the tariffs will harm American consumers, Chinese factories, and the global economy, as China may retaliate with its own tariffs. The tariffs will also likely shift production to other countries, such as Mexico and Vietnam, rather than creating jobs in the US. The Trump administration's unilateral approach, bypassing Congress and the World Trade Organization, is seen as unfair and potentially damaging to US interests.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) issued 50 billion baht in debentures with fixed coupon rates ranging from 1.79% to 3.6%, averaging 2.83%. This is seen as a positive development for the counter, in line with management's plan to refinance short-term debts. Valuetronics is expected to benefit from emerging demand for home IoT and car connectivity, with strong cash flow paving the way for 4.7-6.1% dividend yields.

site_title: F&N bumps up shares in Vietnam's Vinamilk
summary: Frasers & Neaves (F&N) may acquire up to 14.5 million shares in Vietnam's Vinamilk, representing 1% of its issued share capital. F&N already holds 19.96% of Vinamilk's shares. There is no certainty the transaction will materialize, according to a regulatory filing.

site_title: ETFs: Fail-safe investment vehicle or weapon of mass destruction?
summary: ETFs, which attracted record flows in 2017, have raised concerns among industry experts due to their potential for hidden risks. Mohamed El-Erian warns that they over-promote liquidity, while Steven Bregman sees them as a "Delivery Agent of the Great Bubble". However, Mark Weidman, global head of iShares, believes ETF apocalypse concerns are "way overdone". The debate highlights the need for advisers to monitor ETFs diligently and not adopt a "set it and forget it" mindset, as Asia is expected to drive ETF growth and retail investors are predicted to drive massive growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: As Toshiba's US$18b chip unit sale faces tight deadline, IPO looms
summary: Toshiba faces a Friday deadline to secure Chinese antitrust approval for its $18 billion sale of its memory-chip business to a US private equity firm. The deadline may be missed, potentially leading to an IPO. Toshiba aims to complete the sale by March 31 to rebound from financial scandals and a nuclear crisis. If the deadline is not met, Toshiba can walk away without penalties, and activist shareholders are pushing for an IPO instead.

site_title: M1's IMM store to sell Keppel Electric energy plans
summary: M1's IMM store will sell Keppel Electric energy plans, allowing Jurong residents to bundle their home power needs with their telco services. This move follows M1's participation in the Open Electricity Market (OEM) and marks the telco's entry into the energy supplier market.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Roxy Pacific announces changes in management team
summary: Roxy Pacific Holdings announced changes in its management team to "meet ongoing changes and demands in the property industry". Current Managing Director Chris Teo Hong Yeow is redesignated as Deputy CEO, while current CFO Koh Seng Geok becomes Deputy CEO. Other changes include Shermin Chan Poh Choo becoming Group Financial Controller, and Teo Hong Hee and Teo Hong Wee transitioning to new roles in the CEO Office.

site_title: Inside Mars, Jeff Bezos' brainiac pow-wow
summary: Amazon's exclusive three-day conference, Mars, brought together 200 attendees, including astronauts, philosophers, and Nobel prize winners, for a gathering of genius-level minds. The conference, hosted by Jeff Bezos, focused on artificial intelligence and space exploration. Attendees presented novel breakthroughs, such as wearable strength suits and computer chips implanted in brains to resolve Parkinson's disease symptoms. Bezos himself made appearances, including a game of beer pong and a tour of the Blue Origin space capsule. The event was seen as a showcase of Amazon's reputation in AI and its founder's growing comfort in the spotlight.

images.alt_text: Guests sitting around a bonfire with Amazon CEO, Jeff Bezos, during the conference (above).
SpotMini (above), the four-legged robot strutting its stuff.
For the hand-picked Mars attendees, everything is free including room service and food (above).

site_title: Ayondo's IPO sees public applications come in at four-and-half times the number of offer shares
summary: Ayondo's initial public offering (IPO) drew 875 valid applications for 40.36 million offer shares, exceeding the available shares four-and-a-half times. The offer was fully subscribed at 1.3 times, with 561 successful applicants and 270 placees. Fund manager Pheim Asset Management secured 24.9 million shares, and founder Kwan Chee Seng acquired 3.75 million placement shares, giving him a combined stake of 21.6% after the IPO. The offer raised S$18.45 million and increased Ayondo's market capitalisation to S$130.7 million.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Humanity imperiled by abuse of life-giving Nature: reports
summary: A comprehensive survey by the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) warns that humanity is risking its own well-being by over-harvesting and harming Nature's bounty. The report, compiled by over 550 scientists, states that species populations are declining globally, with 90% of Asia-Pacific corals expected to suffer severe degradation by 2050. Unless humanity reverses its unsustainable use of Nature, the report warns of a sixth mass extinction, the first caused by humans, which could undermine economies, livelihoods, and the quality of life of people everywhere.

site_title: Trump threatens to veto spending bill, risking shutdown
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to veto a $1.3 trillion spending bill due to its lack of funding for a border wall and its failure to address Dreamer immigrants. The bill was passed by the House and Senate, but Trump criticized it on Twitter, stating he would veto it unless changes are made. The bill's passage sets the stage for a potential government shutdown later in the day, as funding expires.

site_title: Chinese sailors rescued alive after Malaysia capsize
summary: Two Chinese sailors were rescued alive from the engine room of a sand dredger that capsized off Malaysia two days after the incident, while 12 others remain missing. The rescued sailors are conscious but weak and were taken to a hospital. A Chinese sailor was killed in the initial capsizing, and three others were rescued alive. The cause of the accident is unclear, and a rescue operation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Two Chinese sailors were rescued alive Friday from the engine room of a sand dredger two days after the vessel capsized off Malaysia, while 12 others remain missing, an official said.

site_title: Gaylin Holdings warns of net loss for FY2018
