summary: Gaylin Holdings expects a net loss for FY2018 due to an impairment of S$25 million from aged inventories and weak market conditions in the oil and gas industry. The impairment is based on a professional valuation. The company will disclose further details of its financial performance when it announces its Q4 and FY2018 results on or before May 25, 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 11.65 points lower at 1,865.22 on Friday, with a volume of 2.09 billion shares worth RM2.15 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 827-190.

site_title: US accuses China of stealing patents in WTO complaint
summary: The US has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against China, alleging that China is stealing US patents and breaking WTO rules. The US claims China is denying foreign patent holders basic rights and imposing mandatory contract terms that discriminate against imported foreign technology. China has dismissed the allegations and warned it will retaliate against US imports. The US has also announced tariffs on up to $60 billion in Chinese goods, with a 30-day consultation period before implementation. China has planned measures against US imports worth up to $3 billion.

site_title: A season of changes for F1
summary: The 2018 Formula One season is about to begin, with several changes to the sport. The technical rules have been revised, including the elimination of the shark fin engine cover and T-wing, and teams will have seven slick tyre options instead of five. The sport has also introduced a new logo and grid kids, replacing grid girls, to make it more accessible to a wider audience. The halo cockpit protection device has also been introduced to improve driver safety. However, some changes, such as the lack of overtaking, are expected to remain a challenge for the season.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dive on US-China trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong and Chinese share markets plummeted on Friday due to escalating US-China trade war fears. The Hang Seng Index fell 2.45%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 3.39% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 4.49%. The decline was attributed to tit-for-tat threats between the US and China, raising concerns of a damaging trade war between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: End to Boeing trade case good news for aerospace: Bombardier
summary: Boeing has ended its trade case against Bombardier, allowing the Canadian plane maker to sell its CSeries jets to US carriers without hefty duties. The US trade commission ruled that Bombardier's claim was meritless, and Boeing did not appeal the decision. The case, which began in 2016, heightened trade tensions between Boeing, the US, Canada, and the UK. Analysts say the decision may not lead to long-term damage, and Boeing may start a new messaging campaign with Canada and the UK to repair their relationship.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co's decision to end its trade case over the sale of Bombardier CSeries jets to US carriers is good news for the aerospace industry and the public, the Canadian plane and train maker said on Friday.

site_title: Vietnam halts South China Sea oil drilling project under pressure from Beijing
summary: Vietnam has halted a Spanish energy firm Repsol's oil drilling project in the South China Sea, following pressure from China. The "Red Emperor" block, off Vietnam's southeastern coast, was licensed to Repsol for a $1-billion joint venture with state oil company PetroVietnam. The halt comes after China applied pressure, with Vietnamese officials considering terminating the contract due to the costs of resisting Chinese pressure. The project was paused while the decision-making politburo debates the next steps.

site_title: Motor racing: Ricciardo handed three-place penalty for home race
summary: Daniel Ricciardo has been handed a three-place grid penalty for the Australian Grand Prix due to exceeding speed limits during red flag conditions in practice. The penalty was given after Ricciardo admitted an error in reading his dashboard display. Stewards deemed the breach minor, with no danger created, and imposed a lesser penalty than usual. This is Ricciardo's second penalty for his home Grand Prix, following a disqualification in 2014.

site_title: EC World Reit appoints Goh Toh Sim as CEO
summary: EC World Reit has appointed Goh Toh Sim, current acting CEO and executive director of EC World Asset Management, as CEO and executive director, effective Friday. Mr. Goh was first appointed as acting CEO on February 14, 2018. The nominating and remuneration committee evaluated his experience and agreed he is "appropriately qualified and competent" to assume the role. He will oversee the Reit's operational efficiency, growth, and profitability.

site_title: Singapore shares close 2% lower on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 2% lower on Friday, finishing at 3,421.39 points, with 1.9 billion shares traded worth S$1.9 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 377 to 84. This marked a reversal of the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: GSK pulls out of US$20b race for Pfizer consumer assets
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has withdrawn from a bidding war for Pfizer's consumer healthcare business, which could fetch up to $20 billion. GSK was seen as the frontrunner, but declined to make a final bid due to concerns about returns and capital allocation. Pfizer continues to evaluate alternatives, including a spin-off or sale, and may consider tapping private equity funds if no other bids materialize. The decision comes amid a challenging global consumer health market and investor pressure on GSK and Reckitt Benckiser to exercise financial discipline.

site_title: Starland decides not to convert S$1.03 million loan into Ayondo shares; will be repaid in cash after IPO
summary: Starland Holdings, a Catalist-listed developer, has decided not to convert a S$1.027 million loan into Ayondo shares, instead opting to repay the amount in cash after Ayondo's IPO. This decision comes after a failed reverse takeover attempt in 2017. Ayondo had previously agreed to reimburse S$2.48 million in expenses, which will be settled in new shares, and the settlement will be reflected in subsequent financial results. The loan repayment will occur within 14 days of Ayondo's admission to the Catalist board.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore healthcare startup ObvioHealth raises US$3m Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based healthcare startup ObvioHealth has raised US$3 million in Series A funding, led by TKS I, a life science and healthcare focused venture fund. The funding will support the company's growth needs and expansion of its operational team. ObvioHealth aims to digitize clinical trials, making them faster and more cost-effective while complying with FDA Good Clinical Practices.

site_title: Emas Offshore's net loss deepens for 2H 2017
summary: Emas Offshore, an offshore oil and gas services provider, reported a net loss of $687.5 million for its second half of 2017, deepening from $391.5 million in the same period a year ago. Revenue declined 36% to $56 million due to a weak market environment. The company's full-year net loss was $705.7 million, and its total assets decreased to $466.5 million, while liabilities increased to $1.13 billion. Emas Offshore expects the market environment to remain challenging, with a negative impact on its operations and financial performance.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets limit losses at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets experienced limited losses at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.6%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 shedding 0.9%, and Paris's CAC 40 sliding 1.0%. The losses were less severe than those seen in Asia and the US overnight. Markets were influenced by mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were also a focus.

site_title: Spain to try Catalan separatist leaders for rebellion
summary: Spain's Supreme Court has ruled that 25 Catalan leaders will be tried for rebellion, embezzlement, or disobeying the state, in a move to contain separatist efforts in the northeastern region. The trial, which could result in up to 25 years in prison, follows a banned referendum on independence last year. Separatist leaders, including former president Carles Puigdemont, have denied any wrongdoing, while rights groups have criticized the government's crackdown. The trial's outcome will be closely watched by separatist groups across Europe.

site_title: Noble Group provides reason for founder Richard Elman's resignation
summary: Noble Group's founder Richard Elman resigned as non-executive director due to "amicable differences of opinion" with the board and creditors. Elman, who founded Noble in 1986, departed as CEO in 2009 and remained non-executive chairman until his resignation on March 20, 2018. He remains a substantial shareholder of the company. The resignation comes after a lawsuit by Goldilocks Investment Company accusing Noble of inflating profits. The company had hailed Elman's departure as a "new dawn" for the company.

site_title: US shoppers and Chinese suppliers face hit from Trump levy
summary: US President Donald Trump's $50 billion tariff on Chinese imports is expected to impact American consumers and Chinese exporters. The tariffs, which will be a 25% duty, will likely lead to higher prices for US consumers on items such as Victoria's Secret bras, Guess jeans, and Nike sneakers. Chinese manufacturers, including those in Hong Kong, may see their cost advantage wiped out, while smaller exporters with heavy reliance on the US market worry about their future. Large Chinese companies, however, are diversifying their businesses and may be better equipped to absorb the shock.

site_title: Australia: Shares plunge to 5-week low on trade war worries; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell to a 5-week low on Friday, down 1.6% to 5,840.6, amid fears of a global trade war sparked by US President Donald Trump's memo targeting up to $60 billion in Chinese goods. The materials sector and financial stocks led the losses, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto dropping 3.6% and 4.4%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1.2% as consumer staples and healthcare stocks declined.

site_title: M1 rolls out mobile consumer discounts for Jurong residents who switch to Keppel Electric in Open Electricity Market pilot
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, has launched mobile consumer discounts for Jurong residents who switch to Keppel Electric's Open Electricity Market (OEM) packages. Customers can enjoy discounts on new handsets or data plans, including S$80 off Samsung Galaxy S9 or six months of free "upsized" data. The partnership is part of M1's efforts to offer greater value and flexibility in the liberalised energy market, with Keppel Electric offering six residential plans ranging from discounted tariffs to lower fixed rates for off-peak consumption.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Some Chinese stocks are doing well out of this US trade war
summary: Chinese stocks, particularly agricultural and gold companies, are performing well amidst the US-China trade war. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 4% but some agricultural companies rose 10% or more, driven by expectations that US tariffs will make their products more competitive. Gold miners also gained, with Shandong Gold Mining Co and Zhongjin Gold Corp climbing 6.4% and 5.6%, respectively. In contrast, electronic component makers, home appliances, and furniture/shoe/garment producers declined significantly.

site_title: Singapore consumer prices up 0.5% in February
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose 0.5% in February, in line with economists' estimates, driven by a smaller decline in accommodation costs and stronger service and food price increases. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport, was 1.7%, while healthcare and education costs continued to rise. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects core inflation to remain in the 1-2% range this year and headline inflation to range from 0-1% due to dampening effects from accommodation costs and moderating private road transport inflation.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Dairy Farm to hold 18.25% stake in Robinsons Retail Holdings
summary: Dairy Farm International Holdings is partnering with Robinsons Retail Holdings, with Dairy Farm holding an 18.25% stake in RRHI. The deal involves Dairy Farm exchanging its interest in Rustan Supercenters for new shares and acquiring a 6.1% stake from existing controlling shareholders. The move aims to build a leading food retail business in the Philippines, with Dairy Farm to nominate two directors to RRHI's board. The transaction is expected to take six months to complete and is valued at US$346 million. Dairy Farm will maintain its presence in the Philippines and contribute to consumer market growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble with Wall St as Trump sparks trade war fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Friday, following a sell-off in New York as US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Chinese imports, sparking trade war fears. The US imposed levies on up to $60 billion of Chinese imports, while China retaliated with tariffs on $3 billion worth of US goods. The Dow Jones plummeted 2.4-2.9%, causing losses to Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney. Analysts warn that the trade tensions could disrupt global economic recovery and impact consumer and producer prices.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks dive at open on trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.67% on Friday, March 23, 2018, due to growing fears of a global trade war. Donald Trump imposed billions of dollars in tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting Beijing to draw up retaliatory measures. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,930.23, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 3,172.77. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with investors fearing a broader market impact. The plunge was attributed to trade war fears, marking a significant downturn in the region's markets.

site_title: China pork and farm shares jump on trade threats
summary: China's pork and agriculture shares rose sharply on anticipation of potential new trade barriers on American imports, potentially benefiting domestic producers. China released a list of US goods that could face duties of up to 25%, including pork, fresh fruit, and wine, in retaliation for US President Donald Trump's trade order. Despite a global market rout, Chinese shares defied the trend, with some companies like Hunan New Wellful and Guangdong Wens Foodstuff Group surging 10% and 3.66% respectively.

images.alt_text: Chinese pork and agriculture shares escaped the market downdraft from US-China trade tensions on Friday, rising sharply on anticipation that potential new barriers on American imports could fatten up the sales of domestic producers.

site_title: Vietnam, South Korea agree to do US$100b in bilateral trade by 2020
summary: Vietnam and South Korea agreed to boost bilateral trade to $100 billion by 2020, a 50% increase from last year's total of $66.56 billion. The agreement, signed during South Korean President Moon Jae In's visit, aims to reduce Vietnam's deficit in bilateral trade. Trade between the two countries has risen rapidly since the free trade agreement took effect in 2015, with Samsung Electronics being the largest single foreign investor in Vietnam. The goal is to contribute to Vietnam's goal of becoming an industrialized economy.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index slumps more than 4.5% on trade war fears
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 4.51% to a near six-month low, closing at 20,617.86, amid fears of an all-out trade war between the US and China. US President Donald Trump's unveiling of fresh tariffs against China and the replacement of his national security adviser sparked market anxiety. The strong yen also weighed on Japanese exporters, contributing to the decline. Global stocks, including the Dow, fell, with investors taking refuge in the safe-haven Japanese currency.

site_title: Meituan is said to seek a US$60b valuation in Hong Kong IPO
summary: Meituan Dianping, a Chinese food reviews and delivery giant, is reportedly planning a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) with a potential valuation of at least $60 billion. The company, formed by the merger of Meituan and Dianping, has 320 million active annual buyers and more than four million merchants on its e-commerce platform. Meituan faces competition from rivals backed by Alibaba, Didi Chuxing, and its own backer Tencent Holdings. The IPO comes as investors question whether the company can sustain growth without heavy cash burn.

site_title: Apartment blaze in Ho Chi Minh City kills 13, injures 27
summary: A fire in a Ho Chi Minh City apartment block, Carina Plaza, killed 13 people and injured 27 in the early hours of Friday. The blaze began at 1am at the basement and spread quickly, trapping hundreds of residents. Most victims died from smoke inhalation, with some jumping from high windows. The fire was extinguished after an hour with over 30 fire engines and 200 firefighters on site. The six-year-old block had 736 separate apartments.

site_title: Credit Suisse signals higher pay for Thiam after bonus drought
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Tidjane Thiam's pay for 2017 fell 5% to 9.7 million Swiss francs due to shareholder uproar over his proposed remuneration. The bank's struggles led to a third consecutive loss in 2017. Thiam's pay will "return to levels in line with the expected improvement" in the bank's performance. The executive board waived 40% of its bonuses to quell criticism. Thiam's pay is still higher than many European peers, but lower than at his previous job as CEO at Prudential Plc.

site_title: EU leaders to agree Brexit talks guidelines
summary: European Union leaders will adopt negotiating guidelines for Brexit talks, paving the way for a 21-month transition period and a new dynamic in the negotiations. British Prime Minister Theresa May urged her colleagues to tackle tough questions, including trade and the Irish border, with "energy and ambition". The guidelines call for "intensified efforts" on outstanding parts of the divorce and warn against backtracking on commitments. A deal on a post-Brexit transition has delivered certainty for businesses and citizens, but key issues remain, including the backstop for Northern Ireland's customs union.

site_title: US Congress approves US$1.3t spending bill, averts third shutdown of the year
summary: The US Congress approved a $1.3 trillion spending bill, averting a potential third government shutdown this year. The bill, which funds the government through September, includes significant increases to the military and domestic programs, while rebuffing the Trump administration's efforts to cut spending. The bill was passed by the House 256-167 and the Senate 65-32, with many conservative lawmakers opposing it. The measure includes funding for the military, opioid crisis, and infrastructure projects, but has been criticized for its lack of transparency and the growing national debt, which has surpassed $21 trillion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Indonesia's coal producer, PT Atlas Resources Tbk, filed a lawsuit against Noble Group seeking over US$260 million in compensation. Singapore's consumer prices rose 0.5% in February, and brokers upgraded ST Engineering to 'buy'. M1 launched mobile consumer discounts for Jurong residents switching to Keppel Electric. Singapore's healthcare startup ObvioHealth raised US$3 million in Series A funding. The US Congress approved a US$1.3 trillion spending bill, averting a potential government shutdown.

images.alt_text: Noble will drop a provision from its restructuring proposal that has drawn criticism for attempting to treat shareholders differently depending on how they vote, the company's chairman said in an open letter late Wednesday.

site_title: UOB partners Indonesia financial institution to boost infrastructure development
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has signed a memorandum of understanding with PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero) to support Indonesia's infrastructure development initiatives. The partnership aims to provide infrastructure financing, corporate financing, and project financing for national and provincial projects. This collaboration follows a previous partnership in 2013 and will focus on credit syndication, mezzanine financing, and equity investment. The move is seen as a way to provide resources and expertise for Indonesia's infrastructure development, with UOB's managing director stating that PPPs are a key way to facilitate infrastructure projects in the region.

site_title: Hackers demanding bitcoin ransom attack Atlanta city computers
summary: Hackers demanding a $51,000 bitcoin ransom attacked Atlanta city computers, shutting down internal and external applications. The ransomware assault encrypted some data, prompting a news conference by Mayor Keisha Bottoms. The FBI and Department of Homeland Security are investigating, and the attack is the latest in a series of high-profile ransomware attacks that affected over 200,000 organizations globally last year.

images.alt_text: Hackers demanding ransom payable in bitcoin have attacked computers of the Atlanta city government in the southern US state of Georgia, officials say.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering secures two contracts worth S$53m
summary: Hiap Seng Engineering secured two contracts worth approximately S$53 million in Singapore. The first contract, valued at S$26 million, is for the Sebarok Tank Expansion project with Vopak Terminals Singapore, involving engineering, procurement, construction, and commissioning works. The second contract, valued at S$27 million, is for mechanical and piping works at the catalytic reforming unit revamp project with Singapore Refining Company Private Limited.

site_title: Australia shares fall to over one-month low as trade war fears heat up; NZ also lower
summary: Australia's benchmark share index fell 2% to 5,820.7, its lowest level in over a month, amid fears of a global trade war sparked by US President Donald Trump's memorandum on tariffs on China. China responded with plans to levy additional duties on US imports, threatening Australia's commodity-export reliant economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index lost 2.2% for the week, its largest weekly loss since February. Materials and financial stocks led the losses, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto falling 3.1% and 4.4%, respectively.

site_title: Noble Group's week from hell gets worse as huge lawsuit hits
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-listed commodity trader, is being sued by Indonesian coal producer PT Atlas Resources for over $260 million. The lawsuit, filed in Indonesia, is one of several mounting risks to the company's restructuring plan, which aims to hand control to creditors. The company has faced a crisis over the past three years, losing billions of dollars and selling assets to survive. Analysts say the lawsuit will complicate the restructuring process, with one analyst stating "one by one, a lot of guys may be trying to have a go at this sort of punch at the company."

site_title: Mahathir raises 'remote takeover' theory in MH370 mystery
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has suggested that the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 in 2014 might have been a remote takeover to foil a hijack. The Boeing 777 jet vanished with 239 people on board while en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, with no signs of the plane found in a massive search operation. This theory revives one of the many conspiracy theories surrounding the incident.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter Friday afternoon trading on lower ground; STI at 3,417.8, down 2.1% on the day
summary: Singapore stocks fell 2.1% on Friday, closing at 3,417.8, due to global market declines following US President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on China. The Straits Times Index (STI) was down 73.57 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 331 to 58. Major stocks, including Genting Singapore, Singtel, OCBC Bank, and UOB, also declined. The slump is attributed to concerns of a potential trade war that could hurt global growth.

site_title: Galaxy to buy Wynn stake in move that could reshape Macau
summary: Galaxy Entertainment Group agreed to buy a 5% stake in Wynn Resorts, a surprise move that could reshape the gaming landscape in Macau. Steve Wynn sold his remaining 8 million shares in Wynn Resorts, and Galaxy acquired 5.3 million newly issued shares at $175 each for $927.5 million. The deal was seen as a unique opportunity for Galaxy to acquire an investment in a globally recognized entertainment corporation with high-quality assets and a significant development pipeline.

images.alt_text: Galaxy Entertainment Group agreed to buy a stake in Wynn Resorts, in a surprise move linking two of the biggest operators in Macau and Las Vegas that could reshape the gaming landscape in the Chinese territory.

site_title: UOB partners Indonesia financial institution to boost infrastructure development
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) has partnered with Indonesia's state-owned infrastructure financing company, PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (Persero) (SMI), to support infrastructure development initiatives in Indonesia. The partnership, first established in 2013, aims to collaborate on infrastructure financing, corporate financing, and project financing for national and provincial projects. The agreement also includes support for project preparation and infrastructure advisory services, as well as equity investment and infrastructure fund management. UOB's managing director, Lim Lay Wah, believes PPPs are key to meeting Indonesia's infrastructure development needs.

site_title: Facing labour shortfall, Japan firms turn to refugees
summary: Japan's labour market faces a severe shortage, prompting companies to turn to refugees for employment. Despite Japan's strict asylum policies, a handful of companies, including Dairyu and Uniqlo, are hiring refugees, offering them competitive salaries and benefits. However, activists warn that asylum seekers often face wage discrimination and are vulnerable to exploitation. The Japanese government has granted refugee status to just 20 people out of nearly 20,000 applicants last year, and the process is notoriously slow, with applicants waiting an average of three years for a decision.

site_title: Dropbox IPO priced higher than expected on strong demand
summary: Dropbox Inc's initial public offering was priced at $21 per share, exceeding expectations, raising about $756 million. The company, with 500 million users, competes with major tech firms like Google and Microsoft. Despite a 32% revenue increase in 2017, Dropbox reported a nearly halved net loss of $111.7 million. The strong pricing bodes well for other highly anticipated tech IPOs. The company will have a market cap of about $9.18 billion on a fully diluted share count.

site_title: US Senate passes huge spending bill, sends it to Trump
summary: The US Senate passed a $1.3 trillion federal spending bill, sending it to President Donald Trump for signature. The bill boosts military and domestic spending, increases border security, and funds infrastructure projects, while addressing gun violence but not protecting undocumented immigrants or stabilizing health insurance prices. The measure passed 65-32, avoiding a government shutdown. It now awaits Trump's signature, with his aides indicating he supports the bill.

site_title: Malaysia's Mahathir gatecrashes 'too old to be PM' forum
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 92, gatecrashed a forum discussing whether he's too old to return as PM, citing his "age of the body" not equating to his years. He addressed the crowd, saying he's not senile and is fit to rule. The move comes as Mahathir seeks to challenge the current PM, Najib Razak, in upcoming polls. If successful, Mahathir would become the world's oldest prime minister. His age has raised concerns about his ability to rule, but he remains defiant.

site_title: SUTD provost Chong Tow Chong to be president from Apr 1
summary: The Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has appointed its acting president and founding provost Chong Tow Chong as its new president, effective April 1. Chong will replace Thomas Magnanti, who held the position from 2009 to 2017. Chong brings experience as executive director of A*Star's Science and Engineering Council and Data Storage Institute. He promises a "big and bold" growth phase for the university, focusing on innovative education and research, as well as expanded partnerships with industry and global universities.

images.alt_text: THE Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has appointed its acting president and founding provost Chong Tow Chong as its new president with effect from Apr 1, the tertiary institution said on Friday.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOB Kay Hian upgrades ST Engineering to 'buy'; CIMB, Maybank keep 'add'
summary: Brokers UOB Kay Hian, CIMB, and Maybank have upgraded ST Engineering to a 'buy' rating due to expected higher earnings from its smart city and marine segments. CIMB's target price is S$3.80, UOB Kay Hian's is S$4.10, and Maybank's is S$4.15. Shares in STE traded down 1.4% due to global market decline following US President Trump's tariff announcement on Chinese goods.

site_title: Indonesia coal producer files lawsuit against Noble, seeks over US$260m compensation
summary: NOBLE Group has been sued by Indonesian coal producer PT Atlas Resources Tbk, seeking over US$260 million in compensation. The lawsuit was filed in Indonesia and NOBLE Group has stated it will "vigorously defend" the claim if served. The company has not been informed of the grounds for the claim or further details. NOBLE Group plans to make a further announcement as the matter develops.

site_title: Women at Glencore oil trading unit earn 28% less than men
summary: Women working in oil trading at Glencore earn 28% less pay on average than men, with bonuses also 57% lower. Despite making up 40% of trading employees, women comprise only 16% of top quartile earners. This disparity underscores the lack of women in senior roles at commodities trading houses. Glencore attributes the gap to a greater number of men seeking careers in commodities trading, but the company has committed to supporting women and promoting equal family-friendly practices.

site_title: Markets shed risk, seek refuge in gold as US, China fire trade war's first shots
summary: US and China announce plans to impose tariffs on imports from each other, sparking concerns of a long-drawn trade dispute. Asian stocks plummet, with Singapore, Japan, and Hong Kong experiencing significant declines. Gold prices rise as investors seek refuge in safe-haven assets, while the US dollar weakens against other currencies. Analysts warn of a risk-averse market, with Nomura suggesting the US tariffs are less hawkish than initially feared, but the impact on global equity markets remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe: Shares suffer as trade jitters, weak data weigh
summary: European shares fell 1.6% on Thursday, their lowest level in two weeks, amid concerns about US trade tensions and weak economic data. US President Donald Trump signed a presidential memorandum that could impose tariffs on up to $60 billion in Chinese imports, while the European Union secured an exemption from US tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. A weaker-than-expected business activity survey also weighed on the market, with banks, basic resources stocks, and tech firms leading the losses.

site_title: UPP to regain majority stake in Canada wood firm Taiga for C$27.7m
summary: Singapore-listed paper mill company UPP Holdings is acquiring a majority stake in Canada's Taiga Building Products for C$27.7 million, regaining control of the company after a previous 49% stake was reduced to 49% following Taiga's restructuring. The acquisition includes debt owed by Kublai Canada, and UPP expects the deal to be earnings-accretive, with earnings per share increasing from S$1.50 to S$1.75. The deal is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals.

site_title: China's Baidu gets green light for self-driving vehicle tests in Beijing
summary: China's capital city Beijing has given Baidu, a tech giant, permission to test self-driving cars on city streets, including 33 roads in the less-populated suburbs. The permit is part of China's push to bolster its autonomous vehicle industry, with Baidu leading the effort. The company plans to expand its self-driving project, Apollo, and hopes to have self-driving cars on Chinese roads by 2019. This move comes as the global autonomous vehicle industry faces increased scrutiny following a fatal accident involving an Uber self-driving car in Arizona.

site_title: Maduro revalues Venezuela currency over hyperinflation
summary: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro announced a plan to re-value the country's currency, the bolivar, to combat hyperinflation, which is expected to reach 13,000% this year. The new currency will have three fewer zeroes, with the largest note, the 100,000 bolivar, becoming a 100 bolivar bill. The move is the country's second currency shift in 10 years, following a similar move by Maduro's predecessor Hugo Chavez in 2008. The new currency will begin circulating on June 4.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 18.15 points to 1,858.72 on Friday, with losers outnumbering gainers 378 to 32. The market saw a total of 106.63 million lots traded worth RM37.37 million.

site_title: China's first salvo in Trump trade war is a winning shot
summary: China has imposed tariffs on $3 billion of US goods, affecting about 2% of China's imports, in response to the US's plans to impose tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods. The levies primarily target agricultural and primary metals industries, with minimal impact on China's overall economy. This move is seen as a "warning shot" by China, aiming to avoid escalating the trade war while maintaining a strong position for diplomatic negotiations ahead.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won slide on fears of a US-China trade war
summary: South Korea's stocks and won currency plummeted to two- and three-week lows on March 23, 2018, amid fears of a US-China trade war. US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on Chinese products, prompting China to vow retaliation. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 2.2%, and the won dropped 0.7% against the dollar. Analysts warn that a trade war could severely impact the South Korean economy, with major trade partners the US and China.

site_title: Mirach Energy to resume trading on Friday, following S$5.6m share placement
summary: Mirach Energy will resume trading on the Singapore Exchange on Friday after announcing a S$5.6 million stock placement, issuing 56 million new shares at S$0.10 apiece. The funds raised will be used to settle a RM19 million investment sum. This follows a previously announced investment in a Malaysian project with RCL Kelstar.

site_title: A$5,888-a-night room with karaoke reveals Australia's China bet
summary: Star Entertainment Group's new luxury hotel on Australia's Gold Coast offers a $5,888-a-night room with karaoke, catering to Chinese gamblers. The 57-suite hotel includes a casino with refurbished private gaming rooms and is part of an $850 million development. The move aims to generate half of Australia's high-roller income from other Asian nations, particularly China, following a growing international market. Star Entertainment Group, which once relied on China, now seeks to diversify its revenue streams.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Midas, Raffles Education, Mirach Energy, Genting Singapore
summary: Noble Group faces a lawsuit from PT Atlas Resources Tbk over US$260 million in compensation, while Midas Holdings CEO Patrick Chew has resigned citing health and legal issues. Raffles Education is proposing a renounceable rights issue to raise S$44.6 million, Mirach Energy resumes trading after a S$5.6 million stock placement, and Genting Singapore will hold an EGM to seek shareholders' approval for a domicile change to Singapore.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday as fears of global trade war grow; STI down 2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 2% on Friday as fears of a global trade war grew following US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on Chinese goods. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 71.06 points to 3,420.31. China retaliated with potential tariffs on 128 US goods, including pork, wine, and steel. On Wall Street, the Dow shed 2.9%, the S&P 500 dropped 2.5%, and the Nasdaq fell 2.4%.

site_title: China's hitting the US where it hurts: in the pork belly
summary: China has imposed 25% tariffs on US pork imports in response to US tariffs on Chinese products. The move targets China's massive pork industry, which is the world's largest. China's domestic pork prices have fallen to a 2015 low, making US pork an "easy target." This retaliatory move comes after US President Donald Trump ordered tariffs on Chinese goods. The move is seen as a significant escalation of the trade war between the two countries.

site_title: China eyes measures against US imports to balance tariffs on steel, aluminium
summary: China plans measures against up to $3 billion of US imports to balance tariffs on Chinese steel and aluminium products amid a trade war between the two countries. The country has listed 128 US products that could be targeted if an agreement is not reached. US President Donald Trump signed a presidential memorandum targeting up to $60 billion in Chinese goods with tariffs, starting a 30-day consultation period.

site_title: Japan consumer prices edge up 1.0% in February
summary: Japan's consumer prices rose 1.0% in February, the eighth consecutive quarter of economic growth. However, the inflation rate remains below the 2.0% target, hindering efforts to boost the economy. This marks the longest positive growth run since the late 1980s. Despite this, Japan continues to achieve steady economic growth, but the country's inflation rate remains a concern for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Japan's consumer prices edged up 1.0 per cent in February, government data showed Friday, but inflation was still far below a longstanding target.

site_title: Genting Singapore to seek shareholders' nod to change domicile to Singapore
summary: Genting Singapore plans to hold an extraordinary general meeting on April 17 to seek shareholders' approval to change its domicile from the Isle of Man to Singapore and its company name from Genting Singapore plc to Genting Singapore Limited. The move aims to align the company's country of registration with its country of listing and main operations. If approved, the name change will take effect from the date of re-domiciliation.

site_title: Stocks slide, bonds and yen gain as trade war fears drive rush to safety
summary: US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking fears of a global trade war and driving investors to safety. Stocks slid globally, with the Dow and S&P 500 down 2.9% and 2.5%, respectively, while bonds and the yen gained. The yen rallied against the dollar, reaching its weakest since 2016. Investors fear China may retaliate, potentially escalating the trade war and impacting the global economy.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump signed a presidential memorandum on Thursday that could impose tariffs on up to US$60 billion of imports from China, although the measures have a 30-day consultation period.

site_title: Berlin relaxes AirBnB restrictions
summary: Berlin authorities have relaxed restrictions on short-term rentals, allowing private individuals to rent out their main homes without time limitations, starting May 1. The new rule comes after a 2016 ruling that previously limited home sharing to one room via specialized portals. Under the new law, owners can rent out second homes for 90 days a year, and Airbnb Germany hailed the change as a win for regular people who want to share their homes with travelers. The move aims to balance the need for affordable rentals with concerns over a potential shortage of accommodation for residents.

site_title: A new global benchmark may reduce land conflicts
summary: A new global benchmark, the International Land Measurement Standards (ILMS), aims to reduce land conflicts by providing essential information in every property transaction. The standards, developed by 40 organizations, include details on physical boundaries, land use, ownership, tenure, and estimated land value. If widely adopted, the ILMS could improve tenure security, fair compensation, and transparency in land transactions, particularly in Africa and developing countries, where displacement of local people is a significant driver of investment disputes.

site_title: ILG exploring merger with Apollo's Diamond Resorts: sources
summary: ILG Inc, a US vacation timeshare provider, is exploring a potential merger with Apollo Global Management's Diamond Resorts International Inc as an alternative to a sale. The deal could add over 400 destinations in 35 countries to ILG's 250 managed resorts in 80 countries, with ILG CEO Craig Nash potentially leading the combined company. The talks come as ILG seeks leverage in case negotiations with Marriott Vacations Worldwide Corp are not successful, with the deal potentially valued at over $3.5 billion.

site_title: EU plans tougher consumer laws for Facebook, Gmail
summary: The European Union plans to impose tougher consumer laws on social media networks and email providers like Facebook and Gmail, with fines of at least 4% of turnover. The proposal aims to extend EU consumer law to "free" digital services that collect personal data, giving consumers the right to pre-contractual information and contract cancellation within 14 days. This follows reports of data misuse, including the 2016 US presidential election scandal, and is part of the EU's efforts to regulate technology giants and increase consumer protection.

site_title: India plans to launch flights to Asean capitals from Assam
summary: India plans to launch flights from Assam to Asean capitals, including Singapore, under a scheme subsidizing air travel. The move aims to boost ties with South-east Asia amid growing interest in the region. This is part of India's efforts to expand its presence in the Asean market, following a growing focus on strengthening its relations with South-east Asia.

site_title: China unveils list of potential retaliatory tariffs on US goods
summary: China has released a list of potential tariffs on US$3 billion worth of US goods in retaliation to new US trade sanctions, including 15% tariffs on $1 billion worth of goods and 25% tariffs on $2 billion worth. The list does not include soya beans, which US farmers heavily rely on. The move comes after US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on up to $60 billion of imports to retaliate against China's intellectual property theft. China urges the US to resolve its concerns through dialogue to avoid damage to overall Sino-US cooperation.

images.alt_text: A 25 per cent would be imposed on a second category of goods totalling nearly US$2 billion, including pork and aluminium scrap, after "further evaluating the impact of the US measures on China", the statement said.

site_title: It's make or break for China's US$20b Egyptian capital plan
summary: China's US$20 billion project to develop Egypt's new capital is at a critical juncture after nearly two years of negotiations. The project, led by China Fortune Land Development Co (CFLD), aims to transform 700 square kilometers of desert into a modern hub for government buildings and companies. However, wrangling over revenue sharing has hindered progress. Egyptian officials are studying CFLD's latest proposal, which includes committing to $2 billion in foreign direct investment in the first five years and creating 230,000 jobs over its lifetime.

site_title: The Individualist
summary: Actress and playwright Jo Tan, a former lawyer, has turned to the arts after realizing her passion for acting. She is currently nominated for Best Supporting Actress for her role in Checkpoint Theatre's "Frago." Tan finds inspiration in discovering new things and immersing herself in different lives and circumstances through her work. She is drawn to the vulnerability of human truth and is moved by people who reveal their authenticity, allowing for deeper connections with others and themselves.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Oil retreats after failing to hit US$70/barrel
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday as investors took profits and US stock markets declined, limiting losses despite Opec efforts to curb supplies. Brent crude futures dropped 0.8% to $68.91 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 1.3% to $64.30 a barrel. The decline follows a rally in the past two weeks, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over Middle East supplies. US President Trump's potential tariffs on China also weighed on oil prices.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us founder dies as iconic retail chain folds
summary: Toys 'R' Us founder Charles Lazarus, 94, died a week after the company announced its US operations would be liquidated, shutting down 735 stores and potentially slashing 33,000 jobs. Lazarus founded the company in 1948 as a small childcare store, evolving into a recognizable kids' brand. The move was a result of the online retail boom and debt, prompting a GoFundMe campaign to raise $1 billion to acquire assets through bankruptcy. Billionaire Isaac Larian has pledged to preserve the brand's "innocent experience" for future generations.

site_title: French energy firm Engie to invest S$80m in Singapore innovation centre, create 170 jobs
summary: French energy firm Engie will invest S$80 million in Singapore over five years to develop an innovation centre, creating 170 jobs, primarily engineers. The centre will support district cooling projects in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region. Engie's digital initiatives include real-time data analysis, IoT platforms, and integrated building management systems to improve energy efficiency and comfort. The centre will become Engie's innovation hub for the Asia Pacific, driven by Singapore's Smart Nation initiatives and supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board.

site_title: What's ailing tech? Investors are not waiting to find out
summary: Tech shares plummeted on Thursday, with $2.5 billion withdrawn from the PowerShares QQQ Trust Series 1 ETF, the largest tech-heavy ETF. The decline is driven by concerns over Facebook's use of user data by Cambridge Analytica and fears of a trade war with China. Investors are also worried about potential regulations on the tech industry, with Mark Zuckerberg stating that companies may need to be regulated. The Nasdaq 100 is set for its worst week since February, with Apple and other tech giants also experiencing declines.

site_title: US: Dow Jones ends 2.9% lower as Trump China tariffs spur selloff
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.9% on Thursday as President Trump imposed tariffs on up to $60 billion of Chinese goods, sparking fears of a trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 23,957.89, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 2.5% and 2.4%, respectively. Analysts warn that a trade conflict could harm the global economy and stocks, particularly those reliant on China. The move also raised concerns over interest rates and the Mueller investigation, contributing to the market's volatility.

site_title: AT&T will use Time Warner as 'weapon' if merger goes ahead: US Justice Dept
summary: The US Justice Department is challenging AT&T's $85 billion merger with Time Warner, arguing it would give the company an unfair edge against rival pay TV operators, leading to higher prices for 90 million pay TV subscribers. The government claims the merger would allow AT&T to charge higher prices and hinder innovation, citing a study that suggests consumer costs could rise by over $400 million annually. AT&T's lawyers argue that the combined firm would benefit consumers by competing against tech giants dominating advertising, and that the merger would enable more targeted ads, potentially reducing prices. The case is the highest-profile antitrust battle in years.

site_title: US music sales hit decade high as streaming soars
summary: US music sales reached a decade-high in 2017, driven by a 16.5% revenue growth, the first two-year expansion since 1999. Total recorded music sales from all formats reached $8.7 billion, surpassing 2008 levels. The rise of streaming, with 35.3 million paid subscribers, accounted for the majority of the growth. Physical sales, including vinyl, increased, while digital downloads declined 25%. Industry leaders hope for a bill to guarantee online radio royalties for pre-1972 songs, currently exempt under law, to further boost revenue.

site_title: In world first, Air India crosses Saudi airspace to Israel
summary: Air India launched the world's first scheduled flight from Saudi Arabia to Israel, crossing Saudi airspace, marking a significant improvement in ties between the two countries. The three weekly flights will end a decades-long Saudi ban on commercial flights to Israel. The move comes after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu described relations with the Arab world as the "best ever" due to shared concerns over Iran. Saudi Arabia's decision is seen as a small but significant gesture towards positive relations, despite a lack of an Israeli-Palestinian peace treaty.

site_title: Other tech companies face more scrutiny to tighten data sharing
summary: Facebook's data sharing scandal with Cambridge Analytica has led to increased scrutiny of other tech companies' data sharing practices. US and EU lawmakers are calling for probes into how companies share customer information. The incident has resulted in a 8.5% drop in Facebook shares, with investors fearing new regulation. Other tech companies, including small software developers, may face similar scrutiny and potential regulation.

site_title: Tesla shareholders approve CEO Musk's US$2.6b compensation plan
summary: Tesla shareholders approved a compensation package worth up to $2.6 billion for CEO Elon Musk, with 73% of votes cast in favor, excluding Musk's vote. The plan sets rewards based on Tesla's market value rising to $650 billion over 10 years, surpassing previous top US executive payouts. Musk could own up to $55.8 billion in Tesla stock if he hits all targets, despite shares being down 18% from a year high due to production delays and increasing competition.

site_title: UOB taps data analytics to spur lending to Asean small businesses
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is utilizing data analytics to enhance lending to small businesses in Asean, cutting turnaround time for loan applications by over half and reducing default rates by 50%. The bank's enhanced credit underwriting engine combines existing data with new sources, such as company operations and government databases, to assess credit risk. This has resulted in a more efficient and accurate lending process, providing a "frictionless experience" for customers. The initiative has been rolled out in five Asean markets, addressing a key barrier to financing small businesses: the lack of data.

site_title: Trump ousts McMaster, taps super-hawk Bolton as national security adviser
summary: US President Donald Trump announced the ousting of National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster, replacing him with John Bolton, a hawk who advocates for military force against Iran and North Korea. Bolton, 69, becomes Trump's third national security adviser in 14 months. Trump cited McMaster's inability to unite the country on national security issues as the reason for the change. Bolton, known for his hardline stance against Russia, will take on the role of shaping Trump's foreign policy.

site_title: True Talent
summary: A three-day festival, True Colours Festival, launched in Singapore, featuring artistes with disabilities from around the world, including Canada, the UK, US, Chile, and Japan. The event showcases performances by contemporary dance troupe DAZZLE, wheelchair dancer Rodney Bell, and theatre productions by Singapore and Australia. The festival runs from March 22 to 25 at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, highlighting inclusivity and diversity.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei plunges 3% at open on trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 3% at open on Friday due to revived trade war fears as US President Donald Trump unveiled tariffs on Chinese imports. The Nikkei 225 index fell 648.50 points to 20,943.49, while the Topix index dropped 43.67 points to 1,683.72. This move followed Trump's previous threats, which traders have largely brushed off, resulting in a mixed reaction to new US trade threats.

site_title: Bank of England, seeking digital boost, sets up its own fintech hub
summary: The Bank of England has established its own fintech hub to explore the use of digital technologies that have led to cryptocurrencies like bitcoin. Deputy Governor Dave Ramsden announced the hub, which will be a central point of contact for the fintech sector and a part of a new taskforce aiming to maintain London's global financial center status. The move aims to boost Britain's economy and address its weak productivity growth by leveraging fintech to drive competition and improve internal infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England will set up its own fintech hub to find ways to use the kind of technology that has spawned digital currencies such as bitcoin and which could eventually help boost Britain's economy, a top BoE official said on Thursday.

site_title: Thinking Big
summary: Dinesh Balasingam, co-founder and COO of Chope, a Singapore-based online restaurant booking platform, shares his journey of turning his dream into a reality. After a seven-year gap year, he founded Chope in 2011, which has since seated one million diners and boasts 950,000 active users in eight cities across South-east Asia. Balasingam credits his success to building a strong team and looks up to Spotify's Daniel Ek as a role model. He aims to continue challenging himself and growing, with Chope's future plans unknown.

site_title: Arizona police release video of fatal collision with Uber self-driving SUV
summary: Arizona police released a video of a fatal collision between an Uber self-driving SUV and a pedestrian, Elaine Herzberg, 49, who was killed in Tempe, Arizona, on Sunday night. The incident occurred when Herzberg crossed the road outside of a crosswalk and into the SUV's path. Uber suspended its self-driving testing in North America and federal safety regulators are conducting an investigation. The incident has raised concerns about the safety of autonomous vehicles and could stall their development and testing.

site_title: Dollar hovers above one-month low
summary: The US dollar hovered near a one-month low against a basket of currencies after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter point as expected, signaling a less aggressive rate hike schedule. Investors interpreted the move as dovish, but some analysts saw it as dollar-positive in the short term due to tightening funding conditions. The dollar was 0.1% lower against a basket of currencies, but held above a one-month low of 89.396, as traders may turn to the dollar for security in a potential global market selloff.

site_title: Powell puts market on notice over heightened risks
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell hinted at heightened risks in the market, citing "elevated" asset prices and the threat of a trade war. The Fed raised the benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, with economists expecting more rate hikes in 2018. The market initially reacted positively before Powell's press conference, where he expressed concerns about trade policy and its impact on global economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended slightly in the red, with Treasury yields rising and stocks shedding gains.

site_title: BMW X2 review: Getting cross eyed
summary: BMW's X2 is a breath of fresh air in the crowded crossover segment, offering driving pleasure and bold design. The smallest and newest member of BMW's SUV range, the X2 boasts a 2.0-litre turbo engine with 192 horsepower, a joyful power delivery, and an upbeat soundtrack. With a lower stance, shapelier rear end, and eye-catching design, the X2 stands out from its brother, the X1. While it's not the quietest or most composed vehicle, its fun-to-drive nature and premium interior make it a standout in the segment, despite its high price tag of S$193,888.

site_title: SGX says no conflict of interest with expanded stock research unit
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has expanded its in-house research unit to provide reports on listed companies, despite concerns about potential conflicts of interest. The exchange claims to have measures in place to separate supervision from commercial objectives, including an independent subsidiary. SGX's research focuses on historical analysis and industry news, not buy or sell recommendations. The move is seen as a response to the EU's MiFID II rules, which require fund managers to pay for investment research separately. The expansion aims to attract more companies to list on SGX's venues.

images.alt_text: Can the people who regulate a company also produce research useful to an investor considering buying its stock? Singapore Exchange says the answer is yes.

site_title: Blends are for those seeking mild drinks
summary: A recent spirits panel tasting of 20 blended Scotch whiskies found that they still vastly outsell single malts, despite their proportion of the Scotch market dwindling since 1990. Blended Scotch combines malt and grain whiskies, with grain whisky adding complexity and character. The panel preferred whiskies with assertive malt characters, but found that blended Scotch's mildness and restraint make it appealing to those who prefer whisky that's not as aggressive as many single malts. Top-rated blended Scotch bottles included Buchanan's Master, Teacher's Highland Cream, and Johnnie Walker Black Label.

site_title: Yuuzoo claims tight time frame by SGX was mission 'impossible'
summary: YuuZoo Corporation claimed the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) tight deadline for disclosure was "impossible" to meet, leading to the suspension of its shares. The company was required to provide auditors with business plans and financial analysis by March 8, but asked for an extension until the end of March, which was rejected. YuuZoo ultimately handed over the documents on March 19, with auditors agreeing to review them by March 28. The company disputes the SGX's figures, stating they were "properly derived and computed" according to accounting standards.

site_title: Genting might hit jackpot buying Wynn Resorts
summary: Genting chairman Lim Kok Thay is exploring a potential acquisition of Wynn Resorts, a move that could give the Malaysian gaming and resorts group a significant boost. This comes after Genting failed to win a casino license in Macau in 2002. Lim has expressed his desire to capitalize on the opportunity, potentially rectifying his past loss.

site_title: Asian markets shrug off rate hike as trade war threat looms
summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday despite a US Federal Reserve rate hike, as investors weighed the threat of a trade war between the US and China. Analysts expect three more rate hikes this year due to rising inflationary pressures. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Other news includes Malaysia seizing assets worth RM3 billion, Citigroup predicting a mid-2026 target for the MSCI global equity index, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: STI slips 0.6% after Powell's first rate hike
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a modest dip of 0.56% on Thursday, following the Federal Reserve's rate hike to 1.5-1.75%. The key Straits Times Index fell 19.76 points to 3,491.37, with some 1.5 billion shares traded. Market watchers are concerned over the surge in the three-month US-dollar London interbank offered rate (Libor) to 2.25%, its highest since 2008, and the widening of the Libor-OIS spread, indicating imbalances in the offshore US funding markets.

site_title: Battle Bots
summary: Pacific Rim: Uprising, the sequel to the 2013 original, has been released in cinemas, featuring battles between monsters (Kaiju) and robots (Jaegers). The film is directed by Steven S. DeKnight, replacing Guillermo del Toro. The plot, like the first film, is criticized for being noisy and lacking coherence.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Emblem Of Luxury
summary: Bottega Veneta launches a personalisation programme, reflecting its motto "When your own initials are enough", to cater to individual customers' tastes. The brand offers various personalisation options, including embossing, stamping, and stitching, for bags, wallets, and small leather goods. Available at three boutiques in Singapore, this service allows customers to create unique pieces within a day or a minimum three-month turnaround period. By giving customers control over their luxury purchases, Bottega Veneta aims to enhance its relationship with clients in a highly competitive luxury market.

site_title: Subhash Chandra
summary: Subhash Chandra, chairman of the Essel Group, has expanded his business into the wellness industry with the opening of Yo1 Wellness Center in New York, a 1,310-acre resort focusing on health, fitness, and natural healing. This move follows his successful ventures in media, including Zee News and entertainment networks, and packaging company Essel Propack. Chandra attributes the growing demand for wellness services to people seeking alternatives to traditional medicine. He believes that by offering minimally-invasive therapies, Yo1 can capitalize on this trend and attract a large audience.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Government to fund 300 assessments for Smart Industry Index
summary: The Singapore government will fund 300 assessments for the Smart Industry Index, aiming to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and multinational corporations (MNCs) accelerate industrial transformation efforts. This move is expected to support the country's industrial development and competitiveness.

site_title: Sias president urges China Hongxing to postpone its EGM
summary: Sias president urges China Hongxing to postpone its extraordinary general meeting, citing the need for the company to address shareholders' concerns about its operating subsidiaries. The meeting, scheduled for March 28, will vote on a majority shareholders' bid to acquire the subsidiaries. Sias wants China Hongxing to hold an informal dialogue with shareholders before voting, allowing them to ask questions and understand the issues at hand. The watchdog association also questions the company's valuation and whether it has obtained the best price for the subsidiaries.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: CNMC gets higher share of gold in mine but yield is uncertain
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 16% increase in its share of gold resources in its Sokor project in Malaysia, with 724,000 ounces of measured, indicated, and inferred gold. The company's share of gold resources is 586,000 ounces, with measured resources decreasing to 40,000 ounces and indicated resources increasing to 228,000 ounces. CNMC aims to ramp up production in 2018 after a year of below-average gold output, citing the latest assessment as evidence of the project's commercial viability. The company's shares rose 3.9% on the news.

site_title: Eurozone business boom eases off but growth still solid
summary: The eurozone's economic boom has slowed to its weakest growth in over a year, with a Reuters poll predicting a 0.7% first-quarter GDP growth, slightly faster than expected. The slowdown is attributed to a stubbornly strong euro, which has pushed up the euro against the dollar. Despite this, the eurozone economy remains robust, with the flash composite PMI remaining above the 50 mark. The European Central Bank is expected to keep borrowing costs unchanged until next year, while the US Federal Reserve continues to raise interest rates, forecasting at least two more hikes this year.

site_title: Makeway View sold to Bukit Sembawang Estates unit for S$168m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' unit successfully tendered for the en bloc sale of Makeway View for S$168 million, reflecting a land rate of S$1,626 per square foot per plot ratio. The site, a 10-storey freehold development, can be redeveloped into a 21-22 storey high-rise apartment block with around 154 units, pending authorities' approval. Owners of the 28 apartments and 4 penthouses will receive gross sale proceeds between S$3.86 million and S$10.74 million per unit.

site_title: US retailer Best Buy cutting ties with China's Huawei
summary: US retailer Best Buy is cutting ties with China's Huawei, the largest US consumer electronics retailer, amid heightened scrutiny on Chinese tech firms in the US. Best Buy will stop selling Huawei's devices over the next few weeks, a setback for the Chinese telecommunications giant. The move follows similar actions from US carriers including AT&T, amid simmering tensions over US-China trade and security concerns. Huawei's products meet industry standards, but the company has been forced to sell its flagship smartphone in the US only through open channels due to the tougher climate.

site_title: Meredith looks to sell Time, Fortune, Sports Illustrated; to cut 1,200 jobs
summary: Meredith Corp, the parent company of Time, Fortune, Sports Illustrated, and other magazines, plans to sell these brands as part of its efforts to streamline operations and cut costs. The company, which acquired Time Inc for $1.84 billion, has already cut 200 jobs and plans to lay off another 1,000 positions. Meredith aims to achieve annual savings of $400-500 million, but analysts predict it will need to be more aggressive to reach its cost-cut targets. The company is exploring a sale of these brands, which are seen as not aligning with its core focus on women's magazines.

site_title: US home sales surge, but supply remains a headache
summary: US home sales surged 3% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.54 million units, driven by strong gains in the South and West regions. However, a chronic shortage of houses on the market remains an obstacle, with existing inventory down 8.1% from a year ago. Median house prices rose 5.9% to $241,700, outpacing wage growth, and first-time buyers accounted for 29% of transactions. Economists expect supply to remain tight this year, which may limit modest home sales growth in 2018.

site_title: A peek into the workings of GIC's tech investment group
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC, has established a technology investment group to identify tomorrow's game-changers in the rapidly evolving tech space. Led by Jeremy Kranz, the group builds strong relationships with tech firms and invests in those with good business models at the right moment. With investments in over 50 companies across eight countries, GIC takes a long-term view, employing a "offence, defence and excellence" strategy to hunt for high-potential firms. The group uses a bottom-up approach, focusing on entrepreneurs who can execute well and adopt a hands-on approach to understand the business.

images.alt_text: GIC Head of GIC technology investment group Jeremy Kranz says it comes down to building strong relationships with technology firms and investing in those with good business models at the very right moment.
Chief executive Lim Chow Kiat says internally, GIC describes its strategy in the tech space in the framework of "offence, defence and excellence".

site_title: A Jewel In Paris
summary: Italian jeweller Bvlgari is expanding its hospitality arm, adding a new hotel in Paris, set to open in 2020. This follows previous openings in Beijing, Dubai, Shanghai, and Moscow, with eight properties worldwide, including Milan, London, and Bali. The Paris hotel, designed by Antonio Citterio Patricia Viel and Valode & Pistre, will feature 76 rooms, mainly suites.

site_title: Google 'working on blockchain-for-cloud tech'
summary: Google is working on blockchain technology to support its cloud business and compete with emerging startups using the technology. The company is developing its own distributed digital ledger that third parties can use to post and verify transactions, and plans to offer a white-label version that other companies can run on their own servers. This move aims to differentiate its cloud service from rivals and head off competition in the market, which is expected to grow from $706 million in 2017 to over $60 billion in 2024.

site_title: Jaguar's new SUV costs S$193,999
summary: Jaguar's new SUV, the E-Pace, has arrived in Singapore with a starting price of S$193,999 for the base model. The E-Pace shares its platform with the Land Rover Discovery Sport and Range Rover Evoque, despite its sports car-like design and interior features. The car is available in three versions, including a 2.0 S model with 249 horsepower and a 2.0 SE R-Dynamic version with 300 horsepower. The E-Pace is aimed at newcomers to the Jaguar brand, following the success of the F-Pace, and is expected to boost the brand's coffers.

site_title: Corporate governance should strive for the community good
summary: Corporate governance authorities are considering changes to quarterly reporting, independent director tenure, and dual class shares. The Council on Corporate Disclosure and Governance (CCDG) principle of doing good for the community, not just shareholders, is being referenced as a guiding factor. However, defining the community good and balancing corporate interests is challenging, with potential consequences such as information asymmetry and less qualified board members. Regulators must weigh the impact of their decisions on the community and economy, with dual class shares likely to be allowed to list on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Potter Mania
summary: Singapore-born scientist Wee Hong Ling, who switched careers from NASA to pottery, is set to present a solo exhibition titled "In Flux" at The Private Museum from March 22 to May 6. Her work features four series of ceramic pieces and new blacksmithing works, showcasing her talent in ceramics competitions worldwide. Admission to the exhibition is free.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: When brands hit a wall in developing Asia
summary: Fewer than 20% of brands outgrow their categories in developing Asia, according to research. This high-growth region presents opportunities for FMCG brands, but many struggle to adapt to changing consumer behaviors and market trends. Five common pitfalls include: failing to understand category fundamentals and consumer occasions, inconsistent or inappropriate brand messaging, succumbing to range complexity, failing to deliver in the store, and failing to build the right route to market. To succeed, brands must take a systematic approach, investing in consumer insights, consistent messaging, and in-store execution.

site_title: Easter Outing
summary: The Royal Easter Show in Sydney, Australia, is a major annual event celebrating Aussie country life, featuring animal shows, agricultural competitions, and food demonstrations. The show runs from March 22 to April 3 at Sydney Olympic Park. Additionally, the inaugural Edge Silent Disco will take place on March 26-28, with up to 1,000 participants expected. The event also features a specialty Cheese Burger Pie, created for the show in 2016. Tickets are available at eastershow.com.au.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Looking at workplace aggression through a new lens
summary: Workplace aggression is a widespread issue, affecting employee morale and productivity. Research has identified three primary forms of aggression: abusive supervision, supervisor undermining, and ostracising employees. Studies found that these forms of aggression trigger different emotions and counterproductive behaviors, including anger, anxiety, and avoidance. Abusive supervision leads to "approach" behavior, while ostracism triggers "avoidance" responses. Companies can address these issues by implementing targeted interventions, such as respect policies, training, and wellness schemes, to create a positive work environment and prevent workplace aggression.

site_title: US spending plan includes US$100m for R&D of autonomous cars
summary: A US spending bill includes $100 million for a research and development program on autonomous cars, with $60 million for grants and $38 million for government agencies to conduct research on self-driving vehicles. The funding aims to test feasibility and safety, and will prioritize topics that fill gaps in private sector research. Additionally, up to $1.5 million will be set aside for a comprehensive analysis of the impact of self-driving vehicles on US employment. This comes after a pedestrian was killed in an Uber self-driving SUV accident in Arizona, raising concerns about the deployment of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Page-To-Stage Success
summary: The National Theatre in London has adapted Mark Haddon's bestselling book, The Curious Incident of the Dog In the Night-time, into an award-winning stage play. Directed by Marianne Elliott, the play follows 15-year-old Christopher, a boy with a social disability, as he investigates the murder of his neighbor's dog and clears his own name. The play features a simple stage transforming into different locations through lights and sounds, and multiple actors playing various roles. The Singapore premiere is set to run from March 29 to April 8 at the Esplanade Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Skoda is back - and for good
summary: Skoda has returned to the Singapore car market with a new dealership, operated by Volkswagen Group Singapore, after exiting the market in 2013. The brand is now being handled by VGS, which is offering four models, including the Octavia, Superb, Rapid Spaceback, and Kodiaq, with prices ranging from S$103,400 to S$167,900. The relaunch aims to cater to a diverse group of car buyers and complement VW's existing range, with Skoda's 'Simply Clever' philosophy emphasizing ingeniously designed cars.

site_title: Rising Libor is the story of the year, not Fed, says Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley's chief strategist, Jonathan Garner, says rising private borrowing rates, not a more hawkish US Federal Reserve, are the bigger concern for markets. The three-month US dollar London interbank offered rate (Libor) has reached 2.25%, its highest since 2008, and its gap over risk-free rates has more than doubled to 55 basis points. Garner expects the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates by a quarter of a point to 1.75% and predicts three or four rate hikes, with global equities likely to experience a tougher market for the rest of the year due to high valuations and over-optimistic earnings expectations.

site_title: US: EU, 6 other economies exempt from metals tariffs for now
summary: The US has temporarily exempted the European Union and six other economies, including Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, and South Korea, from the 25% steel tariff and 10% aluminum tariff imposed by President Trump. The exemptions are in effect while talks continue to find a more permanent solution. This move follows joint statements from EU and US officials working towards a solution to avoid tariffs on the trading bloc.

site_title: Weekend Of Feasting
summary: JW Marriott Singapore South Beach is hosting "Taste the Moment", a two-day culinary festival on March 24-25, featuring masterclasses, workshops, and a five-course supper session with dishes like scallops and chorizo. The event includes interactive experiences with visual storytelling, performances, and music. Tickets are available at tasteofjw.com.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: There are many ways China can hit back at Trump: from taxes to probes
summary: China is preparing to retaliate against US President Donald Trump's plan to impose $50 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, with various options available to defend its interests. These include imposing tariffs on US goods, restricting US access to China's government procurement market, and targeting US companies operating in China through customs and regulatory actions. China has already launched a probe into US imports of sorghum and is studying restrictions on US soybean shipments. Beijing is also considering actions such as suspending foreign service providers and denying US companies access to local markets.

site_title: Think cryptocurrency is confusing? Try working out how much tax to pay on it
summary: Cryptocurrency traders are struggling to navigate the complex tax rules governing virtual currencies, with many fearing huge tax bills and increased scrutiny from the IRS. The 2014 IRS guidelines governing taxation of virtual currencies have created confusion, and some traders are even seeking to evade taxes by converting assets into "privacy coins." The IRS has formed a team to investigate cryptocurrency-related crimes, and exchanges like Coinbase are now required to report transactions to the agency. Specialized accountants are helping traders navigate the tax implications, but many are still unaware of their tax obligations, resulting in significant tax bills.

site_title: AIA Singapore appoints new chief technology officer
summary: AIA Singapore has appointed Gunawan Chiu Wu Pin as its new chief technology officer, effective March 19. He replaces Leong Weng Ling, who moved to AIA Group Technology. Chiu will drive and develop digital initiatives for AIA Singapore, part of the company's digital transformation plans. He previously held the chief of technology role at AIA Financial Indonesia, overseeing IT operations and digital initiatives.

site_title: KL - A New Food Paradise
summary: Kuala Lumpur has emerged as a food destination, catching up with Singapore's hip dining scene. New restaurants and cafes are popping up, offering unique dining experiences. Merchant's Lane, a café in Chinatown, serves Hong Kong-style items with a local twist. Nadodi, a 48-seat restaurant, presents a modern take on South Indian cuisine with innovative techniques. Birch, a partially floor-to-ceiling "green house" café, offers creative dishes and cocktails. These establishments, along with others, are revitalizing Kuala Lumpur's food scene, attracting tourists and locals alike.

site_title: Datapulse's compliance review: holistic or compromised?
summary: SGX has directed Datapulse Technology to undertake an independent review of its internal controls and corporate governance practices following recent events, including the Wayco acquisition and the appointment of new directors.
