summary: The International Salvage Union (ISU) reported that its members carried out 252 operations on vessels carrying over 3.4 million tonnes of potentially polluting cargoes in 2017, a significant increase from 213 operations and 2.7 million tonnes in 2016. Despite a 50% drop in gross revenues in the previous year, the number of salvage operations and total pollutants removed increased. The ISU emphasized its members' role in protecting the marine environment, highlighting their work in responding to hurricanes and facilitating humanitarian aid.

site_title: US shoe brands join retailers in lobby against China tariffs
summary: US shoe brands and retailers, including Wal-Mart, Target, Best Buy, and Macy's, have joined forces to lobby against proposed tariffs on imported goods from China, citing higher consumer prices and job losses. The companies argue that tariffs would increase costs for footwear consumers and reduce US jobs. The move comes as President Donald Trump considers sweeping tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: China's electric car executives call for policy support, end to protectionism
summary: China's electric car executives are urging the state to provide more policy clarity and overhaul local government subsidies that have distorted the market. They call for a phase-out of subsidies, consistent national guidelines, and technological standards. Industry executives say the future of the industry will depend on improving performance and driver convenience, with battery life and recharging speeds being major concerns. The state must also tackle "protectionist" local governments that offer extra subsidies and preferential policies, which have hindered market development and innovation.

site_title: Keppel unit secures bonuses worth over £7 million
summary: Keppel Seghers, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure Group, has secured bonuses worth over £7 million (S$12.9 million) with Viridor EfW (Runcorn) for the Phase 2 Thermal Power Station. The bonuses were awarded for Keppel Seghers' "excellence in operational performance" and a technical support agreement valued at £3.25 million was signed. The contract covers plant operation reports, personnel training, and specialist technical support for five years. This is part of a larger waste and renewable energy project in the UK, which processes up to 850,000 tonnes of refuse derived fuel annually.

site_title: Will New Noble be more of the same?
summary: Noble Group's proposed restructuring, led by the existing management team, has raised concerns about the company's governance and transparency. The new company, New Noble, will be listed on the Singapore Exchange, but critics argue that it will be "much like the old one." The current management team, including chairman Paul Brough, has been accused of having flawed nominating processes, leading to conflicts of interest and questionable remuneration. The company's remuneration policies have been criticized, with executives receiving large payouts despite the company's significant losses. The proposed restructuring plan has also been questioned, with concerns about fairness and favoritism towards management and senior creditors.

site_title: Curbing cellphone zombies on the street
summary: Montclair, California, has made it illegal to cross streets while on a phone, texting or listening to music with buds in both ears. The law aims to curb "cellphone zombies" responsible for accidents and pedestrians burying their noses in smartphones while crossing streets. Fines of $100 and up to $500 will be imposed for repeat offenses. This move follows similar laws in Honolulu and Rexburg, Idaho, and is being considered in other states and cities. Distracted walking is a growing concern, contributing to a rise in pedestrian deaths, with 37,461 reported in the US in 2016.

site_title: Shareholder sues Noble and execs, accuses them of inflating profits
summary: A major shareholder, Goldilocks Investment Co, has sued Noble Group and its executives in Singapore, accusing them of inflating profits to raise capital. The lawsuit claims that Noble's management paid themselves inflated salaries and tried to cover up the issue. The company has also undergone a ratings downgrade by S&P Global Ratings, and its shares have fallen. Fund managers of Orbis and Prudential have also sold down their stakes in Noble. The lawsuit seeks relief from Noble on behalf of shareholders, including $169 million paid to executives between 2011 and 2017.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Securing the multi-cloud
summary: Juniper Networks emphasizes the importance of securing multi-cloud platforms as companies shift their data to private and public clouds. The company proposes a custom blend of private, public, and centrally managed clouds to manage and control security. This approach allows less sensitive data to be stored in public clouds and extremely sensitive data to be kept in private data centers. Juniper's solutions, including a Software Defined Secure Network and virtual firewall, aim to provide defense across a multi-vendor environment and automate security policies for both public and private data centers.

site_title: CapitaLand unit to manage mall in Oxley's The Peak in Phnom Penh
summary: CapitaLand Retail has signed an agreement to manage the mall component of The Peak, a high-end integrated development in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The 5-storey mall will have a gross floor area of 420,000 sq ft and will open in 2020. CapitaLand will oversee asset planning, pre-opening, and retail management. The Peak is a 55-storey development that includes an office tower, luxury residential towers, and the mall, majority owned by Oxley Holdings and Worldbridge Land. The partnership aims to optimize returns for The Peak through quality retailers.

site_title: Italy exports first gas as Snam seeks to build up trading hub
summary: Italy has successfully exported its first natural gas, marking a significant milestone for Snam SpA, the nation's pipeline operator. The export is part of efforts to build up southern Europe as a trading hub for gas, aiming to increase flexibility and use storage facilities in Italy. The move aims to deepen connections between Italy's network and the European gas trading business, with potential export destinations including Switzerland, Germany, France, and Northern Europe.

site_title: Singapore still the most liveable city in Asia: Mercer
summary: Singapore remains the most liveable city in Asia, ranking 25th globally, according to Mercer's 2018 Quality of Living survey. The city-state topped the Asian rankings, with Vienna and Zurich taking second and third spots respectively. Other top-ranked Asian cities include Tokyo, Kobe, and Yokohama. Despite economic volatility in Europe, many cities remain attractive destinations for expatriates.

site_title: VW to invest US$340m more in Tennessee plant
summary: Volkswagen is investing an additional US$340 million in its Chattanooga, Tennessee plant to build SUVs, including a five-passenger version of the Atlas. The move comes despite rising international trade friction, with President Trump imposing tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. Analysts warn of a potential trade war, but German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier expressed optimism about resolving the issue, citing possible talks that could avoid a heavy trade conflict. The investment aims to grow Volkswagen's SUV portfolio in the US market.

site_title: Charges to fund T5: Is there another way?
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore is imposing progressively increasing charges on passengers and planes to fund the construction of Terminal 5 and other expansion works. The airport expects to handle 50 million passengers a year by 2030, with demand for air travel in the Asia-Pacific region expected to triple in the next two decades. While airlines cite costs, passengers may feel the brunt of the fees, which could impact demand for travel. The government is funding the lion's share of the infrastructure costs, with Changi Airport Group contributing S$3.6 billion to date.

site_title: French ex-president Sarkozy held in Libya financing probe
summary: French ex-president Nicolas Sarkozy was detained for questioning over allegations that late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi financed his 2007 election campaign with suitcases of cash. Sarkozy, 63, was questioned by officers specializing in corruption and tax evasion in Paris. The investigation also involves Brice Hortefeux, a close ally of Sarkozy's. Sarkozy has denied the allegations, calling them "disgraceful" and "the rantings of vindictive Libyan regime members."

images.alt_text: It is alleged that Gaddafi (right) financed Mr Sarkozy's (left) 2007 election campaign, including with suitcases stuffed with cash.

site_title: Transition deal boosts Brexit hopes of final agreement
summary: The UK and EU have agreed on a provisional Brexit transition deal, set to run until December 31, 2020. The deal aims to smooth the Brexit process and pave the way for tough talks on a final settlement. The UK government wants a transition period to adjust to new frameworks, but some Brexiteers see it as "backsliding." The EU and UK will now focus on a final framework deal, which could be reached by October, and will involve key issues such as the Irish border and a new trade deal.

site_title: Making sense of the wildly varying cryptocurrency rules around the world
summary: Cryptocurrency regulations vary widely across the world, with some countries, like Japan and Singapore, adopting a more hands-off approach, while others, such as China and India, have cracked down on trading and ICOs. The US operates in a gray area, with the Securities and Exchange Commission scrutinizing ICOs and cryptocurrency hedge funds. Global coordination is lacking, and the European Commission is reviewing the bloc's regulatory framework. Russia has proposed banning cryptocurrency payments, while Africa's major economies have varying levels of regulation, with some countries warning about risks like money laundering and tax evasion.

site_title: US dollar perches at one-week high vs yen
summary: The US dollar reached a one-week high against the Japanese yen on Tuesday, trading at 106.52 yen, amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike on Wednesday. The Fed is expected to raise rates for the sixth time since 2015, with two more hikes anticipated for the remainder of the year. The euro also fell, weighed down by a drop in German investor confidence and a Reuters report suggesting ECB policymakers are shifting their focus to the rate path.

site_title: California housing problems are spilling across to neighbouring states
summary: California's housing crisis is spilling over to neighboring states, including Nevada, where a growing number of Californians and companies, such as Tesla, are moving to take advantage of cheap land and low home prices. Reno, Nevada, is experiencing a surge in development, but local residents are concerned about traffic congestion, overcrowded schools, and the impact on the community. Other cities, including Austin, Texas, Boise, Idaho, Denver, Colorado, Phoenix, Arizona, Portland, Oregon, and Seattle, Washington, are also facing similar issues as they attract Californians seeking affordable housing.

site_title: Oracle falls after forecasting slower cloud sales growth
summary: Oracle's stock fell 7.3% in extended trading after the company forecast slower sales growth in cloud-related products, citing a 19-23% increase in cloud sales compared to 32% in the previous quarter. Demand for new software licenses declined 1.8% to $1.39 billion, fueling concerns about the company's ability to shift away from traditional software and become a leader in web-delivered programs.

site_title: Technology advances can help secure formal land rights
summary: New technologies, including satellite imagery, drones, cloud computing, and blockchain, can help secure formal land rights for millions of people worldwide. However, senior World Bank economist Klaus Deininger notes that these technologies alone cannot solve the complex issue of land rights. Only a third of countries have digital land records, and less than half have registered private land. Despite challenges, startups are using mobile phones, drones, and blockchain to help communities map and record their land, and governments have signed deals to build blockchain-based land-titling systems.

site_title: British 'Red Arrows' jet crashes near air base
summary: A British Royal Air Force jet, a Hawk aircraft used by the Red Arrows aerobatic display team, crashed at RAF Valley in Wales on Tuesday. Two people were on board, but details about the incident are being kept secret while an investigation is underway. The Red Arrows are based at RAF Scampton in Lincolnshire, eastern England, and are known for their daring stunts.

site_title: DBS unveils electricity marketplace for Jurong residents to select energy retailers
summary: DBS has launched an electricity marketplace, allowing Jurong residents to switch between energy retailers with a seamless process. The platform, in partnership with iSwitch and Keppel Electric, enables customers to search for and select price plans through the digibank app. The service, starting in April, will involve around 108,000 households and aims to provide a hassle-free switching experience, with no service disruption. This move follows the liberalization of the retail electricity market and is seen as a step towards reimagining banking with digital technology and innovation.

site_title: Electricity market may add sparks to telcos' enterprise arms
summary: Singapore's telcos, including StarHub and M1, are partnering with retailers to offer electricity plans to households and businesses, marking a new revenue stream for the industry. The move aims to leverage telcos' technological expertise and customer networks in the enterprise space, amid challenges in the consumer market. The partnerships also reflect the telcos' focus on emerging areas such as the Smart Nation initiative and the Internet of Things.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Strong outlook draws more Singapore firms to Asean
summary: Singapore businesses increased their overseas credit searches by 3.04% in 2017, driven by a stronger global trade outlook. Asean accounted for the highest proportion of searches, followed by East Asia and Europe. Credit searches on Asean companies rose to 27.74%, while those on East Asian companies climbed marginally to 26.79%. In contrast, credit searches on European companies declined to 12.51%. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau attributed the increase to improved trade conditions and the ratification of a bilateral trade deal between Singapore and the EU.

site_title: Singtel Group rolls out regional mobile wallet platform
summary: Singtel Group launches a regional mobile wallet platform, enabling seamless digital payments across Asia, starting with Thailand in mid-2018. The platform will connect Singtel subscribers with customers of Thai telco AIS and eventually expand to Philippines telco Globe, Indonesia's Telkomsel, and India's Airtel, pending regulatory approval. The move aims to promote financial inclusion and simplify transactions for tourists and small-business owners.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: SPH Magazines undertakes restructuring exercise
summary: SPH Magazines, a magazine arm of Singapore Press Holdings, is undertaking a restructuring exercise to consolidate its position as a major digital network. The move aims to reduce staffing from 379 to around 300, mostly through staff attrition and redeployment. The restructuring is expected to help the company adapt to the changing magazine landscape and focus on its digital presence.

site_title: China needs more space below ground to store gas
summary: China faces a potential natural gas supply crunch due to its booming demand, particularly during winter. Large underground storage caverns are seen as a crucial link to smooth out supply chain issues, but analysts predict that current plans to triple storage capacity by the end of the decade may not be enough. China's growing appetite for natural gas poses a challenge, with analysts warning that the country may need to increase storage capacity further to avoid a repeat of the supply shortages experienced during the winter of 2018.

site_title: What does Putin really want?
summary: Vladimir Putin, set to begin another six-year term as Russian president, has long perplexed American leaders with his autocratic ambitions. Since 2007, he has denounced US global hegemony and used military force to reassert Russian prerogatives in Europe and the Middle East. Putin's recent address to the Federal Assembly boasted about Russia's new "invincible" nuclear arms, capable of overcoming US defenses. His intentions remain unclear, leaving concerns about his ambitions abroad unchanged. Putin's leadership has been marked by struggles for great-power status and unbalanced relations with the US and China.

site_title: Far East-led consortium places 3 of total 15 bids for Holland site
summary: A Far East-led consortium has placed three bids for a prime commercial and residential site in Holland Road, Singapore, as part of the Urban Redevelopment Authority's first dual-envelope tender in eight years. The site, which can have a maximum gross floor area of 59,715 square meters, has drawn 15 bids from 10 consortiums, with four groups placing multiple bids to increase their chances. The winning bid is expected to be announced within two months, with the successful bidder given seven years to complete the project. The site's rarity appeal and potential for a luxury mixed-use development have attracted strong interest from developers, with some predicting bid prices could exceed S$1.6 billion per square foot.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Another shutdown looms as US Congress haggles over spending
summary: US lawmakers are rushing to finalize a $1.2 trillion spending bill to avoid a third government shutdown in three months. The bill, which boosts military and domestic spending by 10%, is expected to be released later Tuesday, with a deadline of midnight Friday. Key issues still up for debate include border and immigration enforcement funding, abortion services funding, and a measure to tighten gun purchase background checks. A "fair compromise" has been reached on the basic structure of the bill, with Senate Democrats hoping to pass it this week to avoid an embarrassing hiccup for Washington.

site_title: Europe is only halfway to healthier banks
summary: The European Commission and the European Central Bank have introduced new rules to make European banks more resilient, requiring lenders to set aside money to cover up to 100% of bad loans. The rules aim to address the lingering issues from the financial crisis, with non-performing loans totaling around 760 billion euros. While the new measures are a step forward, experts argue that the eurozone banking system remains insufficiently equipped to deal with a new crisis, and additional measures, such as expanding the Single Resolution Fund and introducing a joint guarantee on deposits, are needed to prevent a sovereign debt crisis.

site_title: China will open its markets further and aims to avert trade war, says premier
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to further open its markets and avoid a trade war with the US, following the implementation of over-arching trade tariffs on Chinese goods. Li stated China will open its manufacturing sector, relax service sector access, and protect intellectual property rights. The comments come as the US is preparing to impose tariffs on $60 billion worth of Chinese imports. Analysts say a full trade war is unlikely, given China's reduced dependence on exports. Li also urged the US to ease restrictions on Chinese outbound investments.

site_title: Oil hits three-week high as glut shrinks faster than expected
summary: Oil prices surged to a three-week high as the Opec-led alliance accelerated the timeline for curbing a worldwide supply glut. Crude futures in New York rose 2.4% on Tuesday, with global supplies expected to come into balance with demand by the end of September, sooner than previous forecasts. The news was fueled by concerns over potential sanctions against Iran and the Opec alliance's commitment to reducing oversupply.

site_title: Gunman wounds two students, wounded by security, at Maryland high school
summary: A student shot and critically wounded two fellow students at Great Mills High School in Maryland before a campus security officer ended the attack, wounding the shooter. The shooter was taken to a hospital in critical condition. The reason for the shooting remains unclear, with no known relationship or motivation. The incident occurred amid a national debate over school shootings in the US, following a deadly mass shooting at a Florida high school in February.

site_title: Amazon is said to squeeze suppliers to curb losses in price wars
summary: Amazon is increasing transportation fees for suppliers of heavy, bulky products and limiting single low-priced items to offset rising shipping costs. The company is raising fees for products like diapers and beverages, and preparing to make it harder for shoppers to buy small orders of items like toothbrushes and soap. This shift in strategy comes as Amazon's fulfillment expenses surged 43% in 2017, outpacing revenue growth, and the company seeks to cut costs and maintain competitive prices.

site_title: Steinhoff to consider reducing stake in African unit
summary: Steinhoff International Holdings NV is considering selling part of its 58 billion rand (S$6.4 billion) stake in its African operations, Steinhoff Africa Retail Ltd, as the crisis-hit retailer seeks to shore up liquidity. The sale would follow the disposal of shares in PSG Group Ltd and KAP Industrial Ltd, which have raised over US$1.2 billion since an accounting scandal. The move aims to refinance or redeem debt financing within the South African operations, with initial plans to offload a small portion of the stake. Approval from South Africa's financial regulator is required.

site_title: ST Index snaps losing streak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended with a 0.43% or 15.02-point increase to 3,513.31, snapping its four-day losing streak. Financial institutions DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and UOB led the recovery, while tech counters such as AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings, and Hi-P International fell due to the impact of Facebook's data leak and Apple's potential shift to in-house displays. The market's sentiment was also influenced by potential US trade tariffs and the outcome of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting.

site_title: Ezion Holdings and Sias to hold informal meeting with shareholders on Friday
summary: Ezion Holdings, an offshore and marine group, will hold an informal meeting with shareholders on Friday, facilitated by Sias, to discuss the proposed US$1.5 billion refinancing package, including new bonds, shares, and warrants. The meeting aims to address shareholders' queries regarding the transactions, which are subject to their approval.

site_title: LVMH adds 5,000-Swiss franc Hublot to roster of priciest smartwatches
summary: LVMH, the parent company of TAG Heuer and Hublot, is introducing a new smartwatch priced at around 5,000-Swiss francs (S$6,920), making it one of the priciest smartwatches on the market. The Hublot smartwatch will be released in mid-April, coinciding with the FIFA World Cup soccer tournament, and will feature alerts about teams and scores. The watch is expected to generate limited revenue, estimated at around 10 million francs, and is seen as a marketing tool rather than a major revenue driver.

site_title: UAE developers Emaar, Aldar plan 30b dirham in joint projects
summary: Dubai's Emaar and Abu Dhabi's Aldar have partnered to develop 30 billion dirham (S$10.76 billion) worth of real estate projects, including lifestyle developments on Al Saadiyat Island and Emaar Beachfront. This joint venture aims to strengthen the UAE's global economy. The partnership comes as the UAE's property market faces challenges, with declining demand and values. The move is not the first instance of cooperation between Dubai and Abu Dhabi developers, with Emaar Chairman Mohamed Alabbar also leading Abu Dhabi-backed Eagle Hills in international projects.

site_title: SCDF battles oil storage tank fire on Pulau Busing, NEA monitoring air quality
summary: A fire involving an oil storage tank broke out on Pulau Busing, an island off Singapore's south-western coast, on March 20, 2018. The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) responded to the incident, deploying resources to fight the fire. The National Environment Agency (NEA) monitored air quality closely, reporting no spikes in pollutant levels. Firefighting operations continued for over three hours, with SCDF deploying additional resources to tackle the fire.

site_title: World's last male northern white rhino dies
summary: The world's last male northern white rhino, Sudan, has died at Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Kenya, leaving only two females of the subspecies alive. Sudan, 45, was put down due to severe pain and age-related complications. Conservationists hope to save the subspecies through in vitro fertilization using eggs from the remaining females, stored northern white rhino semen, and surrogate southern white rhino females. The loss of Sudan highlights the impact of human greed and neglect on nature, with only 650 rhinos remaining in Kenya, all of which are black rhinos.

site_title: Money manager hopes to profit as Asian investors target Europe
summary: Axa Investment Managers CEO Andrea Rossi expects Asian investors to increasingly target Europe for insurance and investment products, driven by growing disposable income and aging populations in Asia. The company has started joint ventures in Shanghai, Seoul, and Mumbai, and is betting heavily on China, where it received a Wholly Foreign Owned Enterprise license last year. Rossi attributes his success in expanding into Asia to the firm's European roots and marketing efforts, and predicts Asian money managers will compete with Europeans for top-20 global positions in the industry.

site_title: UnUsUal unit to acquire 49% of Chinese film and concert company for 25.2m yuan
summary: UnUsUal Limited's wholly owned subsidiary UnUsUaL Entertainment International Limited has entered into a term sheet to acquire 49% of Beijing Wish for 25.2 million yuan (S$5.2 million) in cash. Beijing Wish, a Chinese film and concert company, will become an associated company of the group. This strategic investment aims to extend UnUsUal's presence in China, with Beijing Wish serving as the group's vehicle in the country upon completion.

site_title: Ryanair to buy Niki Lauda airline in challenge to Lufthansa
summary: Ryanair has agreed to buy a majority stake in Austrian leisure airline Laudamotion, founded by former Formula 1 champion Niki Lauda, in a bid to challenge Lufthansa's dominance in the German and Austrian markets. Ryanair will acquire 24.9% of Laudamotion and increase its stake to 75% with EU approval, leasing six crewed planes to expand its fleet. The deal aims to provide competition to Lufthansa and boost consumer choice and lower fares, with Laudamotion set to start flying from Germany, Switzerland, and Austria this year.

site_title: EMS Energy granted two-month extension for FY2017 results and AGM
summary: EMS Energy has been granted a two-month extension until April 30 to release its FY2017 financial statements and a two-month extension until June 30 to hold its annual general meeting for FY2017. The request came after the Singapore High Court delayed the judgement on its subsidiary's scheme of arrangement due to a contest from a creditor. The company cited high staff turnover in its finance team and the need for more time to complete its external auditors' work as the basis for the extensions.

site_title: Singapore bunkering middlemen face existential threat amid changes
summary: Singapore's bunker industry is experiencing an existential threat due to a margin squeeze caused by a mass flow metering system and the upcoming sulphur cap. Two licensed bunker suppliers, Wired and Barreloil, have undergone massive downsizing and are seeking new equity injections to stay in business. This shake-up signals further consolidation in the industry, with small-scale marine fuel traders and suppliers facing significant challenges. The changes are driven by increasing costs and regulatory pressures, putting the viability of smaller players at risk.

site_title: S&P downgrades Noble rating to 'D'
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded Noble Group's long-term issuer credit rating to 'D' from 'CC' due to the company's failure to make principal and coupon payments on two of its US dollar notes. The ratings agency cited Noble's debt restructuring process, which is expected to be completed by end-July, and its preservation of assets during this time. The downgrade does not expect Noble to meet any outstanding obligations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: State tender for Holland Road site draws 15 bids
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has closed a tender for a 99-year leasehold site in Holland Road, attracting 15 bids. Developers, including consortiums, have submitted concept proposals and prices, with some placing multiple bids. The site, which can have a maximum GFA of 59,715 sq m, must have at least 60% residential use. The successful bidder will be awarded the site with a seven-year development period. Market experts expect the URA to award the site within two months, with China-originated developers also participating.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: UK investigates Facebook over data breach, to raid Cambridge Analytica
summary: Britain's Information Commissioner, Elizabeth Denham, is investigating Facebook over a data breach involving Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy hired by Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. The breach, which involved the harvesting of 50 million Facebook users' data, has raised concerns about consumer privacy and the company's ability to safeguard user information. Facebook has suspended Cambridge Analytica and its parent company, and a warrant is being sought to search the consultancy's offices. The investigation comes as Facebook faces increasing scrutiny over its handling of user data and its impact on society.

site_title: FWD Group uses sports to help those with disabilities
summary: FWD Group, an insurance provider, has partnered with the Special Olympics in the Asia Pacific to support young people with intellectual disabilities through sports and community-driven initiatives. The three-year partnership aims to develop skills for 300 athletes with disabilities, recruit 200 mentors, and promote social inclusion for 12,000 students across seven countries. FWD's goal is to break down barriers faced by individuals with intellectual disabilities in accessing healthcare and employment, fostering a more inclusive society through sports.

images.alt_text: Special Olympics athletes with FWD Group CEO Huynh Thanh Phong signing a football. In February 2018, the company signed a three-year US$1.25 million partnership with the Special Olympics in the Asia Pacific to sponsor its Unified Schools and Athlete Leadership programmes. The partnership also marked the first of FWD Group's community-driven initiatives in Singapore.

site_title: Fifth package bomb strikes Texas, at FedEx facility near San Antonio
summary: A homemade bomb exploded at a FedEx facility near San Antonio, Texas, on Tuesday, the fifth package bomb to strike the city this month. The device, which injured one person, was similar in construction to the previous four, suggesting it was made by the same person. The FBI is investigating the incident and whether it is linked to the earlier attacks, which killed two people and injured six others. The motive behind the attacks is still unclear.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to issue S$120m 3.28% fixed rate notes due 2024
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) has issued S$120m in 3.28% fixed rate notes due 2024 as part of its S$1 billion Multicurrency Medium Term Note Programme. The notes have been assigned a "Baa1" rating by Moody's Investors Service. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings of MCT. DBS Bank is the sole lead manager and bookrunner for the issue.

site_title: Malaysia says concludes talks with Saudi Aramco over Rapid investment
summary: Malaysia has completed talks with Saudi Aramco over the $7 billion investment in Petronas' Refinery and Petrochemical Integrated Development (Rapid) project. Aramco's investment will be finalized by the end of the month, with refinery operations set to begin in 2019. The project, valued at $27 billion, will include a 300,000 barrel-per-day oil refinery and a petrochemical complex. The investment is part of Saudi Aramco's agreement to buy a stake in the project, which was reached in February last year.

site_title: US: Stocks rise ahead of Fed decision
summary: US stocks rose ahead of a Federal Reserve interest rate announcement, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.6% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.3%. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.4% after major technology companies rebounded from Monday's losses. Investors are cautious about trade conflicts and monetary policy, but took advantage of reduced prices to buy in. The Fed is expected to lift interest rates on Wednesday, with investors scrutinizing the central bank's policy statement for implications on further rate hikes.

site_title: South Korea to send K-pop singers to Pyongyang in late March
summary: South Korea will send a group of 160 K-pop singers to Pyongyang from March 31 to April 3, as a reciprocal visit after North Korea sent performers to the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics. The group, including Red Velvet and music industry veterans Cho Yong-pil and Lee Sun-hee, will hold two shows in Pyongyang. This visit is part of a detente between the two nations, following North Korean leader Kim Jong-un's intention to improve ties at the start of the year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose in opening deals on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.4% to 7,071.68 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index adding 0.4% to 12,261.19 points, and Paris' CAC 40 increasing by 0.2% to 5,232.12 points. The gains came ahead of a key Federal Reserve policy meeting, with investors remaining cautious due to ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Demand for pizzas in Russia and Turkey lifts DP Eurasia's profit
summary: DP Eurasia, the master franchise of Domino's Pizza in Turkey and Russia, reported a 28.9% growth in annual core earnings to 96.8 million Turkish lira. The company attributed the growth to the expansion of its store network and rising like-for-like sales, with online orders accounting for over half of all deliveries. Adjusted net profit fell 39.4% to 21.7 million lira due to foreign exchange losses. The company aims to open 30 stores in Turkey and 40-60 in Russia this year.

site_title: Apple grabs 2-year lead in 3D sensing race
summary: Apple has secured a 2-year lead in the 3D sensing technology race, with most Android phones expected to adopt the feature in 2019, two years after Apple's Face ID security was launched in the iPhone X. The technology, which enables accurate facial recognition and secure biometrics, is expected to be worth billions in revenue over the next few years. Bottlenecks in key parts, such as vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers, have hindered mass adoption, leaving major Android producers, including Samsung and Huawei, at a disadvantage.

site_title: Keppel unit secures bonuses, signs five-year technical support agreement with Viridor EfW (Runcorn)
summary: Keppel Seghers, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure Group, has signed a five-year technical support agreement with Viridor EfW (Runcorn) in the UK. As part of the agreement, Keppel Seghers has secured two performance bonuses worth over £7 million, including £4 million in recognition of its "excellence in operational performance." The bonuses were awarded for higher electrical efficiency and lower chemical consumption levels at the Phase 2 Thermal Power Station.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 8.45 points to 1,856.39. The index saw a two billion lots worth RM2 billion in volume, with losers outnumbering gainers 657 to 284.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.43% to 3,513.31 on Tuesday, with 1.4 billion shares worth S$938.1 million traded. Losers outpaced gainers 224 to 195. The rally marked a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with the market seemingly unfazed by US trade tensions.

site_title: Noble Group hit by lawsuit from top shareholder Goldilocks as default looms
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, is facing a lawsuit from its top shareholder Goldilocks Investment Co, alleging the company inflated profits to raise capital. The lawsuit claims management paid themselves inflated salaries and tried to cover up the issue. Goldilocks is seeking US$169 million in damages, including interest and court costs. The lawsuit also accuses Noble Group's executives, including founder Richard Elman, of breaching their fiduciary duties. The company is on the brink of collapse, having posted billions in losses and refusing to pay a 2018 bond.

site_title: China electric car executives call for policy support, end to protectionism
summary: Chinese electric car executives are urging the government to provide more policy clarity and overhaul local subsidy programs that have distorted the market. They call for end to protectionism by local governments that offer extra subsidies to protect their own firms, instead of stimulating the sector as a whole. The industry is pushing for more consistent guidelines, nationwide technological standards, and incentives to improve battery life and recharging speeds. China has already seen significant growth in electric vehicles, with 794,000 units manufactured and sold in 2017, and executives believe the future of the industry hinges on improving performance and convenience.

site_title: Technology holds promise, but no silver bullet for land rights: World Bank
summary: New technologies, including satellite imagery, drones, cloud computing, and blockchain, hold promise for securing formal land rights for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, a senior World Bank economist notes that these technologies are not a silver bullet solution for countries with weak institutions. The World Bank estimates that fewer than a third of countries maintain land records digitally, and less than half have registered or mapped private land. A new generation of startups is using mobile phones and drones to help communities map and record their land, with governments like Rwanda and Georgia signing deals to build blockchain-based land-titling systems.

site_title: Unilever wants to filter China's foul air before it's cleaned up
summary: Unilever's acquisition of Blueair, a Swedish air-purifying business, has proven to be a costly misstep as the market's growth slows in China, its largest market. The company had anticipated a surge in demand for air purifiers, but sales have instead slowed, with growth expected to drop to 7% annually through 2022. This setback comes as Unilever faces challenges in maintaining growth in its portfolio and earning profits from its sustainable initiatives, such as its "sustainable living plan."

site_title: Exercise really can keep you young
summary: A recent study of British recreational cyclists aged 55-79 found that regular exercise can help maintain muscle health and immune function in older adults. The cyclists' muscles retained their size and function across decades, with those who exercised more displaying the healthiest muscles. Their immune systems also showed signs of being younger, with high levels of immune cells and a hormone that protects the thymus. The study's findings challenge the notion that ageing is inevitable and suggest that exercise can be a key factor in maintaining physical health.

site_title: Private fuel retailers nibble away at India's booming market
summary: Private fuel retailers in India are gaining market share, with Reliance Industries Ltd. and Essar Oil Ltd. controlling 8.2% and 6.8% of diesel sales, respectively. State-run retailers remain dominant, controlling over 90% of sales. The growth in market share is attributed to the removal of diesel-price controls in 2014 and record oil consumption. Analysts predict that while private retailers will continue to make inroads, they cannot significantly dent the growth of government-owned companies due to the large market size and volumes.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS unveiled an electricity marketplace for Jurong residents to select energy retailers. Meanwhile, SPH Magazines launched a major restructuring exercise, laying off 13 employees. In international news, a Malaysia agency is set to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Citigroup set a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index, while Thaksin is confident that a Thai court will clear his daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case. UK economy shrunk for the second month.

site_title: North Korea denuclearisation not on agenda in Helsinki talks: Finnish foreign minister
summary: North Korea's denuclearization is not on the agenda in talks in Helsinki, Finland, according to Finnish Foreign Minister Timo Soini. The meeting, which includes North Korean, South Korean, and American delegations, is focused on academics and officials, and is seen as a preparatory step for a potential US-North Korea summit. Soini stated that nuclear weapons are not on the table, despite North Korea's pursuit of its nuclear and missile programs. The talks aim to discuss security on the Korean peninsula and come after a series of diplomatic encounters between the US and North Korea.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks reverse losses; won rises against US dollar
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.42% to 2,485.52, reversing early losses, driven by domestic institutions' purchases. The Korean won strengthened against the US dollar, reaching 1,068.6 per dollar. Bond yields also rose. The move followed losses in US and Japanese stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks bounce back to end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded from early losses, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.11% to end at 31,549.93. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, driven by cautious investors ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting later this week.

site_title: Au revoir, baguette! France goes burger-mad
summary: France has seen a surge in hamburger sales, with 1.5 billion units sold in 2017, surpassing the classic jambon-beurre sandwich for the first time. This trend is attributed to the rise of high-quality, fresh alternatives and the decline of junk food. Burger sales jumped by 9% in 2017, with 85% of restaurants offering American-style burgers, mostly at full table service restaurants. The phenomenon is seen as a significant shift in France's culinary culture, with some predicting burgers may even surpass steak frites in popularity.

site_title: Petronas head calls for oil & gas industry to maintain cost discipline, improve efficiency
summary: Malaysia's Petronas president, Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin, urged the oil and gas industry to maintain cost discipline and improve efficiency, citing RM11.5 billion in savings from the Coral 2.0 cost reduction alliance. With oil prices regaining some ground, he expressed concerns about a "premature exuberance" that could negate efforts to bring costs down. Wan Zulkiflee noted that the industry's long-term outlook remains optimistic, with oil and gas expected to contribute 45-51% of the world's energy mix until 2036, but warned of potential "insufficient supply" due to under-investment in conventional O&G during the downturn.

site_title: Credit Suisse forum holds invite-only K-pop girl band concert
summary: Credit Suisse is using a K-pop girl band concert to attract investors at its Asia conference. Red Velvet, representing S.M. Entertainment Co., will perform after a CEO discusses "cultural technology." This is the latest example of K-pop being used to lure investors, following a similar tactic by Daiwa Capital Markets in January. The "Big 3" entertainment agencies in Korea have seen strong gains in 2018, with S.M. Entertainment leading the pack. The event aims to provide entertainment for attendees, with other activities including a virtual reality tennis match and a smoothie-making station.

site_title: Uncertainty prevails as scandal clouds Japan Abe's future
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces a major political crisis as suspicions surround a land sale to a school operator with ties to his wife, Akie. Abe denies intervening in the heavily discounted sale or altering documents. Finance Minister Taro Aso also denies involvement. The scandal clouds Abe's future, his biggest since taking office five years ago.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing his biggest political crisis since taking office more than five years ago, as suspicions swirl about a land sale to a school operator with ties to his wife.

site_title: Weinstein Company files for bankruptcy in 'new beginning'
summary: The Weinstein Company, founded by Harvey Weinstein, has filed for bankruptcy, marking a "new beginning" for the studio. The company is releasing accusers from non-disclosure agreements, allowing them to speak out without fear of retaliation. A stalking-horse agreement has been reached with Lantern Capital Partners, a Texas-based private equity firm, to purchase assets subject to bankruptcy court approval. The move comes after an investor group abandoned a reported $500 million deal to buy the studio's assets, and amid ongoing investigations into Weinstein's alleged sexual misconduct.

site_title: GIC, others invest £100m in hand-held DNA sequencing firm Oxford Nanopore
summary: GIC, China Construction Bank International, HostPlus, and Oxford Nanopore's existing investors have invested £100 million (S$184 million) in UK-based Oxford Nanopore Technologies, a hand-held DNA sequencing firm. The funds will be used to support a new manufacturing facility, commercial expansion, and product development. Oxford Nanopore's portable DNA sequencing device, minION, has a customer base spanning over 70 countries and is set to drive growth in the DNA information market across various industries. The company aims to capitalize on the global demand for DNA sequencing technologies.

site_title: US expected to impose up to US$60b in China tariffs by Friday: sources
summary: The US is expected to unveil up to $60 billion in new tariffs on Chinese imports by Friday, targeting technology, telecommunications, and intellectual property. The tariffs, authorized under the 1974 US Trade Act, would be subject to a public comment period and could be delayed to allow for negotiations with Beijing. China has vowed to take retaliatory measures in response. The move aims to reduce the US-China trade surplus, which has reached $375 billion. The tariffs could impact consumer products such as clothing and footwear, and have raised concerns among US business groups about job losses and price increases.

site_title: Singtel to launch mobile wallet tie-up with regional associates, starting in Thailand
summary: Singtel plans to launch a mobile wallet interoperability program across its regional associates in Asia by mid-2018. The program will enable customers to make cashless payments in their home currency using their home telco's app at physical merchants abroad. The first associate, Thailand's AIS, will be followed by the Philippines' Globe, Indonesia's Telkomsel, and India's Airtel, pending regulatory approval. The program aims to bring 50 million regional mobile customers together, targeting holidaymakers, business travelers, and small merchants.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down for third straight session on Facebook breach
summary: Tokyo stocks fell for the third consecutive session due to selling pressure in high-tech shares following the Facebook data breach scandal. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.47% to 21,380.97, while the Topix index fell 0.21% to 1,716.29. High-tech shares, including Fanuc and SoftBank Group, were hit by the scandal, which also raised concerns about a regulatory crackdown on technology companies.

site_title: Gold inches lower on firmer US dollar ahead of Fed meet
summary: Gold prices edged lower on Tuesday as the US dollar firmed ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting, with spot gold down 0.1% to $1,314.98 per ounce. The US dollar rose 0.4% to 106.55 yen, pushing gold prices down. Analysts expect the Fed to hike interest rates and signal three more increases this year, but uncertainty remains about the impact of US tariffs on global trade.

images.alt_text: Gold edged lower on Tuesday as the US dollar firmed while traders waited to gauge the path of US monetary policy for the rest of the year from the two-day Federal Reserve meeting that kicks off later in the day.

site_title: US said to offer trade relief for help in pressuring China
summary: The US is offering trade relief to countries that ally with the US in pressuring China over its trade policies. US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer has proposed five conditions for countries to be excluded from tariffs on steel and aluminum, including limiting exports to 2017 levels and addressing China's trade-distorting policies. In exchange, the US will provide relief from tariffs. Countries such as Australia and South Korea have applied for exclusions, while the EU has threatened retaliation against US goods. The US is also considering restrictions on Chinese investments.

site_title: Chinese tycoon's exit revealed abroad where he owned brewery
summary: Chinese tycoon Ye Jianming is stepping down from CEFC China Energy Co's management and will no longer be a shareholder in the company, which owns a brewery and a soccer team in the Czech Republic. This is the first official confirmation of his fate since he was under investigation by Chinese authorities. The move comes amid turmoil and speculation surrounding CEFC, including record bond declines and reports of government takeover. Ye's departure follows a series of deals, including a $9 billion stake in Russian state energy giant Rosneft, and China's crackdown on debt-fueled expansions.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars slip on risk aversion; eyes on Fed meeting
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped on risk aversion ahead of the US Federal Reserve policy meeting, with the Aussie down 0.1% to US$0.7707 and the Kiwi down 0.2% to US$0.7226. Weaker iron ore prices and fears of a global trade war contributed to the sell-off. Investors expect the Fed to raise rates, with analysts divided on the potential for a shift in the "dot plots". The Reserve Bank of Australia reaffirmed its cautious views on consumer spending, keeping interest rates at record lows.

site_title: Facebook under pressure as US, EU urge probes of data practices
summary: Facebook is under pressure from US and EU lawmakers to investigate its data practices after reports that Cambridge Analytica, a UK-based political consultancy, may have improperly gained access to data on 50 million Facebook users. US lawmakers are demanding an explanation from Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and the UK's Information Commissioner's Office is seeking a warrant to search Cambridge Analytica's offices. The company's shares have fallen nearly 7% as investors worry about new legislation that could damage its advertising business. Facebook has hired forensic auditors to investigate and has denied any wrongdoing, but the scandal presents a new threat to the company's reputation.

site_title: BlackBerry must face revived US lawsuit over BlackBerry 10
summary: A US judge has allowed a revived lawsuit against BlackBerry Ltd to proceed, rejecting the company's request to dismiss claims it inflated its stock price by misrepresenting sales prospects for its BlackBerry 10 smartphones. The lawsuit, which includes former executives, alleges BlackBerry misled shareholders in 2013. The judge cited new information from a related case and a US Supreme Court decision that may make it easier for plaintiffs to show that statements of opinion can be misleading. Other defendants include former CEO Thorsten Heins and CFO Brian Bidulka.

images.alt_text: A US judge on Monday rejected BlackBerry Ltd's request to dismiss a lawsuit claiming it inflated its stock price and defrauded shareholders by painting a misleadingly positive picture of sales prospects for its BlackBerry 10 smartphones.

site_title: Warmer temperatures hit oil output in Arctic Alaska: officials
summary: Warmer temperatures in Arctic Alaska have negatively impacted oil production, with the North Slope grade of crude oil averaging 518,000 barrels per day, down from a predicted 533,000 bpd. The drop is attributed to the warmer winter conditions, which hinder the operation of industrial machinery. Production is expected to recover slightly in the next three months, but will decline gradually to 493,000 barrels per day by 2027. The decline is a long-term fiscal problem for the oil-dependent state government.

site_title: California housing problems are spilling across its borders
summary: A growing number of Californians and companies are migrating to cities like Reno, Nevada, in search of affordable housing and lower costs. However, this influx is accompanied by concerns over traffic congestion, overcrowded schools, and a strain on local resources. Cities such as Austin, Texas, and Seattle are also experiencing similar issues as they face a housing crisis and debates over development. The rapid economic growth in Reno has led to a surge in housing prices, with the median home price exceeding $340,000, and a corresponding increase in homelessness.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble with Wall Street as Facebook breach hits tech
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, following sharp losses on Wall Street, amid concerns over a massive data breach at Facebook. The breach, which affected 50 million user profiles, fueled fears of a regulatory crackdown on the technology sector. Tech giants such as Facebook, Apple, and Alphabet plummeted, while other household names were also hit by regulatory concerns. The US losses filtered through to Asia, with several markets, including Hong Kong and Japan, experiencing significant declines.

site_title: China's door to outside will only open wide: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang announced the country will further open up its economy, increasing access to services and manufacturing sectors, and lowering import tariffs. Foreign and domestic firms will be allowed to compete on an equal footing. This move aims to ensure fair competition and protect intellectual property rights. The decision comes amid a global trade war dominated by US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Chinese goods. China will not force technology transfers and will better protect intellectual property rights.

site_title: Australian shares end lower as commodities drag; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Tuesday, falling 0.4% to 5936.4, due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's potential trade measures. Commodity stocks, particularly materials and base metals, were pressured, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Ltd closing down 1.9% and 1.8%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 4.97 points to 8487.15, weighed down by consumer staple and utility stocks. The focus remains on the Federal Reserve's policy meeting later in the day, with investors awaiting a decision on rate hikes this year.

site_title: F J Benjamin sets up advisory board to integrate online and offline retail
summary: F J Benjamin sets up an advisory board to integrate its online and offline retail channels. The advisory board, comprising experts from Google, Zalora, and Codem, will advise the company on strengthening links between its 200+ stores and 1,500 online sales channels in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The goal is to create an economically viable business model that integrates the online ecosystem with its retail infrastructure, utilizing its existing customer database to optimize its network and grow online sales.

site_title: Oracle underwhelms investors with cloud revenue, forecast
summary: Oracle's cloud revenue grew 32% to $1.57 billion in its fiscal third quarter, but the company's forecast of 19-23% growth in the current quarter underwhelmed investors, causing shares to fall 7.3%. Despite this, Oracle's total revenue rose 6.1% to $9.77 billion, and profit excluding items was in line with estimates. The company's cloud unit now accounts for 16% of total revenue, but its software-license business still dominates. Oracle's strategy to leverage its ties to large enterprises and expand its cloud offerings has faced stiff competition from cloud vendors like Amazon and Microsoft.

site_title: Forest City developer Country Garden says annual core profit up 106%
summary: Country Garden Holdings Co Ltd reported a 106% increase in annual core profit to a record 24.7 billion yuan, driven by robust sales and higher margins. The company's net profit rose 126% to 26.1 billion yuan, while revenue increased 48% to 226.9 billion yuan. Despite Beijing's efforts to cool the market, the developer expects to book its best-ever profits for 2017, fueled by increased M&A activity and larger size. Country Garden aims to build 1 million apartments to be leased in three years, following the establishment of a long-term property leasing department.

site_title: For China corn farmers, prices trump policy ahead of planting
summary: China's farmers are expected to plant more corn this year, despite the government's five-year plan to reduce acreage, due to higher prices and profits. Corn prices have risen 11% to a 20-month high, making it more profitable than soybeans, even with increased subsidies. This could offset a 12% rise in soybean planting last year and threaten the government's plan to boost soybean planting by 40%. Farmers are prioritizing corn due to higher profits, with some planning to switch back to corn after switching to soybeans last year.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks slightly down, won holds steady
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index was down 0.15% at 2,471.44 as of 0109 GMT, with bond yields rising. The Korean won held steady at 1,072.1 per dollar, while the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.19%. Foreigners were net sellers of 80.136 million won worth of shares, and the US dollar has risen 0.46% against the won this year.

site_title: Esplanade names Yvonne Tham new CEO from Aug 1
summary: Yvonne Tham, 43, has been appointed as the new CEO of The Esplanade Co, a registered charity and not-for-profit organisation, starting August 1. Tham, who has been with the company since 2014, replaces CEO Benson Puah, who steps down after 20 years. Puah will take a long break to spend time with family and ensure a smooth transition. Tham brings extensive experience in arts and culture policy and management, having previously worked at the National Arts Council and the Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth.

site_title: Foodpanda, Uber take meal apps fight to Bangkok
summary: Foodpanda, Uber Eats, and other meal delivery apps are intensifying competition in Bangkok, with promotions and discounts offered to woo customers. Foodpanda's Thailand chief executive expects deliveries to double to 16,000 per day this year, with Line Corp's Line Man and Go-Jek also entering the market. The industry is projected to reach 31.7 billion baht (S$1.32 billion) in online food ordering this year, with consolidation expected as competition becomes too painful.

site_title: United Airlines image bruised after latest round of PR fiascos
summary: United Airlines faces widespread criticism and potential action by the US Congress, federal authorities, and lawmakers over the death of a French bulldog, Kokito, on a flight. The incident reignites concerns about the airline's customer service failures, following a series of public relations blunders. Federal and local authorities are investigating, and lawmakers have introduced bills to prohibit storing live animals in overhead compartments and establish civil fines for violations. The airline's reputation is at risk, with thousands of social media users threatening to boycott the carrier.

site_title: SPH Magazines launches major restructuring exercise, to lay off 13 employees
summary: SPH Magazines, the magazine arm of Singapore Press Holdings, is launching a major restructuring exercise to lay off 13 employees as part of its efforts to prepare for a digitally-driven future. The company will not close any titles, but will reorganize its staff and operations. The restructuring aims to reduce staff numbers from 379 to around 300 and will involve the transfer of custom publishing and contract titles to Focus Publishing. The company will continue to invest in digital capabilities and analytics, and will focus on developing multi-platform business solutions for its customers.

site_title: China Sports International seeking information on potential undisclosed lawsuits
summary: China Sports International, a mainboard-listed sportswear maker, is seeking information on potential undisclosed lawsuits. The company's board has requested more information from CEO Lin Shao Xiong amid concerns over unpaid fees and potential winding-up proceedings. The company had received a statutory demand for S$50,839.25 in unpaid fees from its legal advisers in December, but no further action has been taken. As a result, the company's shares remain suspended since December 4, 2017. The board will make further announcements when material developments occur.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades CDL to 'buy', OCBC maintains 'buy'
summary: RHB and OCBC have upgraded their ratings on City Developments Limited (CDL) to "buy", citing the launch of condominium project The Tapestry and positive sentiment for Singapore's residential market. RHB has set a target price of S$15, while OCBC maintains a fair value estimate of S$13.25. The brokers believe CDL is a key proxy for the residential market's recovery and has a strong brand positioning and established track record, which should aid in commanding premium prices for its projects.

site_title: Facebook security chief changes role to focus on election fraud
summary: Facebook's chief of security, Alex Stamos, has shifted his role to focus on emerging risks and election security, following internal clashes over handling Russian interference on the platform. Stamos' decision comes amid criticism over Facebook's handling of user data, including a 50 million-member data breach linked to Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. Stamos had previously advocated for investigating Russian manipulation of news on the platform, but his efforts were met with resistance from top executives. The move comes as Facebook faces increasing scrutiny over its data practices and election interference allegations.

site_title: Empowered Xi says China ready to fight 'bloody battle'
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping delivered a nationalist speech, warning against attempts to split the country and vowing to defend China's "one China principle". The speech capped a two-week National People's Congress session that paved the way for Xi to rule for life, lifting presidential term limits. Xi emphasized China's readiness for a "bloody battle" to regain global supremacy, while also addressing concerns about development projects abroad. The session also approved a major government shake-up, including the abolition of term limits, and expanded the Communist Party's role in the country's affairs.

site_title: Australia: Material stocks drag shares; NZ inches down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% due to concerns over US President Donald Trump's potential protectionist trade measures, weighing on commodity stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 29.6 points to 5,929.8. The material sector, led by BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, fell 2% and 2.1%, respectively. Healthcare stocks also declined, with CSL Ltd down 2%. New Zealand's benchmark index inched down 0.1% as consumer staple stocks weighed on the index.

site_title: DBS unveils electricity marketplace for Jurong residents to select energy retailers
summary: DBS has launched an electricity marketplace for Jurong residents, allowing them to switch energy retailers seamlessly. The service, starting in April, involves 108,000 households and partners with iSwitch and Keppel Electric. Through the digibank app, residents can search and select plans, with no service disruption. The move aims to simplify the process, enabling customers to enjoy savings on their bills with just a few clicks. The service will be expanded to other electricity retailers at a later date.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session lower on Tuesday; STI at 3,496.47, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% in the afternoon session on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,496.47. About 669 million shares worth S$401 million changed hands, with IPCO International being the most actively traded stock. Losers outnumbered gainers 211 to 107, and DBS and UOB shares were down 0.4% and 0.2% respectively. The decline comes after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Singapore ranks first in Asia again, 25th globally for quality of living: Mercer survey
summary: Singapore ranks 25th globally and first in Asia for quality of living, according to Mercer's 20th annual survey. Vienna tops the global ranking for the ninth year, with Zurich in second place. Asian cities Tokyo and Kobe rank second and third respectively. South Korea's Seoul falls to 79th due to political instability. Other top-ranked cities include Vancouver, Sydney, and Melbourne in North America, and Dubai in the Middle East. Mercer notes that companies must adapt to a diverse and mobile workforce with changing requirements and aspirations.

site_title: US bans transactions with Venezuela's digital currency: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order banning transactions involving Venezuela's new petro cryptocurrency, deeming it a "scam" by the Maduro government to undermine democracy. The order bars US-based financial transactions involving the cryptocurrency, citing concerns of supporting a corrupt regime. The move comes as the Trump administration explores options to sanction Venezuela's oil sector, following the cryptocurrency's successful pre-sale that raised $735 million. The US Treasury also announced sanctions against four Venezuelan government officials for corruption and economic mismanagement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Tuesday with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks started trading on Tuesday with losses, following heavy selling on Wall Street due to concerns over technology firm regulation in light of the Facebook data breach scandal. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.63%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices lost 0.67% and 0.74% respectively.

site_title: Blue skies above China need more space below ground to store gas
summary: China needs to expand its underground natural gas storage capacity to meet growing demand, despite plans to triple storage by 2030. Currently, storage space accounts for only 3.3% of total demand, with the government aiming to increase it to 4.8% by 2020 and 5.8% by 2030. China's supply crunch this winter was due to infrastructure limitations and a reliance on liquefied natural gas imports, which led to a price shock. Analysts warn that even with increased storage, China may still face chronic gas supply tightness, particularly during winter peaks.

site_title: Credit searches by Singapore firms on overseas companies up 3% in 2017 on stronger trade outlook
summary: Singapore firms conducted 3.04% more overseas credit searches in 2017, driven by a stronger global trade outlook. The majority of searches were on Asean companies, with Malaysia, Indonesia, and Thailand being the top targets. Credit searches on European companies declined, while foreign companies searched on Singapore firms more, with Europe, North America, and East Asia being the top regions. The SCCB expects due diligence activities to pick up in 2018, despite credit ratings remaining unchanged.

site_title: VW to invest US$340m more in Tennessee plant
summary: Volkswagen plans to invest an additional US$340 million at its Chattanooga, Tennessee plant to build SUVs, including a five-passenger version of the Atlas. The move aims to expand the SUV portfolio and demonstrate confidence despite rising international trade tensions. The investment comes after US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, prompting European officials to threaten retaliation. Analysts warn of increased trade war risks, but German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier expressed optimism about resolving the issue.

site_title: Squatters in upmarket London property spark debate over homeless
summary: A group of about 160 homeless people occupied a £17.5 million London property in March, sparking a citywide debate on the treatment of homeless people. The occupation, set to end with a court order, drew attention from London Mayor Sadiq Khan. The incident highlights the growing issue of homelessness in the British capital, with many calling for improved support and housing solutions. The occupation's message, "The homeless are revolting, join them," emphasizes the need for change in how homeless individuals are treated.

images.alt_text: Sleeping on the streets - or rough sleeping - has risen in England for seven consecutive years, according to government figures, with more than 1,000 homeless in London and more than 4,100 nationally, a 134 per cent jump since 2010.

site_title: Foodpanda, Uber take meal apps fight to Bangkok
summary: Foodpanda and Uber Eats are intensifying competition in Bangkok's meal delivery market, with promotions and discounts to attract customers. Foodpanda's Thailand chief executive expects deliveries to double to 16,000 per day this year, while Uber Eats delivers over a million dishes annually. Other competitors, including Grab and Foody Corp's Now service, are also entering the market. The sector is expected to surge in 2018, with Thailand's market projected to hit 31.7 billion baht, driven by the country's strong food culture and growing demand.

site_title: American Dream fails generations of blacks: study
summary: A study published by the Equality of Opportunity Project found that even the richest black boys in the US earn less in adulthood than white boys from similar backgrounds, contradicting the American Dream's ideal of upward income mobility. The research, based on 20 million children, showed a 99% disparity in outcomes between black and white boys in 99% of American neighborhoods. However, this disparity does not exist between black and white girls from comparable families. The study suggests that policies such as mentoring programs and reducing racial bias may be necessary to narrow the black-white gap.

site_title: US retailers, shoe companies urge Trump not to hit China with tariffs
summary: US retailers and shoe companies, including Wal-Mart, Target, Nike, and Macy's, sent a letter to President Donald Trump urging him not to impose massive tariffs on imported goods from China, citing concerns that it would lead to higher consumer prices and punish American working families. The proposed tariffs, valued at over $60 billion, would target electronics, apparel, footwear, and toys, and would not need Congressional approval. The letter was signed by 24 companies, including 82 shoe companies, which argued that adding more tariffs would increase costs for consumers and reduce US jobs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.76 points to 1,846.18. Volume was 63.52 million lots worth RM29.15 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 169 to 61.

site_title: Sick air travellers mostly likely to infect next row: study
summary: Researchers at Emory University and the Georgia Institute of Technology found that people seated within one row and two seats laterally of an infected passenger on a flight have an 80% or greater probability of becoming infected with respiratory infections like SARS and influenza. For all other passengers, the probability of infection is less than 3%. The study also warns that infectious crew members can infect an average of 4.6 passengers per flight, emphasizing the importance of flight attendants not flying when ill.

site_title: Uber self-driving car 'likely not at fault' in fatal accident, say police in preliminary probe
summary: An Uber self-driving car struck and killed a woman in Tempe, Arizona, on March 19, 2018. The woman, Elaine Herzberg, 49, was walking her bicycle outside a crosswalk when she was hit by the vehicle traveling at 65km/h. Police say the Uber was likely not at fault, but charges could be filed against the operator. The incident has raised concerns about the safety of autonomous vehicles, prompting calls for a national moratorium on robot car testing on public roads. Uber has suspended North American tests of its self-driving vehicles.

site_title: Belgium says investigating 'significant' meat fraud
summary: Belgium is investigating a "significant" meat fraud operation involving the food company Veviba, which allegedly distributed falsely labelled meat products to Hong Kong, Ivory Coast, and Kosovo. The products, including those with altered freezing dates, were distributed until the end of 2016. Agriculture Minister Denis Ducarme accused Veviba of using "mafia practices" in the distribution of meat. The Belgian food security authority, Afsca, notified the affected nations and the incident has caused a minor scandal in Belgium following recent European food scares.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday following US tech selloff; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 13.85 points to 3,484.44, following a US tech selloff that dented trader sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.35% on Wall Street, while regional markets also declined. About 45 million shares changed hands on the Singapore Exchange, with losers outnumbering gainers 103 to 27.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after tech selloff on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on March 20, 2018, after US stocks declined due to a Facebook data breach scandal. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% to 21,311.63, while the Topix index dropped 0.66% to 1,708.54. The decline follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Shares sink, Micro Focus plummets
summary: European shares fell 1.1% ahead of a US interest rate hike, while Micro Focus plummeted 46% after cutting its annual revenue forecast and CEO quitting. The tech sector index tumbled 2.5%, its worst fall since February. Hammerson soared 24% after rebuffing a takeover offer from Klepierre, boosting commercial real estate stocks. Investors are cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting, with some downgrading tech stocks to 'neutral' and upgrading utilities to 'overweight'.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Union Gas, JEP, CapitaLand, Oxley
summary: Union Gas Holdings announced a S$9.2 million acquisition of Union Energy Corporation, with 24.3 million shares to be issued at S$0.2647 per share. JEP Holdings CEO Soh Chee Siong relinquished his role as executive director due to personal interest. CapitaLand Retail signed an agreement to manage a mall in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, as part of The Peak development.

site_title: US, China flex muscles at G-20 meeting
summary: US and Chinese finance ministers flexed their muscles at the G-20 meeting in Buenos Aires, highlighting tensions over trade. The US is set to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum on Friday, targeting China's steel-producing overcapacity, while the EU is considering a plan to tax US tech giants. Despite disagreements, analysts suggest a collective solution may be the best option, with potential agreements on reducing steel industry overcapacity.

site_title: Fund managers Prudential, Orbis dispose Noble shares
summary: Fund managers Prudential and Orbis have sold approximately 42 million shares of Noble Group worth S$5.5 million on the open market from March 14 to 19. The sales reduced their stakes in Noble from 10.1% to 9.9% and 10.1% to 8.9% respectively. Noble shares plummeted 7.2% to 10.3 Singapore cents apiece, their lowest since 1999, following the company's decision not to pay a US$379 million bond due on Tuesday, putting it on course for its first note default.

site_title: Aramco eyes local IPO, may spike overseas listing: report
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil giant, Aramco, is considering listing shares on a local exchange instead of an overseas listing, according to a report by The Wall Street Journal. This comes as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman prepares to meet with President Donald Trump, who has lobbied for a US Aramco listing. The IPO, initially valued at $100 billion, may now be less necessary due to higher oil prices. The listing on a domestic exchange would be a key part of Saudi Arabia's reform program to diversify its economy and reduce reliance on oil revenues.

site_title: Amazon said to have mulled acquiring some Toys 'R' Us stores
summary: Amazon considered acquiring some Toys 'R' Us stores, but is not interested in maintaining the brand. The online giant would use the vacant spaces for its own purposes, such as showcasing its Echo devices and expanding its brick-and-mortar presence. This move would put inventory closer to customers, enabling quick delivery to e-commerce customers. However, Amazon is under little pressure to hammer out a deal, and similar talks about acquiring RadioShack locations in 2015 led nowhere.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc has looked at the possibility of expanding its retail footprint by acquiring some locations from bankrupt Toys 'R' Us Inc, according to people with knowledge of the situation.

site_title: More companies in South-east Asia planning to divest: survey
summary: South-east Asian companies are increasingly planning to divest, with 88% of respondents in the region indicating intentions to do so within the next two years, similar to the global figure of 87%.
