Investors who ignore big data and AI risk becoming ineffective or obsolete. The emergence of "smart-enabled" investors who implement decision support tools will be key to success in the future.

site_title: A car fit for the modern Bond
summary: Aston Martin's DB11 coupe, featuring a 4.0-litre twin-turbo V8 engine, offers a balance of style and performance. Weighing 115kg less than its V12 counterpart, the V8 model delivers 510hp and a more agile driving experience. The car boasts a refined and controlled power delivery, with three drivetrain modes, and a unique character distinct from the Mercedes-AMG GT S. With a lower price tag and improved interior, the DB11 4.0 V8 is a welcome addition to Aston Martin's lineup, suitable for both everyday driving and spirited performances.

site_title: Bank of Singapore seeks to expand family office business
summary: Bank of Singapore is expanding its family office business, driven by increasing demand from wealthy families seeking to manage their investments globally. The bank aims to double assets under management to $500 million per banker over the next three to four years. This expansion will heighten competition with European banks, particularly UBS and Credit Suisse. Singapore's government provides incentives for family offices, including tax exemptions, which will be leveraged to attract clients from China, Europe, and the Middle East. The bank's assets under management have risen to $100 billion, up 21% annually over the past five years.

site_title: L'Oreal buys mobile app provider of digital makeovers
summary: L'Oreal has acquired ModiFace, a Canadian mobile app provider of digital makeovers, for an undisclosed sum. The acquisition will give L'Oreal tools to test make-up and lipstick online using augmented reality technology. ModiFace's software allows users to see their faces transformed in real time, and the company has partnered with L'Oreal brands such as Sephora and Estee Lauder. The deal strengthens L'Oreal's position in digital and is part of the company's strategy to provide digital experiences to consumers, with a focus on men's grooming and e-commerce growth in key markets.

site_title: Non-oil exports shrink 5.9% in Feb, far below economists' expectations of 4.8% expansion
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports shrank 5.9% in February, far below economists' expectations of a 4.8% expansion. The decline is attributed to the Chinese New Year effect, with electronics shipments also falling 12.3% and non-electronics shipments down 3.4%. Economists caution that the slowdown may be a temporary phenomenon, but some warn of a more significant decline in exports if the global trade environment deteriorates. The manufacturing data on March 26 will provide further insight into the country's export performance.

site_title: Tech's whiz-kids are growing up - again. Phew!
summary: Tech industry leaders are maturing, acknowledging flaws and taking responsibility for mistakes. Former "whiz kids" like Mark Zuckerberg, Sundar Pichai, and Larry Page are now in their 30s and 40s, with more self-awareness and a willingness to address consequences. The industry's largest companies are shifting from a "move fast and break things" culture to more thoughtful, grown-up solutions. This shift is driven by the growing number of parents among tech elites, who are reevaluating the impact of their work on society and the world.

site_title: Virtual reality lets rare works of art take a field trip
summary: The Kremer Museum, a private collection of 17th-century Dutch and Flemish paintings, has launched a mobile app that allows users to visit the virtual museum using Google Daydream-ready phones and VR headsets. The app features 74 artworks from the collection, with each painting photographed 3,000 times and merged into a 3D image. The museum aims to make art more accessible worldwide, with plans to donate smartphones and VR helmets to selected schools, starting in India. The app is free, and the Kremers hope it will reach a wider audience than traditional exhibitions.

site_title: Wheeler-Dealer
summary: Mobike co-founder Joe Xia believes the sharing economy will transform cities, despite regulatory challenges. The bike-sharing firm, valued over $1 billion, is expanding globally, with Singapore as its first international location. Xia thinks convenience is key to the success of startups, as they meet real customer needs, not just fake ones. He sees a close relationship between Mobike and the government, with regulations that support the sharing economy. Xia also envisions Mobike's future expansion into other transportation services, such as electric bicycles and possibly even flying cars. Despite concerns about abandoned bikes, Xia emphasizes the importance of building relationships with governments and meeting local regulations before expansion.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: The ultimate luxury good now costs at least US$10 million
summary: The UK art market experienced an 8% increase to $12.9 billion in 2017, boosted by the pound's weakness, but its growth was less impressive than the US and China. China surpassed the UK in market share, accounting for 21% of sales, while the US had 42%. The Brexit vote's impact on the market remains uncertain, with the UK's art trade with Europe estimated to be lower than official figures suggest. The art market's reliance on mega-sales by big-name artists, with over one-third of sales valued at over $10 million, is also a concern for the industry's smaller businesses and employment.

site_title: Hatten Land terminates two proposed acquisitions
summary: Malaysian property developer Hatten Land has terminated two proposed acquisitions, citing a weakened share price. The moves, announced on March 16, include the termination of agreements for the acquisition of a 85% stake in Rico Development Sdn Bhd and a 75% stake in Rico Ventures Sdn Bhd. The company stated that the acquisitions will not have a material adverse impact on its financials.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets opened flat on Friday, with the London FTSE 100 index at 7,136.23 points. The Paris CAC 40 dipped 0.1% and the German DAX's opening was delayed due to a technical issue. Analysts expect stubbornly low inflation data from the European Central Bank, which may limit concerns about an imminent trade war. Despite this, the European market appears to be unfazed by US President Donald Trump's recent appointment of Lary Kudlow, a supporter of the "America first" agenda.

site_title: Japanese companies call for EU-Japan trade deal to apply to UK during transition
summary: Japanese business groups have urged the EU to apply its trade deal with Japan to the UK during its transition period, aiming to minimize disruptions. The Japan Business Council in Europe and Keidanren, the Japan Business Federation, called for close trade and regulations between Britain and the EU after the transition phase. Japan has agreed a trade deal with the EU in principle but it has not yet entered into force.

site_title: STI extends losses to close 0.2% lower on Friday
summary: The Singapore bourse closed 0.2% lower on Friday, extending its losses for the third straight day. The Straits Times Index finished at 3,512.14, down 5.6 points. Despite a bullish view on the index's medium term, traders await the March Federal Open Market Committee meeting for leads, expecting an interest rate hike. The market was influenced by weak export data and a lack of fresh catalysts, with some stocks, including OCBC and DBS, falling between 1% and 1.5%.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: How to know when a company represents a paradigm shift
summary: A company represents a paradigm shift when it fundamentally changes its industry by reinventing itself and exploiting pressing problems. This concept, coined by Thomas Kuhn, describes a business that upends its industry, changing how it operates and generates profit. Companies like Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, and Uber have exemplified this, as well as Netflix, Tesla, and WeWork. These businesses have created new markets, disrupted traditional practices, and driven innovation, marking a significant shift in their respective industries.

site_title: Asean, Australia to make it easier for businesses to conduct cross-border digital trade
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a new Digital Standards Cooperation Initiative to facilitate cross-border digital trade between Asean and Australia. The initiative aims to reduce costs and make it easier for businesses to conduct digital trade, particularly for small and medium enterprises. The move is part of Asean's efforts to strengthen regional economic integration and deepen interdependence. The two leaders emphasized the importance of free trade and cooperation in the face of protectionism and rising trade tensions.

site_title: Businesses must train workers for the future: Temasek CEO
summary: Temasek CEO Ho Ching and Greater Sydney Commissioner Lucy Turnbull urged businesses to train workers for the future, promote gender equality, and adopt sustainability. They made the call at the Asean-Australia business summit in Sydney.

site_title: EU calls for industry input on US tariff retaliation list
summary: The European Commission has called for industry input on a list of US products that will be subject to import tariffs if the US imposes duties on European steel and aluminum. The EU plans to impose 25% duties on 2.8 billion euros worth of US imports, including maize, motorbikes, and other goods. The US has already imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum, with exemptions for Canada and Mexico. The EU aims to counterbalance the estimated 6.4 billion euros of damage to its aluminum and steel sectors. Industry views are due by March 26.

site_title: Chinese takeovers sparking pushback from US, Europe and others
summary: Governments worldwide, particularly in Europe, are pushing for stricter vetting of foreign investments, citing national security concerns amid China's growing economic influence. The US, Australia, and Canada are leading the charge, while the EU proposes a Europe-wide framework to screen investment deals. However, implementing these measures poses a difficult policy puzzle, balancing safeguarding strategic industries with courting Chinese investors. China's Made in China 2025 policy has sparked concerns, and some countries, like Germany, are divided over how to cope with China's rise.

images.alt_text: The 2016 purchase of Kuka, Germany's biggest and most advanced maker of robotics, by a Chinese company set off concerns over the transfer of European know-how to China.
Li Shufu, chairman of Chinese car giant Geely has stealthily amassed a US$9 billion stake in Daimler, a crown jewel of Germany's auto industry.

site_title: Bitcoin's 'death cross' looms as strategist eyes US$2,800
summary: Bitcoin's price is expected to fall as a "death cross" forms, a technical indicator suggesting weakness in the market. The 50-day moving average has dropped to its closest proximity to the 200-day moving average in nine months, signaling a potential 76% tumble from February highs to around $2,800. This is based on analysis by Paul Day, a technical analyst, who studied Bitcoin's 2013 tumble and concluded that a similar downturn is likely. The indicator's bearish momentum and regulatory risks may contribute to the expected price drop.

images.alt_text: The tea leaves don't bode well for Bitcoin.

site_title: Infinio Group unit to acquire majority stake in Oxley Holdings subsidiary for S$10.4m
summary: Infinio Group's wholly owned unit plans to acquire a majority stake in Oxley Holdings' subsidiary, Oxley Batam, for S$10.4 million. The acquisition aims to enable Infinio to undertake a viable property development business and diversify revenue streams. If completed by March 31, 2017, the deal would have resulted in a net asset value of S$33.7 million. The proposed acquisition is expected to substantially increase Infinio's asset base and business operations, with the purchase satisfied wholly by cash and bank borrowings.

site_title: Tenders launched for parcels at Mattar Road, Silat Avenue
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) of Singapore has launched two residential sites, one at Mattar Road with a 6,230.2 sq m area and a maximum of 250 units, and the other at Silat Avenue with a 22,851.6 sq m area and a maximum of 1,125 units. The tender for the sites will close on April 26. Analysts expect the winning bids to be around S$1,300 to S$1,400 per sq ft for Silat Avenue and S$1,100 per sq ft for Mattar Road.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 'Life of Pi' actor Irrfan Khan reveals battle with tumour
summary: Indian actor Irrfan Khan has been diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumour, which he revealed in a Twitter message. The tumour, originating from the cells of the neuroendocrine system, is rare and can develop in the intestines or pancreas. Khan dismissed speculation about the tumour being cancerous and is travelling overseas for treatment. He expressed gratitude for the love and support of those around him, stating he aims to return with more stories to tell.

site_title: HK mulls over tax on unsold apartments to unlock supply
summary: Hong Kong is considering a tax on unsold apartments to address its red-hot housing market. Financial Secretary Paul Chan said the levy would need a specific target and not apply across the board. The move aims to unlock the supply of empty homes being hoarded by developers, who have been selling units in batches and increasing prices. This practice has driven up residential prices, which have more than doubled in the past decade. Similar taxes have been implemented in Vancouver and Victoria, Australia, but Chan's approach focuses on developers rather than owners.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% down, extending its losses for the third straight day, at 3,512.14. The market was weighed down by soft leads from Wall Street and fears over trade tensions and US politics. Weak February non-oil domestic exports data also disappointed, pointing to weak manufacturing in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in five weeks, surpassing 6% for the first time since 2007. This increase is expected to impact the condo market in Singapore, particularly for prime projects priced above S$3,000 psf, as demand is expected to test. Manhattan rents have reached another record, with more increases anticipated. Meanwhile, UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and WeWork has secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy space in Singapore. These developments indicate ongoing challenges in the global real estate market.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US jumps to 14-year high after tax cuts
summary: US consumer sentiment surged to a 14-year high in March, reaching 102, driven by tax cuts boosting disposable incomes. However, inflation expectations and tariffs on imported steel and aluminum dimmed the outlook. The survey found that lower-income households were more optimistic, while higher-income households were less so. Despite this, 59% of respondents cited recent financial progress, and income gains were cited by a five-decade high. The boost in confidence is expected to support consumer spending, the largest part of the US economy.

site_title: Abe's support falls to 39% amid cronyism scandal
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's support has fallen to 39.3% amid a suspected cronyism scandal, with opposition parties calling for Finance Minister Taro Aso's resignation. The scandal involves a discounted sale of state-owned land to a school operator linked to Abe's wife, Akie, and allegations of a cover-up. Abe and Aso have denied wrongdoing, but the affair could dash Abe's hopes of winning a third term as head of his Liberal Democratic Party. Protesters have gathered outside Abe's office, calling for his resignation and Aso's departure.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.12 points to 1,846.39. The index saw 2.9 billion lots traded worth RM4.3 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 504 to 382.

site_title: Compact Metal revives 2015 restructuring plan to trade as cement dealer
summary: Compact Metal Industries, a Singapore-listed aluminium dealer, has revived a 2015 restructuring plan to trade as a cement dealer. The company will transfer its shares to International Cement Group, an investment holding company, and become an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary. The move aims to diversify into the cement business, meet Singapore Exchange's financial entry criteria watch list requirements, and achieve flexibility in new acquisitions, expansions, or divestments. The proposed restructuring requires shareholder approval of at least three-quarters of the share value.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: URA launches tenders for residential sites at Mattar Road, Silat Avenue
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched two residential sites at Mattar Road and Silat Avenue for sale by public tender. The Mattar Road site has a 6,230.2 sqm area and can yield 250 units, while the Silat Avenue site has a 22,851.6 sqm area and can yield 1,125 units. The tender will close on April 26 and will be batched with another site at Cuscaden Road.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: The greenest run in Singapore
summary: The Income Eco Run, Singapore's premier eco-run, returns in April with new distances and initiatives to promote environmental conservation. The event, organized by insurer NTUC Income, aims to reduce production waste and encourage participants to adopt zero-waste practices. This year's event features a 5km fun run, 1.2km kids dash, and 800m kids dash, as well as reduced plastic packaging and the use of reusable water bottles. The event also promotes sustainable transportation through the #runhomesg initiative and encourages staff to participate as Zero Waste Runners.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: CK Hutchison Chairman Li Ka-shing to retire, become adviser
summary: Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing, will retire as chairman of CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd at the upcoming Annual General Meeting on May 10, becoming a senior adviser to the group. His eldest son, Victor Li, will take over the reins of the business. Li Ka-shing will also retire as chairman of CK Asset Holdings Ltd, a property group. The decision follows earlier speculation about his retirement in 2018, and he had initially stated he would stay on as an adviser even after stepping down.

site_title: M&As in Singapore down 28% so far this year
summary: Singapore's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) scene is off to a slow start this year, with overall M&A activity reaching US$8 billion, down 24.8% from the year-ago period. The real estate sector led deal-making, accounting for 35% of the market share, while materials and industrials sectors also saw significant increases. Cross-border activity fell 57.8% to US$3.3 billion, with inbound M&A activity plummeting 79.4%. Private equity-backed M&As in Singapore were down 92% year-to-date, while domestic M&A activity grew 30.3%. Completed M&A deals involving Singapore rose 9.9% to US$28.9 billion.

site_title: HL Global Enterprises gets in-principle nod from SGX for share conversion
summary: HL Global Enterprises received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) to convert its non-redeemable convertible cumulative preference shares (NCCPS) into new ordinary shares at a ratio of one ordinary share for every 10 NCCPS. The approval is subject to compliance with SGX-ST's listing requirements and shareholder approval. The company will convene an extraordinary general meeting to obtain final approval and will list the conversion shares on the SGX-ST.

site_title: Lung Kee (Bermuda) Holdings' full-year profit up 45%
summary: Lung Kee (Bermuda) Holdings reported a 45% increase in full-year earnings to HK$278.3 million, driven by a one-off gain from the sale of a Shanghai subsidiary. Revenue rose 13% to HK$2.51 billion, primarily due to growth in the China business. The company attributed sales growth to booming demand for mould products in the automotive, intelligent household, and electronic sectors. Despite a rise in raw materials costs, Lung Kee managed operating costs, and a final dividend of 16 HK cents per share and a special dividend of 12 HK cents per share will be paid to shareholders.

site_title: Rejecting protectionism, Asean and Australia commit to free trade
summary: Asean and Australia have committed to free trade, rejecting protectionism, at a special meeting in Sydney. Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Singapore's Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of embracing free trade, not retreat from it, amid a looming trade war between the US, China, and Europe. The meeting also addressed human rights concerns, particularly in Myanmar and Cambodia, and the growing influence of China in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on foreign buying; won flat
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 1.59 points or 0.06% to 2,493.97 at 0632 GMT, driven by foreign buying that recouped early losses. The Korean won was marginally weaker against the dollar, while bond yields rose. The index ended the week with a 1.4% gain, and the KOSPI is up around 1% so far this year. Foreigners were net buyers of 100,360 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Hong Kong mulls tax on unsold apartments to curb soaring prices
summary: Hong Kong is considering imposing a tax on unsold apartments to curb the city's soaring housing prices. The Financial Secretary, Paul Chan, said the tax would target developers who hoard properties, a practice that has led to a significant increase in unsold units. The move aims to unlock the supply of empty homes and cool the market, which has seen prices more than double in the past decade. The tax would replicate Singapore's system, imposing penalties on developers who fail to sell their unsold properties.

site_title: Do small caps still have a place in your portfolio?
summary: Small-cap stocks have historically underperformed large-cap stocks, with the S&P 500 returning 21.8% in 2017 compared to the top 5 US companies (Apple, Google, Microsoft, Exxon Mobil, and Amazon) which returned an average of 35%. In Singapore, the Straits Times Index has grown 118% since 2007, while the FTSE Small Cap Index has declined by 30% over the same period. This trend is attributed to the effect of exchange-traded funds and other factors.

site_title: HSBC Singapore ramping up investment for consumer and wholesale business, hiring 300 more
summary: HSBC Singapore is ramping up investment in its consumer and wholesale banking businesses, hiring 300 more people over the next three years. The bank aims to significantly increase its market share in the country, where it currently has around 3,000 employees. HSBC has launched a new retail banking branch in Raffles Place, marking a shift towards increased financial advisory activities. The bank plans to focus on supporting the macro-economic and structural developments in the region, particularly in Southeast Asia, and aims to play a critical role in Singapore's ambition to be the leading wealth and trade hub of the region.

site_title: HNA-backed airlines begin paying overdue bills to fuel supplier
summary: HNA-backed airlines have begun paying overdue jet-fuel bills to China National Aviation Fuel Group, a state-owned supplier. Despite not settling the full amount owed, fuel supply remains normal. HNA Group's airline businesses are in the midst of over $10 billion in asset sales to ease financial pressures. The company has also denied reports of selling its Capital Air unit. This move comes as HNA Group prioritizes passenger interest and maintains safe operations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week with a loss
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week with a loss, falling 0.12% to 31,501.97, as fears of a trade war offset optimism from US President Donald Trump's talks with North Korea. The Shanghai Composite Index also declined 0.65%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.61%. The losses come despite Trump's face-to-face talks with North Korea leader Kim Jong Un, which sparked optimism about a potential easing of tensions.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore non-oil exports fell 5.9% in February, ending six months of growth. Meanwhile, HSBC Singapore is hiring 300 more staff to expand its consumer and wholesale banking business. The bank aims to grab a bigger share of the market. In other news, Toys 'R' Us' Asia business remains unaffected by US closures, and the company is even expanding. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% down on Friday, extending its losses for the third straight day.

site_title: Noble says it won't make payment on 2018 bonds
summary: NOBLE Group, a commodity trading company, announced it won't pay the principal and interest on its $379 million US bonds due on March 20 and the coupon on its 2020 notes. The decision was made after consulting with legal and financial advisers and creditors. Noble signed a restructuring support agreement (RSA) with creditors holding 46% of its senior debt, but it's unclear how much of the 2018 bond this group holds. The announcement came after the company's shares fell 10.5% on Friday.

site_title: Aramco getting cool response on IPO from US investors: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia's state-owned oil company Aramco is facing a lukewarm response from US investors regarding its initial public offering (IPO), with some expressing concerns over the company's valuation of $2 trillion, dividend yield, and potential impact of the shale boom on oil prices. Despite efforts to reassure investors, Aramco's IPO is still uncertain, with some investors questioning the company's exposure to fossil fuels amid growing concerns over climate change. The Saudi government is aiming to sell around 5% of the company, potentially raising $100 billion, and is considering delaying the IPO to 2019.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's willingness to delay the initial public offering of state oil company Aramco to 2019 has several motivations, from regulatory risk to competing projects in the government's crowded agenda.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us says Asia business not affected by US closures
summary: Toys 'R' Us (Asia) reports that its business in the region is unaffected by the US closures, despite the parent company's bankruptcy filing in September. The Asian entity is a separate, financially independent joint venture with an 85% stake in Toys 'R' Us Inc. and a 15% stake in Fung Retailing. The company operates over 400 stores across Greater China and South-East Asia, with plans to open new stores, including 30 in China.

site_title: ComfortDelGro reorganises businesses in Vietnam, China
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, Singapore's largest taxi operator, has reorganized its businesses in Vietnam and China. The company has combined operations of ComfortDelGro Savico Taxi Company and Vietnam Taxi Co, and acquired a 10% stake in Chongqing ComfortDelGro Driver Training Co in China. The moves are aimed at achieving greater efficiencies and are not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. The reorganization is part of the company's rationalization efforts in the taxi business in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tech, healthcare stocks gain
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday, driven by gains in technology and healthcare stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 16.59 points, or 0.07%, to 24,890.25, while the S&P 500 gained 6.18 points, or 0.224946%, to 2,753.51. Investors were assessing the impact of US tariffs on the global economy and turmoil in the Trump administration.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on strong yen, political woes
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.58% on Friday due to a strong yen and concerns over US and Japanese politics. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed at 21,676.51, down from its early gains. Investors were cautious amid worries over US President Donald Trump's trade policy and growing pressure on Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government over a favouritism scandal. The dollar strengthened against the yen, leading to a decline in shares.

site_title: Bank of Singapore seeks to expand its family office business
summary: Bank of Singapore, a private bank of Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, is expanding its family office business in Singapore, capitalizing on the city-state's favorable environment for wealthy investors. CEO Bahren Shaari said the demand for family offices is increasing, driven by families seeking to manage their wealth globally. The bank aims to double assets under management to US$500 million per banker over three to four years, with a focus on rich families from China, Europe, and the Middle East. This expansion will heighten competition with European firms and tap OCBC's onshore presence in Taiwan.

site_title: Myanmar to start US$2.5b Yangon station revamp
summary: Myanmar is set to begin a $2.5 billion redevelopment of the Yangon railway station, a six-decade-old colonial landmark, in June after contract negotiations are completed. The project, the largest under Aung San Suu Kyi's government, aims to preserve the historic station while adding a futuristic new one, residential, and commercial real estate. Construction is expected to take eight years and has attracted Asian investment despite international criticism of Suu Kyi's government over the Rohingya refugee crisis. A consortium led by Min Dhama Co, Oxley Holdings, and Sino Great Wall Co was selected as the preferred bidder.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars play defence as markets fret on US policy
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars slipped in value against the US dollar on Friday, amid risk aversion and concerns over a global trade war. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7784, while the kiwi dollar dropped to US$0.7254. The moves were attributed to President Donald Trump's decision to fire National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster and reports of potential tariffs on Chinese goods. Economists warn that the Australian dollar could be heavily impacted by US-driven trade tensions due to Australia's current account deficits and reliance on China for commodity exports.

site_title: Top oil trader Vitol has new CEO as Taylor becomes chairman
summary: Vitol Group, the world's largest independent oil trader, has appointed Russell Hardy as its new CEO, replacing Ian Taylor. Taylor, who led the company for over two decades, will remain chairman. Hardy, a chemical engineer and Vitol veteran, will face significant challenges in the industry, which is experiencing decreased profit margins due to increased competition and transparency. Under Taylor's leadership, Vitol expanded globally, increasing its net income from $22.9 million to a record $2.28 billion in 2009.

site_title: Quick takes: Outlook still robust despite February's export contraction, but pace of growth will slow
summary: Singapore's February exports contracted for the first time in six months, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declining 5.9% from the same period last year. Economists attribute the decline to the Chinese New Year, which typically causes a base effect on NODX. Despite this, the overall year-on-year growth rate remains at 3.5%. The slowdown in electronics exports, a key driver of Singapore's growth, is also expected to continue, with economists predicting moderating growth in 2018.

site_title: Russia will 'of course' expel British diplomats: Lavrov
summary: Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov announced that Moscow will expel British diplomats in response to London's decision to kick out 23 Russian officials over the poisoning of ex-double agent Sergei Skripal. Lavrov stated that his country has no motive to target Skripal, but the poisoning could be used to "complicate" the World Cup. The move is seen as a response to the joint statement by Britain, France, Germany, and the US condemning the attack on Skripal and his daughter.

site_title: Trump to oust national security adviser HR McMaster: report
summary: US President Donald Trump has decided to remove National Security Adviser HR McMaster, according to a report by The Washington Post. Trump is discussing potential replacements but wants to avoid humiliating McMaster, a move similar to his recent firing of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. There are no changes at the National Security Council, according to White House spokeswoman Sarah Sanders. Speculation surrounds potential replacements, including education secretary Betsy DeVos and housing and urban development secretary Ben Carson.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session lower on Friday; STI at 3,512.78, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% in the afternoon session on Friday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,512.78, down 4.95 points. The most actively traded stock was JEP Holdings, falling S$0.007 to S$0.077. About 828 million shares worth S$528 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 186 to 140.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks falter as trade worries hurt sentiment; won down
summary: South Korea's stock market fell on Friday due to trade war worries, with the Kospi index down 0.56% at 2,478.44. The Korean won lost 0.49% against the dollar, weighed by the US dollar's strength in global markets. The decline followed US tariffs, sparking concerns about a potential trade war. Despite this, US stocks edged to fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising.

site_title: Asean, Australia to make it easier for businesses to conduct cross-border digital trade
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of free trade, warning against protectionism and trade wars. They announced a new Digital Standards Cooperation Initiative to facilitate cross-border digital trade and strengthen regional economic integration. The initiative aims to establish interoperable digital standards, making it easier for businesses to conduct trade in the region, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: Hot stock: Oxley falls 4.5% after announcing share placement
summary: Oxley Holdings' stock fell 4.5% after announcing a share placement of 156.8 million new shares at S$0.51 each, raising S$78.1 million. The issue price represents a 8.8% discount to its VWAP of S$0.559. This is Oxley's lowest trading price since March 1st.

site_title: Toyota, Uber in talks on self-driving tech: report
summary: Uber Technologies is in talks with Toyota Motor Co. to install its self-driving system in Toyota vehicles. The companies are discussing a possible deal for Toyota to use Uber's technology in one of its minivan models. This collaboration would allow Toyota to quickly bring new mobility technologies to market, while Uber seeks to sell its autonomous driving technology to outside companies. The partnership aligns with Toyota's existing partnership with Uber on ride-hailing and self-driving systems, and comes as global carmakers and tech companies compete to develop self-driving cars.

site_title: Taiwan doles out incentives to retain talent as China woos investment
summary: Taiwan is introducing more incentives to retain talent and strengthen protection for company trade secrets, amid China's efforts to attract investment from Taiwanese companies. The move counters China's plan to treat Taiwan companies in certain sectors as equal to mainland companies, sparking concerns about Taiwan's sovereignty. Taiwan's deputy premier announced plans to shorten IPO review periods and actively investigate trade secret leaks, while also warning Taiwanese companies and people to exercise caution when dealing with China. The government aims to maintain national security and protect basic rights.

images.alt_text: Taiwan will dole out more incentives aimed at retaining talented workers and strengthening protection for company trade secrets, the deputy premier said on Friday, in a bid to counter China's efforts to draw investment by Taiwan companies.

site_title: Fintech Ayondo registers offer documents for Catalist listing
summary: EU-based fintech firm Ayondo has submitted offer documents for a Singapore listing on the Catalist junior board, becoming the first financial technology firm to do so. The initial public offering (IPO) will consist of 80.77 million shares, with shares offered at S$0.26 apiece, pegging gross proceeds at roughly S$21 million. Trading is set to begin on March 26, with net proceeds expected to raise about S$18.5 million, with half allocated towards loan repayment.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: AT&T merger trial to go twice as long as first estimate
summary: US District Judge Richard Leon has estimated the trial to block AT&T's $85.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner to last up to eight weeks, twice as long as initially expected. The Justice Department claims the deal would harm competition and increase costs for consumers, citing a $36 million monthly price increase. However, AT&T and Time Warner dispute this figure, claiming the price increase would be just 45 cents per subscriber per month. The trial is set to start on March 19, with opening arguments scheduled for March 21.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened relatively flat on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) edging down 0.4% to 3,505.17. About 59.8 million shares worth S$76 million changed hands, with Marco Polo Marine being the most actively traded counter. Worries about US President Donald Trump's trade policy offset positive US economic data, leading to a mixed session.

site_title: Slow start to year as proceeds raised by Singapore bond offerings drop 21.5%
summary: Singapore's primary bond offerings have seen a slow start to the year, raising US$6.7 billion as of March 2018, a 21.5% drop from the same period in 2017. This is the lowest start to a year since 2015. The financial sector dominated the market with US$4.3 billion in proceeds, followed by government and agencies with 26%. DBS Group Holdings took the lead in underwriting Singapore-issued bonds with US$1.4 billion in related proceeds. The real estate sector was a distant third with 5% market share.

site_title: Kuroda wins second term at Bank of Japan
summary: Japan's parliament approved Haruhiko Kuroda for a second term as central bank governor, with a mandate to battle deflation and boost the country's economy. Kuroda, 73, has guided the Bank of Japan since 2013 with ultra-aggressive monetary easing, but has failed to hit the inflation target of 2%. Despite this, the economy has shown signs of improvement, with Japan enjoying its longest unbroken spell of quarterly growth since the 1980s. Kuroda has pledged to stay the course and continue the easing policy to realize the inflation target.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on Wesfarmers' spinoff plan; NZ at record
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday, snapping a three-session losing streak, driven by Wesfarmers' 6.3% gain after announcing plans to spin off its Coles supermarket division. The S&P/ASX 200 index finished the week down 0.2%. Other sectors, including materials and healthcare, also contributed to the gains. In contrast, the "Big Four" banks fell due to a government-backed inquiry into the sector. New Zealand's benchmark index reversed early losses to close at a record.

site_title: Indonesia open to idea of Australia as full Asean member
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has expressed support for Australia's potential membership in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), citing benefits for regional stability, economic stability, and political stability. This comes as Australia hosts a special Asean summit in Sydney, where China's growing influence and the threat of violent extremism are key themes. Australia has been a dialogue partner of Asean since 1974 and has been urged to aim for full membership by 2024. Widodo's endorsement marks the first time an Indonesian president has supported Australia's bid for Asean membership.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports fall 5.9% in February after 4 months of growth
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports declined 5.9% in February, the first drop in four months, due in part to the Chinese New Year. This fell short of economists' expectations of a 4.8% expansion. Electronics and non-electronics shipments both declined, with electronic exports dropping 12.3% and non-electronic exports sliding 3.4%. The decline was led by China, the European Union, and Taiwan, while the US, Japan, and South Korea were the only major markets to see an increase.

site_title: Australia: Shares up as Wesfarmers jumps on spin-off plans; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Friday, driven by Wesfarmers' 6% surge after announcing plans to spin off its Coles supermarket division. Materials stocks also gained, with top miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto up 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. However, financial stocks limited gains, with the "Big Four" banks down 0.5-0.9%. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2% and is set to end the week up 1.1%.

site_title: Ex-Siemens executive pleads guilty in US$100m bribery plot
summary: A former Siemens executive, Eberhard Reichert, pleaded guilty to conspiring to pay tens of millions of dollars in bribes to officials in Argentina, as part of a decades-long bribery scheme. Reichert, 78, admitted to participating in a decade-long scheme to pay bribes to Argentine officials, members of the opposition, and candidates. He has not been sentenced yet. This case is part of a landmark investigation by the US Justice Department, which resulted in Siemens paying $1.6 billion in fines and the return of ill-gotten gains in 2008.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oxley, Datapulse, LifeBrandz, Top Glove
summary: Stocks to watch: Oxley Holdings, Datapulse Technology, LifeBrandz, and Top Glove. Oxley Holdings issued 156.8 million new shares to raise S$78.1 million, while Datapulse Technology posted a net profit of S$38.1 million, a turnaround from a loss the previous year. LifeBrandz saw losses widen due to burgeoning expenses, and Top Glove's second-quarter net profit surged 31% year on year.

site_title: Myanmar needs urgent reforms as economy's in the woods
summary: Myanmar's economy is experiencing a downturn, with business confidence plummeting due to unclear economic policy and a lack of reforms. The Aung San Suu Kyi-led government has delayed a key reform allowing foreign companies to purchase stakes in local companies, sparking concerns among investors. Insurgency-affected areas have instead seen the emergence of "ceasefire capitalism," where local governments and businesses collaborate in a nexus that is unlikely to be dismantled by the reform process. The country's economic growth has slowed, and the World Bank lists Myanmar as one of the fastest growing economies in East Asia, but with a high life expectancy and infant mortality rate. Urgent reforms are needed to address the country's economic challenges.

site_title: South Korea, US to scale down military drills: report
summary: South Korea and the US will scale down and shorten annual joint military exercises due to a diplomatic thaw with North Korea. The reduced drills, known as Key Resolve and Foal Eagle, are in response to an improving relationship between the two Koreas and the US, with a planned summit between Seoul and Pyongyang set for next month. US President Donald Trump is also expected to meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un by the end of May, further easing tensions. The reduced exercises are seen as a step towards reducing the risk of provocation from North Korea.

site_title: Dream Job
summary: Tirso Garcia, also known as Jnr Tirso, has achieved success with his passion-driven business, Choice Cuts Goods + Coffee, which combines music and coffee in a relaxed atmosphere. Founded by Garcia and his partner Andee Reyes, the café aims to bring together like-minded individuals who share their love for music. Garcia's DJ career and hip-hop influences shaped his venture, and he plans to continue growing Choice Cuts through innovation and community engagement. The café has become a no-frills spot for people to unwind and connect over music.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher in cautious trade
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.24% to 21,855.88, and the Topix index rising 0.14% to 1,746.09. The gains were driven by a weakening yen against the dollar. Investors remained cautious due to concerns over US and Japanese political risks.

site_title: Florida foot bridge collapse leaves 4 people dead
summary: A newly erected pedestrian bridge in Florida collapsed, killing 4 people and injuring 10. The 53m long bridge, built by Munilla Construction Management, collapsed on top of vehicles at a traffic light, trapping at least eight vehicles. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating the cause of the collapse, which was intended to provide a walkway over a busy street where a student was killed in August. The bridge was designed to withstand a Category 5 hurricane and was built using Accelerated Bridge Construction methods.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed heading into weekend
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed close on Friday, driven by concerns over a global trade war and uncertainty surrounding US interest rates. Despite a positive jobs and wages report, investors remained cautious due to ongoing tensions between the US and China. The removal of a moderate secretary of state from the Trump administration added to the unease. However, a meeting between Trump and Kim Jong Un to discuss North Korea's nuclear program provided relief, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Businesses must train workers for the future: Ho Ching at Asean-Australia business summit
summary: Businesses must train workers for the future, promote gender equality, and adopt sustainability, according to Ho Ching, CEO of Temasek Holdings. Speaking at the Asean-Australia business summit, Ho emphasized the importance of businesses contributing to creating a fair and equitable society alongside governments and civic society. This includes reskilling and upskilling workers to adapt to technological change. Greater Sydney Commissioner Lucy Turnbull highlighted the need for increased female participation in the workforce and leadership roles to benefit the global economy and societies.

site_title: Businesses must train workers for the future: Ho Ching at Asean-Australia business summit
summary: Businesses must invest in training workers for the future, promoting gender equality, and embracing sustainability, according to Temasek Holdings CEO Ho Ching and Greater Sydney Commissioner Lucy Turnbull. They emphasized the importance of businesses contributing to creating a fair and equitable society alongside governments and civic society. With technological change on the rise, businesses, governments, and labor movements must work together to reskill and upskill the workforce. Ho Ching noted that businesses have a stake in the well-being of their communities and must prioritize financial returns alongside social responsibility.

site_title: Asean, Australia to make it easier for businesses to conduct cross-border digital trade
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced a new Digital Standards Cooperation Initiative to facilitate cross-border digital trade in Asean and Australia. The initiative aims to develop interoperable digital standards, making it easier for businesses to conduct digital trade, and tap into the region's growing digital economy. The move is seen as a push against protectionism and a step towards strengthening regional economic integration.

images.alt_text: Protectionism is a "dead end", Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said on Friday, as he and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made a strong push for countries to continue working together on free trade.

site_title: Europe: Consumer stocks a headache as Britain's FTSE inches higher
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,139.76 points, recovering from a three-day losing streak. Unilever fell 1.7% after announcing it would move its corporate headquarters to Rotterdam a year before Brexit, potentially affecting its FTSE 100 listing. Consumer stocks were also impacted, with PZ Cussons' shares dropping 16% after a profit warning and Hammerson's shares falling 5% after a downgrade.

site_title: Hits For The Home
summary: HOOQ, a video-on-demand joint venture, is set to release several blockbusters in March, including Star Wars Episode VIII: The Last Jedi and Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle. These titles, along with Pixar's Coco, will be available for streaming on mobile devices and in living rooms. Download the HOOQ app from the Apple Store or Google Play to access the content. A complimentary trial is available at www.hooq.tv.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Queen consents to Prince Harry, Markle wedding
summary: Queen Elizabeth II has given her formal consent for Prince Harry to marry US actress Meghan Markle. The Queen's consent was given at a meeting of her Privy Council in Buckingham Palace, stating she would "signify under the Great Seal" and enter the register of the Privy Council. The marriage is set to take place on May 19 at St George's Chapel in Windsor Castle. This marks the first time a member of the royal family will marry a non-royal, with Harry moving down the line of succession to sixth place.

site_title: Australia central bank warns global markets too complacent on rate risks
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Deputy Governor, Guy Debelle, warned that global markets are too complacent about interest rate risks, citing a lack of adequate compensation for those risks. Despite record-high stock prices, market participants have failed to heed warnings about a potential shift upwards in the rate structure. Debelle noted that past predictions of higher market volatility have been proven wrong, but he believes there is a higher probability of being correct this time, citing the potential for a larger and more sustained shift in the rate structure.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.10 points to 1,842.17 on Friday, opening lower. The index saw 59.6 million lots traded worth RM18.9 million. Losers outpaced gainers 105 to 56.

site_title: Oxley to raise S$78.1m from placement of 156.8m new shares at S$0.51 apiece
summary: OXLEY Holdings has agreed to issue 156.8 million new shares at S$0.51 apiece to raise S$78.1 million. The placement is an 8.8% discount to the previous trading price and is expected to broaden the shareholder base and improve trading liquidity. The funds will be used for working capital and project development. The company's executive chairman and CEO expressed confidence in the long-term prospects, citing the strong interest from institutional funds and the recovery in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Oil edges up but rising crude supply checks gains
summary: Oil prices rose 23 cents to settle at $61.19 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude and $65.12 a barrel for Brent crude, driven by a global demand forecast to pick up this year. However, rising supply, led by the US, is expected to limit crude gains. The International Energy Agency warned that non-Opec supply will grow by 1.8 million bpd, while demand will grow by 1.5 million bpd, offsetting some supply constraints from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

site_title: Spotify to go public on April 3
summary: Spotify is set to go public on April 3, listing its shares directly on the New York Stock Exchange, avoiding the cost of underwriters and allowing its founders to maintain control. The company, which has a 42% share of the global streaming market, has voiced confidence in its fast-paced growth despite yet to turn a profit. Co-founder and CEO Daniel Ek expressed his views on the process, stating that going public is not about "the pomp or the circumstance" and that the company will not be throwing any parties to celebrate.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees reshaping of industries driving M&A
summary: Goldman Sachs' global M&A co-head Michael Carr says industries in flux, such as semiconductors and food, will drive M&A activity. Despite rising interest rates and regulatory uncertainty, Carr notes that companies are fueling dealmaking with new technologies and demographic shifts. US merger and acquisition volumes reached $389 billion this year, driven by mega deals like Cigna's $52 billion acquisition of Express Scripts. Carr expects M&A to continue due to companies having more cash to invest, citing the US corporate tax rate cut to 21%.

site_title: Mr Tan Goes To Washington: How the Broadcom-Qualcomm deal unravelled
summary: Broadcom CEO Tan Hock Eng's $117 billion takeover of Qualcomm was rejected by US President Donald Trump due to national security concerns, despite Broadcom's assurances that the deal would not pose a threat. Trump's decision was driven by concerns about China's telecommunications giant Huawei Technologies Co. and the potential risks of Broadcom's Singaporean roots. Despite Broadcom's efforts to reassure officials, including a meeting at the Pentagon, Trump issued an order stating that there was credible evidence that Broadcom might take action that would impair US national security. The deal's collapse has significant implications for the semiconductor industry and the global tech landscape.

site_title: Gold slips as dollar gains on US jobs data, political tensions underpin
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.5% to $1,317.52 per ounce as the US dollar strengthened following job data and amid escalating tensions between Britain and Russia. The dollar's rise made dollar-priced gold less attractive to investors, while a stronger dollar also limited gold's potential gains. Market participants await the Federal Reserve meeting, citing concerns over interest rate hikes.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Friday due to investor concerns over a potential global trade war. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.43% to 31,404.71, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: Mayweather ready to start MMA training soon
summary: Floyd Mayweather, the former welterweight boxing champion, is reportedly set to start MMA training in preparation for a potential fight. Mayweather, 41, has been in talks with former UFC champion Tyron Woodley, and plans to start working out soon. He believes he needs 6-8 months to get ready and has expressed confidence in his wrestling and hand game. Mayweather's last fight was a one-off boxing bout against Conor McGregor in 2017, and he has claimed to have made $300 million from the event.

site_title: Bali shuts down Internet, flights for Nyepi Day of Silence
summary: Bali, Indonesia, will observe Nyepi Day of Silence, a Hindu festival, by shutting down internet and flights for 24 hours starting March 16, 2018. Residents will stop daily activities, remain indoors, and engage in meditation, fasting, and introspection. Non-Hindus, including tourists, are asked to stay in their homes or hotels, with public services remaining open. The festival includes beachside ceremonies, effigy burning, and water-pouring ceremonies, and affects approximately 480 flights, including 240 international ones.

site_title: Disney's strategy chief given task of saving TV
summary: Disney's strategy chief, Kevin Mayer, has been tasked with leading the company's shift from traditional TV to on-demand viewing. Mayer, 55, will oversee businesses including the Hulu streaming service and international TV networks, while also executing Disney's investment in the company's investment in the streaming service. The move aims to determine the future of the company's consumer brand. Mayer's role has been expanded to also include responsibility for ABC, ESPN, and other channels, alongside parks chief Bob Chapek, who is also rising in the company's ranks.

site_title: Nutryfarm International unit to acquire stake in First Linkage
summary: Nutryfarm International acquired a 45% stake in First Linkage for 90 million yuan (S$18.7 million). The deal prompted a 35% surge in First Linkage's share price, leading the Singapore Exchange to query the company about the sudden price jump. The stock price rally came as Nutryfarm was finalizing the terms of the deal.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Cathay Pacific shares rise on airfare outlook
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a smaller-than-expected annual loss of HK$1.26 billion due to a rebound in the cargo market and lower fuel hedging losses. The airline expects airfares to recover further this year, with passenger yields expected to continue their momentum. Cathay plans to add 4.2-4.3% capacity in its passenger business and 5% capacity in its cargo business in 2018. The airline aims to boost profitability through a three-year turnaround programme targeting HK$4 billion in savings, with CEO Rupert Hogg stating there is still "a lot of work to be done".

site_title: With Qualcomm behind it, Broadcom looks to smaller deals
summary: Broadcom, following its failed hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm, is likely to pursue smaller acquisitions of chipmakers. The company's smart phone chip business is expected to see a drop in demand from a North American customer, believed to be Apple, and an increase from a Korean customer, Samsung Electronics. Despite a failed bid, Broadcom plans to redomicile to the US, fueling expectations for future acquisitions. Analysts believe the company will scout for smaller targets, potentially driving earnings growth and stock movement.

site_title: US hits Russia with sanctions for election meddling
summary: The US imposed sanctions on Russia's top spy agencies and 19 individuals for interfering in the 2016 US presidential election and cyberattacks. The sanctions target entities and individuals involved in the election meddling, Petya cyberattack, and attempts to hack the US energy grid. The move comes despite President Trump's denial of Russia's involvement, and is seen as a response to the ongoing Russia probe led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. The sanctions are part of a broader effort to counter Russia's "malign" cyber activity, with more sanctions expected to follow.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's administration levied sanctions against Russia's top spy agencies and more than a dozen individuals Thursday for trying to influence the 2016 US presidential election and two separate cyberattacks.

site_title: Decade Of Darkness
summary: Experimental musician Dylan Tan and Norwegian composer Lasse Marhaug reunited to record a collaborative album, "In Praise of Shadows", 10 years after their initial, unfinished session in 2006. The album features contrasting drone-like and angular electronic material, released on limited edition vinyl or digitally. The duo's reunion marks a return to their dark and haunting sound, captured in the album's cover photo shot by Philipp Aldrup. "In Praise of Shadows" is now available for purchase.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Toys 'R' Us to wind up all its stores in US
summary: Toys 'R' Us to close all its US stores, affecting approximately 33,000 jobs, following bankruptcy and debt issues. The iconic toy retailer cited poor leadership and increased competition from online retailers like Amazon as key factors in its demise. The company is exploring strategies to keep the brand alive, including the sale of US stores, and pursuing a "going concern" reorganisation and sale process for its Canadian and international operations.

site_title: Nippon Steel to buy Sweden's Ovako
summary: Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp announced it will buy Sweden's Ovako, a specialty steel manufacturer, for undisclosed terms. The deal will give Japan's largest steelmaker a European manufacturing base and add 780,000 tonnes of annual output. The purchase is Nippon Steel's second international foray this month, following a bid for Essar Steel India Ltd. The move aims to strengthen Nippon Steel's global business and expand its technology capabilities in the European market.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as trade worries weigh on sentiment
summary: US stocks ended the day mixed, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.5% to 24,873.66, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index lost 0.1% each. Worries over President Trump's trade policy and potential punitive measures against Beijing outweighed positive economic data, including a drop in jobless claims and a gain in manufacturing activity. The Trump Organization was also subpoenaed by Special Counsel Robert Mueller, and Alibaba jumped 3.5% on plans for a China stock listing.

site_title: EU ready to hit big US tech firms with 3% turnover tax
summary: The European Union is proposing a 3% tax on the turnover of large tech firms, including Google and Facebook, with annual worldwide revenues above $1.21 billion. The tax, expected to be adopted next week, would apply to companies with annual "taxable" revenues above $50 million in the EU. The tax would target digital advertising, online platforms, and digital marketplaces, and would be levied by the countries where the digital users are located. The EU aims to address concerns over cross-border tax policies and ensure that large tech firms pay their fair share of taxes.

images.alt_text: Large companies with significant digital revenues in the European Union such as Google and Facebook could face a 3 per cent tax on their turnover under a draft proposal by the European Commission seen by Reuters.

site_title: VP Bank to upgrade Singapore subsidiary to full branch
summary: VP Bank will upgrade its Singapore subsidiary to a full branch, targeting a July implementation, to capture Asia's growing credit demand. The bank will also upgrade its merchant bank licence to a wholesale banking one for increased freedom and capacity. This move is part of VP Bank's 10th anniversary celebrations in Singapore. The new structure aims to provide more flexibility and support for the bank's growing Asian business.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: S Korea's fuel oil imports soar as coal, nuclear plants shut
summary: South Korea's coal-fired power plants have been shut down temporarily to reduce air pollution, leading to a surge in fuel oil imports to meet power demand. The country's fuel oil imports have jumped to 200,000 tonnes in March, up from 92,000 tonnes in February, with first-quarter imports expected to be 417,000 tonnes, a 28% increase from last year. Burning fuel oil for power results in lower carbon dioxide emissions but releases more toxic particles into the air. The increased fuel oil demand is partly due to reduced nuclear power due to planned maintenance.

site_title: Light art lights up Marina Bay
summary: The i Light Marina Bay festival has returned to Singapore with 22 light art installations from 14 countries, including a heart sculpture, a mailboX, and a chandelier made from upcycled coffee bottles. The festival, which runs until April 1, also features a pop-up bar, an inflatable park, and live music. Artist Franck Pelletier's heart sculpture aims to spread joy and love, while the mailboX encourages social interaction. The event promotes sustainability, using recycled and low-energy materials, and is free to attend.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Manhattan landlords race to fill apartments in declining market
summary: Manhattan landlords are aggressively filling vacant apartments in a declining market, with units finding tenants in just 34 days on average. Rents dropped 2.8% from a year earlier to $3,168 after owners cut prices by 2.4% and offered concessions such as free Wi-Fi, cable, and reduced security deposits. Landlords are getting creative with incentives, including rent-free months, pet-friendly policies, and moving cost assistance. The trend is expected to continue, with 5,630 new apartments listed for rent in Manhattan this year.

site_title: George Lucas breaks ground on US$1 billion story-telling museum
summary: George Lucas broke ground on his $1 billion storytelling museum in Los Angeles, a non-profit enterprise that will showcase art from various mediums, including Star Wars. The museum will feature Lucas' personal art collection, including items from films like Casablanca and The Wizard of Oz. The self-funded project is expected to take four years to complete and will include dining space, theaters, and a public research library. Lucas aims to promote diverse art forms and provide a platform for underrepresented art.

site_title: Britain enters final Brexit talks with listless economy, high debt
summary: The UK enters the final Brexit negotiations with a sluggish economy and high debt, totaling £1.84 trillion or 85.6% of GDP. Chancellor Philip Hammond's spring economic statement raised the 2018 growth forecast to 1.5%, but public sector net borrowing remains at 2.2% of GDP. Despite this, Hammond aims to ease austerity and increase spending on the National Health Service and education. The UK's debt burden and interest payments pose a significant concern, with the cost of debt interest payments exceeding £50 billion annually.

site_title: Millions join Prime for Amazon TV shows
summary: Amazon's Prime video service drew over 5 million viewers worldwide for its top TV shows by early 2017, according to company documents. The shows, known as Prime Originals, accounted for a quarter of estimated Prime sign-ups from 2014 to 2017. The company credits specific shows for luring new Prime members, with an average cost per subscriber of $63. Analysts estimate 75 million or more customers have Prime subscriptions worldwide, with 26 million US Prime members watching TV and movies on Amazon as of early 2017.

site_title: Myanmar needs urgent reforms as economy's in the woods
summary: Myanmar's economy is in crisis due to delayed corporate reforms, plunging business confidence, and unclear economic policy. The Aung San Suu Kyi-led government has postponed allowing foreign companies to purchase stakes of up to 35% in local companies, further exacerbating the economic woes. The country's insurgency-affected areas have instead seen the emergence of "ceasefire capitalism," where local governments and businesses collaborate in an atmosphere of impunity. The government's failure to address these issues has led to growing resentment among minority populations and international concerns about new sanctions.

site_title: Education needed to make 'foreign Reits' more welcome in the local market
summary: Singapore's Reit market is expected to welcome more foreign-asset S-Reits as they have performed better than local counterparts this year. Foreign-asset S-Reits, such as IReit Global and Manulife US Reit, have generated positive returns, while local Reits have struggled. The Singapore Exchange is attracting more foreign-asset S-Reits to list, with Sasseur Reit, offering Chinese outlet mall exposure, set to list soon. However, investors, including Singapore-based funds, have been hesitant to invest in foreign-asset S-Reits due to lack of understanding of foreign property markets. Education and increased coverage are needed to address this issue.

site_title: CDL to launch new Tampines condominium
summary: CDL is launching The Tapestry, a new condominium project in Tampines with 861 units, starting from S$596,000 for a one-bedder. The project, which has over 50 facilities and smart technologies, is the first premium suburban condominium launch this year. It marks a significant addition to the Tampines area, offering a range of living options for homebuyers.

site_title: As US mortgage rates rise, refinancing falls to two-month low
summary: US mortgage rates reached a four-year high, increasing to 4.69% for 30-year conforming mortgages, leading to a two-month low in refinancing activity. Refinancing applications fell 2.2% to 1,159.3, the lowest level since December. However, home buyer applications increased 3.4% to 246.5, a five-week high, driven by rising home values. Experts expect a tough refinance year, but a strong purchase market, with interest rates expected to remain high amid inflation concerns.

site_title: More luxe brands going for big time in resale
summary: Vacheron Constantin, the oldest Swiss luxury watch brand, is expanding its presence in the vintage watch market. The company, which produces around 22,000 timepieces yearly, has been discreetly selling vintage Vacheron Constantin watches since 2005. This move comes as other luxury brands, including Audemars Piguet, Breitling, and Hublot, also plan to enter the resale market. The pre-owned watch market is estimated to be worth $5 billion annually and is growing rapidly, with sales of used watches increasing by 40% annually in the past five years. The entry of big brands is seen as a potential boost to the credibility of the resale business and could expand the customer base.

site_title: CNY lull, absence of launches cause 28% drop in Feb new home sales
summary: Singapore's private home sales dropped 28% in February, with 377 units sold, compared to 524 in January, due to a lull in new launches during the Chinese New Year. However, some developers are raising prices at their previously launched projects, and interest from buyers remains strong, with 98.4% of sales coming from existing projects. Experts predict a recovery in the market, with median prices expected to rise 5% in 2018 and developer sales to increase 19% year-on-year.

site_title: S&P raises Yanlord Land's rating from 'BB-' to 'BB' on better financial position
summary: S&P Global Ratings has raised Yanlord Land Group's long-term corporate credit rating from 'BB-' to 'BB' due to improved financial position and profitability. The rating upgrade reflects the company's ability to sustain its strong financial position over the next two to three years, driven by high profitability and good financial discipline. However, the rating could be downgraded if the debt-to-EBITDA ratio weakens to above four times on a sustained basis.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: The US's creeping protectionism may curb appetite for dealmaking
summary: US President Donald Trump blocked Broadcom's $117 billion bid for Qualcomm on national security grounds, citing a risk to the US' lead in creating technology and setting standards for mobile communications. This move may curb appetite for cross-border dealmaking, affecting market sentiments and corporate investment. Rising protectionism and economic nationalism pose risks to global trade and cross-border economic integration, with other countries also becoming more resistant to perceived foreign takeovers. This trend could hurt US and global growth prospects, with cross-border M&As already having a high failure rate of around 50%.

site_title: Myanmar In Pictures
summary: Myanmar photographer Minzayar Oo's month-long exhibition "State of Flux" at Objectifs showcases his decade-long documentation of the country's changes, including its transition, Rohingya people's fate, and jade mining industry. The exhibition runs till April 15 and is accompanied by artist talks and a seminar. Oo's photographs have appeared in prominent publications such as Time and National Geographic.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Catnip For Cat Lovers
summary: Nobuaki Takekawa's new showcase, Cat Olympics: In Memory of Torajiro, is now open at Ota Fine Arts in Gillman Barracks, Singapore, until April 14. The exhibit features hundreds of ceramic cats participating in sporting activities, cat drawings, and cat-shaped protest signs, all created in memory of Takekawa's late cat Torajiro, who died a year ago. The quirky show is a tribute to the artist's beloved pet and cat lovers can enjoy the creative expressions.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Noble's improved terms for shareholders leave Goldilocks unimpressed
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate, has released a revised restructuring plan that includes improved terms for shareholders, but a major shareholder, Goldilocks Investment Company, has expressed dissatisfaction, calling the move "nothing more than window-dressing" and a show of arrogance. The revised terms offer existing shareholders the option to acquire a further 10% stake from senior creditors and a performance incentive share option to subscribe for another 5% in additional equity. Goldilocks warned that it will escalate the matter and expects the clause allowing Noble to sell assets to a new company without shareholder consent to be thrown out in court.

images.alt_text: Noble said on Wednesday it has signed a restructuring support agreement with an expanded group of creditors, after tweaking the terms for its management and perpetual bondholders.

site_title: Pro-Trump TV pundit is president's new top economic adviser
summary: President Donald Trump has appointed conservative TV pundit Larry Kudlow as his new top economic adviser, replacing Gary Cohn. Kudlow, a 70-year-old former chief economist for Bear Stearns, had initially opposed blanket tariffs on steel and aluminum imports but now supports a "coalition" approach to confront China. Kudlow's appointment marks a departure from the scholarly types normally chosen for the role, and he will lead the National Economic Council, a policy body created in 1993.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group's film "BE With You" opened at No 1 at the South Korean box office, selling 112,301 tickets and grossing US$805,500 on its opening day. The film has been sold to 17 countries worldwide. Oxley Holdings requested a trading halt for a proposed share placement to fund project development and working capital. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering secured a joint venture with Ssangyong and Daewoo to build Singapore's first "smart" hospital, the Woodlands Health Campus, worth S$970 million.

site_title: A tale of blood, fraud and money traces Theranos CEO's fall from grace
summary: Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes' startup, valued at $9 billion, has been accused of a "breathtaking scale of deception" by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). Holmes and former president Ramesh "Sunny" Balwani allegedly misled investors with false product demonstrations, exaggerated claims about the technology's deployment, and incorrect financial statements. As part of a settlement, Holmes agreed to a $500,000 fine, a 10-year ban on serving as a company officer, and relinquished majority voting control. Balwani will face the SEC in court.

images.alt_text: The SEC has accused Ms Holmes of an elaborate, years-long fraud that included misleading product demonstrations.

site_title: Watch this space in BT Weekend
summary: The article discusses the impact of smartwatches, particularly the Apple Watch, on the traditional Swiss mechanical watch industry. Despite initial fears, some in the industry view the Apple Watch as a boon for fine watchmaking, as it highlights the importance of craftsmanship and style. Meanwhile, the sharing economy, exemplified by companies like AirBnB and Uber, is reevaluated in the context of blockchain technology, challenging its true concept of sharing. The article concludes that traditional watches, like Rolex, may see a resurgence in sales, potentially overtaking total Swiss watch shipments.

site_title: Vitol targets South Asia's LNG boom with import projects in Pakistan, Bangladesh
summary: Vitol, a Swiss trade house, is developing import projects in Pakistan and Bangladesh to tap into the region's booming liquefied natural gas (LNG) market. The company is partnering with Total on a floating LNG import facility in Karachi and going it alone in Bangladesh to develop a small-scale FSRU. Other rival trading houses, Trafigura and Gunvor, are also developing LNG projects in the region, betting on the countries' growing demand for gas. The projects are expected to expand the region's LNG trade five-fold by 2022.

site_title: Ho Ren Yung
summary: Banyan Tree Spa & Gallery has relaunched its body and aromatherapy products with a focus on sustainability and natural ingredients, using 99% natural ingredients and eco-friendly packaging made from recycled plastic. The redesign aims to meet the growing demand for wellness products and align with the brand's values of purpose and integrity. Assistant Vice-President Ho Ren Yung, daughter of Banyan Tree founders, led the reformulation process, driven by a desire to improve the products and better inject wellness into consumers' lives.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Chip Eng Seng exits Tower Melbourne project with A$55m sale
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation has exited its Australian redevelopment project Tower Melbourne after finding a buyer willing to pay A$55 million (S$56 million) for the site. The company had previously cancelled 556 sales contracts and returned deposits due to protracted legal proceedings. The sale allows Chip Eng Seng to unlock value from the property and fund its operations. The group considers the sale a clean exit from the project, which was originally planned for redevelopment into a 71-storey tower with 581 residential units.

site_title: US hits Russians with sanctions over election meddling, cyber attacks
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on 19 Russian individuals and five groups, including Moscow's intelligence services, for meddling in the 2016 US election and malicious cyber attacks. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin stated that additional sanctions against Russian government officials and oligarchs are planned, severing their access to the US financial system. The sanctions follow US intelligence agencies' conclusion that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential campaign and US Special Counsel Robert Mueller's charges against 13 Russian individuals and three companies for participating in a conspiracy to tamper in the election.

site_title: Lufthansa foresees fierce competition in 2018
summary: Lufthansa expects intense competition in 2018 as foreign carriers target the German market, following the collapse of Air Berlin last year. The airline's operating profit is forecast to slide 70% from 2017, snapping a three-year record annual earnings streak. Lufthansa will trim capacity plans due to increased competition from low-cost carriers like EasyJet and Ryanair. The company's cautious approach is attributed to "significant fluctuations" in business, with fuel costs expected to rise by 700 million euros.

site_title: Dollar falls against yen on global trade tensions
