The study argues that interest rates dropped only about one percentage point on 10-year US Treasury securities, contrary to previous estimates. If this conclusion stands, it would alter the narrative of the economic recovery and imply that the Fed's policy was less effective than previously thought, potentially limiting its ability to stimulate the economy in future recessions.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: NetLink NBN Trust (NLT NBN) is expected to weather economic cycles due to its defensive income streams and dominant position as Singapore's sole residential fibre network provider. Analysts value the trust based on a dividend discount model, citing a stable earnings outlook. In contrast, Maybank Kim Eng Research maintains a negative view on the sector, citing potential tariff wars and competition from TPG's acquisition of spectrum rights, which could lead to 2-4% declines in wireless revenue for incumbents.

site_title: Adidas Q4 revenue up 12% on China, US sales and retro trend
summary: Adidas reported a 12% increase in Q4 revenue, driven by strong sales in China and North America, as well as a retro trend in sneakers. The company expects a 10% growth rate for the year, with revenue growth decelerating in western Europe and the Middle East. Adidas is benefiting from the popularity of its retro sneakers, which have helped steal market share from competitors. The company also announced plans to buy back its own shares and increase its target for the operating margin to 11.5% by 2020.

site_title: Britain to expel 23 Russian diplomats over attempted murder of ex-spy
summary: Britain has expelled 23 Russian diplomats in retaliation for the nerve agent attack on former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter, who were found critically ill in Salisbury. Prime Minister Theresa May said the expulsion will degrade Russian intelligence capabilities in Britain and freeze Russian state assets. The move follows Russia's refusal to acknowledge its involvement and comes after US President Donald Trump expressed support for May's stance. The crisis has raised pressure on policymakers, particularly ahead of Russian elections, and has strained relations between Moscow and London.

site_title: Noble creditors sign debt restructuring deal
summary: Noble Group has signed a debt restructuring support agreement with an expanded group of creditors, increasing support from 46% to 75% of its senior debt. The agreement includes improved terms for management and perpetual bondholders, such as the ability to exchange securities for new bonds with a lower face value. Shares rose 8% after the announcement, while bonds due in 2022 increased 5.24%. Analysts say the revised terms are a step towards providing a sustainable capital structure, but perpetual bondholders may not be better off than initially proposed.

site_title: Hedge funds drawing SEC scrutiny in crypto crackdown
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is scrutinizing hedge funds that invest in cryptocurrencies and initial coin offerings (ICOs), raising concerns about investors' awareness of risks and potential law-breaking. The SEC has sent requests to funds asking about pricing methods and compliance with rules, with some receiving subpoenas from the Enforcement Division. The agency is worried that investors are pouring billions into crypto assets without adequate assessment of risks and that some profiting from the market may be breaking the law.

site_title: PM Lee in Sydney for Asean-Australia meetings
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is on an official visit to Australia from Thursday to Sunday, attending the third Singapore-Australia Leaders' Summit and the Asean-Australia Special Summit. The leaders will discuss regional security, science, and trade, including the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership. Lee will also meet with Australian officials and attend various conferences, including a counter-terrorism conference and a Small and Medium Enterprise Conference. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties and cooperation on regional issues.

site_title: Scores of activities for The Fullerton Building's 90th anniversary
summary: The Fullerton Hotel is celebrating its 90th anniversary with a three-day "Fullerton Concours d'Elegance" event from June 29 to July 1, featuring over 90 vintage and classic cars, as well as supercars, luxury yacht displays, and charity convoys. The event will also include gala dinners, art and cultural exhibitions. Proceeds from a silent auction will be donated to the President's Challenge, a charity initiative. The event aims to pay tribute to the building's heritage and celebrate its continued relevance in bringing the community together.

site_title: The worst seems to be over for Cathay Pacific
summary: Cathay Pacific has posted a smaller-than-expected annual loss of HK$1.26 billion, its biggest in nine years, due to a rebound in the cargo market and moderating ticket price falls. The airline's efforts to turn around, including a three-year turnaround program targeting HK$4 billion in savings, appear to be bearing fruit. Analysts say the worst is over for Cathay Pacific, predicting a small net profit of HK$377 million for 2018, with 2019 expected to be a better year.

site_title: Presidential race shaping up to be a rematch between Jokowi and Prabowo
summary: The 2019 Indonesian presidential election is shaping up to be a rematch between incumbent Joko Widodo and former special forces general Prabowo Subianto. Jakarta governor Anies Baswedan has ruled out a presidential run, suggesting the race is between Jokowi and Prabowo. Polls indicate Jokowi has a significant lead, with double the support of Prabowo. Prabowo's official backing is limited to his own party and a few parliamentary coalitions, and his decision to wait may create an opportunity for a third candidate, such as ultra-nationalist Gatot Nurmantyo.

site_title: Retail sales dip for third straight month in Feb
summary: US retail sales declined 0.1% in February for the third consecutive month, with motor vehicle and big-ticket item purchases being the main drivers of the decline. Consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of US economic activity, appears to have slowed at the start of the year, but a strong labour market and a $1.5 trillion income tax cut package are expected to support spending. GDP growth estimates for the first quarter are around a 2% annualized rate, slightly lower than initially expected.

site_title: Google to ban cryptocurrency, initial coin offering ads
summary: Google to ban online advertisements promoting cryptocurrencies and initial coin offerings starting in June, as part of a broader crackdown on high-risk financial products. The move follows Facebook's similar ban in January, and will block ads for cryptocurrencies and financial products like binary options. The decision aims to reduce malicious and deceptive ads, with Google removing over 3.2 billion ads from its network in 2017. The ban is unlikely to have a significant impact on ad revenue, which reached $95.4 billion last year.

site_title: BOC Aviation posts record profit of US$587m for 2017
summary: BOC Aviation Ltd, Asia's second-largest aircraft lessor, reported a record net profit of US$587 million for 2017, a 40% increase from the previous year, driven by higher lease revenue and US tax cuts. The company's fleet grew to 318 aircraft, with 74 jets delivered in 2017, and its net lease yield remained steady at 8.4%. The result surpassed analysts' average estimate of US$519.5 million.

site_title: It's a culinary party at New York's casual Indian restaurants
summary: New York's casual Indian restaurants, inspired by Babu Ji, are gaining popularity. These "Baby Ji" restaurants, such as Rahi, Badshah, Old Monk, and aRoqa, offer a modern take on traditional Indian cuisine at affordable prices. They focus on creating a casual, party-like atmosphere with unique decor and creative menu items. While not exact replicas of Babu Ji, they share a similar style of dining that resonates with current sensibilities. These restaurants are a refreshing alternative to traditional, formal Indian dining establishments, filling the middle ground in the city's culinary scene.

site_title: Greek students' electric car catches Tesla's attention
summary: Greek students' electric car, Pyrforos, has caught Tesla's attention, leading the US carmaker to invest in Greece with a $1.2 billion research and development facility. The vehicle, designed and built by engineering students at the National Technical University of Athens, has won awards at the Shell Eco-Marathon championship. The investment is seen as a step towards Greece's recovery from a decade of financial crisis, with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras welcoming the move. The facility is expected to hire 40 engineers, mostly from the diaspora, and could help put Greece on the map of global innovation.

site_title: Dollar eyes one-month lows as fears of trade war grow
summary: The US dollar fell to near one-week lows as concerns over a potential trade war with China grew. The US is seeking to impose tariffs of up to $60 billion on Chinese imports, sparking fears of an escalation. This news hit the dollar, which had recovered from February lows and reached a six-week high earlier this month. The dollar's decline was partly due to growing expectations of multiple interest rate increases this year.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ipco International's interim CEO Goh Hin Calm voluntarily resigned after facing charges related to the 2013 penny stock crash. The move comes as James Blythman, a new Ipco shareholder, replaced Carlson Smith as CFO. Meanwhile, confectioner Khong Guan saw a net profit of S$792,000 for the six months to Jan 31, and Vibrant Group reported a profit of S$2.3 million for the three months to Jan 31, despite a significant decline in net profit attributable to owners.

site_title: Japan would lose voice of prudence if scandal brings down Aso
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso faces a scandal that could lead to his resignation, potentially crippling Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government's fiscal prudence. Aso has been a key voice against radical spending, and his departure could embolden advocates of more aggressive fiscal and monetary policies. The scandal involves altered records of a discounted sale of state-owned land, and opposition lawmakers are calling for Aso's head. Aso's survival is uncertain, and his departure could impact Japan's public debt, which is the largest among major industrialized nations, and the Bank of Japan's exit strategy from its monetary stimulus.

site_title: Life insurance body acts on hiring perks
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore has introduced measures to address recruitment incentives for financial advisers. The guidelines, co-created with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), include setting sales targets at a reasonable level, spreading out payment of sign-on incentives, and closer monitoring of representatives. The measures aim to prevent the movement of 30 or more representatives from the same firm within a 60-day period, a practice seen in the mass recruitment of agents from Great Eastern to AIA Financial Advisers last year. The guidelines apply to LIA members and related financial advisory firms.

site_title: Robot rides are going to deliver pizza and parcels before they transport people
summary: Companies are shifting focus from self-driving cars to autonomous delivery of pizzas and parcels, as the latter is seen as a more lucrative venture. Several major companies, including Amazon and BHP, are investing heavily in AI-focused innovation hubs to drive this shift. Autonomous delivery technology is expected to become more prevalent in the near future, potentially displacing human drivers in the delivery industry.

site_title: Iran Air to allow women pilots for the first time
summary: Iran Air, the national airline of Iran, has announced that it will allow women to work as pilots for the first time. The decision was made by CEO Farzaneh Sharafbafi, who is also the first woman to hold the position. Women have been permitted to fly planes in Iran, but never worked for the airline. The first women pilots will start as co-pilots, marking a significant step for social development and equality in the country.

site_title: OCBC sets up in-house AI unit with initial investment of S$10m over 3 years
summary: OCBC Bank has established an in-house AI unit, AI Lab@TOV, with an initial investment of S$10 million over three years. The lab aims to drive AI adoption in banking services, particularly in wealth advisory and loans financing. Led by Ken Wong, the team of data scientists plans to double its headcount within a year. OCBC has already employed AI in its operations, with success in reducing transaction review volume by 35% and increasing suspicious transaction accuracy by four times. The move is seen as a competitive advantage for the bank.

site_title: Furla buys Singapore operations from franchisee
summary: Italian luxury bag brand Furla has bought its Singapore operations from a franchisee for an undisclosed sum after 15 years of cooperation. The company now directly operates five stores in Singapore, including a flagship in Marina Bay Sands, and plans to ramp up its presence in the city-state. Furla's sales in the Asia-Pacific region surged 50% last year, driven by the expansion of its distribution network with stronger, direct oversight. The company sees Asia as a key growth region and plans to invest more in Singapore.

site_title: China's steel production up despite govt's winter curbs
summary: China's steel production increased in January and February, defying government efforts to curb output due to a growing surplus and slowing demand. Despite this, steel prices fell in Shanghai, with rebar futures hitting their lowest in almost four months. The strong output data was driven by mills seeking to capitalize on high prices. The decline in steel prices extended a losing streak for rebar futures, which had been declining since last summer.

site_title: The future of women in Asean: Three priorities for govts
summary: ASEAN countries need to prioritize policies to support women's economic participation, with a focus on maternity and childcare benefits, targeted training, and increased participation in STEM fields. Governments can mandate minimum support for women at work, provide subsidies for childcare and training, and promote STEM education. The region's human capital, particularly women, is key to its growth and resilience, and addressing the disparities in these areas is crucial to achieving gender parity and remaining a global growth hotspot.

site_title: Minbu Villa up for collective sale with S$145.8m reserve price
summary: Minbu Villa, a 10-storey freehold development in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale at a reserve price of S$145.8 million. The site can be developed up to 36 storeys with an allowable gross floor area of 107,593 sq ft. Strategically located near Novena Health City and the Balestier/Novena neighbourhoods, the site offers a unique value proposition. The tender will close on April 17, 2018.

site_title: Banks commit to reskill, redeploy staff amid tech changes
summary: Singapore's banks have committed to reskilling and redeploying staff amid technological changes, with 160 member banks under the Association of Banks in Singapore to adhere to new HR practices. The banks must assess the impact of technology on their workforce and conduct retrenchment exercises "responsibly." The aim is to build a "strong Singapore core" of talent in the financial sector, with the government aiming to create 3,000 net jobs every year in financial services and 1,000 in the fintech sector.

site_title: CrimsonLogic brings out the fun in coding
summary: CrimsonLogic, a Singapore-based IT company, has launched a CSR outreach program to educate and empower children through coding. The company works with local communities, children's homes, and non-profit organizations to design and run digital government systems, and also aims to strengthen Singapore's pool of IT professionals. Over five years, the program has seen a significant increase in employee volunteer participation, from less than 1% to 1/3 of the workforce, and has been deemed successful in making coding a viable career option for children.

site_title: Asian healthcare hits investment sweet spot, but beware heady valuations
summary: Asian healthcare investments are thriving due to strong growth fundamentals and favorable regulatory environments. Private equity firms have made over 400 investments in the last five years, with an average internal rate of return of 17.5% in emerging market healthcare firms. However, investors should be cautious of inflated valuations, particularly in the hospital-centric model, and look for value in specialist provision outside of hospitals, such as ambulatory centers and specialist inpatient facilities.

site_title: South Africa rebukes Australian minister for white farmer comments
summary: South Africa rebuked Australian Minister Peter Dutton for suggesting white farmers needed help due to "horrific circumstances" in the country. Dutton made the comments during a documentary about violent rural crime, stating farmers deserved "special attention" from a "civilised country." The South African government denied the threat of expropriation of land, saying it was a democratic process. The rebuke came after Afriforum, a rights group, described being a white farmer as one of the most dangerous jobs in the country, with a higher murder rate than police officers.

site_title: Tokyo Gas wins destination flexibility from new Malaysia LNG purchase
summary: Tokyo Gas has signed a 13-year long-term liquefied natural gas (LNG) deal with Petronas, a Malaysian state oil firm, with flexible destination clauses. The deal, which will be Tokyo Gas's first long-term deal since Japan's anti-trust body ruled against restrictive destination clauses, highlights the shift in the LNG market. The deal's shorter duration and smaller volumes also reflect the growing supply and depressed prices, with buyers gaining the upper hand. Tokyo Gas will buy Malaysian LNG for up to 500,000 tonnes per year in the first six years and up to 900,000 tonnes per year in the remaining years.

site_title: Crocs shoes lose EU patent in court setback
summary: The EU's General Court ruled that Crocs' shoe design cannot be patented in Europe due to its public availability before registration. The design, which has sold 300 million pairs worldwide, was deemed "lacking novelty" by the EU patent office in 2016. The court upheld the decision, confirming the cancellation of the patent. This ruling prevents Crocs from seeking protection for its iconic design in the EU market, potentially impacting its business.

site_title: Ex-GM of Ang Mo Kio Town Council charged with accepting S$107,000 worth of bribes
summary: A former general manager and secretary of Ang Mo Kio Town Council, Wong Chee Meng, 58, was charged with corruption for accepting S$107,000 in bribes from two building firms and their director between 2014 and 2016. He faces 55 counts of corruptly accepting gratification and could be fined up to S$100,000 and jailed for up to seven years if convicted. His co-conspirator, Chia Sin Lan, also faces charges, and their companies could be fined up to S$100,000. The case is set to be heard on April 11.

images.alt_text: A former general manager and secretary of Ang Mo Kio Town Council, who allegedly took bribes from two building firms and their director, was on Wednesday charged with corruption.

site_title: Minbu Villa in Balestier launched for collective sale with S$145.8m reserve price
summary: Minbu Villa, a 10-storey freehold development in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale with a reserve price of S$145.8 million. The site, with a land area of 38,426 sq ft, offers a land rate of S$1,355 per square foot per plot ratio. The tender will close on April 17, 2018, and the site may be developed up to 36 storeys with an allowable gross floor area of 107,593 sq ft. The location is prime, with easy access to Novena Health City and nearby amenities.

site_title: US retail sales decline for third straight month in Feb
summary: US retail sales declined 0.1% in February for the third straight month, indicating a slowdown in economic growth in the first quarter. Consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of US economic activity, appears to have slowed at the start of the year after accelerating in the fourth quarter. Despite a strong labor market and a US$1.5 trillion income tax cut package, economists expect modest economic growth in the first quarter, with gross domestic product growth estimates ranging around a 2% annualized rate.

site_title: Opec acknowledges scale of shale boom as supply outstrips demand
summary: Opec forecasts that new oil supplies from non-Opec producers will exceed demand growth this year, as the US shale industry continues to flourish. Global oil demand will rise 1.6 million barrels a day, but can be covered by an increase of 1.66 million barrels a day in supplies from outside Opec. As a result, Opec's supply cuts may not be as effective in clearing the inventory surplus, requiring the cartel to supply 200,000 barrels a day less than anticipated.

site_title: Tributes pour in as world mourns death of genius Stephen Hawking
summary: Renowned British physicist Stephen Hawking, known for his groundbreaking work on black holes and his inspirational story of overcoming a motor neurone disease, has died at the age of 76. Hawking's family announced his passing on the 139th anniversary of Albert Einstein's birth, with tributes pouring in from scientists, celebrities, and world leaders, praising his genius, wit, and courage. Despite his physical disability, Hawking defied predictions and lived a life of remarkable achievement, leaving behind a legacy that will continue to inspire generations.

site_title: Pearl Bank Apartments: What sort of consent was needed
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) clarified that 100% consent is needed for voluntary conservation of strata-titled developments like Pearl Bank Apartments due to the Building Maintenance & Strata Management Act, which prohibits altering the aggregate share value of lots in a strata scheme. This act requires termination of the strata scheme and reconstitution with equitable share allocation for all subsidiary proprietors (SPs). The URA considers each proposal based on conservation merits, but the act's restrictions necessitate 100% owner consent for such changes. This contrasts with en bloc sales, which require 80% consent.

site_title: Game of Steel: lots of signals, but little substance
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs on steel and aluminium imports are unlikely to change the global supply-demand dynamic for steel. Despite Trump's rhetoric, US steel production has remained flat since the 1980s, and domestic production accounts for 80% of total US steel demand. China is the largest steel producer, and the US is the third-largest. Tariffs will likely have little impact on global prices and may lead to a global supply glut. The US strategy may lead to a trade war, affecting investment sentiment and company performance, with potential losers including manufacturers and investors.

site_title: Facebook expresses concern over Sri Lanka ban
summary: Facebook expressed concern over Sri Lanka's ban on its platform, citing incendiary material shared on the site. The government blocked Facebook in response to online hate speech that fueled violence during anti-Muslim riots, resulting in three deaths. Facebook hopes to lift the island-wide blackout once the tech giant agrees to take quicker action to remove hateful content. The company is responding to Sri Lanka's concerns and seeking to resolve the issue.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.4% lower at 3,539.41, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid heightened US political tension and trade war fears. The index saw 231 losers and 182 gainers, with 1.9 billion shares worth S$1.2 billion traded.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Walmart beefs up grocery delivery as battle with Amazon intensifies
summary: Walmart plans to expand its grocery delivery service to over 100 metro areas this year, reaching 40% of US households by the end of the year. The service, currently in six cities, will be handled by Uber and other providers, with a $9.95 service fee and a $30 minimum purchase. This move aims to boost online sales and compete with Amazon's Prime Now service, which offers free two-hour delivery. Walmart's online business had been a bright spot, but it stumbled during the holiday season, and the company is looking to regain profitability.

site_title: US proposes WTO reforms likely targeting China
summary: The US has proposed World Trade Organization reforms targeting non-compliance by members, including China, with existing rules. The proposed reforms would punish members for violating basic rules, with a focus on China's alleged breaches of WTO agreements. US officials have accused China of implementing measures to prop up domestic industries that breach WTO rules, failing to provide notifications, and rarely facing consequences. The move appears to be part of Washington's "America first" agenda.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.97 points to 1,857.06. Volume reached 2.3 billion lots worth RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 635 to 332.

site_title: MAS to reduce duplication, automate data submission from financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced a roadmap to eliminate duplication in data requests to financial institutions by the end of 2019. Measures include reusing data, automating data submission, and allowing institutions to decline duplicate requests. Financial institutions will also submit data in machine-readable formats starting April 1 and undergo changes to data requirements to reduce reporting burden. The initiative aims to make data submission more efficient and seamless for both MAS and financial institutions.

site_title: Global trade war biggest risk for Singapore, say economists
summary: Singapore's economy is forecasted to grow 3.2% in 2018, up from 3.0% in December, with economists citing a global trade war as the biggest downside risk. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's quarterly survey of professional forecasters noted that 88% of respondents consider trade protectionism the top risk, with manufacturing growth expected to slow. Despite this, economists remain optimistic about the finance and insurance, wholesale and retail trade, and accommodation and food services sectors. The top potential upside is the electronics sector outperforming expectations, with 47% of respondents citing it.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Rising services costs lift US producer prices in Feb
summary: US producer prices increased 0.2% in February, exceeding expectations, driven by a rise in services costs. The year-on-year increase in the producer price index (PPI) rose to 2.8%, up from 2.7% in January. This growth was primarily offset by a decline in the price of goods.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's 2018 economic growth forecast has been raised to 3.2% by private-sector economists for the second consecutive time. Noble Group signed an agreement on its restructuring plan, and Uber launched its first-in-Asia carpooling service, UberCommute. 160 banks in Singapore committed to inclusive hiring and assessing the impact of technology on jobs. PCS opened a US$80m naphtha import facility, and OCBC set up an in-house AI unit. Singapore shares closed 0.4% down at the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Putin win puts relations with West in jeopardy
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is expected to win re-election, solidifying his grip on power for another six years. With a popular domestic image and a strong economy, Putin's main challenge is maintaining high voter turnout. The West has been increasingly critical of Putin, and relations with the US have deteriorated due to ongoing tensions, including US sanctions and disagreements over international issues. A potential fourth term for Putin could see him attempt to change the constitution, groom a successor, or step back and allow free elections, but these scenarios are uncertain and may be hindered by internal power struggles and foreign policy challenges.

site_title: US: Stocks edge higher amid trade war worries
summary: US stocks edged higher in early trading on Wednesday, rising 0.1% to 25,039.68 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained 0.1% to 2,768.65 and 7,516.72, respectively. Despite concerns over rising international trade tensions, investors appear to be shrugging off worries for now, with the market seemingly focused on the current trading session.

site_title: India central bank chief calls for more powers over state lenders in wake of fraud
summary: India's central bank chief, Urjit Patel, called for reforms to give the regulator more powers over state-run banks, citing the $2 billion Punjab National Bank fraud case. Patel criticized the dual regulation system, where the central bank and government regulate state-run banks, saying it led to "tremors" like the recent fraud. Patel also defended the RBI's role and launched a broadside against the government, which has been critical of the regulator and auditors. Patel wants to remove limitations on the RBI's powers, including the ability to remove directors and initiate liquidation.

site_title: AA Group Holdings unit faces S$130k fine for lapse in worker safety
summary: A wholly-owned subsidiary of AA Group Holdings, Engineering Manufacturing Services, has been charged with a S$130,000 fine for failing to ensure worker safety during painting works at a Singapore factory. The company had taken measures to prevent similar incidents in the future. The incident is expected not to impact the financial position of the group. A court hearing is scheduled for May 10.

site_title: APAC Realty in marketing deal with Chinese real estate firm MLN Overseas
summary: APAC Realty, owner of ERA Realty Network in Singapore, has signed a marketing deal with Chinese real estate firm MLN Overseas to help its Chinese clients buy properties in Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia. Under the arrangement, MLN will refer clients to ERA for the buying process and after-sale services. This partnership aims to tap into the growing demand for Singapore properties from Chinese buyers.

site_title: Vibrant Group's Q3 net profit drops by 88.6% to S$146,000 as non-controlling interests take bulk of earnings
summary: Vibrant Group's Q3 net profit dropped 88.6% to S$146,000, mainly due to unrealised foreign exchange loss and higher finance costs. Despite a 3.3-fold increase in revenue to S$177.3 million, most earnings went to non-controlling interests. The company attributed the increase to higher profits from its real estate business. Earnings per share plummeted to 0.02 Singapore cents. The group has a net gearing of 0.94 times and is looking to improve its position.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Ipco International interim CEO Goh Hin Calm resigns
summary: Ipco International interim CEO Goh Hin Calm resigned voluntarily on Wednesday, amid charges related to the 2013 penny stock crash. Goh, out on bail of S$750,000, steps down following James Blythman's placement as a shareholder last year and the replacement of Carlson Smith as CFO. The move comes after Goh and Ipco's former CEO Quah Su-Ling face trial.

site_title: Noble responds to SGX queries on corporate governance report, full-year results
summary: Noble Group has clarified to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) that it did not fully disclose remuneration details of key management personnel due to competitive industry conditions. The company cited the sensitivity and confidentiality of such matters. Noble also explained that it delegated authority to its Remuneration and Options Committee to approve remuneration policies and packages. The company reported a full-year loss of US$4.9 billion for 2017, with revenue falling 26% to US$6.43 billion. Noble attributed some expenses related to the termination of its former CEO, Jeff Frase, to "other emoluments" of US$16.7 million and share-based payments of US$3.5 million.

site_title: Cash and mobile banking can be sound proposition in emerging markets
summary: A McKinsey report suggests that mobile banking can significantly raise profitability in cash-based economies by increasing digital transactions. Despite concerns that a cashless society may marginalize those without banking access, the report notes that the costs of digital transactions can be lowered with automated systems. Companies like Grab are expanding their financial services to the underbanked in emerging markets, using partnerships with local consumer players to build networks quickly. The report highlights growth opportunities in data-based financial services and micropayments, but also notes risks, including the need to monitor the effectiveness of agency networks.

site_title: Khong Guan H1 earnings swell to S$792,000
summary: Khong Guan, a confectioner, reported a net profit of S$792,000 for the six months to Jan 31, up almost eight times from the same period last year. Despite a slight increase in group turnover, earnings were driven by higher foreign exchange gains and unrealised fair-value gains on short-term investments. The company expects to improve operational results in the second half-year.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks snap 4-day rising streak on trade war fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Wednesday, snapping a four-day rising streak, due to fears of a Sino-US trade war. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.5% to 31,435.01, while China's Shanghai Composite index fell 0.57% to 3,310.2389 points. Optimism from China's solid economic data was outweighed by concerns over a potential trade war, which has been a major focus for investors.

site_title: China Kangda Food warns of potential loss for FY 2017
summary: China Kangda Food Company has warned of potential loss for FY 2017 due to a decline in unaudited net profit, mainly attributed to increased mortality rates of chickens caused by bad weather in 2017 and higher administrative costs. The company expects a preliminary review of its unaudited financial information for the year ended Dec 31, 2017, to show a lower-than-expected net profit.

site_title: ECB needs more evidence that inflation is rising: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the bank needs further evidence of rising inflation to adjust monetary policy, despite increasing confidence in inflation convergence towards its target. Draghi emphasized the need for "further evidence" to support policy decisions, maintaining a patient, persistent, and prudent approach.

site_title: Weakened Merkel begins 4th term beset by challenges
summary: German lawmakers re-elected Angela Merkel as chancellor for a fourth term, with 364 votes to 315, amidst a fragile coalition and dwindling personal standing. Merkel faces challenges including a trade standoff with the US, domestic demands from within her coalition, and pressure from abroad, including from France and Britain. Her authority was dented by her 2015 refugee policy and her government's inability to deliver on promises. Merkel's spokesman said she would focus on bilateral and international issues, while the SPD vowed to deliver distinctive policies to regain voter trust.

site_title: 8Telecom narrows FY2017 net loss to S$1.5m on higher revenue from subsidiary
summary: 8Telecom International Holdings narrowed its full-year net loss to S$1.5 million in FY2017, from S$27.3 million in the previous year, driven by higher revenue from subsidiary Arete M. Revenue surged to S$727,000, mainly due to secured projects by Arete M. The group also explored new business opportunities, including investing in a new office and hiring more staff. Total liabilities rose 78% to S$7.04 million, mainly due to loans taken by Arete M. The company remains committed to supporting Arete M's growth, but may consider disposing of the subsidiary if unable to secure new financing.

site_title: Australian shares close lower as banks weigh; NZ ends run of gains
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to close at 5935.3, led by losses in banking stocks amid an official inquiry into the sector. National Australia Bank's shares dropped 1.2% after it was accused of issuing US$19 billion in home loans with falsified documents. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand also fell 0.5%, ending a four-session gain streak, due to losses in healthcare and telecom stocks.

site_title: Europe: Adidas boost and strong miners keep European shares afloat
summary: European shares rose 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by strong results from Adidas and robust mining stocks. Adidas jumped 8.8% after announcing a share buyback and lifting its 2020 profitability target. In contrast, Spain's IBEX fell 0.5% due to disappointing results from Inditex. US President Trump's threat to impose tariffs on Chinese imports weighed on technology stocks, but European miners and healthcare companies helped offset the impact.

site_title: PCS opens US$80m naphtha import facilities on Jurong Island
summary: PCS has officially opened its US$80 million naphtha import facilities on Jurong Island, a project announced in 2016. The facilities include eight storage tanks with 240,000 cubic meters of capacity and a 120,000 deadweight tonnage liquid berth. The new installation will enable PCS to handle larger vessels and reduce drop-offs by naphtha tankers, increasing competitiveness and reliability for the company's customers. The project is expected to enhance Singapore's energy and chemicals industry, and improve its competitiveness.

site_title: More than 20 hectares to be kept aside for orchid nurseries: NParks
summary: National Parks Board (NParks) has allocated over 20 hectares of land for orchid nurseries, with the first tranche set to be released for tender in June. The land parcels, located in Lim Chu Kang and Sungei Tengah, will come with basic infrastructure to support quick start-up of operations. This move aims to preserve Singapore's orchid heritage, marking the first time land has been allocated specifically for orchid nurseries.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: LIA adopts guidelines on recruitment incentives for financial advisers in Singapore
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) Singapore has adopted guidelines for recruitment incentives of financial advisers in Singapore. The guidelines include setting sales targets at a reasonable level, spreading out payment of sign-on incentives over six years, and monitoring representatives for at least two years. The measures aim to prevent adverse effects on customers during industry movements. The guidelines were co-created with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and follow a mass recruitment of 300 financial advisers from Great Eastern to AIA last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks snap four-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.87% on Wednesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid concerns over a potential trade war between the US and China. US President Donald Trump replaced his top diplomat, Rex Tillerson, and is reportedly planning new tariffs on China. Investors locked in profits, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 190.81 points to 21,777.29. Analysts fear a harsher trade stance under Mike Pompeo, leading to increased risk aversion and caution among equity investors.

site_title: Prudential's full-year earnings up on stronger Asia growth; to spin off M&G Prudential
summary: British insurer Prudential reported a 6% rise in IFRS operating profit to £4.7 billion for the full-year 2017, driven by double-digit growth in its Asia business. The company's Asia new business profit increased 12% and IFRS operating profit from the Asia business grew 15%. Prudential also announced plans to demerge its UK & Europe business, M&G Prudential, into two separately-listed companies, with Prudential retaining its UK headquarters and a premium listing on the London Stock Exchange.

site_title: China's regulators compete to look tough as political pressure mounts
summary: China's financial regulators are increasing enforcement activities amid pressure to curb financial risk, with officials risking trouble for not acting fast enough or being tough enough. The Communist Party is overseeing a major overhaul of the financial regulatory structure, with President Xi Jinping emphasizing national security as a key priority. New regulations have been introduced, but some senior industry sources say they are unnecessarily harsh and may hurt the economy. The anti-corruption drive has led to a focus on regulation over development, with regulators being told to submit work materials unrelated to corruption for review.

site_title: Defence lawyer slams Malaysian police over Kim murder probe
summary: A Malaysian defence lawyer has criticized the police investigation into the murder of North Korean leader Kim Jong-nam, calling it "shoddy" and potentially leading to an unfair trial. Defence lawyer Gooi Soon Seng questioned the investigation's chief officer, alleging that police failed to investigate key evidence and denied access to suspect Siti Aisyah during her detention. The trial of Aisyah and another suspect, Doan Thi Huong, is ongoing, with the defence arguing that the women were tricked into becoming inadvertent assassins in an elaborate plot by North Korean agents.

site_title: APAC Realty inks deal to manage MLN Overseas properties in Singapore, South-east Asia
summary: APAC Realty has signed an agreement with MLN Overseas to manage Chinese clients' properties in Singapore, Thailand, and Malaysia. Under the deal, MLN will refer clients to ERA for entire property purchase processes, while ERA will provide after-sale services in Malaysia and Thailand. The partnership aims to expand ERA's presence in the Chinese market and provide more services to MLN clients.

site_title: Google to ban ads on cryptocurrencies, related products
summary: Google will ban ads for cryptocurrencies and related products starting in June. The company will also remove 3.2 billion ads that violated its policies in 2017. This move follows Facebook's decision to ban similar ads in January. The policy will be implemented across Google's platforms, including Facebook and Instagram. The ban aims to improve the ads experience and prevent harmful or intrusive ads.

site_title: Straits Trading unit takes stake in Japanese residential property with 989m yen investment
summary: Straits Trading Company has taken a stake in a Japanese residential property, investing 989 million yen (S$12.2 million) in a 134-unit rental apartment in Saitama. The deal is part of Straits Trading's strategy to redeploy capital from existing low-yielding properties into higher-return opportunities. The investment is expected to have a minimal impact on the company's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Microsoft plans its first cloud-data centres in Middle East
summary: Microsoft plans to open its first cloud-data centres in Abu Dhabi and Dubai, expanding its geographic reach in the Middle East to win cloud-computing business worldwide. The company also plans to open sites in Switzerland and Germany, following a boost in spending to add cloud capacity. Microsoft aims to store information and applications closer to customers to speed data transfers and satisfy local laws. This move is part of the company's rivalry with Amazon Web Services, which is the largest seller of cloud services.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Corp will open data centres in Abu Dhabi and Dubai, its first in the Middle East, part of the software maker's rapid geographic expansion to win cloud-computing business worldwide and pry customers from Amazon.com Inc.

site_title: Bubble-tea maker triples in Hong Kong stock market debut
summary: B & S International Holdings Ltd, a Hong Kong bubble tea maker, made its stock market debut with shares tripling in value, reaching HK$3.17, after pricing at HK$1. The IPO was the most oversubscribed among 51 Hong Kong IPOs in 2018, with orders for 2,601 times as many shares as sold. Analysts attribute the surge to speculation, citing the company's relatively small size and numerous Taiwanese bubble tea competitors in Hong Kong.

site_title: Britain to expel 23 Russian diplomats, freeze Russian state assets
summary: Britain is expelling 23 Russian diplomats in retaliation for the nerve agent attack on former Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter, with the diplomats having just one week to leave. The move also freezes Russian state assets that may be used to threaten UK nationals or residents. The expulsion is seen as a significant blow to Russian intelligence capabilities in Britain, with Prime Minister Theresa May stating that Russia was culpable in the attempted murder and threatening the lives of other British citizens.

site_title: OCBC sets up in-house AI unit with initial investment of S$10m over 3 years
summary: OCBC Bank has established an in-house AI unit, AI Lab@TOV, with an initial investment of S$10 million over three years. The unit aims to drive AI adoption across banking services, such as wealth advisory and loan financing. The lab, led by Ken Wong, consists of three data scientists and plans to double its headcount within a year. OCBC has already employed AI in its operations, including the AI-powered chatbot "Emma" and a partnership with Thetaray to identify suspicious transactions, resulting in a 35% reduction in transaction reviews and a fourfold increase in accuracy.

images.alt_text: AI Lab@TOV sits within The Open Vault at OCBC, which is led by Pranav Seth (fron), head of e-Business, Business Transformation and Fintech and Innovation Group. Ken Wong, head of AI Lab@TOV (centre), Wu Qiong (left) and Vikash Ranjan (right) comprise the pioneering AI Lab@TOV team.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts annual loss of HK$1.26b, biggest in 9 years
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported its largest annual loss in nine years, logging a net loss of HK$1.26 billion for 2017 due to fierce competition from mainland Chinese and Middle Eastern rivals. The airline attributed the loss to overcapacity, but reported an attributable profit of HK$792 million in the second half, boosted by an improving cargo market. Cathay Pacific is in its second year of a three-year turnaround program aiming to make HK$4 billion in savings through job cuts and increased productivity.

site_title: Stephen Hawking, physicist who reshaped cosmology, dies at 76
summary: Stephen Hawking, renowned British physicist and cosmologist, has died at 76. Hawking, who suffered from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, passed away peacefully at his home in Cambridge, England. He was a leading figure in cosmology, proposing that black holes emit radiation and eventually evaporate, and showed that the universe had a beginning. Hawking's work, including his best-selling book "A Brief History of Time," had a profound impact on the history of science, despite the Nobel Prize in Physics being elusive. His legacy will live on, with his children and colleagues praising his courage, brilliance, and humor.

site_title: Japan's Abe weighing talks with North Korea's Kim: reports
summary: Japan is considering a summit between Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, according to local media reports. The talks could be part of Tokyo's new approach to dealing with North Korea, following US President Donald Trump's planned talks with the North Korean leader. Japan fears being left behind if talks proceed without its involvement, and is studying policies to resolve North Korea's nuclear and missile issues, as well as the abduction of Japanese citizens.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC initiates coverage on NetLink NBN Trust, issues 'buy'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has initiated coverage on NetLink NBN Trust with a "buy" rating, assigning a fair value estimate of S$0.91. Analyst Eugene Chua expects NetLink to "weather through various economic cycles" due to its defensive income streams and position as the sole provider of residential fibre networks in Singapore, leading to higher penetration rates for fibre broadband services. The analyst also expects NetLink to benefit from growth in connected services and stable earnings outlook.

site_title: Hungry Deutsche Bank looks to reclaim M&A laurels
summary: Germany's Deutsche Bank aims to reclaim its position as a top-tier investment bank in European mergers and acquisitions, having slipped to 10th place in 2016. The bank's M&A division head, Robin Rousseau, says it can regain its third-place rank in fees by 2019, having made significant progress in clearing up financial and legal issues. Despite a rocky start in 2018, Deutsche has been involved in high-profile deals and has a good pipeline, according to analysts, who expect the bank to remain among the top European banks in M&A.

site_title: Noble Group share trading halted pending statement
summary: Noble Group's share trading was halted in Singapore on March 14, 2018, pending a statement. The commodities trader was close to finalizing a US$3.4 billion debt-for-equity swap to restructure its debt, crucial for its survival. Noble has sold billions of dollars of assets, taken writedowns, and cut hundreds of jobs over the past three years. The trading halt comes after the company's negotiations with senior creditors to restructure its debt.

site_title: 160 banks in Singapore commit to inclusive hiring, to assess tech impact on jobs
summary: Singapore's Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has committed to 160 banks adopting inclusive hiring practices, assessing tech impact on jobs, and re-skilling staff for new roles. The aim is to build a "strong Singapore core" of talent in the financial sector. The HR advisory, developed by ABS, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and others, calls for banks to hire based on skills required for the job, rather than experience or qualifications alone. The goal is to create 3,000 net jobs annually in financial services and 1,000 in the fintech sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks tumble at open on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.20% at the open on Wednesday, following a global sell-off due to concerns over Donald Trump's approach to international relations. The Hang Seng Index fell to 31,223.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.35%. This decline is attributed to Trump's decision to sack Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, sparking worries about a hardline approach.

site_title: Uber launches its first-in-Asia carpooling service
summary: Uber launched UberCommute, its first carpooling service in Asia, in Singapore. The service allows riders to plan trips up to a week in advance or request a ride within an hour, with fares up to 51% cheaper than uberX. Drivers can recoup costs of their daily commute, including petrol and parking. The service differs from GrabHitch, with agreements on drop-off points and expenses incurred by drivers. UberCommute aims to provide a viable option for drivers, reflecting local regulations.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip on US protectionism fears
summary: Asian shares declined on Wednesday amid US protectionism fears, with investors seeking safety amid President Trump's firing of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and potential tariffs on Chinese imports. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific index fell 0.3%, while Australian and Japanese shares dropped 0.8% and 0.8%, respectively. The US dollar weakened, and bonds rose, following losses on Wall Street. Analysts warn that protectionism could lead to currency manipulation and further market instability.

site_title: Economists raise Singapore's 2018 growth forecast to 3.2%
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have raised the country's 2018 economic growth forecast to 3.2%, up from 3.0% in December. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's quarterly survey of professional forecasters also expects 2.8% growth in 2019. Optimism has grown in the finance and insurance, wholesale and retail trade, and accommodation and food services sectors, while manufacturing and non-oil domestic exports have seen decreased expectations. A global trade war and Chinese economy slowdown remain major concerns, but property market performance and the electronics sector's potential upside are seen as positives.

site_title: China Jan-Feb property investment growth strongest since 2015
summary: China's real estate investment growth surged in January and February, its strongest pace since 2015, as developers rushed to launch new projects amid a government crackdown on risky financing. However, property sales growth slowed from a year ago, indicating efforts to stem speculation in the sector are paying off. This development is seen as a key risk for China this year, with real estate directly affecting 40 other business sectors. The data suggests a shift towards more cautious investment in the property market.

site_title: Broadcom ditching Qualcomm bid on government opposition: sources
summary: Broadcom Ltd is abandoning its bid to acquire Qualcomm Inc after US President Donald Trump blocked the deal citing national security risks. The planned announcement is set for early Wednesday morning, marking the end of a months-long battle for the technology industry's largest deal. The decision comes after Trump expressed concerns over the potential risks to US national security. Broadcom had agreed to a $121 billion deal in November 2017, but the acquisition faced significant regulatory hurdles before Trump's intervention.

site_title: Tillerson not working his deal-making magic on Russia
summary: Former US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson failed to deliver deal-making magic with Russia, unlike his experience as CEO of Exxon Mobil. In 2012, he partnered with Rosneft on a $500 billion Arctic exploration deal, earning the Russian Order of Friendship from President Vladimir Putin. However, this attempt at building a rapport with Russia ultimately proved unsuccessful, with the US-Russian relationship cooling after Russia's annexation of Crimea. As a result, President Donald Trump no longer needs Tillerson's services, highlighting the former secretary of state's inability to achieve the desired diplomatic breakthroughs with Russia.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session lower on Wednesday; STI at 3,537.22, down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.5% in the afternoon session on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index at 3,537.22, down 16.51 points. The most actively traded stock, JEP Holdings, traded at S$0.077. Active index stocks included DBS, up 1.1%, and UOB, up 0.8%. Losers outnumbered gainers 209 to 126, with about 825 million shares worth S$607 million changing hands.

site_title: Group of Noble creditors sign support for restructuring
summary: NOBLE Group has signed a restructuring support agreement (RSA) with a group of senior creditors representing 50% of existing senior claims. Deutsche Bank AG and ING Bank have also signed the RSA, with ING seeking credit approval. The agreement is seen as a positive step towards Noble's proposed financial restructuring, with advisers indicating broad support from creditors holding 15% of existing senior claims.

site_title: OUE prices S$304.75m concurrent offering of 5-year convertible, exchangeable bonds
summary: OUE has priced a S$304.75 million concurrent offering of 5-year convertible and exchangeable bonds, priced at S$154.75 million with a 1.5% coupon. The conversion price is S$2.112 per share, representing a 10% premium over the property developer's closing price.

site_title: BOJ signals confidence on smooth exit from easy policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence in a smooth exit from its ultra-loose monetary policy, citing the success of keeping yields low and maintaining market trust in Japan's finances. However, he noted that it was too early to debate specifics given the current inflation gap with the 2% target. The BOJ's nine-member board showed a rift in opinions, with some members calling for greater scrutiny of the policy's drawbacks and others advocating for expanding stimulus. The central bank kept monetary settings unchanged, but Kuroda signaled his readiness to adjust policy if the economic recovery loses steam.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda on Wednesday voiced confidence the central bank could engineer a smooth exit from its ultra-loose monetary policy, but said it was too early to debate specifics with inflation still distant from its target.

site_title: Singapore shares edge lower on Wednesday morning; STI down 0.76%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.76% in early trading on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 26.84 points to 3,526.89. The decline came amid US stock losses on Tuesday, fueled by fears of a trade war. By 9:14am, 78.8 million shares worth S$185.4 million had changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 132 to 52.

site_title: MAS to reduce duplication and automate data submission from financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced a roadmap to eliminate duplication in data requests from financial institutions by the end of 2019. The roadmap aims to automate data submission and reduce resources needed to produce data, making it more efficient for MAS to process and analyze the data. Measures include using data reusability, allowing financial institutions to decline duplicate requests, and requiring new regulatory returns to be submitted in machine-readable formats from April 1. The goal is to co-create an industry data collection platform that benefits both MAS and financial institutions.

site_title: Tillerson sacking spells doom for Iran nuclear deal
summary: US President Donald Trump's sacking of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson may signal the end of the Iran nuclear deal. Trump cited disagreements on the deal, with Trump wanting to "break" it and Tillerson believing it was "OK." The deal, signed in 2015, restricts Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief. With Trump's decision to fire Tillerson, it appears likely that the US will withdraw from the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, potentially dooming the deal and straining US ties with European allies.

site_title: China Jan-Feb factory output, investment stronger than expected
summary: China's industrial output expanded 7.2% in the first two months of the year, beating forecasts, and fixed-asset investment growth rose 7.9%, exceeding expectations. Retail sales grew 9.7%, slightly below projections. Despite a slowdown in momentum expected by many economists, early data suggests China's economy remains resilient, keeping a synchronized global recovery on track. Premier Li Keqiang reiterated China's aim to expand its economy by 6.5% this year, with officials hinting at more cautious spending to reduce debt risks.

site_title: US dollar struggles after Tillerson's dismissal strikes down recovery
summary: The US dollar declined 0.1% against the yen to 106.490 yen after the dismissal of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, which was seen as a significant event in the currency market. The dollar's recovery was halted after a two-week high, and it is now expected to face further challenges due to ongoing US political uncertainty. The Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on March 20 is also expected to impact the dollar's value, with some analysts suggesting it may accelerate the pace of rate hikes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, March 14, 2018, as investor sentiment was hurt by US President Donald Trump's replacement of his secretary of state and plans for new tariffs on China. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.81% to 21,790.80, while the Topix index dropped 0.66% to 1,739.53.

site_title: Former Ang Mo Kio Town Council GM charged with accepting bribes worth S$107,000
summary: A former general manager of Ang Mo Kio Town Council, Wong Chee Meng, has been charged with accepting bribes worth S$107,000 from two building firms and their director. The alleged bribes took place between 2014 and 2016 and included overseas remittances, job placements, and discounts on purchases. Wong, 58, faces 55 counts of corruption, while his alleged co-conspirator, Chia Sin Lan, faces 55 counts. Both are out on bail and intend to claim trial on April 11.

site_title: Dog dies on United Airlines flight after being forced into overhead bin
summary: A woman's small dog died on a United Airlines flight after being forced into an overhead bin. The incident occurred on a 3.5-hour flight from Houston to New York, where the flight attendant pressured the owner to place the dog in the bin despite her request to keep it under her seat. United Airlines has taken full responsibility and is investigating the incident, offering the family a refund for their tickets, including a pet cabin fee. This is not the first time United has faced scrutiny for animal deaths on its flights, with 18 animals killed and 13 injured in transport in 2017.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Alliance Mineral Assets, CapitaLand, Boustead Singapore, Gaylin
summary:

site_title: Sacked Tillerson: US must respond to Russia's behaviour
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson warned in his farewell remarks that the US must respond to Russia's "troubling behavior and actions." He stated that continued aggression could lead to greater isolation, not in anyone's interest. Tillerson also praised the hard work of his State Department in building sanctions and diplomatic pressure, which had "exceeded expectations." He will pass authority to Deputy Secretary John Sullivan at midnight and remain at the department until March 31.

site_title: Trump can learn from Albright about North Korea talks
summary: US President Donald Trump may benefit from learning from Madeleine Albright's experience with North Korea. Albright's 2000 trip to Pyongyang, led by then-Secretary of State Bill Clinton, failed to secure a nuclear agreement. She was criticized for flattering North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, who later revealed that his country had continued to develop and test missiles. Trump's upcoming meeting with Kim could be historic but also potentially costly if he fails to negotiate meaningful concessions. Trump should consult with Albright to avoid repeating her mistakes and instead focus on helping North Koreans achieve basic human yearnings for freedom.

site_title: Singapore private condo rents up by 1% in February; HDB rents rise 0.5%: SRX
summary: Singapore's private condo rents rose 1% in February 2018, higher than the 0.5% increase in January. Rents in Core Central Region rose 2.3%, while Outside Central Region and Rest of Central Region saw 0.7% and 0.2% increases, respectively. On a year-on-year basis, rents were down 0.7%. In contrast, HDB rents rose 0.5% in February, with some unit types experiencing larger increases. The number of private condos rented fell 20.4% in February, while HDB rental-flat volumes declined 19.1%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.59 points to 1,862.44. Losers outnumbered gainers 92 to 77, with volume at 55 million lots worth RM19.45 million.

site_title: Japan's Abe is latest leader mulling Kim meeting: report
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is exploring a possible meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, following US President Donald Trump's decision to meet with Kim. This would be a departure from Abe's previous stance of "maximum pressure" on the regime. Abe's government is considering a new approach to deal with North Korea, possibly focusing on resolving the issue of Japanese citizens abducted by the regime. The move comes amid a domestic scandal threatening Abe's bid for a record-long term as prime minister.

site_title: Former South Korean president Lee Myung Bak reports for questioning
summary: Former South Korean president Lee Myung Bak reported to prosecutors for questioning in a corruption probe, apologizing for the controversy. This marks the first time a living former South Korean president has been involved in a criminal inquiry. The investigation is part of a broader probe into corruption and embezzlement during Lee's presidency.

images.alt_text: Former South Korean president Lee Myung Bak reported to prosecutors for questioning in a corruption probe Wednesday and apologised for the controversy.

site_title: CAAS partners Searidge Tech to explore AI use in air traffic management
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) partnered with Searidge Technologies to research the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in airport control tower operations. The collaboration aims to enhance safety and performance in flight operations through AI-powered functions such as predictive runway incursion and collision detection. The solution's design will incorporate feedback from operational and technical users, and is part of CAAS' drive to develop innovative air traffic management solutions.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as banks drag amid inquiry; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 5,930.8, with banking stocks leading the decline amid an inquiry into the sector. The inquiry's first day focused on National Australia Bank's issuance of nearly $19 billion in home loans with falsified documents. Other major banks, including Commonwealth Bank, also dropped between 0.9 and 1.2%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.6% as the country posted a wider-than-expected current account deficit.

site_title: Inflation firms in February, without major acceleration
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in February, matching expectations, and inflation is creeping up towards the Federal Reserve's target without major acceleration. The core gauge, excluding food and energy, also increased 0.2%. The data suggests a gradual pace of interest-rate hikes, with the Fed likely to raise rates this month but not more than three times in 2018. This easing of fears led to a rise in Wall Street's main indexes.

site_title: Alliance Mineral, Tawana Resources start lithium production at Australia mine
summary: Lithium production has commenced at the Bald Hill Lithium and Tantalum Mine in Western Australia, following the commissioning of a dense media separation circuit. The production will be ramped up over several months, with the completion of stage 2 of the lithium fines circuit design and tantalum circuits still pending. The joint venture between Alliance Mineral Assets and Tawana Resources is the first lithium production facility in Australia.

site_title: Europe: Shares sag after Trump ousts US chief diplomat Tillerson
summary: US President Donald Trump fired Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, causing European shares to fall 1% and the euro to rise 0.5% against the dollar. Frankfurt's DAX took the worst hit, down 1.6%. The move was seen as a sign of Trump's shift in foreign policy priorities, with the euro zone currency typically hurt by a rise in the dollar. Investors are now focusing on US-EU trade talks and potential tariffs.

site_title: Google guru Page tests flying taxis in New Zealand
summary: Google co-founder Larry Page's company Kitty Hawk is testing flying taxis in New Zealand as part of a six-year project. The Cora aircraft, with a dozen small lift rotors, can carry two passengers and reach speeds of 150 kmh. Approved by New Zealand regulators, the prototype is designed to be quieter and more sustainable than traditional aircraft. The service aims to revolutionize personal transport, with operations planned around Christchurch and a focus on reducing congestion and pollution.

site_title: Super Apps shaping the future of finance
summary: Digital platforms are transforming the finance industry, blurring the lines between traditional banking and tech companies. Tech platforms are becoming demand aggregators, taking on lending and custodian functions, while banks will focus on managing compliance-heavy services. According to a 2017 report, tech companies will retain control of customer relationships, while banks become component suppliers. This shift is driven by the need for tech companies to access a wide user base across various consumer sectors through integrated payments infrastructure. The traditional banking value chain is becoming unbound, leading to a significant change in the industry landscape.

site_title: US students to stage walkout against gun violence
summary: US students are set to stage a nationwide 17-minute walkout on Wednesday to honor the victims of the Parkland school shooting, one month after the tragedy. The event, called the "National School Walkout," is a tribute to the 17 students and staff killed in the February 14th shooting. The walkout is also a protest against the high number of gun-related deaths in the US, with over 30,000 annual fatalities. The walkout is scheduled to begin at 10:00am and will be held in solidarity with students and families affected by gun violence.

site_title: Trump trade shifts could undo tax boon: business lobby
summary: US business sentiment has surged after tax cuts, but a shift in trade policies under President Trump could undo these gains, according to the Business Roundtable. The group warns of a "possible major headwind" from restrictive trade policies and a US exit from NAFTA, which would be a "disaster" for US companies. A quarterly business survey showed surging expectations for hiring and capital investment.

site_title: US crude falls 1% on concerns over rising output
summary: US crude oil prices fell 1% due to concerns over rising US production, which reached an all-time record of over 10.3 million barrels per day. The decline in oil prices was also influenced by weak equity markets, which have trended in tandem with oil prices. Brent crude futures dropped 0.5% to $64.64 per barrel, while US West Texas crude futures fell 1.06% to $60.71 per barrel.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as trade war fears rise
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as trade war fears rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.7% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.6%. President Trump's replacement of Secretary of State Rex Tillerson with Mike Pompeo, and reports of new tariffs on China, contributed to market uncertainty. Financial stocks, including Bank of America and Citigroup, also declined, while technology shares fell sharply, with Apple and Google dropping 1% and 2.3%, respectively. The market's retreat was attributed to concerns about the administration's stability and potential impact on trade policies.

site_title: Boustead Singapore's substantial shareholder disposes entire stake
summary: Boustead Singapore's substantial shareholder Saiman Ernawan has disposed of his entire stake in the company, reducing his interest from 9.46% to 0%. Ernawan sold 20.4 million shares on March 9 and another 29 million shares on March 12, with the company buying back the shares at the same price. This move comes after queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding a spike in trading activity. Ernawan's remaining shares were sold on March 12, bringing his stake to zero, with chairman Wong Fong Fui remaining the largest substantial shareholder.

site_title: The world is falling apart but there's room for optimism
summary: The world is experiencing a growing sense of pessimism, fueled by fears of nuclear war, economic uncertainty, and social disorder. However, experts like Gregg Easterbrook and Steven Pinker argue that this outlook is misguided, citing statistics showing improvements in poverty rates, violent crime, and living standards. They attribute the pessimism to a "collapse anxiety" fueled by short-term problems and the media's focus on crises, rather than long-term achievements. Easterbrook suggests that the world is generally getting better, and that this optimism can counteract the pessimism, leading to progress and improvement.

site_title: Winklevoss twins pitch plan to regulate digital money
summary: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler, have proposed a plan to regulate the digital money market through an industry-sponsored virtual commodity association. The proposal aims to establish and police cryptocurrency standards, ensuring consumer protection and market integrity. US Commodity Futures Trading Commission member Brian Quintenz welcomed the idea, stating it would add an additional layer of oversight. The twins' Gemini bitcoin exchange has been a key player in the market, and their plan comes as the British government calls for global regulation of bitcoin, with the G20 addressing the topic this month.

site_title: Oxley in final negotiations to sell block in Ireland project
summary: Oxley Holdings is in final negotiations to sell a 300-year lease of a block in its Dublin Landings project in Ireland. The mixed-use development, launched in 2016, features 65,000 square meters of office and retail space and over 270 luxury apartments. Oxley expects the sale to boost revenue and cash flow. The company has already secured an anchor tenant for the project, the National Treasury Management Agency of Ireland, which took a 25-year lease.

site_title: LNG is the new shale oil with US as disruptor-in-chief
summary: The US is poised to disrupt the liquefied natural gas (LNG) market, becoming a swing producer and challenging traditional trade flows, especially in fast-growing Asian markets. As the US ramps up production, major producers like Royal Dutch Shell warn of an impending supply gap that will require over $200 billion of investment by 2030. The US is expected to add 50 million tonnes of annual capacity by 2020, which could lead to increased competition for traditional exporters like Qatar and Australia. The LNG market is expected to adapt to the arrival of US production, but unlike crude oil, it lacks an established producer group to coordinate a response.

site_title: Trump sacks Tillerson, names CIA's Pompeo as Secretary of State
summary: US President Donald Trump sacked Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, replacing him with CIA Director Mike Pompeo. The move comes amid disagreements over Iran's nuclear deal and just hours after Tillerson returned from a week-long trip to Africa. Trump stated he and Tillerson had differing mindsets and praised Pompeo's intellect, citing his experience in intelligence gathering and modernizing capabilities. The dismissal follows a wave of departures in Trump's inner circle and has sent European stocks and bond yields down.

site_title: STI rises 0.4% ahead of key US data
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,553.73, finishing higher for the fourth consecutive day, despite US stocks losing steam overnight. The index defied expectations, with key regional peers closing in varied moods. The gains came ahead of key US inflation data, which will be scrutinized for clues on the Federal Reserve's tightening policy. The mixed regional performance saw rises in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Malaysia, while China and Australia closed lower.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Trump seeking tariffs on up to US$60b Chinese goods; targets tech, telecoms
summary: US President Donald Trump is seeking to impose tariffs on up to $60 billion of Chinese imports, targeting the technology and telecommunications sectors, amid allegations of intellectual property theft. The move, part of a "Section 301" investigation, could lead to a broader list of 100 products. The tariffs aim to punish China for its investment policies forcing US companies to give up technology secrets, and come after Trump's protectionist agenda and previous tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. A harsh response from Beijing is expected, complicating efforts to recruit allies to pressure China.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is seeking to impose tariffs on up to US$60 billion of Chinese imports and will target the technology and telecommunications sectors, two people who had discussed the issue with the Trump administration said on Tuesday.

site_title: G20 financial heads to urge crypto-asset monitoring to safeguard financial stability
summary: G20 financial leaders will urge international standard-setting bodies to strengthen monitoring of crypto-assets and assess the need for a multilateral response to potential financial stability threats. The call comes as regulators globally raise alarms over cryptocurrencies' risks, including money laundering and terrorist financing. Japan, France, and Germany have already proposed regulations for the bitcoin market, while the US Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered online trading platforms to register and follow additional rules. The goal is to balance the potential benefits of crypto-assets in improving financial efficiency and inclusiveness.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices up 1.9% in Feb; units sold rise 11.3%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale prices rose 1.9% in February, surpassing the 1.3% month-on-month increase in January, and marking the seventh consecutive month of growth. This brought prices to 1% higher than the peak in January 2014 and 7.6% higher than a year ago. The number of resale non-landed private homes sold also increased by 11.3% from January, with 1,212 units sold, and was 68.6% higher than the previous year. Market watchers attribute the rebound to positive sentiments in the property market and limited new launches.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Next Goldman CEO could be a banker who moonlights as a DJ
summary: Goldman Sachs has chosen David Solomon, a 56-year-old investment banker and part-time DJ, as the next CEO, succeeding Lloyd Blankfein. Solomon, who moonlights as DJ D-Sol, was the sole heir apparent after Blankfein's potential retirement, following the abrupt retirement of rival candidate Harvey Schwartz. The decision marks a strategic shift for Goldman, which is under siege from declining traditional business models and limited presence in key markets. Solomon has been working to address these shortcomings since his elevation to president in 2016.

images.alt_text: Mr Schwartz (left) and Mr Solomon, then co-chief operating officers at Goldman Sachs, in New York, last November. The elevation of Mr Solomon, a Goldman veteran who moonlights under the name DJ D-Sol, spinning electronic-dance music, marks a strategic shift for the bank.

site_title: Metropolitan Opera sacks legendary conductor James Levine after abuse probe
summary: The Metropolitan Opera has fired legendary conductor James Levine after a three-month investigation found "credible evidence" of sexual abuse and harassment of younger musicians. Levine, 74, had been music director for 40 years and was set to retire in 2016.
