site_title: Hot stock: Jubilee shares climb 11% after boosting stake in EG Industries, broker's call
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings shares rose 11% after the company acquired 3.5 million EG Industries shares, increasing its stake from 11.72% to 13.03%. The acquisition was made at RM1.95 million (S$658,000) and follows a broker's recommendation to "add" the stock with a target price of S$0.051. Analysts expect Jubilee to swing back into profit after two years of losses, driven by the growth of its electronic component sales and expansion of its moulding capacity.

site_title: Irish VR start-up eyes global roll-out after London listing
summary: Irish VR start-up VR Education Holdings (VRE) is listing in London and Dublin to fund the global roll-out of its virtual reality platform. The company, founded by David and Sandra Whelan, has secured over $10.9 million in funding, valuing it at $19.3 million. VRE's platform, which includes experiences such as the Apollo 11 and Titanic simulations, will be supported by high-end VR headsets and can be used by educators, trainers, and corporate trainers. The company aims to attract top talent and expand globally.

site_title: VWs using more diesel, failing pollution tests after recalls: study
summary: A study by the Australian Automobile Association found that Volkswagen vehicles recalled and fixed after the "dieselgate" scandal are still using more fuel and failing pollution tests in real-world settings. The study showed that affected vehicles were using up to 14% more diesel and emitting noxious emissions 400% higher than lab tests. Volkswagen has rejected the comparison, citing approval from German authorities, but the AAA argues that actual driving tests are needed to ensure regulatory settings reflect real-world conditions.

site_title: Perennial to buy Pontiac unit's 50% stake in Capitol Singapore for S$528m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings agreed to buy Pontiac Land's 50% stake in Capitol Singapore for S$528 million. Perennial will pay S$129.6 million in cash and discharge loans of S$368.6 million, along with interest accrued. The deal includes ancillary payments of S$3 million to Patina Hotels & Resorts.

site_title: Yoma to upgrade taxis, offer vehicle financing for Grab drivers in Myanmar
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings signed an agreement with ride-hailing service Grab to upgrade taxis in Myanmar, providing vehicle financing for Grab drivers. The partnership aims to improve the quality of vehicles, driver service, and safety standards in Yangon. Yoma will offer leasing and rental car options for GrabTaxi drivers, complementing its existing vehicle rental services. The collaboration is expected to support Grab's recently launched services, including GrabTaxi Plus and Grab for Business.

site_title: Knife attacker shot dead outside Iran ambassador's Vienna residence: police
summary: A 26-year-old Austrian was shot dead outside the Iranian ambassador's residence in Vienna after attacking a guard with a knife. The assailant died on the spot, and the guard, who suffered a wound to his upper arm, acted within the rules. The motive for the attack is not yet known. Police have ordered reinforcements around diplomatic missions in the city.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won climb to multi-week highs on increased risk appetite
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index reached a five-week high, closing at 2,481.90, driven by increased risk appetite after easing tensions on the Korean peninsula. The Korean won also surged to a six-week high, reaching 1,064.5 per dollar. Strong gains on Wall Street supported sentiment, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The rally comes as investors become more optimistic despite ongoing trade uncertainty and mixed Fed views.

site_title: Rise of violent Buddhist rhetoric in Asia defies stereotypes
summary: A surge in violent Buddhist rhetoric in Asia is defying stereotypes of Buddhism as a peaceful philosophy. In Sri Lanka, Myanmar, and Thailand, hardline monks have led anti-Muslim riots, with Buddhist mobs attacking Muslim-owned establishments and individuals. Experts say this surge is fueled by historical grievances, Islamophobia, and a perceived threat to Buddhism. The violence is often justified by Buddhist fundamentalist groups, who portray Islam as invasive and a threat to Buddhist nations. This aggressive rhetoric has already led to the displacement of Rohingya Muslims and has the potential to spread to vulnerable minorities.

site_title: Sony among suitors for US$4b EMI catalogue: sources
summary: Sony is in preliminary talks to acquire a majority stake in EMI Music Publishing, a catalogue of over 2.1 million songs including hits from Beyonce and Carole King, for at least $4 billion. Mubadala Investment Co, the Abu Dhabi-based owner, is seeking a valuation for EMI and has approached other potential buyers, including Sony, Warner Music Group, and entertainment groups. A sale would solidify Sony's position as the largest music publisher and align with the growing demand for music copyrights due to booming streaming services.

site_title: Broker's take: Maybank Kim Eng raises ST Engineering to 'buy'
summary: Maybank Kim Eng analysts have upgraded their call on ST Engineering to "buy" and increased their 12-month target price to S$4.15, citing growth catalysts in the recovering engineering industry. The analysts highlight the company's focus on integration across its businesses, as well as growth in the aerospace, electronics, and autonomous mobile robot markets. However, they note that the marine sector remains challenging in the near term. ST Engineering shares rose 1.2% to S$3.42 following the upgrade.

site_title: It's complicated: China torn on Trump, Kim talks
summary: China is divided on US President Donald Trump's decision to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, with some expressing concern that Beijing will be left out of the negotiations. Despite being North Korea's only ally and main economic lifeline, China has backed UN sanctions against Pyongyang and has not met with Kim since 2011. China's top leaders have praised Trump's "positive" move, but some experts believe Beijing may offer to host the meeting to increase its influence. The country's prime interest in the Korean peninsula is denuclearization and peace, rather than its relations with North and South Korea.

site_title: Hot stock: Boustead Singapore says substantial shareholder keen to exit
summary: Boustead Singapore shares rose nearly six percent on Monday after a substantial shareholder expressed interest in exiting the company. The company did not disclose further details about the possible exit. Boustead Singapore's shares hit a high of 81 cents before easing to 80.5 cents at noon, with its subsidiary also trading heavily. The company's largest substantial shareholders include chairman and CEO Wong Fong Fui and investment fund FMR LLC. Despite the trading activity, Boustead Singapore's outlook and business health remain positive, with recent acquisitions and revenue growth contributing to its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Oil edges up on reduced US drilling activity, booming job market
summary: Oil prices edged up on Monday due to a drop in US drilling activity and a strong US job market, which is expected to drive higher fuel demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 6 cents to $62.10 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 9 cents to $65.58 per barrel. The US economy added 313,000 jobs in February, and energy companies cut oil rigs for the first time in almost two months. Despite lower rig counts, US crude oil production is expected to rise further, surpassing top exporter Saudi Arabia and rival Russia.

images.alt_text: Oil markets edged up on Monday on the back of a drop in the number of US rigs drilling for more production and as the US economy continued to create jobs, which industry hopes will drive higher fuel demand.

site_title: Name of Japan PM Abe's wife removed from land sale documents: Kyodo
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's wife, Akie, was removed from documents related to the sale of state-owned land, following government acknowledgement that the documents had been altered. The move comes as pressure mounts on Abe and Finance Minister Taro Aso over the case. The Ministry of Finance initially acknowledged the alteration, with the name of Akie Abe being removed from the documents.

site_title: US dollar slips vs yen on concerns over suspected Japan cronyism scandal
summary: The US dollar slipped against the yen due to concerns over a suspected cronyism scandal in Japan involving Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's wife and a school operator. The scandal has led to increased pressure on Abe and his ally Finance Minister Taro Aso, potentially dampening investors' risk appetites. The yen strengthened, and the dollar eased 0.2% to 106.62 yen, as market participants worried about economic uncertainty and the impact on Japan's economic policies.

images.alt_text: The dollar eased versus the yen on Monday, as traders worried that a suspected cronyism scandal in Japan involving the sale of state-owned land could dampen investors' risk appetites.

site_title: Prada shares jump 13% on growth outlook
summary: Prada shares jumped 13% after the Italian luxury goods maker reported it would return to growth in 2018, reversing a sales slide in the second half of 2017. This comes after years of falling profit, with competitors Kering and LVMH boosting sales. Prada's shares reached their highest level since May 2017, outperforming the Hang Seng Index. The news boosted investor confidence in the luxury goods sector.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index up 34.51 points to 3,520.08, driven by gains in Allied Technologies and other active stocks. About 83 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 132 to 29. Regional markets also saw gains, including the Topix index in Tokyo and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.96 points to 1,851.88, with 208 gainers outnumbering 38 losers. The index saw 66.56 million lots traded at RM23.45 million. This follows a global stock market rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Kim Jong-un wants to sign peace treaty with Trump: report
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un is reportedly seeking to sign a peace treaty with US President Donald Trump, potentially including establishing diplomatic relations and an embassy in Pyongyang. This comes as Kim is set to meet with Trump, although a location has yet to be decided. In a separate meeting with South Korean President Moon Jae-in, Kim is expected to discuss denuclearization, cultural exchanges, and reunifying separated families. The development may signal a shift in North Korea's stance on its nuclear program and its relations with the US.

site_title: Asia: Shares rally as US job data revive risk appetite
summary: Asian shares rallied on Monday, with MSCI's Asia-Pacific index gaining 1.1% for a third session of gains. The US jobs report, which showed stronger-than-expected employment numbers, eased fears of inflation and faster rate hikes, boosting risk appetite globally. Australia's mining shares surged on news that the country could be exempt from new US trade tariffs on steel and aluminium imports, while South Korea rose 1% and Australia's main index added 0.7%.

site_title: Flippy the fast food robot temporarily decommissioned for being too slow
summary: A California-based fast food chain, CaliBurger, temporarily decommissioned its robot, Flippy, after it struggled to keep up with customer demand. The robot, designed to flip burgers and monitor cooking times, was overwhelmed by the influx of customers. Instead of replacing human staff, CaliBurger retrained its employees to work more efficiently alongside Flippy. The robot's developer, Miso Robotics, sees it as a "third hand" to assist in cooking tasks, not replace jobs.

site_title: Japan cronyism scandal hitting Abe popularity: poll
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces a growing scandal over favoritism, with the finance ministry set to admit altering key documents related to a land sale favoring a close friend. The scandal has hit Abe's popularity, with a poll showing his support dropping to 48% from 54% last month. Opposition politicians have alleged the sale was influenced by the Abe family's ties to the buyer, a right-wing operator of private schools. The scandal has paralyzed parliament, with some lawmakers boycotting debates, and has raised concerns about Abe's leadership.

site_title: Jubilee Industries boosts stake in EG Industries through open market purchase
summary: Jubilee Industries Holdings, a Catalist-listed company, has acquired approximately 3.5 million shares of EG Industries through an open market purchase for RM1.95 million, increasing its stake from 11.72% to 13.03%. The acquisition is aimed at supporting EG Industries' long-term growth prospects and expansion in the electronics business unit and mechanical business unit, driven by improved global demand for electronic products.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump considers ex-Microsoft executive as top economic adviser
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering Chris Liddell, a former Microsoft executive and General Motors CEO, as his top economic adviser. Liddell's background in running major companies and his experience working behind the scenes at the White House make him an attractive candidate. The move comes after Gary Cohn's resignation, which was sparked by Trump's decision to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports. Peter Navarro and Larry Kudlow are also being considered for the position, but Liddell's skills and experience have made him a top contender.

site_title: Russian authorities say 'terrorists' killed in foiled attack
summary: Russian security services announced that they killed "terrorists" who were planning an attack near Saratov, southwest Russia, in a foiled operation. The incident occurred a week before Russia's presidential election and three months before the 2018 World Cup. The FSB recovered explosives, homemade grenades, and pistols, and two men were fatally wounded in an exchange of gunfire. This is the second such operation announced by the FSB in recent weeks, following the killing of an IS member in early February.

site_title: Tesla paused Model 3 production for planned upgrade in February
summary: Tesla temporarily suspended Model 3 production from Feb 20-24 for planned work to improve automation and increase production rates. The pause was considered normal and common for ramping up a new product. The company aims to reach weekly production rates of 2,500 by the end of the first quarter and 5,000 by the end of the second quarter. Despite the challenges, Tesla plans to address bottlenecks and add capacity to increase production rates during the first quarter and second quarter.

images.alt_text: Tesla Inc temporarily suspended production of its Model 3 electric car from Feb 20-24 for planned work to adjust equipment in order to improve automation and increase production rates.

site_title: Cuba vote opens final chapter of Castro era
summary: Cubans voted to ratify a new National Assembly, paving the way for the election of a new president, the first in nearly 60 years outside the Castro family. President Raul Castro, 86, will step down next month, with likely successor Miguel Diaz-Canel casting his ballot. Diaz-Canel, the first vice-president, has promised "peace, liberty, independence, and the sovereignty of the people" will endure. Over 8 million Cubans voted for 605 candidates, with over 90% turnout expected, marking the beginning of major change at the top in Cuba.

site_title: Singapore's Golden Gate raising US$100m venture capital fund: source
summary: Singapore's Golden Gate Ventures is raising a US$100 million third fund to invest in e-commerce, payments, and mobile apps in South-east Asia. Founded in 2011 by former Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, the firm has already launched two funds and invested in over 30 companies in the region. The new fund is expected to close by the end of 2018, with investors including Temasek Holdings, Facebook's Eduardo Saverin, and South Korea's Hanwha Life Insurance Co. This move follows a surge in fundraising activities in the region, with other firms such as Wavemaker Partners and NSI Ventures also raising funds.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Datapulse, Yoma, Breadtalk, Perennial, Jubilee
summary: Noble Group failed to pay a US$750 million coupon on its notes due March 9, 2022, but has a 30-day grace period. Datapulse Technology has appointed a law firm to review its internal controls and corporate governance practices after a Singapore Exchange notice. Yoma Strategic Holdings signed a deal with ride-hailing service Grab to upgrade taxis and provide financing. Breadtalk Group entered a joint venture with Wu Pao Chun Food to operate bakeries in China, Hong Kong, and Singapore. Perennial Real Estate Holdings bought a stake in Capitol Singapore for S$528 million. Jubilee Industries Holdings raised its stake in EG Industries to 13.03% after buying 3.5 million shares.

site_title: Lotto tickets are nice, boss, but may I have my bonus?
summary: United Airlines replaced a standard bonus with a lottery that would give nothing to most of its workers, awarding lavish prizes to a few lucky winners, sparking criticism. The company's attempt to build excitement and a sense of accomplishment backfired after workers expressed hostility. Gamification techniques, such as lotteries and point systems, are increasingly used in workplaces to motivate employees, but critics argue that they can be used to save money and shift the burden from shareholders to workers. Research suggests that gamification can be an effective way to motivate workers, but it should not replace fair compensation.

site_title: Hong Kong democrats struggle to recapture lost ground in by-elections
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy camp struggled to regain seats in by-elections, with a low turnout of 43% of eligible voters. The opposition won two seats, while the pro-establishment camp secured one. A recount is needed in one district after a narrow margin separated the winners. The outcome could limit veto power and pave the way for a "rubber-stamp" parliament. The low turnout coincided with China's constitutional change allowing President Xi Jinping to stay in power indefinitely, fueling concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Awilco Drilling confirms US$425m rig-building award to Keppel O&M

site_title: Asia's big developers 'more vulnerable' to shocks, BIS warns
summary: Asia's major developers are more vulnerable to financial shocks due to declining profitability, according to the Bank for International Settlements. Higher interest rates, sinking property prices, or falling currencies could worsen developers' financial health, with potential significant economic repercussions. This warning comes as the global economy tightens, forcing developers to sell inventory and lay off workers. Thailand's developers are an exception to the trend of sinking profitability.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on falling yen, US jobs data
summary: Tokyo shares rose 2.03% on Monday, driven by robust US jobs data and a falling yen. The Nikkei 225 index surged 435.06 points to 21,904.26, while the Topix index advanced 1.49% to 1,741.11. site_title: White House to help arm school staff: officials
summary: The Trump administration plans to provide technical assistance to states to arm school staff under a "pragmatic plan" to increase campus safety. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos announced the plan after the Florida school shooting that killed 17 people. The plan includes mental health care, background checks, and violence prevention programs. The administration will also chair a federal commission on school safety and provide firearms training to qualified volunteer school personnel. The plan has been met with skepticism from educators, who have stated that parents and educators "overwhelmingly reject the idea of arming school staff."

site_title: Deutsche Bank board said to seek 6,000 job cuts at retail unit

site_title: Hong Kong goes to the polls in crunch test for Democrats
summary: Hong Kong held by-elections on Sunday, where pro-democracy candidates are seeking to regain lost seats amidst a tense atmosphere and China's increasing pressure on the semi-autonomous city. The elections come after Beijing barred high-profile young candidate Agnes Chow from standing due to her party's promotion of self-determination. Pro-democracy activists Joshua Wong and Nathan Law faced heckling and intimidation, while supporters of the pro-establishment establishment cast the opposition as provoking violence. site_title: BreadTalk to take Taiwan's Wu Pao Chun bakeries into China, Hong Kong, Singapore

site_title: Germany, China warn Trump tariff moves threaten global trade
summary: Germany and China have warned US President Donald Trump's tariff moves on metal imports could threaten global trade, with Germany's Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries calling for a united European response. summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin is positioning himself as the economic voice of reason within the White House, following the departure of Gary Cohn. summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) makes a high-stakes gamble by predicting which flu virus types will dominate the coming season to prepare a vaccine. The WHO's Global Influenza Surveillance and Response System analyzes data from 143 national influenza centres to create a cocktail vaccine covering three or four bases. The choice of vaccine mix has had mixed results in the past, with the 2017-18 northern hemisphere vaccine being 70% effective against one strain but only 20% effective against another. The WHO's predictions are made eight to ten months ahead of the flu season.

images.alt_text: Every year, two different vaccines are proposed - one for the northern hemisphere winter, one for the south.

site_title: First deal on new HDB resale portal is completed in half the time
summary: A couple in Singapore successfully completed a resale HDB transaction in just eight weeks using the newly revamped online portal, halving the typical transaction time. The portal, launched in January 2018, allows buyers and sellers to complete necessary forms and checks online, reducing the need for multiple appointments. The first deal was completed by a 35-year-old real estate marketing director and his wife, who paid $338,000 for a three-room flat in Hougang Ave 3. The move aims to streamline the resale process and is part of the government's Real Estate Industry Transformation Map.

site_title: Intel mulls possible defensive bid for Broadcom, WSJ reports
summary: Intel is considering a potential defensive bid for Broadcom Ltd, following the chipmaker's bid for Qualcomm Inc, according to the Wall Street Journal. Intel, the world's second-largest semiconductor maker, is keeping a close eye on the US$117 billion takeover battle and may step in with its own offer if Broadcom prevails. A combined company would pose a competitive threat to Intel, and the company is working with advisers to explore alternatives.

site_title: Australia to secure exemption from US tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Friday that he has spoken with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and is working on an agreement to exempt Australia from US tariffs on steel and aluminum, citing a fair and reciprocal military and trade relationship. This move comes despite Australia being a small global exporter of steel, with exports worth just over A$400 million to the US last year. Turnbull confirmed the exemption on Twitter, stating it's good for jobs in both countries.

site_title: CPTPP shows 11 nations know how to make a win-win deal in a time of rising protectionism: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised the newly signed Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a significant achievement for the 11 nations involved. The agreement demonstrates a "win-win deal" in a time of rising protectionism and nationalism. Lee thanked the other nations for their commitment and credited Japan's leadership under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and Singapore's trade negotiating team for their efforts. Countries will now need to ratify the agreement, with Singapore aiming to do so expeditiously.

site_title: Horse, spooked on Florida dance floor, throws off semi-naked rider
summary: A snow-white horse became spooked on a dance floor at Mokai Lounge in Miami Beach, throwing off its semi-naked rider and causing a commotion. Footage of the incident sparked outrage, with over 1,000 people signing a petition to revoke the club's license and a Yelp review page being shut down. The Miami Beach Police Department launched a joint investigation with local officials, expressing concern over the allegations of animal abuse. The incident has left the club closed and facing social media backlash.

site_title: Golf: Tiger stalks Conners at Valspar Championship
summary: Tiger Woods regained the lead at the Valspar Championship, driving fans into a frenzy with a three-under par 68, for a four-under total of 138. This briefly surpassed Canadian rookie Corey Conners, who held the overnight lead with a 69 for 136. Woods' performance positions him for a strong weekend, but Conners remains two strokes ahead.

site_title: Nobel prize-winning British scientist John Sulston dies at 75: Institute
summary: Nobel Prize-winning British scientist Sir John Sulston, a key figure in deciphering the human genome, has died at 75. He was jointly awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2002 for his gene research, particularly in understanding programmed cell death. Sulston led Britain's human genome mapping project and insisted on public domain data, contributing to the open access movement. He founded the Sanger Centre in 1992, now a leading genome research center. His dedication to free access to scientific information has had a lasting impact on humanity.

site_title: Demand for programmers hits full boil as US job market simmers
summary: The US job market is experiencing a surge in demand for programmers, with companies competing fiercely to recruit and retain software engineers. The scarcity of talent has led to new strategies, such as training and apprenticeships, and companies are adopting non-geographic models to hire remote workers. This shift is driven by the changing nature of the software business, which favors collaboration and teamwork over technical expertise. As a result, companies are finding ways to create their own supply of workers, holding down costs and limiting wage gains for technology firms.

site_title: J Lo and A-Rod help Bronx kids live the American real estate dream
summary: Jennifer Lopez and Alex Rodriguez have launched "Project Destined," a real estate program for 50 Bronx students, aiming to teach them the ins and outs of financing and real estate. The students will compete to develop a $1.5 million building in the Bronx, with the winning team becoming minority shareholders and receiving university tuition funding. The program, sponsored by J Lo and A-Rod, aims to provide a pathway to wealth and ownership for students from low-income backgrounds, with the goal of putting owners and stakeholders in their communities.

site_title: Koh Brothers unit wins bid for Toho Mansion
summary: Koh Brothers' subsidiary, KBD Ventures, has won the en bloc tender for Toho Mansion on Holland Road for S$120.43 million, with an average price of S$1,805 per square foot per plot ratio. The freehold site can be redeveloped to a project with a potential gross floor area of 6,818.7 sq m. The site is zoned for residential use and enjoys a high development baseline with no development charge. Koh Brothers plans to redevelop the property and expand its development portfolio in Singapore, with plans to launch the project at an opportune time to capitalize on the up cycle in the residential sector.

site_title: Far from home and censors, some Chinese students dissent on Xi's power
summary: Chinese students in the US have begun to speak out against President Xi Jinping's proposed indefinite term limit, sparking a wave of protests at several colleges. Posters bearing the slogan "NeverMyPresident" appeared at universities such as New York University and the University of California, San Diego, expressing dissent against Xi's rule. The protests, largely driven by students from the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars, reflect growing dissent among Chinese citizens and a willingness to speak out publicly despite government censorship.

site_title: Shell waiting to jump into Indonesia small-scale LNG industry
summary: Shell, a leading energy company, is poised to enter Indonesia's small-scale LNG industry once the government establishes a framework. According to Steve Hill, Shell's executive vice-president, the company believes the economic viability of small-scale LNG is realistic and will be competitive with diesel in remote areas. However, the Indonesian government has yet to create a suitable regulatory environment. Despite this, Shell expects to be keen on entering the market once it becomes viable.

site_title: Disney shareholders throw out CEO's pay package as 'excessive'
summary: Disney shareholders rejected a compensation plan for CEO Bob Iger, worth up to $48.5 million annually and a $100 million equity grant, in a non-binding vote. The plan was tied to the company's planned $52.4 billion acquisition of 21st Century Fox assets. Fifty-two percent of shareholders voted against the plan, citing concerns over its magnitude. Despite this, Iger's continuation as CEO is seen as crucial for the Fox acquisition, with total shareholder return more than quadrupled during his tenure.

site_title: Waymo self-driving rigs to haul Google cargo
summary: Google-owned Waymo announced its self-driving trucks will haul cargo to its data centers in Georgia, starting a pilot program on Monday. The trucks will operate in the Atlanta area, with human drivers on board to take control if needed. This follows a similar announcement by rival Uber, which is using self-driving semi-trucks in Arizona. Waymo's technology is learning to drive big rigs in a similar way to human drivers, with the goal of improving safety and efficiency in the trucking industry.

site_title: Nasdaq surges to end at record after strong US jobs report
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, with the Nasdaq ending at a record high after a strong US jobs report and a summit announcement between the US and North Korea. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.8% to 7,560.81, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also advanced 1.8% and 1.7% respectively. The jobs report showed 313,000 new jobs added, with unemployment remaining steady at 4.1%, and moderating wage growth. The news boosted Wall Street sentiment and investor confidence, with shares of Netflix, Intel, and Alphabet rising.

site_title: The convoluted math behind the art fairs everyone loves to hate
summary: Art fairs, which originated in the 1970s, have become a crucial platform for galleries to sell art, driven by shifting demographics of wealth. These events allow collectors to discover multiple galleries and artists in a concentrated manner. Despite high entry fees, art fairs generate revenue primarily from booth rental fees, with some fairs also charging ticket sales and offering sponsorship opportunities. Non-profit fairs, such as the ADAA, use sponsorship revenue to support charitable causes. However, larger fairs, like Art Basel, face challenges in profitability due to high operating costs and depreciations.

site_title: Best Buy CEO says turnaround done, room to compete with Amazon
summary: Best Buy CEO Hubert Joly announced the company has completed a five-year turnaround and is ready to compete with Amazon, countering the notion that US retail is a "winner-takes-all" market. The retailer has invested in price-matching, faster delivery, and improved customer service to attract customers, resulting in its best sales in a decade and a 271% increase in its share price over the past five years. With about 15% of the US consumer electronics market, Best Buy believes there is room to grow alongside rival Amazon.

site_title: No partial offer for Datapulse, says Ascapia
summary: Singapore-based Ascapia Capital has decided not to pursue a partial takeover of drama-hit Datapulse Technology, citing an "absolute secrecy" rule in the takeover code. As a result, the company will not be able to launch an offer for Datapulse over the next six months. Datapulse's stock dropped to S$0.34 following the announcement, while the company's directors expressed relief and a commitment to expediting corporate and regulatory actions.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
Anita Gabriel

site_title: Gold off lows as US dollar slips on slowing US wage gains
summary: Gold prices rebounded from lows on Friday as the US dollar slipped, following slower-than-expected wage gains that may limit inflation increases this year. The US jobs growth data showed the biggest increase in 1-1/2 years, but slower wage gains tempered expectations of interest rate hikes. Gold prices remained unchanged, and US gold futures settled up 0.2%. The news of US President Donald Trump's meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong Un also supported gold prices, but the reaction was muted.

site_title: High-end flippers fuel art auctions
summary: High-end art auction houses Sotheby's and Christie's are experiencing a trend of reselling artworks multiple times in search of quick profits, with some pieces changing hands as many as five times in 16 years. This phenomenon, known as "flipping," is driven by increased demand from new collectors in Asia and a shift in viewing art as an investment, resulting in a shrinking ownership period. The resales are also fueled by changes in tax laws, making it harder for auction houses to sell artworks without incurring capital gains.

site_title: Goodluck Garden sold to Qingjian for S$610m
summary: Goodluck Garden, a 210-unit residential development in Singapore, has been sold collectively to the Qingjian Group of Companies for S$610 million. The sale price translates to a land price of about S$1,210 psf ppr, with a 10% bonus balcony, and 81.93% of owners consenting to the sale. The process took only six months, with Knight Frank Singapore marketing the project and receiving strong competitive bids. The sale price is the third largest en bloc deal this year, following Park West's S$841 million transaction and Pearl Bank Apartments' S$728 million transaction.

site_title: Goldilocks welcomes order for Noble to appoint IFA to assess revamp plan
summary: GOLDILOCKS Investment Co, a major shareholder of Noble Group, has welcomed the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) decision to require Noble to appoint an independent financial advisor (IFA) to assess its restructuring plan. The plan has been met with skepticism from minority shareholders, who claim it unfairly favors management and penalizes them. The SGX's move is seen as a response to minority shareholders' unhappiness, with GOLDILOCKS describing it as a "step in the right direction."

site_title: Trump's bellicosity secures diplomatic coup - for now
summary: US President Donald Trump has secured a diplomatic coup by negotiating with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, with talks set to take place before the end of May. The surprise announcement marked a significant shift in Trump's approach to the region, with experts praising the move as a potential breakthrough. However, questions remain about what Trump is prepared to offer in return for North Korea's nuclear disarmament, with some analysts warning of a lack of credibility and experience in international negotiation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIIC Environment has received in-principal approval from the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong for a dual primary listing, with trading expected to begin on March 23. The company has appointed Credit Suisse Securities as designated dealer and Haitong International Securities as alternate designated dealer for the bridging arrangements. This move aims to migrate shares to Hong Kong, expanding the company's presence in the Chinese territory.

site_title: Sans US, smaller CPTPP gains, but it will still lift members' trade
summary: Singapore's Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has unlocked opportunities for the country's firms, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The 11-member trade pact will provide substantial elimination of tariffs and non-tariff barriers, improved access for service suppliers, and greater facilitation of investments. Moody's projects a 2.7% boost to Singapore's real national income in 2030, making it the second-biggest winner after Malaysia. The pact is expected to benefit Singapore's exporters and service sector, particularly those interested in entering the markets of Canada, Mexico, Japan, and Australia.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: China ready to retaliate over Trump's tariffs
summary: China has vowed to retaliate against the US over newly imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum, with Foreign Minister Wang Yi calling the move a "mistaken prescription" that will be "harmful" to the global economy. The US has also announced plans to investigate China's intellectual property practices, which could have a significant impact on various industries. China is likely to respond with tariffs on selected US products or pressure on US firms operating in China, limiting the consequences to its domestic economy.

site_title: Brazil feels pain of US steel tariffs
summary: Brazil's iron and steel shares plummeted after the US imposed 25% tariffs on steel and 10% on aluminum, a move that could significantly impact Brazil's steel exports to the US. Foreign Minister Aloysio Nunes warned that Brazil would take "all necessary steps" to protect its rights and interests. The move could lead to a trade war and has raised concerns about the potential economic impact on Brazil.

images.alt_text: Brazilian iron and steel shares took a hit Friday, as markets weighed a potential trade war in response to Washington's decision to impose hefty tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum.

site_title: Wynn Resorts to pay US$2.6b to settle lawsuit with Japan's Universal
summary: Wynn Resorts has agreed to pay US$2.6 billion to settle a six-year-old lawsuit with Japan's Universal Entertainment Corp. The lawsuit stemmed from a 2012 forced redemption of a stake held by Universal's unit Aruze USA, with Universal accusing Wynn Resorts' board of breaching fiduciary duties and violating racketeering laws. The settlement resolves all claims between the parties, marking a conclusion to a dispute that pitted casino mogul Steve Wynn against his former associate Kazuo Okada.

site_title: Telcos: Economic, operational & regulatory factors
summary: The telecommunications sector is influenced by economic, operational, and regulatory factors. Key considerations for investors include price elasticity of demand, the impact of new-age services, and a company's market position. Competition, regulatory environment, and barriers to entry are also crucial. Long-term drivers include urbanisation, market penetration rates, and customer purchasing power. Performance metrics such as ARPU, subscriber additions, and churn rates are essential to gauge a telco's financial health. The sector's structure is changing, with increased competition from OTT services and the need for operators to stay relevant through technological advancements.

site_title: Bank of Singapore hires Anthony Simcic as managing director of int'l team
summary: Bank of Singapore has hired Anthony Simcic as managing director of its international team, effective March 12. Simcic brings over 18 years of banking experience to the role, reporting directly to Olivier Denis, global market head. This appointment is part of Bank of Singapore's expansion efforts.

site_title: US, China agree to keep pressure on North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to maintain pressure and sanctions on North Korea until the country takes tangible steps toward complete, verifiable, and irreversible denuclearization. The agreement came after Trump accepted an invitation to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un before the end of May. The White House stated that both leaders committed to maintaining pressure and sanctions until North Korea meets these conditions, a move aimed at preventing backsliding.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump enlisted the help of China's Xi Jinping to keep sanctions pressure on North Korea Friday, amid fears that an audacious diplomatic gambit by the US president could lead to backsliding.

site_title: US job growth surges in February
summary: US job growth surged in February with a 313,000 job increase, the largest since July 2016, and the unemployment rate remained at a 17-year low of 4.1%. Average hourly earnings edged up 0.1% to $26.75, a slowdown from January. The moderation in wage growth may temper expectations of a fourth interest rate hike this year, but economists still expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates at its March policy meeting.

images.alt_text: US job growth surged in February, recording its biggest increase in more than 1½ years, but a slowdown in wage gains pointed to a gradual increase in inflation this year.

site_title: Like it or not, the interview process is changing
summary: The interview process is evolving, with video interviews, job auditions, and virtual reality assessments becoming more popular among employers. According to a 2018 LinkedIn Talent Solutions report, traditional interviews can fall short in evaluating a candidate's capabilities, and new interview models are being used to assess soft skills, teamwork, and grit. Companies like Credit Suisse and LinkedIn are using video interviews to access a wider pool of candidates and increase diversity. While technology is changing the game, it's essential for job seekers to be tech-savvy and prepared for virtual interviews, with proper equipment and a professional environment.

site_title: The death of Goldilocks?
summary: The US has announced tariffs on steel and aluminium, sparking uncertainty and potential for a global trade war. The move, led by President Trump, has raised concerns about a domino effect and negative signalling towards a US-China trade war. Two scenarios are possible: a benign one-off move by Trump or a full-blown trade war. The markets are expected to remain volatile, with emerging markets potentially affected. The US is seeking concessions from trading partners in exchange for exemptions from the tariffs, which will depend on the price asked and whether partners believe it is a fair cost to pay.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realtors and investors are bracing for a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, which may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, while Manhattan rents hit a record and UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, and New World Group is selling its China property assets. WeWork has secured new tenants and filled space at its Singapore location.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hongkong Land Holdings reported a 5% increase in average rent for its Central office portfolio, with vacancy rates declining to 1.4%. Analysts believe the company's Central office portfolio will benefit from strong mainland demand and limited supply in the medium term. ComfortDelGro is expected to benefit from potential regulatory changes in the private-hire car services industry, while Dairy Farm International faces a strategic review that may impact its future performance. Hongkong Land is trading at a 52% discount to its peers.

site_title: iPhone assembler Foxconn gears up for China's biggest IPO since 2015
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese company and Apple's largest assembly partner, is set to make its initial public offering (IPO) in Shanghai, potentially becoming China's largest since 2015. The IPO aims to raise 27.3 billion yuan to fund projects in artificial intelligence and 5G wireless technologies, valuing the business at up to 400 billion yuan. The debut is seen as a significant move to attract capital from Taiwan and bring tech listings back to the mainland, with analysts estimating a share-price multiple of 15 to 19 times earnings.

site_title: Tanjong Katong bungalow market on a roll
summary: A string of large freehold bungalow deals have been sealed in the Tanjong Katong area in Singapore, with some transactions involving families already living in the area for redevelopment. The deals were sealed in Boscombe, Branksome, Lyndhurst, Wilkinson, and Arthur roads, with buyers opting for the area over other prime districts due to its convenience and existing community.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Economic agencies have flexibility to let in needed foreign skills
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say has announced that economic agencies can exercise flexibility in allowing companies to hire foreign professionals, but with conditions. Companies must focus on developing local workers with required skills and comply with the Fair Consideration Framework, which prioritizes Singaporean workers. The government aims to balance short-term talent needs with long-term dependency on foreign manpower. The minister emphasized the importance of building local capabilities and transforming the economy, while also supporting businesses in their efforts to grow and transform.

site_title: Asia's biggest exporters bristle over new US tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, sparking warnings of trade wars and damage to relations from major Asian nations. Japan, China, and South Korea expressed strong opposition, with China labeling the move "resolutely opposed" and South Korea considering a WTO complaint. Industry calls for retaliation were made, raising concerns about the impact on bilateral ties and global trade.

site_title: SGX's healthcare stocks' rebound continues into Q1 this year
summary: Singapore's 10 largest healthcare counters by market capitalisation have averaged a 12.1% price gain and 15.3% total return over the last 12 months, outperforming the SGX All Healthcare Index and the Straits Times Index. The sector's rebound is attributed to investors seeking refuge in defensive plays during periods of global volatility. With Asia's healthcare spending levels expected to increase, SGX-listed healthcare stocks are poised to benefit from the growing patient needs.

site_title: US job growth surged in Feb
summary: US job growth surged in February with a 313,000 jobs increase, the largest in over 1-1/2 years, as construction jobs rose by 61,000. Average hourly earnings edged up 0.1% to $26.75, but at a slower pace than January. The unemployment rate remained at 4.1%, a 17-year low, while the labor force participation rate rose to 63.0%. Despite a slowdown in wage growth, economists expect the unemployment rate to fall to 3.5% this year, and the Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates at its March meeting.

site_title: Grab launches region's first bike-sharing marketplace
summary: Grab has launched GrabCycle, the region's first bike-sharing marketplace, in Singapore. The app unites bike and e-scooter sharing services on one platform, partnering with oBike, GBikes, Anywheel, and Popscoot. GrabCycle aims to improve mobility in cities and re-design public spaces for bike-sharing and personal mobility options. The platform is expected to roll out regionally, with Grab studying commuting patterns and data to identify new cycling pathways and common parking spots.

site_title: Holiday resorts and their killjoy rules
summary: Luxury hotels are implementing strict rules to maintain their brand image, often at the expense of guest comfort and memories. Some resorts ban photos, restrict casual attire, and prohibit technology in public areas. Examples include the COMO Shambhala in Bali, which prohibits professional photography, and Chiva-Som, which has a no-technology policy. While these rules are intended to preserve quality and exclusivity, they can be seen as overly restrictive and may deter guests from returning. The trend raises questions about the balance between luxury and accessibility in the hospitality industry.

site_title: Short cuts
summary: DBS Bank's web series "DBS Sparks" has garnered over 100 million views and 11 million digital likes, shares, and comments since its rollout in 2016. The series, which features two fictional bankers navigating complex financial situations, is an example of "microcinema" – short-form content that tells a story and taps people's penchant for stories. Brands are shifting towards this approach, finding that it creates emotional connections and avoids interruptive advertising. The campaign has led to a 5.6% increase in new acquisitions for the SME and consumer business in Hong Kong, and DBS plans to continue investing in digital brand storytelling.

images.alt_text: SHORT CUTS: How brands have found a direct route to customers with video storytelling.

DBS Sparks' brand storytelling campaign (above) directed by David Tsui from Hong Kong (who shot the cinematic series of Solvil et Titus commercials), does not peddle promotional loan rates, opting to illustrate its slogan, "Live more, bank less".
Bobo's Three Wishes' campaign (above) features a "fish deity" called Lord Yellowtail.
Home Team's video about a bomb blast in a mall, directed by Singaporean filmmaker Boo Junfeng, mimics a CGI-packed action thriller.

"Stories work so well that people don't skip them but share them instead. The engagement around these stories is pretty amazing. To the client, their investment in the content production and marketing is also more justified." - Co-founder of short film content platform Viddsee, Derek Tan

"Almost every filmmaker in Singapore, be it your Eric (Khoo), Royston (Tan), (Boo) Junfeng, even Jack (Neo), in the early days of their careers, all started out doing short films. Now, clients and advertising agencies will pay them to do short-form content." - Gary Goh, Singapore GM of Double M, the commercial production division of mm2 Entertainment.

site_title: India's top court allows 'living wills' for terminally ill
summary: India's top court approved the use of "living wills" for terminally ill patients, allowing them to refuse medical treatment and hasten their death. The ruling, seen as "historic," enables families of patients in permanent vegetative states to withdraw life support according to the patient's wishes. The court's guidelines, set to prevail until legislation is enacted, recognize the right to refuse care under controlled conditions, joining a growing list of countries that permit living wills, including Britain, France, Germany, and Spain.

site_title: STI ends flat on trade war fears
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat on March 9, 2018, despite a positive news of the US and North Korea's first summit, which is expected to take place by May. The US and North Korea's agreement to stop nuclear and missile testing boosted regional market sentiment, but was overshadowed by China's 13th National People's Congress and the US tariffs on steel and aluminium, excluding Canada and Mexico. The STI closed 5.13 points higher, or 0.15%, after trading 1.7 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: SPH, Singapore Polytechnic announce tie-up to co-create video content for advertisers
summary: SPH and Singapore Polytechnic (SP) have announced a collaboration to co-create video content for advertisers, specifically targeting millennials in the fashion and beauty space. DMC students will be mentored by content specialists from SPH's Content Lab, conceptualizing and producing videos in dedicated spaces. The content will be based on concepts proposed by students and will provide a new medium for advertisers to reach younger audiences.

site_title: Government to split Air India's debt ahead of stake sale
summary: India plans to split Air India's $8.5 billion debt into sustainable and unsustainable debt, transferring the unsustainable part to a special purpose vehicle before selling a stake in the state-owned carrier. The government has decided to sell the loss-making airline, citing its debt burden and bloated cost structure. Initial bids for Air India are expected to be invited in the coming weeks, with companies such as IndiGo, Tata Group, and Celebi Aviation Holdings expressing interest in buying some of the airline's operations.

site_title: A remarkable piece of diplomacy and a win for free trade
summary: The Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has been signed in Chile, marking a significant step forward for free trade among 11 Pacific Rim nations. The pact aims to boost exports by 6% by 2030 and bring economic gains of $157 billion to its members. Key benefits include the elimination of tariffs, improved labor and environmental standards, and enhanced data movement and service exchange. The agreement is expected to have a positive impact on businesses, particularly in the shipping, logistics, and electronics sectors, with Singapore expected to see a 6.2% boost in exports by 2030.

images.alt_text: The signing in Chile of the new trade pact between 11 Pacific Rim nations is a harbinger for the 500 million individuals and businesses within the countries it serves.

site_title: Commodities are casualties of US deficit
summary: The US's massive debt, reaching $20.6 trillion, is affecting global commodities, particularly gold and oil. Gold has shown weak trending activity, with prices trading within a broad band between $1,210 and $1,350. A potential breakout above $1,350 may not hold, with the current consolidation using $1,350 as a resistance level. In contrast, oil's trading band around $11 wide, with support near $43 and resistance near $54, suggests a potential upside target of $76. The debt-induced symptoms are also expected to continue, with the world likely funding the US deficit through the purchase of US Treasuries.

site_title: Triyards' CFO leaves cash-strapped yard group
summary: TRIYARDS Holdings announced the resignation of its CFO, Yan Naing Aung, effective March 28, 2018. Aung was responsible for the group's corporate financial matters. The cash-strapped yard group had previously announced the termination of a shipbuilding order and was seeking additional time to file its first-quarter financial results. This move comes amidst the company's financial struggles, which include a shipbuilding order cancellation and a delay in filing financial results. The reasons behind Aung's departure are unclear, but the resignation is the latest in a series of personnel changes at the company.

site_title: Bitcoin's bad week gets worse as selloff deepens to 20%
summary: Bitcoin fell 4.9% to US$8,875.60, marking a 20% decline for the week, amid increased regulatory scrutiny in the US and Japan, a theft at a major trading venue, and Mt Gox's bankruptcy trustee selling the exchange's holdings.

site_title: UBS boosts compensation for CEO and staff after profit rises
summary: UBS Group AG has boosted its CEO Sergio Ermotti's pay to 14.2 million Swiss francs, up from 13.7 million francs in 2016. The bank also increased its bonus pool by about 6% to 3.1 billion francs, citing strong financial results and a maintained capital position. This comes after a year of competition from other industries and a "tricky year" for compensation in the industry, according to Andrea Orcel, head of UBS's investment bank.

site_title: Hedge funds tripling short bets grab market attention in Denmark
summary: Denmark's financial watchdog welcomes a surge in hedge fund short bets on Danish stocks, which have tripled in value over the past five years. The regulator views short selling as healthy, as it improves pricing accuracy and adds liquidity to the market. Despite a ban on short bets against Danish banks during the financial crisis, the regulator now regards such speculation as beneficial. This trend is part of a global increase in short interest, driven by the growth of alternative investing vehicles in hedge funds.

site_title: Hwa Hong buys stake in firm that is buying London property for £15m
summary: Hwa Hong Corporation has acquired a 50% stake in Loman Holdings for £50 (S$91) to invest in London's commercial property market. Loman Holdings owns Capital Loman, which has signed an agreement to buy a £14.85 million freehold property in the Southbank area for £14.85 million. The investment aims to expand Hwa Hong's portfolio and generate recurrent rental income and capital appreciation. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to earnings per share but not material for the company's financial year ending December 2018.

site_title: Magnus Energy to raise S$1.18m from placement of 1.31b new shares
summary: Magnus Energy Group is issuing 1.31 billion new shares at 0.09 Singapore cent apiece to raise S$1.18 million. The placement aims to bolster its working capital and fund business growth. The shares represent 10.37% of the company's enlarged share base. Key subscribers include oil contractor Blue Water Engineering, alternative-investments firm Idola Cakrawala International, and individuals such as Chung See Mooi and Charles Madhavan. The proceeds will be used for general working capital and a microalgae plant nearing completion.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat
summary: Singapore shares ended flat on Friday due to uncertainty over US trade tariffs on steel and aluminium imports. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.15% to 3,485.57, despite a boost from Creative Technology's 10.7% gain, driven by positive reviews for its Super X-Fi system. The market was also influenced by mixed signals from the US Federal Reserve, with investors holding onto shares ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: South Korea to consider WTO complaint over US steel tariffs
summary: South Korea plans to ask the US for an exemption from President Trump's new 25% steel tariffs and consider filing a complaint to the World Trade Organization (WTO) if denied. The tariffs, imposed on foreign steel and aluminum, are expected to deal a serious blow to South Korea's steel exports to the US, with a potential 22% cut in exports worth almost $1 billion. South Korea is a treaty ally of the US and is renegotiating a free trade agreement. The country will seek consultations with the US Trade Representative and consider WTO action if unsuccessful.

site_title: Muslims pray under military protection in Sri Lanka after riots
summary: Tensions in Sri Lanka escalated after four days of riots targeting Muslims, leaving at least three dead and 140 arrested. The violence, sparked by the death of a Sinhalese man at the hands of a Muslim, resulted in nearly 200 Muslim businesses and homes destroyed, including 11 mosques. The government declared a state of emergency and deployed troops to guard mosques, while social media was blocked to curb hate speech. The country's tourism industry suffered significant losses, with hotel occupancy rates dropping to 30% due to the unrest.

site_title: EU set to add Bahamas, US Virgin Islands to tax haven blacklist
summary: The European Union is set to add the Bahamas, US Virgin Islands, and Saint Kitts and Nevis to its blacklist of tax havens, bringing the total to nine jurisdictions. EU finance ministers are expected to endorse the decision at a meeting on Tuesday, while Bahrain, the Marshall Islands, and Saint Lucia will be delisted. The blacklist maintains strict controls on financial transactions with the EU, while jurisdictions on the grey list, which includes dozens of countries, will be monitored for compliance with EU anti-tax avoidance standards.

site_title: Eunos Mansion sold en-bloc for S$220 million
summary: A unit of Fragrance Group has purchased the freehold Eunos Mansion in a collective sale for S$220 million, with each unit expected to receive between S$1.48 million to S$4.7 million. The 111,735 sq ft site has a plot ratio of 1.6 and is close to the Paya Lebar Regional Centre and business parks, making it suitable for a mid-sized condominium project. The sale does not require development charges due to its high development baseline.

site_title: Medicine is getting personal
summary: Pharmacogenomics, the study of how genes affect a person's response to drugs, is expected to revolutionize medical treatment by providing tailored and accurate prescriptions. By analyzing a patient's genetic makeup, doctors can choose the best-fit drug and dosage, reducing adverse reactions and hospitalizations. The US FDA has already begun recommending genetic testing for certain medications, and several countries have established guidelines for pharmacogenomic testing. As DNA sequencing costs decline, personalized medicine is expected to become more widespread, enabling doctors to make informed decisions about treatment and potentially saving patients time and money.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.30 points to 1,843.92 on Friday, with 491 gainers outnumbering 459 losers. The index closed at RM2.01 billion in volume.

site_title: Clash of the Reds at Old Trafford
summary: Manchester United and Liverpool face off in a crucial English Premier League match at Old Trafford, with the second-placed Red Devils holding a 2-point advantage over the team from Merseyside. The match is a must-win for both teams, with Manchester City leading the title chase and a four-horse race for the league's runner-up spot. Liverpool, in rich form, boasts a lethal strikeforce led by Mohamed Salah and Roberto Firmino, while Manchester United's powerful striker Romelu Lukaku and midfielder Jesse Lingard look to give their team the edge.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Jumbo to include Hong Kong's "Tsui Wah" brand in its portfolio
summary: Jumbo Group has signed a joint venture agreement with Tsui Wah Holdings to expand the Hong Kong-style "Cha Chaan Teng" under the "Tsui Wah" brand into Singapore. The 49:51 joint venture will use Tsui Wah's trademarks and trade names, and will be funded by Jumbo's internal resources. This marks Tsui Wah's first entry into the South-east Asian consumer market, with 70 outlets in Hong Kong, Macau, and China. The introduction of "Tsui Wah" in Singapore is expected to bring the brand's global presence to 71 locations.

site_title: Scope for 'selective' flexibility in foreign manpower policy: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say has proposed flexibility in the foreign manpower policy to address talent shortages, particularly in tech sectors. Companies can bring in foreign workers with skills in demand globally but lacking in Singapore, as long as they consider local workers. However, the criteria for Employment Passes have been made more stringent. The government aims to make the economy more manpower-lean and encourage companies to attract and retain better workers. Lim emphasized the need for long-term capabilities and urged businesses to balance short-term growth with long-term development.

site_title: Wilmar beefs up stake in Shree Renuka Sugars to 39%, triggering open offer
summary: Wilmar International has increased its stake in Shree Renuka Sugars to 39% after subscribing to 481.8 million compulsorily convertible preference shares at 16.28 Indian rupees per share. Wilmar also converted its CCPS into common equity shares, and as part of a debt restructuring package, lenders converted a part of SRSL's bank debts into common equity shares. An open offer has been made for the acquisition of up to 26% of SRSL's emerging equity share capital at 16.29 rupees per share from public shareholders, with the open offer price 0.01 rupees higher than the subscription price.

site_title: Petronas plans to upgrade Kerteh refinery by 2022
summary: Petronas plans to upgrade its Kerteh refinery in Malaysia by 2022 to produce higher quality fuels and expand the types of crude it processes. The refinery aims to switch from light sweet Tapis crude to medium-sweet Kimanis and other grades. The upgrade will allow the refinery to meet Euro V standard specifications, but its capacity will remain unchanged. The refinery's primary units will be modified to accommodate the new crude processing.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:

Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half of the year, citing an operating loss similar to the first half.
