summary: Asian markets declined for the second consecutive day, led by Hong Kong's 1% drop, as investors worry about a global trade war sparked by US President Donald Trump's steel and aluminum tariffs. Tokyo and Shanghai also fell, with the US dollar under pressure due to trade war concerns. The US dollar's decline was attributed to Trump's "American First" protectionist drive, with officials from Beijing to Brussels expressing concerns. The Shanghai stock market set a 2018 economic growth target of 6.5%, lower than the previous year's 6.9%.

site_title: Temasek to hold roundtable on governance and ethics with portfolio companies in wake of Keppel bribery scandal
summary: Temasek Holdings will hold a roundtable discussion with its portfolio companies to strengthen governance models in the wake of the Keppel Corporation bribery scandal. Chairman Lim Boon Heng emphasized the need for companies to address corruption beyond bribery, including price-fixing and collusion. The roundtable aims to help companies improve their governance and ethics, following the scandal that led to Keppel's offshore and marine division being suspended. The discussion is part of Temasek's efforts to promote integrity and compliance within its portfolio companies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Almost 2,500 GM Korea workers apply for voluntary redundancy package
summary: Almost 2,500 workers at GM Korea, equivalent to 15% of its staff, have applied for a voluntary redundancy package as the company undergoes drastic restructuring. The package, offered to those who applied by March 2, includes three times their annual base salary, college tuition, and over $9,000 towards a new car. The US carmaker aims to cut 5,000 South Korean jobs but maintain production if Seoul agrees to its $2.8 billion proposal. The South Korean government is set to start due diligence on GM Korea this week, weighing whether to rescue the unit with taxpayers' money.

images.alt_text: GM shocked South Korea last month when it said it was closing down one plant and would decide on the fate of three others in the coming weeks - decisions that hang on potential financial support from Seoul and the amount of concessions it can gain from unions.

site_title: Neymar leaves hospital by helicopter for recovery
summary: Brazilian soccer star Neymar left a hospital by helicopter on March 4, 2018, after a successful foot operation, marking the beginning of his recovery ahead of the World Cup. The 26-year-old Paris Saint-Germain forward will not start training for at least six weeks. His recovery will be monitored by Brazil and PSG physiotherapists, with the possibility of returning to play in May if his team makes it to the Champions League semi-finals. Neymar's operation was successful, with a fractured fifth metatarsal in his right foot.

images.alt_text: Brazilian superstar Neymar left hospital by helicopter on Sunday, a day after a successful foot operation, to begin his recovery ahead of a possible World Cup return.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.44 points to 1,853.63. The market saw 55.59 million lots traded worth RM14.53 million, with 108 gainers and 56 losers.

site_title: Port automation imperative for Singapore: Kalmar
summary: Kalmar, a port equipment supplier, emphasizes the importance of automation for Singapore's port operations to attract large box ships and major shipping lines. The development of the Tuas mega port project presents a huge business opportunity for port equipment suppliers, with Kalmar participating in the tenders for automated guided vehicles (AGVs). The use of all-electric equipment not only improves service consistency but also reduces environmental impact and operational costs. However, cost remains a significant stumbling block in port automation, with prices currently being twice as high as traditional equipment.

site_title: Australia: US tariffs, Italian election weigh on shares; NZ stocks higher
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Monday, weighed down by proposed US tariffs on steel and aluminum, and uncertainty over Italy's hung parliament. US stock futures declined amid fears of a global trade war, affecting Asian stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,905.9.

site_title: Oscars host Kimmel takes on Hollywood sexism
summary: Comedian Jimmy Kimmel addressed sexism in Hollywood during the Oscars, criticizing the industry's handling of the Harvey Weinstein scandal. He stated that the world is watching and that the Oscars must set an example to stop sexual harassment. Kimmel highlighted the work of the #MeToo and Time's Up campaigns and noted that only 11% of movies are made by women. He also made light of the era, joking about the Oscar statuette and referencing President Donald Trump. Kimmel celebrated milestones, including the debut film of Jordan Peele and the oldest acting nominee, Christopher Plummer.

images.alt_text: Comedian Jimmy Kimmel on Sunday took aim at sexism in Hollywood and disgraced movie mogul Harvey Weinstein as he opened the Oscars on an unusually serious note - albeit with a traditional dose of jokes.

site_title: China to raise defence budget by 8.1% in 2018: Xinhua
summary: China's 2018 defence budget will increase by 8.1% to 1.26 trillion yuan, according to a report by the official Xinhua news agency. The budget boost is the same as last year's and reflects China's economy transitioning from rapid growth to high-quality development. The move is seen as a strategic shift to strengthen the country's military capabilities amid rising global competition.

site_title: Pay as you build
summary: Singapore's infrastructure funding plans aim to balance government borrowing and private sector involvement. Experts agree that leveraging debt funding can reduce the need for tapping national reserves and spread the development cost across different generations. Issuing infrastructure bonds by government agencies can impose market discipline and deepen the local capital markets. The "save and borrow" approach is seen as a prudent and practical strategy to future-proof the country's infrastructure and boost economic prospects. Experts emphasize the need for a well-structured debt financing plan, government assurance, and a clear revenue model to benefit both the public and private sectors.

site_title: Eni and Shell go on trial over Nigeria kickback scandal
summary: Oil giants Eni and Shell are going on trial in Milan, charged with bribery and corruption in the 2011 purchase of an offshore oilfield in Nigeria, OPL245, valued at $1.3 billion. Eni CEO Claudio Descalzi and others face the charges, which allege that bribes were paid to Nigerian officials, including former president Goodluck Jonathan and oil minister Dan Etete. Both companies deny the charges, with Eni stating its confidence in the judicial process. The trial comes amid Nigeria's efforts to combat corruption, led by President Muhammadu Buhari.

site_title: Canada's Saputo considers milk plant sale to appease Australian regulator
summary: Canada's Saputo Inc is considering the sale of a milk plant in Victoria state to address concerns from Australia's competition watchdog about its buyout of Murray Goulburn Co-operative. The deal, valued up to A$490 million, may leave some Victorian farmers with limited choice when selling their milk. Saputo has initiated discussions with the ACCC to address the concerns and obtain clearance. A rival, Bega Cheese Ltd, has expressed interest in the Koroit plant, and Murray Goulburn has agreed to work closely with Saputo and the ACCC to seek approval of the asset sale.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI maintains 'buy' on Cityneon, raises target price on strong FY17, future growth
summary: KGI Securities maintains its "buy" rating on Cityneon Holdings with a raised 12-month target price of S$1.54, citing strong FY17 earnings and potential future growth. The company's FY17 net profit exceeded expectations, driven by its intellectual property (IP) rights segment, which saw revenue grow 187% year-on-year. KGI also expects Cityneon to benefit from a potential acquisition and higher margins due to its move up the value chain from building and construction services to providing design services.

site_title: Euro edges up in choppy trade after Italian exit polls
summary: The euro edged up 0.27% to US$1.2350 after Italian exit polls showed a hung parliament but no single party had enough seats to form government. A centre-right coalition is expected to win most seats, with the eurosceptic 5-Star Movement falling short of an absolute majority. The outcome was seen as a relief, contributing to a brief dip in the euro before it rebounded.

site_title: Singapore business confidence rises for 2nd straight quarter: SCCB
summary: Singapore business confidence rose for the second consecutive quarter in Q2 2018, with the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB) index jumping to +8.50 percentage points. The services and transportation sectors were the most upbeat, while the manufacturing sector weakened, with only three indicators in positive territory. The construction sector was the most downbeat, with only two indicators in the positive region. This improvement in business confidence is a positive sign for the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Ryobi Kiso opens geotechnical engineering and industrial tech centre in Singapore
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings has launched a geotechnical engineering and industrial technology centre in Singapore, focusing on developing deep industrial technology capabilities in areas such as geotechnical engineering and heavy machinery. The centre aims to solve engineering challenges, promote sustainable construction, and raise productivity. With support from the Singapore Economic Development Board, the company plans to develop a core group of ground engineering specialists with expertise in digital technologies, and create a pipeline of highly specialised digital talent to push the development of new capabilities and solutions for the ground engineering sector.

site_title: EU plans to tax 2-6% of tech giants' sales: French economy minister
summary: The European Union plans to unveil a directive within weeks taxing 2-6% of tech giants' sales, with French economy minister Bruno Le Maire stating it will be closer to 2%. The tax aims to capture the true value created in the region by companies like Amazon, Facebook, and Google. The EU is considering taxing revenue instead of earnings due to differing country rules. This move follows EU countries' efforts to tax these companies in a fair and consistent manner.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on lingering trade war fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday due to lingering trade war fears, with steelmakers and exporters falling. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.43% to 21,091.13, while the Topix index dropped 0.44% to 1,700.76. The decline was attributed to ongoing worries about a potential trade war, despite US stocks reaching fresh records earlier in the day.

site_title: Memories Group inks 1.3b kyat deal for luxury yacht business in Myanmar
summary: Memories Group, a Myanmar-based tourism company, has signed a deal to buy luxury yachting business Burma Boating for 1.3 billion kyat (S$1.3 million). This is the company's first acquisition since its debut in January 2018, and is part of an expansion plan to grow its presence in Myanmar's tourism market. The acquisition is earnings accretive and aims to increase the company's footprint in the country's tourism industry.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: 5-Star will be pillar of Italian government if exit polls confirmed": MP
summary: Italy's 5-Star Movement, led by Luigi Di Maio, is expected to be a central pillar of the next government if exit polls confirm its large lead, according to a party lawmaker. The party is expected to be the largest party, but a centre-right coalition led by former prime minister Silvio Berlusconi is likely to win the most seats.

site_title: Days of tax cuts are finished in UK, think-tank warns
summary: The UK's tax cutting era is over, according to the Resolution Foundation think tank. A surge in healthcare costs due to an aging population is expected to increase spending by 20 billion pounds by 2030 and 60 billion pounds by 2040. The think tank's chair, David Willetts, warns that baby-boomers will need to contribute more to the system, potentially through higher wealth taxes or increased taxes on basic rates. Politicians will need to implement reforms to address the issue, or risk cutting access to the National Health Service and exacerbating social care crises.

site_title: China warns Taiwan it won't tolerate separatist activities
summary: China has warned Taiwan that it will not tolerate any separatist activities and will safeguard China's territorial integrity, according to Premier Li Keqiang. China has been infuriated by a US bill that aims to increase official contacts with Taiwan, and has been increasing warnings about the risk of war. China considers democratic Taiwan to be a wayward province and integral part of "one China", and has never renounced the use of force to bring the island under its control. The US bill only needs President Trump's signature to become law, which could further strain relations between the two nations.

site_title: DeClout to step up investments, slash CEO's pay and 'right-size' some departments in turnaround plan
summary: DeClout, a CATALIST-listed infocomm technology company, has announced a turnaround plan in response to its first net loss. The company will slash CEO's pay by 40%, reduce senior management and managers' pay by 20%, freeze staff salaries, and "right-size" certain departments. This move aims to reduce corporate expenses by at least 20% in FY2018, from S$7.6 million in FY2017. The plan is expected to cut costs and improve the company's financial performance.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Stocks to watch: DeClout, Memories Group, AEM Holdings, KLW Holdings
summary: DeClout announced four strategic initiatives, including expanding data-based revenue streams, to pare losses and return to profitability. Memories Group acquired Burma Boating for 1.3 billion kyat, expanding its luxury yachting business in southern Myanmar. AEM Holdings secured new long-only institutional and family funds as shareholders, with its largest shareholder selling a 6% stake. KLW Holdings struck a deal to pay 35.3 billion rupiah for a plot of land in South Jakarta to turn into a mixed-use development.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Australia job advertisements dip 0.3% in Feb: ANZ survey
summary: Australian job advertisements dipped 0.3% in February, following a 6.2% rise in January, according to a survey by Australia and New Zealand Banking Group. Despite this, the average number of job ads per week remained 13.3% higher than a year ago, indicating healthy demand for labor. The jobless rate fell to 5.5% and business conditions remain elevated, with the Reserve Bank of Australia expected to keep interest rates at 1.5% due to contained inflation and wage growth at 2.1%.

images.alt_text: Australian job advertisements in newspapers and on the internet eased only slightly in February after boasting their biggest rise in a decade the previous month, a solid result that pointed to still-healthy demand for labour.

site_title: YouTube disciplines right-wing channels as it steps up moderation efforts
summary: YouTube has stepped up moderation efforts, disciplining prominent right-wing channels and conspiracy theorists, including Mike Cernovich and Infowars, for violating its community guidelines. The company has issued strikes to over a dozen accounts, with some being terminated for hate speech, nudity, or graphic content. YouTube denies the actions are ideologically driven, stating that accounts are removed based on policies, but critics argue the site is reacting to negative attention. The company is hiring more moderators to address the issue of misinformation, but experts say more training is needed to handle nuanced videos.

site_title: At joke-filled dinner, Trump suggests US will meet with North Korea
summary: President Donald Trump suggested the US will meet with North Korea, but emphasized Pyongyang must "denuke" first. He made the comment during a joke-filled dinner with journalists, stating "we will be meeting and we'll see if anything positive happens." However, a senior US administration official clarified that Trump did not receive a direct call from North Korea. The US-North Korea talks would be the first between the Trump administration and Pyongyang, amid a standoff over North Korea's nuclear development.

images.alt_text: In the midst of a joke-filled monologue at a dinner with journalists, President Donald Trump suggested on Saturday that the United States will be meeting with North Korea but has told Pyongyang it must first"denuke."

site_title: Fall in bitcoin transactions raises questions about its popularity
summary: Bitcoin transactions have declined significantly, with daily transactions dropping by half from December highs and reaching a two-year low in February. This has raised concerns among investors, with some predicting a bear market. Experts attribute the decline to a cooling hype cycle, but others believe it's a sign of the market maturing. The decline in transactions may also be due to the increasing popularity of alternative cryptocurrencies, with some websites now accepting a wider range of digital currencies.

site_title: China's parliament opens focused on Xi power play
summary: China's National People's Congress (NPC) opened on Monday, marking the start of a two-week session aimed at expanding President Xi Jinping's power and potentially paving the way for a lifetime of rule. The session will see the removal of the two-term limit for the presidency, enshrining Xi's name in the state constitution, and the creation of a new national anti-corruption agency. Analysts warn that the move risks ending a "collective" model of leadership, maintaining stability after Mao's reign. The NPC is expected to approve the amendments, but some legislators may voice displeasure through abstentions or opposition to key appointments.

site_title: Two dead, one missing after avalanches in French Alps
summary: Avalanches in the French Alps have claimed two lives and left one missing, with three others still trapped. The incidents occurred in separate areas, including the Vallorcines resort and the Tarentaise Valley, while four skiers were killed in a similar avalanche in the Mercantour National park. Interior Minister Gerard Collomb warned of the dangers of off-piste skiing, urging caution and following local signs to avoid putting oneself in danger.

site_title: China a step closer to rolling out nationwide social credit system
summary: China is moving closer to implementing a nationwide social credit system, which will assign scores to citizens based on their financial activity, university diplomas, internet behavior, and other factors. Those with low scores will face "punishments" and reduced access to public and private services. The system aims to promote trust-keeping and distinguish good from bad behavior, but human rights groups warn of potential privacy violations and misuse of personal data. The government plans to merge best practices from existing trial systems and roll out a national scheme in the coming years.

site_title: UK factories start 2018 well, helped by European demand: EEF
summary: British manufacturing showed resilience at the start of 2018, with output near historic highs and strong confidence among factories. The EEF manufacturers' association and BDO reported a slight cooling of momentum from last year, but factories remain on track to contribute to British economic growth in 2018. Strong demand from European customers, particularly two-thirds of manufacturers, helped the sector, despite uncertainty over Brexit and rising factory price pressures. The outcome of Brexit negotiations will impact the sector's outlook.

site_title: S Korea sending envoys to N Korea as Trump suggests US willing to talk
summary: South Korea announced a two-day visit by senior security officials to North Korea, amid US President Donald Trump's hint at being willing to talk to Pyongyang. North Korea denounced upcoming joint US-South Korean military exercises, warning it would take counter measures against the US if they proceed. The visit comes as tensions between the US and North Korea remain high, with the US-South Korea exercises set to take place in the coming days.

site_title: Key US lawmaker urges steel tariff exemptions for Nafta allies
summary: US Representative Kevin Brady urged exemptions for steel and aluminum from Canada and Mexico, citing fair trade, amid escalating tensions over President Trump's proposed tariffs. Brady, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, expressed hope for a Nafta deal and said the US should consider exemptions for other countries as well. Canada and Mexico have threatened retaliation, while the EU has vowed 25% tariffs on US imports if Trump proceeds with the tariffs. The US and its North American allies are set to meet on Monday to discuss the tariffs.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Drawing from reserves to fund healthcare will deplete 'precious nest egg': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the country cannot draw from its reserves to fund healthcare spending, as it would deplete its "precious nest egg." Instead, the government plans to raise the Goods and Services Tax (GST) by two percentage points to 9% by 2025 to fund increased healthcare spending. Lee emphasized the need for long-term planning, saying the government has done the responsible thing by being transparent about its plans and tax increases.

site_title: US oil & gas industry slams Trump's steel tariff plans
summary: The US oil and gas industry has strongly opposed President Donald Trump's plan to impose 25% tariffs on steel imports and 10% on aluminum imports, citing potential job losses and increased costs for pipeline projects. Industry groups, including the Association of Oil Pipe Lines and the American Petroleum Institute, warned that the tariffs could lead to a trade war with China and harm US jobs. A study by the Association of Oil Pipe Lines found that a 25% increase in pipeline costs could add $76 million to a typical project budget.

site_title: Vietnam seeks to pacify China as US carrier visit signals warming ties
summary: A US aircraft carrier, the USS Carl Vinson, visited Vietnam for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War, signaling growing strategic ties between the former foes. The visit aims to ease concerns of Vietnam's giant neighbor, China, over the disputed South China Sea. Vietnamese diplomats have been working to maintain stable ties with China while standing up to it. The visit marks the biggest US military presence in Vietnam since 1975 and comes amid efforts to deter China's growing military presence in the region.

site_title: Employers to get more flexi-work help: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's government will provide an enhanced WorkPro Work-Life Grant, worth S$30 million over two years, to support family-friendly workplaces with flexible work arrangements. Employers can receive up to S$2,000 for each worker on a flexible work arrangement, with a higher grant of up to S$3,500 for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) engaging in job sharing. The changes aim to encourage more women to stay in the workforce, as most prefer to remain employed or rejoin the workforce at the earliest opportunity.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: That S$4.5b MAS contribution
summary: Singapore sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. A new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for tariff-hit businesses. The country also has opportunities to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Meanwhile, workers are advised to future-proof their careers before a crisis strikes, with better employment rates seen among graduates. Deputy Prime Minister Gan also plans to visit the US for trade talks.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Three questions with Spirit Sports
summary: Spirit Sports, a footwear distributor, plans to expand its staff and turnover through digital technologies over the next 12 months. General manager Stephanie Benedetti attributes the challenges of digital transformation to a lack of messaging and community events for small businesses. Cloud-based solutions, such as Xero's platform, have helped Spirit Sports streamline processes and make informed business decisions. The company is also exploring regional expansion, particularly in Malaysia, and is taking advantage of government schemes to incorporate technology and grow.

site_title: Mastercard focuses on empowering women
summary: Mastercard has been focusing on empowering women through various corporate social responsibility initiatives worldwide. The company's efforts in Singapore began 15 years ago, with a focus on engaging women of different ages and socio-economic backgrounds. Mastercard has partnered with the Singapore Committee for UN Women to launch programs such as Girls4Tech, which aims to reach 13,000 girls in Singapore by 2018, and Project Inspire, a challenge that provides a platform for aspiring changemakers to create better socio-economic opportunities for women and girls. The company also offers scholarships exclusively for women at the undergraduate and postgraduate levels, and has awarded 17 scholarships since 2011.

site_title: Budget 2018: Small businesses need right mindset to embrace digital future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) adopt digital solutions, with a focus on productivity and growth. The new Productivity Solutions Grant provides funding for up to 70% of qualifying costs. However, SMEs often struggle to change their mindsets and adopt new technologies. Experts recommend a combination of government outreach, on-the-ground operational advice, and education to help SMEs overcome this hurdle and effectively utilize the available funding.

site_title: Chinese feed makers 'will cope' if soybean imports from US hurt
summary: China's top soybean feed maker, New Hope Group, says it will find ways to cope if US soybean imports are hurt due to trade tensions. Chairman Liu Yonghao expressed confidence in finding alternative supplies, despite warnings that curbing US imports could increase prices. China is the world's largest soy importer and relies heavily on US imports, which could shift to Brazil if the spat escalates, with Brazil already gaining a bigger share of the lucrative Chinese market.

images.alt_text: Business executives say Beijing could target more critical agricultural commodities, such as soybeans, the United States' biggest agricultural export by value, worth more than US$12 billion last year.

site_title: China to host trade talks with US as tensions rise
summary: China will host US officials for trade talks, with Vice-Foreign Minister Zhang Yesui stating China doesn't want a trade war but won't allow its interests to be harmed. The talks aim to address trade issues between the two economies. No details on the timing or participants were given. This move comes amid rising tensions between China and the US, with China's GDP growth expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Cape Town project could improve land rights access for world's poor
summary: An innovative project in Cape Town, South Africa, aims to improve land rights access for the world's poor by rebuilding 72 shacks on city-owned land. The "Empower Shack" scheme will eventually hand property rights to the families, allowing them to own the land they live on. The city has committed to rezone the land at a future date, marking a potential breakthrough in providing ownership for low-income residents.

site_title: Forget about cars - can fashion help Detroit make a comeback?
summary: Jeffry Aronsson, a turnaround specialist and former executive at Oscar de la Renta and LVMH, proposes creating a fashion hub in Detroit, dubbed Project Treadwing, where every aspect of fashion design, manufacturing, and marketing can take place. The project aims to capitalize on technology and retail trends, creating jobs for skilled and unskilled workers. Aronsson believes Detroit's vast empty land, lower unemployment rate, and potential influx of workers from Puerto Rico could make the project successful, disrupting the fashion industry's reliance on cheap labor and outsourcing.

site_title: Wie pulls off spectacular win
summary: Michelle Wie wins the HSBC World Women's Championship by one stroke, shooting a 7-under 65 in the final round to claim her first LPGA tournament victory since 2014. Wie, a crowd favorite, holed a 36-foot birdie putt from off the green on the 72nd hole to secure the win, after earlier making birdies on six other holes. The 28-year-old American finished with a 17-under 271 total, beating compatriot Nelly Korda by one stroke.

images.alt_text: "I knew if I shot almost 7, 8-under, I'd have a chance, and that was my one and only goal. It was crazy. I still don't know what's going on right now, my head's running at a million miles an hour." - Michelle Wie (above).

site_title: Agriculture index may be in early stages of next extended uptrend
summary: The Bloomberg Agriculture Subindex Total Return has been in a downtrend since 2012, but may be in the early stages of a trend reversal. The index has fallen 51% over the past five years, but a cyclical bottom was formed in December 2008, which took seven years to establish. A similar pattern is emerging, with the January 2018 low of 95.19 potentially marking the start of the next cyclical bottom. A significant mean reversion is expected, with a major trend reversal and potential secular uptrend, which could see the index rally explosively for 3-5 years, potentially retesting the 192 extreme expensive range.

site_title: Three questions with The Floral Atelier
summary: The Floral Atelier's founder, Lelian Chew, emphasizes the importance of technology in boosting business growth. Chew's luxury wedding planning and design firm, The Wedding Atelier, is its sister company. Chew believes digital orientation is crucial for businesses to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Ms Chew: 'Automating cumbersome processes also frees up my team's time to focus on more productive work.'

site_title: EU may give foreign investment screening laws more teeth for national security
summary: The European Union may strengthen its foreign investment screening laws to address national security concerns, particularly with China's growing acquisitions abroad. EU lawmaker Franck Proust wants to bolster the draft legislation to prevent foreign threats to critical infrastructure and strategic industries. The proposal would create a centralized database and alert mechanism, but would not give the EU final approval power over deals. Proust aims to introduce language to ensure EU governments share information on foreign-investment projects and seeks support from EU national governments and former communist eastern members.

site_title: Yen emerging as currency-market winner as trade tensions rise
summary: The yen has emerged as a winner in the $5.1 trillion-a-day currency market amid rising US trade tensions. The yen surged to a record high against the dollar, reaching 105.48, as investors sought refuge in safe-haven currencies. The US tariffs could reduce US growth by 0.2 percentage points, and the yen's appreciation is seen as a response to the potential shift in global growth. Investors are betting on a potential dollar decline, with some predicting a dollar-yen rate of 80 by 2019.

site_title: Surbana Jurong guns for S$3.8b in fees in 3-5 years; eyes two architectural firms
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean urban and infrastructure consultancy, has revised its targets, aiming for S$3.8 billion in revenue and 20,000 employees globally within 3-5 years. The company's aggressive expansion plans come after exceeding initial targets through successive acquisitions. Surbana Jurong is now focusing on acquiring two architectural firms to further boost its growth.

site_title: BlackRock poses tough questions to gunmakers, sellers in its portfolios
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is pressuring gunmakers and retailers in its portfolios to explain how they monitor firearm sales and use. The move comes after the February shooting in Parkland, Florida, that left 17 dead. BlackRock will also study creating new index-based portfolios excluding gunmakers and retailers, potentially reducing demand for industry stocks. The company is asking gunmakers about background checks and gun misuse, while retailers will be asked about strategies to prevent misuse of guns.

site_title: NY's latest property buzz: US$240m for air space
summary: JPMorgan Chase is purchasing air rights from Grand Central Terminal for approximately US$240 million to build its new midtown Manhattan headquarters. The bank is also buying 100,000 square feet of air rights from St Bartholomew's Church and may purchase air rights from a second religious institution. The deals, part of the city's rezoning of Midtown East, will reshape the area's dense skyline and benefit the city through increased tax revenue. The air rights sales will allow sellers to reap a fortune, with the city receiving a portion of the proceeds.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for last week's tanker and dry bulk market reveals firm rates for LR2 and LR1 vessels, with LR2 rates increasing 15 points to around WS 115. The 80,000-tonne cross Med market experienced downward pressure, while the 70,000-tonne Caribbean/upcoast market remained steady. VLCC rates hovered around WS 37/38 for 270,000 tonnes to China and WS 17.5 for 280,000 tonnes to US Gulf. Supramax rates defied spot market fluctuations, with a 63,200-dwt fixed basis delivery Canakkale redelivery China at $24,000. Handy vessel rates showed strong improvement, with a 34,000-dwt fixed on a 30,000-tonne maize voyage from Topolobampo to Puerto Cabello at $29.00.

site_title: Recent market volatility unlikely to derail IPO gravy train
summary: Market volatility in the past two months is unlikely to deter Singapore's initial public offering (IPO) outlook, with investment bankers expecting companies from the healthcare, food and beverage, infrastructure, and Reits sectors to list this year. The global economy's rosy outlook and resilient business fundamentals support equity markets, and recent market movements have taken place against a backdrop of increasing share prices over the past six months. Despite potential risks, including trade wars and interest rate hikes, experts believe it will be a good year for IPOs, both in Singapore and globally.

site_title: SingHaiyi aims to build branding as a Singapore company
summary: SingHaiyi Group, a Singapore-listed developer, aims to build its brand as a Singapore company by focusing on product quality and diversifying into commercial development both in Singapore and overseas. The group, controlled by the Tang family, has secured collective sale sites for residential projects and is studying the Australian and European markets, where it has a stake in Cromwell Property Group. With a 50% stake in three collective sale sites, SingHaiyi's residential landbank exceeds 900 units, and the group plans to roll out residential projects in the third or fourth quarter.

site_title: Norway firms lag green standards set by wealth fund
summary: Norwegian companies are lagging behind the high environmental reporting standards set by the country's $1 trillion wealth fund, which requires 9,100 companies to submit data on issues such as water use and climate effects to the CDP. The fund, which invests abroad due to Norway's government restrictions, aims to promote sustainable practices globally. Despite the fund's efforts, many Norwegian companies are not meeting the required standards, highlighting a gap between Norway's rhetoric and reality in promoting environmental responsibility.

site_title: Big banks bounce back in Saudi Arabia after purge
summary: Major global banks, including UBS, Goldman Sachs, and Citigroup, are expanding their presence in Saudi Arabia four months after a crackdown on corruption. Despite initial market uncertainty, the banks appear unfazed as some high-profile detainees have been released. The Saudi government has increased a $10 billion syndicated loan facility, and private companies are planning to tap markets for equity and debt. Experts view the anti-corruption drive as a net positive for investors, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's Ehsan Khoman stating that foreign investors will likely take comfort from the lack of foreign investor targets.

site_title: Punjab National Bank official was bribed in fraud case
summary: A Punjab National Bank official, Yashwant Joshi, received gold and diamond jewellery worth $60,000 from billionaire jeweller Nirav Modi in exchange for issuing fraudulent letters of undertakings. Joshi, a manager at the bank's Mumbai branch, admitted to receiving the bribes and is among 14 people arrested in the $2 billion bank fraud case. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) alleges that Joshi and other bank officials colluded with Modi to cheat the bank, and the case is ongoing.

site_title: Local market could continue to feel unsettled
summary: US stocks are expected to remain volatile this week due to concerns over potential trade wars and aggressive monetary policy. The Dow Jones fell 0.3% last Friday and is down 3% for the week. The European Union has also taken a tough stance against US President Donald Trump's tariffs, fueling market anxiety. Meanwhile, the US Federal Reserve is set to unveil its monetary policy, which may lead to tighter interest rates and further dampen risk appetite.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Airbus plans to move or cut 3,600 jobs: magazine
summary: Airbus plans to cut or move 3,600 jobs across its German, Spanish, and British factories due to declining production rates of the A380 and A400M aircraft. The move is part of a "workforce adaptation" plan to be discussed with unions at a European committee meeting on March 7. Airbus has adjusted A380 production rates due to weak demand and reduced A400M delivery rates as part of a redesign of the program's roadmap. The company will discuss the impact on employees with social partners, aiming to find the best solutions.

site_title: Shivering Europe hopes for weekend respite as deep freeze persists
summary: Europe is bracing for a brief weekend respite from a deep freeze, which has claimed over 60 lives, as temperatures are expected to rise slightly. The brutal Siberian cold front has caused heavy snowfall and blizzards, leading to major delays on roads, railways, and airports. However, some regions saw marginally improved conditions on Friday, with Britain's Met Office predicting a slight rise in Arctic temperatures over the weekend.

site_title: Hyundai Motor warns tariffs may jeopardise US production plans
summary: Hyundai Motor warns that US production plans may be jeopardized due to the Trump administration's steel and aluminum tariffs. The company's spokesman, Jim Trainor, stated that the tariffs could increase production costs, leading to higher prices for US consumers and decreased demand. Hyundai builds vehicles in Alabama and Georgia, and the company is cautious about the impact of the tariffs on its operations. The move joins Toyota and Ford in expressing concerns about the tariffs, which could affect US production and consumer demand.

site_title: At least 5 dead as storm brings wind, floods and snow to US Northeast
summary: A major winter storm, dubbed "Windmaggedon," brought strong winds, heavy rain, and snow to the US Northeast, resulting in at least five fatalities. The storm caused widespread disruptions, including the cancellation of over 3,000 flights and the suspension of Amtrak services. Coastal flooding alerts were issued, with over 100,000 power outages reported in Massachusetts. The storm's impact was felt across the region, with schools closed and roads evacuated in some areas. The National Weather Service warned of potential damage from high winds and flooding.

site_title: China's censorship spreading to more platforms
summary: China is expanding its online censorship efforts beyond its own digital borders, targeting non-Chinese apps and services. The country's Great Firewall system, which filters what users see online, is being supplemented by monitoring and controlling what people say on foreign apps like WhatsApp. This move aims to exert greater control over global conversations about China, with Beijing reportedly paying attention to what its citizens discuss on these platforms.

site_title: Markets clear German hurdle; Italy's up next
summary: Germany's grand coalition, led by Chancellor Angela Merkel, was revived after the Social Democrats (SPD) voted decisively for a tie-up with Merkel's conservatives, clearing the way for a new government. This outcome is expected to boost the euro, stock, and bond markets. Meanwhile, Italy is holding a national election under a complex new voting system, with polls predicting a hung parliament. Financial markets have shown little concern about the Italian outcome, with Italian bond yields at a three-week low, and investors awaiting the outcome of the election to assess its impact on the eurozone.

site_title: YCH Group, Forchn Holdings join forces to deepen Belt and Road Initiative investments
summary: YCH Group and Forchn Holdings have signed a memorandum of understanding to deepen cooperation in the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) by launching a $150 million BRI Logistics Real Estate Private Equity Fund. The fund will invest in warehousing and logistics assets in South-east Asia and China, aiming to establish YCH as a key player in the BRI. The partnership will also provide e-commerce and omni-channel logistics services in the Asean and China regions, further strengthening their offerings in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Health savings outweigh costs of limiting global warming: study
summary: A new study found that limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius could save more lives and health than the estimated cost of implementing such measures, with potential health savings ranging from $22.1 trillion to $41.6 trillion. Under a 1.5-degree limit, the estimated health benefits could be between $39.7 trillion and $56.1 trillion. The countries most likely to see significant health savings are India and China, where air pollution is a major issue.

site_title: Europe: FTSE hits Dec 2016 low as May's Brexit speech fails to inspire
summary: The UK's FTSE 100 index hit a 1-year low on Friday, closing 1.5% down at 7,069.90 points, due to concerns over trade disputes and Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit speech failing to inspire confidence. The speech's "no deal is better than a bad deal" stance was seen as unclear and potentially costly. Steel producers and miners were among the biggest fallers, while paper and packaging firm Mondi rebounded after announcing a special dividend.

site_title: Trade war talk pushes gold prices higher as dollar eases
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to impose tariffs on aluminium and steel raised fears of retaliation, pushing gold prices higher as the dollar eases. Gold rose 0.5% to $1,322.54 per ounce, with US gold futures up 1.4% at $1,323.40 per ounce. The threat of a global trade war is seen as a potential safe-haven investment, with lower real yields and a weaker dollar impacting trade.

site_title: AEM Holdings' largest shareholder sells 6% stake to new institutional investors for S$24.4 million
summary: AEM Holdings' largest shareholder, Orion Phoenix, sold 4 million shares to new institutional investors for S$24.4 million, a 4.84% discount from the last traded price. This reduced Orion Phoenix's stake from 23.3% to 17.3%. The move aims to broaden the company's shareholding structure and attract more long-only institutional and family funds, which are expected to bring higher scrutiny and demand for management accountability.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: US stock market bumps & slumps amid trade war, rate hike fears
summary: The US stock market experienced a correction amidst trade war and rate hike fears, overshadowing positive corporate and economic data. Despite this, major indexes remain close to records. The correction follows the "Trump bump" during the Donald Trump presidency. Investors are cautious due to the threat of trade wars, rising interest rates, and political instability. Markets in Singapore and other regions continue to rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Three Australians die, more sick in listeria outbreak tied to melons
summary: Three Australians have died and 12 others are sick in a listeria outbreak linked to contaminated rockmelons, primarily from New South Wales. The outbreak affects 15 elderly people across the country, with symptoms appearing up to six weeks after consumption. Health authorities advise vulnerable individuals to discard any rockmelon purchased before March 1 and recommend seeking medical attention if symptoms occur. Listeria, a rare but deadly bacteria, can cause flu-like symptoms and is often fatal in those with weakened immunity.

site_title: The world's embracing SUVs: Bad news for climate
summary: The global SUV market is booming, with sales tripling in the past decade and now accounting for over one in three cars sold worldwide. The rise of SUVs and crossovers is slowing progress in reducing emissions from the world's cars and trucks, which are major contributors to greenhouse gas emissions. SUVs are less efficient than smaller cars, generally by about 30%, and are less likely to go electric due to technological hurdles and consumer preferences. The trend is driven by rising incomes, lower gas prices, and a desire for status and space, particularly in China and western Europe.

site_title: Impact of World Bank's sanction on SMEC muted, says Surbana Jurong
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singaporean company, owns Australian-based SMEC Holdings, which was sanctioned by the World Bank for 12 months due to improper payments and misrepresentations in World Bank-financed projects in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and India. Despite the sanction, Surbana Jurong's CEO says the impact will be minimal as SMEC's dependence on the World Bank is small. The company is implementing measures to prevent future wrongdoings, including tracking subcontractor experiences.

site_title: Singapore must remain open to talent, new ideas
summary: Singaporean small business leaders are urging the government to relax foreign manpower rules to attract more talent and ideas, as companies invest in new technologies and expand abroad. Participants in a roundtable discussion said the current rules are limiting their ability to hire skilled workers, hindering growth. Experts emphasize the need for Singapore to remain open to new talent and ideas to be a center for digital innovation and attract tech services providers from abroad. Relaxing foreign manpower rules could help Singaporean businesses succeed in new markets and capitalize on global opportunities.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed amid trade war fears
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Friday as bargain hunting in technology shares offset concerns over a potential trade war. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% to 24,534.52, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5% and 1.0%, respectively. President Donald Trump's vow of tariffs on imported steel and aluminum sparked worries, but investors remained optimistic, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Keep an open mind, but watch the wallet
summary: Art fairs have become increasingly important in the art world, with many established fairs competing with international gatherings like Art Basel. The fairs offer a platform for dealers and collectors to network, learn, and buy art, but can also lead to overpaying and impulsive purchases. Experienced collectors advise caution, recommending that newcomers attend fairs slowly and carefully. Top galleries like David Zwirner and Thaddaeus Ropac use fairs to showcase their artists and sell pieces, while some art advisers see the fairs as a convenient way to see multiple works, but others, like Lisa Schiff, caution against buying at fairs due to the lack of proper assessment.

site_title: S'pore companies to get more support for PMET job sharing, in bid to boost family-friendly flexi-work schemes
summary: Singapore companies will receive more support for PMET job sharing under the WorkPro Work-Life Grant, aiming to boost family-friendly flexible work schemes. Funding amounts will be raised and the qualifying criterion relaxed, supporting employers in adopting flexible work arrangements. The grant, initially set to expire on March 31, will now be extended to provide more support for employers and employees.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Oil rises as Wall Street bounces off lows, crude posts weekly loss
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday as Wall Street stocks rebounded from session lows, despite benchmark crude futures posting a weekly decline. Brent futures rose 0.9% to $64.37 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 0.4% to $61.25 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over US plans to impose tariffs on steel and aluminum, which could squeeze economic growth and impact oil demand. Oil prices have fallen over the past week, with Brent down 4% and WTI down 3%.

site_title: Afghan man held after bomb threat near Bern station
summary: A young Afghan man was arrested in Bern, Switzerland, after a bomb threat was reported near the city's train station and suspicious objects were found in a nearby church. The man, who was identified as Afghan, was found behaving strangely and was arrested. Two suspicious objects in his possession were rendered harmless, and there were no injuries or damage. Rail traffic was not affected, but passengers were required to use an alternative entrance to the station. The incident remains under investigation.

site_title: The Place Holdings gets extension to meet financial criteria for SGX watch-list exit
summary: The Place Holdings, a Singapore-listed media company, has been granted a one-month extension to meet the financial criteria to exit the bourse watch-list. The company must now finalize its audited financial statements by April 4 and meet the average daily market capitalization requirement of S$40 million over the last six months. This is the second extension, following its initial one-month extension in 2017. The Place Holdings was previously removed from the watch-list on June 5, 2017, after reporting a profit before tax of S$723,000 in 2017.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cosco Shipping International has exercised its right to acquire Cogent Holdings' dissenting shares at S$1.02 per share after its initial offer turned unconditional. Cosco has also secured the Singapore Exchange's approval for Cogent's delisting. Compact Metal Industries has submitted for removal from the watch-list after demonstrating the ability to meet SGX listing requirements. Blackgold Natural Resources has announced changes to its board of directors, including Philip Cecil Rickard taking on additional roles.

site_title: Big data boss
summary: In Singapore, companies are adopting data analytics to transform modern human resources management. By analyzing employee data from various sources, companies can predict employee turnover, tailor training programs, and improve talent retention. Tech giants like Google and companies like DBS, OCBC, and UOB are pioneering people analytics, which has shown clear benefits in boosting productivity, reducing attrition rates, and recruiting effectively. However, concerns over employee data privacy are emerging, with HR practitioners emphasizing the need for transparency and clear communication with employees. Despite these challenges, many companies are finding success in leveraging data analytics to enhance HR functions.

site_title: IMF: Trump tariffs would damage US, global economies
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that US President Donald Trump's steel and aluminium tariffs would harm the US and global economies. The tariffs, which include 25% on steel and 10% on aluminium, would hurt the manufacturing and construction sectors. The IMF urged countries to work constructively to resolve trade disagreements without resorting to emergency measures, citing the risk of a trade war and its negative impact on global stock markets. The IMF also warned that other countries could use national security as a rationale to impose similar tariffs.

site_title: Trump sours flagging Nafta talks with steel trade war threats
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose 25% tariffs on steel imports and 10% on aluminum goods, crushing hopes for substantial progress in renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Trump's "America First" strategy has soured the negotiations, with Canadian and Mexican officials expressing outrage and considering retaliatory measures. The talks had been ongoing for six months, with some less contentious chapters potentially still being concluded, but the risk of a tariff war has thrown up new roadblocks.

site_title: China's CEFC Shanghai International downgraded after its bond trade is suspended
summary: China's CEFC Shanghai International Group had its long-term issuer rating downgraded from AAA to AA+ by credit ratings agency China Lianhe Credit Rating Co. after suspending bond trading amid a probe into the chairman of its parent company, CEFC China Energy chairman Ye Jianming, who is under investigation for suspected economic crimes. The rating downgrade was made due to concerns the investigation may affect the company's future development.

site_title: LafargeHolcim CEO launches overhaul, takes big Q4 charge
summary: LafargeHolcim CEO Jan Jenisch launched a five-year overhaul plan, aiming to grow faster than the market and cut costs. The company reported a Q4 net loss of 3.1 billion Swiss francs, partly due to a 3.8 billion-franc impairment charge. Jenisch cleared the decks for his plan, which includes cost-cutting measures to improve profitability. The company's goal is to outperform the market, despite the current losses.

site_title: Apple Macs, Hershey's Kisses and Bud beer caught up in aluminium tariff plan
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose 25% tariffs on imported steel and 10% on aluminum for "a long period of time". The move is expected to affect a wide range of businesses, including those that use aluminum in products such as beer, candy, and electronics. The tariffs are likely to lead to higher costs, job losses, and price increases for consumers. Major companies, including Molson Coors and Anheuser-Busch InBev, have urged the Trump Administration to reconsider the proposal, citing concerns over the impact on the US beer industry and national security.

site_title: Wuhan to implement transparent mortgage payments to rein in soaring prices
summary: Wuhan, China, has implemented a rule requiring property developers to open designated bank accounts for new home mortgages to monitor payments and deter illegal fee hikes. The measure aims to rein in soaring prices, with average new home prices still rising 5% in January. Developers who break the rule may face penalties, including being suspended from online property transactions. This move is part of China's efforts to clamp down on speculation and control housing prices.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Pact scheme to include tie-ups among SMEs
summary: Singapore has allocated S$100 million over the next three years for its integrated Pact programme, which aims to support partnerships among small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and start-ups. The programme, administered by the Economic Development Board (EDB) and Enterprise Singapore, will offer up to 70% support for qualifying costs in capability development and business development. Additionally, the government has extended the Venture Debt Programme and raised the level of support for the Market Readiness Assistance grant. The Asean Leadership Programme will also be launched to help local business leaders gain a deeper understanding of the region.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: All plant, no plastic
summary: A Kiwi company, For The Better Good, has invented the world's first plant-based water bottle, eliminating the need for plastic waste. The Plant Bottle, made from materials such as corn, potatoes, and cellulose, is biodegradable and can be refilled at water points. Its founder, Jayden Klinac, aims to reduce plastic waste and promote a harmonious relationship between humanity and nature. With a cost of NZ$4.50, the Plant Bottle is envisioned to revolutionize the manufacturing industry, making plastic alternatives more accessible and environmentally friendly.

site_title: Reits
summary: US mortgage rates have risen for the first time in five weeks, marking a shift in the market. This comes as the Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, with more increases anticipated. Meanwhile, UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, and Goldman Sachs has acquired a large portfolio of Seoul hotel and retail assets. These developments signal a changing landscape in the real estate market.

site_title: The world of luxury carpets gets the rug pulled out from under it
summary: Luxury carpets, once a staple of high-end homes, are losing their allure due to widespread fakes and changing tastes. The market, which was once dominated by antique Persian rugs, has been flooded with imitations. Experts say that high-end dealers are now steering clients away from expensive rugs, as they are more trouble than they're worth. The rise of Moroccan Berber rugs, which can be completed in a few months and are relatively affordable, has become a popular alternative. Designers and collectors are shifting their focus to more casual, folkloric carpets that are easier to find and more affordable.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) reported FY17 results lower than expected due to one-off costs and lower-than-expected health segment margins. However, the company's earnings were driven by contributions from pediatric clinics and improving diagnostic business in 2H17. Despite the lower-than-expected results, analysts at DBS Group Research maintain a "Buy" rating with a target price of S$0.73, citing the company's improving performance and growth prospects.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: No 'test balloons' on GST tax hike, says Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat refuted Workers' Party chairman Sylvia Lim's allegation that the government floated "test balloons" about raising the Goods and Services Tax (GST). Heng stated that the government has enough funds for its current term but needs increased taxes to cover rising healthcare costs. He emphasized that a GST hike is necessary beyond the current government term to address these expenditure needs.

site_title: Blackgold Natural Resources unveils board changes
summary: BLACKGOLD Natural Resources announced changes to its board of directors. Intekhab Ahmad Khan stepped down as independent non-executive chairman, while Philip Cecil Rickard took on the role and added membership to the nominating committee. Bala Chandran and Gerald Lim Thien Su were appointed to the audit and remuneration committees, respectively. These changes will take effect on March 3, 2018.

site_title: Three Datapulse investors move to rally the troops
summary: Three minority shareholders of Datapulse Technology, led by Chew Ah Kong, are rallying support to oust newly-appointed directors and contest the company's diversification agenda. They claim the acquisitions, including a $3.5 million deal with a Malaysian haircare products maker, are risky and unclear. The shareholders have communicated their grievances to the regulator and plan to attend the April 20 shareholder meeting to make a decision. The Singapore Exchange has also intervened, demanding an independent review of the company's system and events surrounding the acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Acquisitions rise; buybacks surge to S$61m
summary: The Straits Times Index declined 0.4% in February, with its dividend inclusive return for the first two months of 2018 reaching 3.6%. Share buybacks surged to S$134 million, with Sembcorp Industries buying back 1 million shares at S$3.2 million. Meanwhile, Global Investments Limited's manager acquired 1.7 million shares, increasing his stake to 0.46%. Other notable transactions included Stamford Land's director acquiring 318,000 shares and Lum Chang's managing director acquiring 310,500 shares.

site_title: Singapore to pursue deeper ties with EU as Asean chair
summary: Singapore, as Asean chair, aims to deepen ties with the European Union through a stalled free-trade agreement. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang sees the time is right for greater region-to-region integration amid rising anti-trade sentiments. The EU is Asean's largest source of foreign direct investment and top trading partner, and Singapore seeks to build confidence and trust with the EU to resume negotiations for an Asean-EU FTA. The region has made progress in economic integration, with intra-Asean import tariffs eliminated and trade costs reduced, making a renewed pursuit of deeper bi-regional economic integration timely.

site_title: Mercedes CLS review: A cut above
summary: The Mercedes-Benz CLS has undergone significant transformations under its skin, retaining its low-cut roof but with a new, more curved design. The third-generation model boasts a shark-nosed front end and a smooth, flowing body. Powered by a new 3.0-liter engine family, the CLS 450 and CLS 53 offer impressive performance, with the CLS 53 reaching 0-100 km/h in 4.1 seconds. The car features an EQ Boost system, a 48-volt system, and an electric turbocharger, providing exceptional refinement and comfort. With a large boot and expandable rear seats, the CLS is both practical and stylish.

site_title: Flying taxis may be years away, but the groundwork is gaining pace
summary: Companies like Airbus, Uber, and Joby Aviation are investing in flying taxi services, envisioning battery-powered aircraft that can transport people like drones. Airbus is partnering with Blade to expand helicopter hailing services, while Uber aims to start testing its urban air taxis in 2020. Joby Aviation has raised $100 million in funding, and Boeing acquired Aurora Flight Sciences, a company specializing in pilotless aircraft. The services are seen as a natural progression of vehicles, with quieter and more affordable alternatives to helicopters. However, regulatory hurdles and technical challenges remain, and the feasibility of these services is still uncertain.

site_title: Mighty morphin' power angbaos
summary: A Chinese New Year tradition, the angbao, has no definitive origins, with varying practices and stories about its start. Some attribute it to the Song Dynasty, while others claim it began in the Tang Dynasty. The practice of giving angbaos to children by their elders is believed to have originated from a legend about the Eight Immortals helping an elderly couple save their son from a demon. As technology advances, e-angbaos are becoming increasingly popular, with DBS Bank and Grab launching digital alternatives. This shift may change the way angbao holidays are celebrated, but the tradition's rules are still being made up as it goes along.

site_title: Singapore to pursue deeper ties with EU as Asean chair
summary: Singapore, as Asean chair, aims to deepen ties with the European Union (EU) through a stalled free-trade agreement. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang sees the time right for greater region-to-region integration, despite rising anti-trade sentiments. The EU is Asean's largest source of foreign direct investment and top trading partner. Talks on an Asean-EU free-trade agreement (FTA) are expected to resume, with a pragmatic approach focusing on building confidence and trust, and avoiding premature negotiations.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Productivity Solutions Grant to cover six sectors first
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 introduced a Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) with an initial S$110 million over three years to support sector-specific solutions in retail, food, logistics, precision engineering, wholesale, and landscaping industries, aligning with Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs).

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Swissco's Hong Kong units placed under voluntary liquidation
summary: Swissco's Hong Kong units, including four step-down companies, have been placed under creditors' voluntary liquidation due to financial struggles. The judicial managers appointed John Robert Lees and Mat Ng as liquidators. Swissco had applied for judicial management in 2016 and received an extension in 2017. The move follows the rejection of its debt restructuring plan by main lenders. The liquidation of the four Hong Kong units is part of the company's overall financial restructuring efforts.

site_title: Frasers Property's Thai unit prices 3 more debenture offerings totalling up to 5b baht
summary: Frasers Property's Thai unit, Frasers Property Holdings (Thailand), priced three debenture offerings totaling up to 5 billion Thai baht (S$1.05 billion) under its 25 billion baht program. The debentures, due 2021, 2023, and 2028, offer interest rates of 2.19%, 2.55%, and 3.54% respectively. The proceeds will be used for debt repayment, investment, and working capital. The offerings are made to institutional and high net worth investors on a private placement basis, with Bangkok Bank, Bank of Ayudhya, and United Overseas Bank serving as joint lead arrangers.

site_title: Oei Hong Leong withdraws acceptance for his IPC shares
summary: Singaporean tycoon Oei Hong Leong has withdrawn his acceptance of a deal to acquire a 32.96% stake in real estate group IPC Corporation. Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments, the offeror, is seeking professional advice on the about-turn. The deal, valued at roughly $40 million, would have required a mandatory unconditional offer for the remaining shares. The withdrawal leaves the acquisition uncertain, with IPC Corporation stating it will provide further updates as necessary.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Rebalance your portfolio amid rising rates and rising volatility
summary: Investors should rebalance their portfolios amid rising interest rates and volatility. BlackRock's Fixed Income Global Opportunities Fund offers a defensive approach with a low duration of 0.27 years, shielding investors from rising rates. Conversely, PIMCO Income Fund provides a more aggressive option with a floating rate exposure, benefiting from rising rates. As yields are likely to continue rising, investors should consider protection or taking advantage of the opportunities presented by rising rates, with a focus on managing risk and capital allocation.

site_title: Ipco boots out CFO, names new investor as finance chief
summary: Ipco International has dismissed its executive director and CFO, Carlson Smith, due to "misconduct" and failure to conduct on-site visits to group's China and US subsidiaries. The decision was made after an extraordinary general meeting on January 19, at which a new investor, James Blythman, requisitioned Smith's ouster. Smith's dismissal is effective February 27.

site_title: Cosco Shipping exercises right to buy shares from dissenting Cogent shareholders
summary: Cosco Shipping International exercised its right to acquire shares from dissenting Cogent shareholders after its voluntary cash offer turned unconditional. The offer price was set at S$1.02 per share, with 92.05% of shares accepted. The Singapore Exchange granted approval for the delisting of Cogent.

site_title: Australia home prices fall for fifth month in February
summary: Australia's major cities saw a fifth consecutive month of falling home prices in February, with Sydney experiencing a 0.6% drop, its first negative reading since 2012. The decline is attributed to tighter rules on investment lending, which has chilled the Sydney market. Annual growth in prices slowed to 2%, from 3.2% in January, and 10.5% in mid-2017. Melbourne's prices rose 0.1% in February, but still 6.9% higher for the year.

images.alt_text: The inexorable rise of prices in Australia's major cities has put homes out of reach for many first-time buyers.

site_title: Saudi builder Jabal Omar to close Umm Al Qura merger deal in 2018
summary: Saudi Arabia's largest listed property developer, Jabal Omar Development, expects to finalize its merger deal with Umm Al Qura Development and Construction in 2018, aiming to strengthen its presence in Mecca's real estate market. The deal, valued at 50 billion riyals (S$17.6 billion), is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's economic reforms to diversify the economy away from oil. Jabal Omar plans to issue Islamic bonds and launch a real estate fund to finance its mega project, which includes commercial malls, residential properties, and hotels.

site_title: Winners and losers from new tariffs
summary: US steelmakers are expected to benefit from new tariffs, with a 25% tariff on steel and 10% on aluminum from all countries. Domestic hot-rolled coil prices have already risen, reaching around $780 per metric ton. This is a result of aggressive lobbying by US steel producers against unfair competition from China, Russia, and South Korea.

site_title: Infineon launches chip venture with Chinese carmaker SAIC
summary: Infineon Technologies AG, a German chipmaker, has teamed up with SAIC Motor Corp Ltd, China's largest carmaker, to produce power modules for electric cars and plug-in hybrids. The joint venture, called SAIC Infineon Automotive Power Modules, will invest at least 100 million euros and hire 250 people to expand Infineon's chip factory in Wuxi. The move is expected to benefit from China's growing demand for electric cars, with the government aiming to produce seven million such cars by 2025.

site_title: YCH Group, Forchn Holdings join forces to deepen Belt and Road Initiative investments
summary: YCH Group and Forchn Holdings signed a memorandum of understanding to deepen cooperation in the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) investments. The companies will explore a $150 million BRI Logistics Real Estate Private Equity Fund to invest in warehousing and logistics assets in South-east Asia and China. The partnership aims to establish YCH as a key player in the BRI and provide clients with infrastructure and expertise to expand their businesses. The collaboration also includes e-commerce and omni-channel logistics services and real estate portfolio maximization.

site_title: FEC Properties snags Hollandia collective sale site for S$183.4m
summary: FEC Properties has acquired the Hollandia collective sale site in Singapore for S$183.4 million, marking the 9th collective sale site sold in Singapore this year, valued at S$3.3 billion. The site will be redeveloped into a high-end residential development with a total GFA of about 10,000 sq m, according to Far East Consortium's regulatory filing. The acquisition aligns with the company's regionalisation strategy and adds to its development pipeline in Singapore.

site_title: YCH Group, Forchn Holdings join forces to deepen Belt and Road Initiative investments
summary: YCH Group and Forchn Holdings signed a memorandum of understanding to deepen cooperation in the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). They plan to launch a $150 million BRI Logistics Real Estate Private Equity Fund to invest in South-east Asia and China. The partnership aims to strengthen their offerings in the Asia-Pacific region and tap into the growing BRI opportunity. The companies will also collaborate on e-commerce and omni-channel logistics services in the Asean and China regions.

site_title: From guns to climate, companies are taking on issues govt won't
summary: US companies are increasingly taking a stand on social and political issues where the government is failing, driven by consumer pressure and the desire for a "double bottom line" that balances profits and social responsibility. Following the Parkland school shooting, companies such as Delta Air Lines and Walmart have ended discounts for NRA members, while BlackRock is exploring removing gun-related investments from portfolios. The trend is also seen in companies adopting sustainable practices, supporting LGBTQ+ employees, and promoting climate change efforts, with some 60% of consumers citing politics as a factor in their purchasing decisions.

site_title: Beckham's MLS partner eyes new Miami stadium sites
summary: David Beckham's Miami MLS expansion team is facing a setback as his partner, Jorge Mas, is exploring new stadium sites due to the 9-acre Overtown tract being deemed insufficient for a high-tech stadium. Mas wants a 25,000-seat stadium with office space and tech facilities, requiring more land. Sites near the Miami River and Marlins' baseball park are being scouted, with approval from MLS still needed. The project's timeline remains uncertain, leaving fans in the dark, as opposition from neighbors could complicate the stadium's approval process.

site_title: US Fed's Powell sees 'no evidence' of overheating economy
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated he sees no evidence of the US economy overheating, despite a strengthening labor market and growth outlook. He reiterated the central bank's plan to gradually raise interest rates to balance unemployment and inflation. Powell also expressed confidence in the economy's ability to absorb a tightening labor market without causing inflation, citing a strong jobless rate and inflation under the 2% target.

site_title: May wants reciprocal binding trade agreements after Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the UK's future trading relationship with the EU should maintain reciprocal binding agreements to cover more areas than any other trade deal after Brexit. She emphasized the importance of maintaining close ties on regulations and standards to prevent border delays. May also confirmed that the UK will not let Brexit jeopardize progress on securing peace in Northern Ireland, ensuring a joint responsibility to find a solution.

site_title: Bitcoin has entered the awkward adolescence stage
summary: Bitcoin has entered a "awkward adolescence" stage, characterized by high volatility but limited institutional acceptance. Despite the introduction of cleared Bitcoin derivatives, which provide greater visibility into the market, institutional investors have been cautious, with only a few thousand Bitcoin traded through these contracts. Bitcoin prices have continued to fluctuate at around 100% annualized volatility, but have also risen to previously uncharted highs, with the price never trading below $5,000 since LedgerX opened its clearinghouse. The market suggests that Bitcoin's volatility is smooth and follows a normal distribution, making it an attractive investment option for traditional institutions.

site_title: May sets out vision for frictionless trade after Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May outlined a vision for frictionless trade after Brexit, calling for a deep partnership with the European Union. She proposed a tailor-made deal with independent arbitration and new arrangements for regulation and financial services. May suggested binding reciprocal agreements but emphasized that British laws don't need to be the same as the EU to achieve regulatory outcomes. The goal is to avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK, with the EU proposing a customs union for Northern Ireland.

site_title: A priceless way to engage customers
summary: Mastercard invests heavily in sports sponsorships to connect consumers to their passions, including partnerships with UEFA, Cricket Australia, the Rugby World Cup, and tennis events like the Australian Open. The company delivers "Priceless" experiences to its cardholders, providing unique experiences at events such as backstage tours and meet-and-greets with athletes. According to Mastercard's senior vice-president, these sponsorships help tap into well-established equity platforms and provide authentic experiences for customers, serving as a competitive differentiator.
